title: what it feel like to die
context: do you want to know what will happen a your body start shutting down my mother and i sat across from the hospice nurse in my parent colorado home it wa 2005 and my mother had reached the end of treatment for metastatic breast cancer a month or two earlier she d been able to take the dog for daily walk in the mountain and travel to australia with my father now she wa weak exhausted from the disease and chemotherapy and pain medication my mother had been the one to decide with her doctor s blessing to stop pursuing the dwindling chemo option and she had been the one to ask her doctor to call hospice still we weren t prepared for the nurse s question my mother and i exchanged glance a little shocked but what we felt most wa a sense of relief during six and a half year of treatment although my mother saw two general practitioner six oncologist a cardiologist several radiation technician nurse at two chemotherapy facility and surgeon at three different clinic not once to my knowledge had anyone talked to her about what would happen a she died there s good reason roughly from the last two week until the last breath somewhere in that interval people become too sick or too drowsy or too unconscious to tell u what they re experiencing say margaret campbell a professor of nursing at wayne state university who ha worked in palliative care for decade the way death is talked about tends to be based on what family friend and medical professional see rather than account of what dying actually feel like james hallenbeck a palliative care specialist at stanford university often compare dying to black hole we can see the effect of black hole but it is extremely difficult if not impossible to look inside them they exert an increasingly strong gravitational pull the closer one get to them a one pass the event horizon apparently the law of physic begin to change what doe dying feel like despite a growing body of research about death the actual physical experience of dying the last few day or moment remains shrouded in mystery medicine is just beginning to peek beyond the horizon until about 100 year ago almost all dying happened quickly but modern medicine ha radically changed how long the end of life can be stretched now american who have access to medical care often die gradually of lingering disease like most terminal cancer or complication from diabetes or dementia rather than quickly from say a farm accident or the flu according to the center for disease control s most recent figure american are most likely to die of heart disease cancer or chronic pulmonary lung disease pre death dream were frequently so intense that the dream carried into wakefulness for those who do die gradually there s often a final rapid slide that happens in roughly the last few day of life a phase known a active dying during this time hallenbeck writes in palliative care perspective his guide to palliative care for physician people tend to lose their sens and desire in a certain order first hunger and then thirst are lost speech is lost next followed by vision the last sens to go are usually hearing and touch whether dying is physically painful or how painful it is appears to vary there are some kind of condition where pain is inevitable campbell say there are some patient that just get really really old and just fade away and there s no distress having a disease associated with pain doesn t mean you ll necessarily endure a difficult death either most people dying of cancer need pain medication to keep them comfortable campbell note and the medicine usually work if they re getting a good comprehensive pain regimen they can die peacefully she say when people become too weak to cough or swallow some start to make a noise in the back of their throat the sound can be deeply disturbing a if the patient is suffering but that s not what it feel like to the person dying a far a doctor can tell in fact medical researcher believe that the phenomenon which is commonly called a death rattle probably doesn t hurt ultimately because most people lose awareness or consciousness in their last few hour or day it s hard to know for certain how much patient are suffering we generally believe that if your brain is really in a comatose kind of situation or you re not really responsive that your perception how you feel about thing may also be significantly decreased say david hui an oncologist and palliative care specialist who research the sign of approaching death you may or may not even be aware of what s happening a week or two after we spoke to the nurse my mother sank into a state where she wa rarely conscious when she wa awake it wa only the most basic part of her that wa there the part that told her leg to move to get her to the bathroom the automated step in brushing her teeth and then wiping the sink afterward her mind turned away from her child and husband for the first time i wanted to know what she wa thinking about i wanted to know where her mind wa being at the bedside of an unresponsive dying person can feel like trying to find out whether someone is home by looking through thick curtained window is the person sleeping dreaming experiencing something supernatural is her mind gone for many dying people the brain doe the same thing that the body doe in that it start to sacrifice area which are le critical to survival say david hovda director of the ucla brain injury research center he compare the breakdown to what happens in aging people tend to lose their ability for complex or executive planning learning motor skill and in what turn out to be a very important function inhibition the wave get higher and higher and eventually they carry the person out to sea a the brain begin to change and start to die different part become excited and one of the part that becomes excited is the visual system hovda explains and so that s where people begin to see light recent research point to evidence that the sharpening of the sens some people report also seems to match what we know about the brain s response to dying jimo borjigin a neuroscientist at the university of michigan first became intrigued by this subject when she noticed something strange in the brain of animal in another experiment just before the animal died neurochemical in the brain suddenly surged while scientist had known that brain neuron continued to fire after a person died this wa different the neuron were secreting new chemical and in large amount a lot of cardiac arrest survivor describe that during their unconscious period they have this amazing experience in their brain she say they see light and then they describe the experience a realer than real she realized the sudden release of neurochemical might help to explain this feeling borjigin and her research team tried an experiment they anesthetized eight rat and then stopped their heart suddenly all the different region of the brain became synchronized she say the rat brain showed higher power in different frequency wave and also what is known a coherence the electrical activity from different part of the brain working together if you re focusing attention doing something trying to figure out a word or trying to remember a face when you re doing high level cognitive activity these feature go up borjigin say these are well used parameter in studying human consciousness in awake human so we thought if you re alert or aroused similar parameter should also go up in the dying brain in fact that wa the case in her last couple of week when my mother s mind seemed to be floating off somewhere else most of the time she would sometimes lift her arm into the air plucking at invisible object with her finger once i captured her hand in mine and asked what she d been doing putting thing away she answered smiling dreamily this half dreaming half waking state is common in dying people in fact researcher led by christopher kerr at a hospice center outside buffalo new york conducted a study of dying people s dream most of the patient interviewed 88 percent had at least one dream or vision and those dream usually felt different to them from normal dream for one thing the dream seemed clearer more real the patient pre death dream were frequently so intense that the dream carried into wakefulness and the dying often experienced them a waking reality the researcher write in the journal of palliative medicine seventy two percent of the patient dreamed about reuniting with people who had already died fifty nine percent said they dreamed about getting ready to travel somewhere twenty eight percent dreamed about meaningful experience in the past patient were interviewed every day so the same people often reported dream about multiple subject for most of the patient the dream were comforting and positive the researcher say the dream often helped decrease the fear of death the predominant quality of pre death dream vision wa a sense of personal meaning which frequently carried emotional significance for the patient they report

title: if donald trump were black would the gop base accept him the answer is obvious
context: last summer a black real estate developer and reality television show host let s call him donell trump announced his candidacy for president of the united state a notorious adulterer donell trump ha fathered five child with three different wife over decade in the medium spotlight he ha insulted a slew of woman by calling them among many other slur fat ugly and pig he told one female journalist she had the face of a dog once the proprietor of a global beauty pageant whose contestant he routinely demeaned donell trump is obsessed with boasting about his sexual prowess he joked about the size of his anatomy during a live televised debate and riffed about dating his adult daughter if donell trump s attitude toward the fairer sex could be distilled into a single sentence it s what he told esquire in 1991 it really doesn t matter what the medium write about you a long a you ve got a young and beautiful piece of as then there s money donell trump can t get enough of it he s obsessed with ostentatious display of wealth donell trump constantly exaggerates his personal net worth and his larger than life existence shiny watch fast car big yacht massive crib resembles that of a rap star a substantial part of his fortune wa made through shady business venture that took advantage of working class people but donell trump ha no apology donell trump also display rank ignorance about every single political issue he s asked about speaks at a fifth grade reading level and ha trouble forming grammatically correct sentence he routinely nudge attendee at his rally to beat up protestors ha boasted that he could shoot someone on manhattan s 5th avenue to prove his voter loyalty to him and ha dropped hint that his supporter should kill his opponent presented with such a presidential candidate one who seemingly went out of his way to personify every negative stereotype our society hold about black male sexuality avarice and propensity to violence how would the republican party base and conservative entertainment industry respond would bill o reilly and jerry falwell jr praise donell trump a a model american businessman and moral leader or would they lament how this habitual homewrecker and baby daddy to three separate woman symbolized the epidemic of african american absentee fatherhood would rush limbaugh insist that donell trump s half literate tirade were the heartfelt plea of a down to earth blue collar billionaire or instead treat his listener to a rant about the inanity of ebonics a racial double standard exists at the core of the republican party and conservative medium world f t in a sense we already know how this segment of the right would respond to such a hypothetical black politician given the way they ve treated president obama an intellectual ivy league educated cool tempered family man obama ha nevertheless been portrayed by much of the right wing medium a nothing short of the anti christ a crypto muslim manchurian candidate secretly plotting to destroy america meanwhile many of the same people who claim with a straight face that the plagiarizing former nude model melania trump would make an ideal first lady slam michelle obama s innocuous healthy eating initiative a nothing le than a maoist reeducation scheme granted if conservative rejected donell trump a unfit for office they wouldn t be in the wrong the value donell trump exemplifies pride greed envy a literal catalog of the seven deadly sin are one we ought to recoil from when choosing a president my point is that the very voter and medium personality who would almost certainly condemn donell have embraced donald which indicates the degree to which a racial double standard exists at the core of the republican party and conservative medium world replace the outer borough white ethnic vulgarity with african american ghetto vernacular and they d call the man a thug some conservative may respond to this thought exercise by claiming that actually republican voter would enthusiastically welcome a black candidate a donell trump so long a he too championed nationalist politically incorrect anti immigrant populism but the closest the gop ever had to a black trump 2012 contender herman cain fizzled out a soon a sexual harassment allegation against him became public moreover so much of donald trump s popularity is based on unsubtle appeal to white nationalism that despite the thought exercise above it s impossible to imagine a true black analogue trump s hesitance to condemn david duke his law and order mantra evocative of richard nixon s southern strategy and his conspiracy theory about the president s birth certificate are all intended to whip up white racial resentment which brings u to the crux of the matter whether the subject is poverty police brutality or affirmative action conservative are loath to acknowledge the presence of racism in american society yet it s far from hidden it course through the presidential campaign a the notion of a donell trump candidacy clearly show james kirchick is a fellow with the foreign policy initiative his book the end of europe is forthcoming from yale university press

psychologist at skidmore college in saratoga spring n y that includes his emphasis on terrorism unsurprisingly but also his preoccupation with immigration this focus might be helping trump since solomon s recent research show that people who are thinking about death are more likely to say they support him study subject who were prompted to talk about their own death later rated their support for trump 1 66 point higher on a five point scale than those who were prompted to talk about pain generally i m not suggesting that any of this is calculated but almost everything that he doe is demonstrably effective for raising these non conscious existential concern that in turn make his kind of candidacy all the more alluring solomon said solomon is part of a group of researcher that ha spent decade investigating the connection between death and a broad variety of human belief and behavior their inspiration ha been the work of ernest becker an anthropologist who argued that the fear of death wa a kind of fundamental principle in explaining human psychology becker won a pulitzer prize for his 1973 book solomon is part of a group of researcher that ha spent decade investigating the research is still preliminary and controversial and they haven t worked out a complete theory but they have discovered a number of startling fact about how people think about death for example solomon and florette cohen of the city university of new york college of staten island recently found evidence that asking people to think about immigrant also get them thinking about death solomon and cohen asked a small group of volunteer at the college of staten island to respond to one of three prompt one group wa asked to write down what they thought would happen in a much detail a possible if about immigration then the two researcher gave the participant a set of word with letter missing and asked them to fill in the blank to get an idea of what the participant were thinking about shown c o f f _ _ for example many people might write coffee especially student in college if they were thinking about death however they might write coffin instead the participant who had been asked to think about immigration had death on their mind too almost to the same extent a those who had been asked to think about death explicitly assigned score from zero to one based on how many word related to death they produced those who had been asked to think about immigration scored 0 92 on average while those who had been asked to think about death scored 0 96 those asked to think about pain scored just 0 19 there wa no evidence that the effect wa greater for conservative participant in the study solomon said he hope to replicate the study which wa completed with a small group of a few dozen student at the college of staten island yet the result accord with those of similar study that suggest people interpret challenge to their culture a threat to their very existence yet the result accord with those of similar study that suggest people interpret challenge to their culture a threat to their very existence a different group of researcher found that after a group of canadian read an article in which canadian cultural trope were mocked they were thinking about death too the pattern extends to religious belief the pattern extends to religious belief another study found a comparable effect in atheist confronted with argument in favor of intelligent design and a third concluded that pointing out logical inconsistency in the bible made thought of death also more accessible to fundamentalist christian for solomon the research suggests that when people create meaning in their life whether through religion nationality or staying at home with a 30 pack of beer and spraying some cheez whiz on a cracker in solomon s word they are protecting themselves from their constant awareness of death he and his colleague for solomon the research suggests that when people create meaning in their life whether through religion nationality or staying at home with a 30 pack of beer and spraying some cheez whiz on a cracker in solomon s word they are protecting themselves from their constant awareness of death he and his colleague have argued that the same is true of clothing and grooming and that human conceal their nature a animal from themselves to avoid thinking about their mortality solomon and his colleague also have found that thinking about death make charismatic resolute leader more appealing they solomon and his colleague also have found that thinking about death make charismatic resolute leader more appealing they showed that to be true during president george w bush s successful campaign for reelection against john f kerry now the secretary of state in 2004 and solomon s new research with cohen ha produced similar result for trump they rated participant support for trump on a scale out of five point based on their answer to several question the average rating for those who had been reminded of their mortality wa 3 8 point but it wa just 2 2 point for those who had been asked to think about pain solomon said these result suggest that the fear of death is one of several interrelated psychological concept that could help explain why trump ha been so successful including authoritarianism an aversion to uncertainty and racial prejudice it sure seems like an existentially shaky historical moment where it ha become increasingly difficult for the average american to perceive that they have any basis for either meaning or self worth solomon said it is a factor and in a very close election it could matter

title: ex con remember their worst job after being released from prison
context: getting a job when you first get out of prison can be a nightmare most employer refuse to hire someone fresh out the fed or convict who are still incarcerated but allowed to get a job through work release other prisoner are so shell shocked from being back in a society that changed dramatically while they were locked up that figuring out how to do basic thing like use public transportation or a cell phone can feel like a herculean task according to the national institute of justice over 60 percent of ex con are jobless up to a year after release that said getting a job is a necessary step for prisoner to integrate back into society often time it s a requirement by the criminal justice system or else freshly released inmate will risk being sent back to the fed but even when ex con do manage to get hired the work is underpaid demoralizing and their employer don t do much to encourage the re entry process there are organizer that help former prisoner assimilate into the workforce but the support is generally few and far between after serving 23 year in the fed the first job i got on the outside wa a a saute cook at an italian restaurant despite my earning two college degree while in prison the work sucked and i wa forced to do the grunt work no one else would do like clean out the fryer every night i wasn t in any position to argue and risk being canned and my employer took advantage of this i dreaded that job but a i ve talked with other ex con over the year about their first gig on the outside i now consider myself lucky the fact that over 75 percent of ex con are rearrested within five year of releas e should be no surprise when the only job offered to people with criminal record are the gig no one else applies for vice chatted with three ex con to get more perspective on what re entering the workforce wa like once they got out of prison image of cattle rancher via wikimedia creative common mendoor smith 43 year old from iowa served 12 year for marijuana possession released from custody in 2013 the worst job i had wa working on a cattle ranch a a utility farmer making 8 25 an hour i had to be there from about 6 am to 5 pm every day and the commute wa 45 minute from the halfway house i wa placed in it wasn t really tough work but the handling of manure and animal wa rough a wa taking care of the calf and cow dealing with cow everyday is messy and i d have to clean out their living pen i remember calving one shift during the winter and when i did my hourly inspection of the herd i noticed a cow with an extremely bad vaginal prolapse i called my bos and he called the vet who came out at four in the morning i had to lift the cow s vaginal inside and hold them while the vet tried to stuff them back inside the cow after about an hour and a half of lifting and stuffing this slimy nasty thing the vet finally got it all back inside and sewed up when i did my final inspection of the morning at 10 am the cow had died all that work wa for nothing having to stick my entire arm in a cow to help pull out a calf wa not fun either you work super hard to pull one of the slimy thing out and then you have to scoop the little thing up and take off before the cow attack you for holding it calf having a 1 200 pound animal chase you is a little intimidating i had two coworkers that knew about my criminal situation they asked a lot of question stuff about what wa prison like and what i did to get all that time my bos wa a good bos he helped me get my class a driver s license so i could drive truck for him he wa a big help and wa instrumental in me getting the job i have now the farm wa a tight knit family so i wa treated well but the work wa completely horrible it prepared me for the struggle of rebuilding my life after prison though it didn t kill me and it made me stronger that job sucked but i wa still glad to have it because i wouldn t be in the position i m in today otherwise david hibdon 55 year old from missouri served 10 year for drug conspiracy released from custody in 2014 my first job out of prison wa the worst job available in colombia missouri i wa picking up trash at the city dump in 100 plus degree weather for 8 an hour i had to walk around 27 acre and pick up the trash that blew off the truck rain or shine some day i walked through raw sewage or mud up to my ankle the halfway house didn t provide transportation to the job and i had to walk there every morning it wa a seven mile walk that took over two hour i had to be there at seven in the morning and got off at 4 pm with only a short lunch break in between with my first paycheck i bought a bike and then it only took me forty minute to get to work i wa making about 50 buck a day but i wa required to give 25 percent to the halfway house if i bought a soda or cigarette i wa almost broke it took me two month in the halfway house to save up and buy a 500 car i worked there because it wa the only job available nobody wanted the job because of the stink and the dust blowing on you from the trash truck no one else would take these job besides ex con at the halfway house and all the other ex con that worked there would sleep on a nearby hill or smoke k2 all day while i wa working i wa alienated out there it wa one of the most degrading experience i ever went through but i got past it it sure didn t help me become a better person cause i wa still the same after i ve had four job since i ve been out and i never told anyone i wa on parole until after i wa hired or they wouldn t have hired me i eventually started my own business subcontracting myself out to do maintenance on rental property i could go back to the dump if i wanted but that job sucked image of a telemarketing call center via mike vargas 44 year old from washington dc served 14 year for a drug conspiracy released from custody in 2009 it wasn t hard getting a job when i came home it just wasn t a good job i started working the same week i wa released at this telemarketing place that hired ex con at 7 25 an hour you had to be there talking to people on the phone all day cold calling trying to collect donation for different organization around the state and country it wa cool at first but after a while i wa starting to feel like a robot i worked with mostly young people and there were also a bunch of ex con working there anybody could have got hired at this place but the condition were terrible you had a total of 16 minute of break time for a full eight hour shift if you went to get a coke you had to clock out if you went to the bathroom you had to clock out if you didn t kiss as you were an outsider there wa a lot of favoritism and also a big turnover within staff of course dude would curse out the bos one dude even jumped up picked up a computer and slammed it down because he couldn t get anybody to donate he walked out shortly after but most ex con needed the job to get out of the halfway house so they just kept working there until something better came along i quit that job when i had something better lined up it served it purpose because if you don t have a gig you have to stay at the halfway i ve had like seven or eight job since then i ve done a lot of different thing but that wa the worst i m a machinist now and i assemble part all day at a machine it s easier and the pay is better but i am always looking for something better
question: ex con remember their worst job after being released from prison what are the worst job that ex con remember after being released from prison

text: working on a cattle ranch a a utility farmer
picking up trash at the city dump in 100 plus degree weather

title: we ve finally figured out when the moon formed
context: the cataclysmic collision between earth and a mar size object that forged the moon may have occurred about 4 47 billion year ago suggests a study of meteorite with ancient fragment from that cosmic impact this finding suggests that one day it may be possible to find sample of what the primordial earth wa like before the giant impact that formed the moon or to uncover bit of the impacting rock itself earth wa born about 4 5 billion year ago and scientist think the moon formed shortly afterward the leading explanation for the moon s origin known a the giant impact hypothesis suggests that the moon resulted from the collision of two protoplanets or embryonic world one of those wa the young earth and the other wa a potentially mar size object called theia the moon then coalesced from the rubble how earth s moon wa made a photo timeline by understanding the moon we can tell the story of the early bombardment of earth study lead author william bottke a planetary scientist at the southwest research institute in boulder colorado told space com however the precise timeline of this giant impact event is under dispute the age of the most ancient lunar sample the apollo astronaut brought back are still debated since these sample have typically been battered and heated by subsequent cosmic impact to understand the formation and evolution of our world a well a those in the inner solar system we need to understand the timing of major event during the planet formation era bottke said to find out more about this giant impact scientist developed a computer model of the event they found that the impact not only created a disk of debris near earth that formed the moon but it also ejected huge amount of rubble a much a several percent of earth s mass away from earth and the moon the simulation found that numerous fragment from the moon forming impact hundred of million of which were at least a mile 1 6 kilometer long blasted the asteroid belt striking asteroid there at speed of more than 22 370 mph 36 000 km h more than twice a fast a typical crash in the belt these collision from the moon forming impact would have generated superheated material the researcher said in an explosion there is often collateral damage where nearby building and innocent bystander are affected bottke said investigator can learn about the explosive device and the explosion itself by studying what happened to people infrastructure and whether trace amount of the explosive device can be found among the blast damage here the innocent bystander were the main belt asteroid collision against these asteroid in more recent time returned these remnant to earth in stony meteorite which the scientist now have analyzed and used to date the age of the impact in a sense the asteroid belt ha been an eyewitness to multiple drive by shooting from the earliest time in solar system history bottke said by reading the trace left behind we can use asteroid sample to tell u who did it when they did it and how they did it the researcher deduced that the moon forming impact occurred about 4 47 billion year ago in agreement with many previous estimate we can now use asteroid for the first time to tell u about many of the major event that took place in the inner solar system during the planet formation era bottke said this give u a new window on a time period which ha been virtually unknown up to now this research raise the intriguing possibility that trace amount of the primordial earth or moon forming impactor called theia may still be found on asteroid today or possibly within some of our meteorite bottke said it may be simply a matter of looking and asking the right question finding these material would be one of the holy grail of geology we have no rock older than 4 billion year old on earth and no one know the exact nature of the original building block of our planet if future research can uncover example of this impact in asteroid sample possibly by getting them from an asteroid sample return mission like osiris rex we would have one of the key piece of the puzzle explaining why our world is the way it is and what ha changed since it infancy bottke said the scientist detailed their finding in the april 17 issue of the journal science

title: white wine and beer are source of arsenic in diet study find
context: white wine beer and brussels sprout can be major source of the toxic metal arsenic in people s diet according to a new study researcher analyzed the diet of 852 people in new hampshire and wine and to a lesser extent red wine brussels sprout and dark meat fish such a salmon tuna and sardine according to the study published last week nov 16 in the nutrition journal the most significant source of arsenic in most people s diet is drinking water the new study is the first to take into account the level of arsenic in the participant household water when looking at the amount of arsenic coming from food the result suggest that diet can be an important source of people s arsenic exposure over the long term regardless of arsenic concentration in their drinking water the researcher said the element arsenic occurs naturally in the environment long term exposure to arsenic even at low level ha been linked to increased risk of bladder lung and skin cancer a well a type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease the environmental protection agency epa limit the arsenic in drinking water to 10 microgram per litter for drinking water but there are few limit set for food 5 thing you should know about arsenic in the study the arsenic level in the participant household tap water were well below the epa limit at 0 30 microgram per liter on average however 52 participant had tap water arsenic level higher than the epa s limit the arsenic level in participant toenail were 0 12 microgram per gram on average however it is unclear what level of concentration found in toenail sample might signal an unsafe level of arsenic exposure said study author kathryn cottingham researcher at dartmouth college in new hampshire the toenail measurement in the study served only a a way to compare level among people the researcher said people who reported drinking on average two and half beer or a glass of white wine every day had arsenic level 20 to 30 percent higher than those of people who didn t drink the study wasn t designed to find why higher consumption of beer and wine wa linked to higher arsenic level but a few scenario are possible cottingham said 7 way alcohol affect your health one possibility is that the ingredient in beer and wine are high in arsenic it is also possible that arsenic is added during the filtration process that give beer and wine their sparkly clear look a one recent study suggested cottingham said and lastly alcohol itself may be to blame for the higher arsenic level by impairing the body s ability to detoxify arsenic the mechanism that our body use to try to get rid of the stuff that is not good for u can be impaired by alcohol consumption cottingham said the researcher didn t find a link between arsenic level and intake of rice which is thought to be relatively high in arsenic but in line with previous study they found that the more dark meat fish people ate the higher were their arsenic level people who ate dark meat fish once a week had about a 7 percent higher arsenic concentration in their toenail compared with people who consumed these fish le than once a month although some food are high in arsenic people don t need to avoid them entirely cottingham said probably the best way to avoid exposure from diet is to mix it up in the food and not eat the same thing every day it s also important to keep water source safe she said if someone is drinking water from a private well they should get it tested water is something we are drinking and using every day cottingham said so knowing what your water exposure is i think is a big piece of the puzzle
question: what s lurking in your white wine will scare you what will scare you in your white wine

title: 5 reason why no one ha built a better epipen
context: oston mom denise clark ha been buying epipens annually for the past 16 year ever since her son wa diagnosed with a serious peanut allergy problem is he won t carry his epipen around with him because it won t fit into his pocket it s large and it s impractical clark said where s he going to put it this underscore a simple truth epipens just aren t that great they re reliable sure they ll buy a patient who s in the midst of a severe allergic reaction a few crucial minute to make his way to the hospital but they re also bulky their epinephrine solution isn t particularly shelf stable and will easily degrade in temperature that are too low or too high they expire after about a year and they re not so user friendly though epipens come with a practice kit user in the midst of an allergy attack have mistaken which end s the pointy end and stabbed their thumb instead of their thigh the device have come under fire in the past month for their escalating sticker price a pack of two epipens now list for 608 mylan which owns the epipen brand though the device itself is actually manufactured by pfizer note that it redesigned the product in 2009 added feature including the flip top case and is investing substantial amount in research into additional improvement such a a formulation with a longer shelf life but critic say mylan ha little incentive to improve epipens if you re the monopolist and you ve got a product that expires every year and it s not super easy to carry around so the safest thing to do is have several tucked away in different place i don t see why there would be any pressure to innovate said nicholson price an assistant professor at the university of michigan law school who study health care regulation and patent law epipen s flaw seem like feature not a bug price said competitor have tried to make run at the epipen and more are trying now that there s such a spotlight on the product but it s unclear if anything can displace the familiar auto injector with the bright orange cap here s why 1 mylan ha patent protection that last through 2025 epinephrine a a drug wa first synthesized more than a century ago it s been used for various medical application since then and wa first packaged in an auto injector to protect soldier against chemical warfare back in the 1970s but mylan ha a lock on the particular epipen design that million of patient parent and school nurse have come to trust the company s main innovation ha been a bright orange cap that cover the needle but release automatically when a patient push an epipen against her thigh so there s no need to stop and unscrew the cover in the midst of an allergy attack the very fact that the epipen ha been dominant for so long make it hard for challenger to come in with a radically different design mylan is now pledging to make a generic version which it say will be identical except for the label if you re a parent and your child s suffering from an allergic reaction you have to give them an injection and don t want to read the instruction in that moment said matthew allen head of drug delivery for cambridge consultant you just have to know how to use it allen s work at cambridge consultant center around designing other form of auto injector he said the food and drug administration ha rule to standardize the way these life saving device work those rule keep consumer safe but they also make it difficult to come up with design that can meet the standard without infringing on mylan s patent it would not be very difficult to create an epipen product in term of engineering allen said it s not rocket science it s purely the patent that stop u 2 there s no room for error when you re treating anaphylaxis chris stepanian is ceo of windgap medical a boston startup that s been working on a next generation epinephrine auto injector for the past five year windgap s device is meant to improve upon the epipen it s supposed to be smaller about the size of a bic lighter with a much more stable formulation of epinephrine intended to survive in a pant pocket without getting overheated but that s proving easier said than done stepanian said he s at least a few year away from bringing his newfangled auto injector to market though epipen component look pretty basic mylan note that it is made up of 26 part and must be able to deliver the drug with a sterile needle within second stepanian agrees that it s more complicated than it seems at first glance it s really challenging to make a reliable auto injector and surprisingly hard to make a combination drug product he said it s a tough thing to nail down the drug supply chain the plastic and design and then incorporate that all together and put the drug inside it and then regardless of how the user us it get the appropriate dose within the acceptable limit of the fda stepanian added at least mylan and pfizer have done a good job of making a pretty reliable one one epipen alternative that did make it to market the auvi q an epinephrine auto injector shaped like a bulky credit card but sanofi recalled the device last year over concern that patient weren t getting the correct dose every time it returned the commercial and marketing right to kaleo from whom it licensed the auto injector in 2009 a representative from kaleo said that it s in the process of evaluating when and how to bring the auvi q back to the market but sanofi is no longer involved 3 it doesn t take an auto injector to get epinephrine into the body but it sure help in the wake of the recent outrage at mylan los angeles based mannkind corporation announced it s developing an inhalable form of epinephrine we could make something very tiny that you could carry on a keychain much smaller than an epipen or auto injector by far mannkind ceo matthew pfeffer said mannkind already ha an inhalable insulin product called afrezza on the market which give diabetic an alternative to injection but it s proved exceedingly tough to get patient to switch from a format of insulin intake they re familiar with to an inhaler sale have been far below expectation the same problem could stymie an epinephrine inhaler especially since one of the frightening feature of an anaphylactic attack is that the airway constrict which in theory anyway could make it hard for a patient to use the inhaler in a moment of crisis 4 the regulatory process is slow and expensive a lot of the challenge lie in the regulatory system said mark baum ceo of san diego based imprimis a compound pharmaceutical company that s working on a cheaper alternative to the epipen it can take a long time and a lot of money to get fda approval for a new product the only time it make economic sense to take the risk of going through these clinical trial is when you have a situation like this baum said but when the market wa more normalized when the epipen wa only retailing around 100 competitor questioned whether it wa worth taking that risk public anger at epipen is so high right now that baum figure it is worth taking the risk imprimis ha had it eye on the epinephrine auto injector market for about two year now it s finally going to go for it we re just focused on being that competition he said 5 the public hasn t spoken loud enough denise clark whose son ha that peanut allergy is a consultant with boston medtech advisor she help medical device company with design market analysis and regulatory strategy but though she work in the field every day she say she never even thought much about the flaw of the epipen design or the lack of innovation until the product started hitting headline it s something that s always been irritating to me but not to the point that i ve looked at it closely until i had to start paying all this money clark said granted the federal trade commission ha been fielding complaint about mylan s pricing for year and complaint about the device s clunkiness are no secret but since the epipen is generally covered by insurance many customer have simply gone with it that mean there s been little pressure from the paying public for innovation i guess mylan s motto is if it ain t broke don t fix it clark said they have such a monopoly so why would they bother improving the epipen
question: 5 reason why no one ha built a better epipen what are the five reason why no one ha built a better epipen

procured before he get to work on the evening s meal jason love listening to live music it s our favorite thing to do together i should also add that our 19 year old daughter paris would rather go to paint i love his artwork i would call him an artist except for the law degree that keep him at his downtown office most day from 9 to 5 or at least it did before i got sick if you re looking for a dreamy let s go for it travel companion jason is your man he also ha an affinity for tiny thing taster spoon little jar a mini sculpture of a couple sitting on a bench which he presented to me a a reminder of how our family began here is the kind of man jason is he showed up at our first pregnancy ultrasound with flower this is a man who because he is always up early surprise me every sunday morning by making some kind of oddball smiley face out of item near the coffeepot a spoon a mug a banana this is a man who emerges from the minimart or gas station and say give me your palm and voila a colorful gumball appears he know i love all the flavor but white my guess is you know enough about him now so let s swipe right wait did i mention that he is incredibly handsome i m going to miss looking at that face of his if he sound like a prince and our relationship seems like a fairy tale it s not too far off except for all of the regular stuff that come from two and a half decade of playing house together and the part about me getting cancer blech in my most recent memoir written entirely before my diagnosis i invited reader to send in suggestion for matching tattoo the idea being that author and reader would be bonded by ink i wa totally serious about this and encouraged submitter to be serious a well hundred poured in a few week after publication in august i heard from a 62 year old librarian in milwaukee named paulette she suggested the word more this wa based on an essay in the book where i mention that more wa my first spoken word true and now it may very well be my last time shall tell in september paulette drove down to meet me at a chicago tattoo parlor she got hers her very first on her left wrist i got mine on the underside of my left forearm in my daughter s handwriting this wa my second tattoo the first is a small lowercase j that ha been on my ankle for 25 year you can probably guess what it stand for jason ha one too but with more letter akr i want more time with jason i want more time with my child i want more time sipping martini at the green mill jazz club on thursday night but that is not going to happen i probably have only a few day left being a person on this planet so why i am doing this i am wrapping this up on valentine s day and the most genuine non vase oriented gift i can hope for is that the right person read this find different in thousand of way from their ethnicity to their income to their sleepover policy but we set out to find the way they are the same in selecting candidate to study we ignored sibling who do the same work in the same industry like venus and serena williams and family that come from a great fortune or legacy like the trump or the kennedy we looked for family in which all the sibling did well and we defined success by leadership service or achievement not just fame or money alone of course genetics play a role for every family but we focused on upbringing and sibling dynamic instead some of the consistency are fairly predictable while none of these sibling grew up rich they were privileged in many other way they had involved parent and lot of opportunity and most saw college a involved in political activism of some kind most recall a conflict heavy family life but that conflict wa rarely between the parent many had a strong awareness of mortality a child and most said they grew up with much more freedom than their friend did we talked to mayor and poet and judge and rapper jew from chicago and indian from kansa and haitian from nebraska we talked to sibling together and alone and we talked to parent where we could here are six striking quality they shared immigrant drive a gino rodriguez wa boxing with his daughter in chicago saroja srinivasan a hindu who is university of kansa everyone they knew wa back in india we made a conscious decision that we are different enough so we should do everything we can to make the kid feel part of their community saroja recall that meant cooking hot dog and pizza a well a dosas and pakoras watching the kansa jayhawks in a living room adorned with indian devotional art and arranging present under the family shrine to celebrate krishmas their version of christmas just like their neighbor the three srinivasan child sri srija and srinija played basketball and went shopping and rode dirt bike but they didn t have chore in the same way their friend did in the srinivasan household le wa required but more wa expected there wa no one person responsible for the trash or dish it wa more like look around what s mom doing doe she need help recall srinija the youngest put thing away pay attention also nobody got an allowance instead a drawer in the living room table contained petty cash for anyone to use on the one hand it meant great permissiveness that is way better than an allowance say srinija on the other hand responsibility for every choice her older sister srija put it this way if i took 20 that meant sri and srinija couldn t go to the movie the srinivasan family left and right courtesy of the srinivasan family the three kid now adult say they grew up understanding that the family wa more important grow up to sit on the u s court of appeal for the d c circuit his name wa floated earlier this year a a candidate for the supreme court srija is the interim deputy chief for the san mateo county health system responsible for public health effort affecting more than 700 000 californian and srinija is an entrepreneur who wa one of the first employee at yahoo and now sits on the board of tumor when she wa 13 jack is a grammy winning musician who is the lead singer of bleacher and lead guitarist of fun now on hiatus rachel is a new york city based fashion de signer they re unlike many of the other eight family their parent aren t immigrant or educator nobody in their family cared much about politics and they didn t break rule because there weren t any rule to break instead since their sister s death more than a decade ago the antonoffs say they re motivated by a constant awareness of their own mortality when you hear about a movie coming out that you re excited to see do you not think every time oh i hope i m still alive rachel asks sitting in the los angeles studio where jack is recording his latest album jack nod digging into a cupcake in honor of his 32nd birthday i have to get my gallbladder out and i don t want to do it until this record is done in case i die on the table he say everything back up to the amount of work i do before i die that creates a work ethic there s an urgency the antonoff family left courtesy of the antonoff family right amy lombard posttraumatic growth is a tricky concept for many kid and even adult a loss of this magnitude may i wa doing he say i wa a changed person it can also help a family get their priority straight jack and rachel s mother shira antonoff said sarah s death drowned out all the petty judgment and expectation of their suburban new jersey community she let her kid skip school she didn t insist they finish college and she took jack to get his lip pierced at age 15 to the shock and dismay of other mother in the grocery store the core wa we ve had a sick kid we ve had a kid who s died so let s get real about what s important here shira say you ve got to find a path in life that you re really happy with a free range childhood like many of the other sibling in this story tan and maya lin grew up on a university campus were raised by immigrant parent and bickered constantly over board game they were also allowed to do practically anything they wanted you could say it wa the opposite of helicopter parenting their father henry huan lin had been forced to take calligraphy class while parent who closely monitored their movement and many said they were raised with significantly more freedom than their friend by the standard of today s helicopter parent they ran wild the dungey sister rode all over sacramento on their bike alone the antonoffs were allowed to skip school whenever they wanted six year old zeke emanuel regularly escorted 4 year old rahm home from nursery school on a chicago city bus she wa a supporter of u but she didn t tell u what to do and she allowed u to play and develop our own idea say zeke of his mother she didn t even worry too much whether they were safe or not esther wojcicki taught her daughter to swim a soon a they could walk specifically so that she wouldn t have to watch them when they played near the backyard pool i empowered them early because i wanted to make sure they could take care of themselves she say they could read early so they could read sign they could do math early so they could handle money even by the comparatively lax stan dard of the 1970s the wojcicki girl had more freedom than most five year old susan wa often left to babysit 4 year old janet and infant anne and local mother raised their eyebrow when the girl rode their bike alone to the dime store a mile away but esther ha a theory the more you do for your kid the le they do for themselves and the le empowered they feel she say thousand of extraordinary family flourish across america and the new generation of hyperaware parent may raise thousand more but none of the parent in this story set out to raise successful child instead the six commonality of our nine family combined to create drive grit and social consciousness that propelled all the sibling on their own chosen path you cannot reach anybody s goal you ve got to reach your own goal say gino rodriguez you cannot reach a goal unless you set that goal for yourself that s why i can and i will are five word without an object a push without direction look how call about heroin to their help line it wasn t just that we were getting call about heroin we were getting call about heroin and teen specifically he say it became clear that this wa a problem in some supplier wa 30 year old emily started skipping school and then didn t try out for cheerleading the next year doing heroin became part of her daily routine when a friend wanted to try it for her sixteenth birthday emily realized heroin wasn t her little secret anymore it wa something other kid at her school were doing too over the course of two year she entered treatment six time overdosed on heroin twice and ran away from home emily wa thrown out of a hotel and a homeless shelter after that she returned home and attended twelve step meeting but continued to use finally a switch flipped i wa willing to go to any length to get high and then it became clear that i needed to go to any length to get sober i had to change every single thing in my life which wa terrifying emily say but when the pain of staying the same wa greater than the pain of change that s when i knew i really had to do something in 2012 and 2013 local news report in denver chicago atlanta seattle orange county syracuse and a growing number of other area told the tale of teen dying from heroin case like andrew s are becoming more of the norm while those of recovering addict like emily seem to be more of the title: doe sparkling water have a downside
context: plain seltzer or sparkling water s lack of sugar calorie added color or artificial flavor and it relatively low acidity make it a generally healthy choice compared to most beverage option on the market including most soda juice and sport drink but check the product label to avoid added sweetener or sodium or other additive seltzer is water that ha had pressurized carbon dioxide added to give it bubble sparkling water is the umbrella term for carbonated water including naturally carbonated sparkling mineral water and artificially carbonated seltzer and club soda study have not shown ill health effect from drinking seltzer or other plain sparkling water 2006 study found an association between drinking cola and low bone mineral density but the association wa not seen in those who drank other carbonated beverage cola with their low ph a measure of acidity also have the potential to erode tooth enamel but a study published earlier this year in the journal of the american dental association found that the ph of plain sparkling water about 5 is not low enough to erode enamel carbonation doe not in itself lead to dental erosion said dr john ruby an adjunct professor of pediatric dentistry at the university of alabama at birmingham who co authored the paper it s when they add citric acid or phosphoric acid that s in your classic soft drink that the ph can drop below the critical ph of 4 where you then can have dental erosion a an outcome for example coca cola ha a ph of about 2 4 making it potentially over 100 time more erosive than sparkling water because ph is on a logarithmic scale bottled seltzer that have been flavored with citric acid the acid found naturally in citrus fruit like lemon and lime may be acidic enough to damage enamel but you can get flavor in a le acidic form by adding a slice of lemon or lime or other fruit vegetable or herb such a cucumber mint or basil to plain sparkling water according to a spokesman from the american dental association the greatest potential health drawback of consuming bottled sparkling water is missing out on the benefit of fluoride when you drink it instead of fluoridated tap water in home sparkling water maker such a sodastream have gained popularity in recent year because they save money and have environmental benefit but an additional advantage of making your own sparkling water from the tap may be the fluoride which the ada emphasizes is essential for maintaining long term oral health an additional health note club soda which contains added sodium to mimic the taste of mineral water is not the same a seltzer the amount of sodium can be small and varies by brand but it can add up if consuming many serving too much sodium can increase blood pressure and current sodium level among most american are already considered too high

title: if you re not rotating your grocery in your fridge you re doing it wrong
context: a part of huffpost s reclaim project huffpost taste will focus the entire month of july on simple way you can reduce food waste in your own home photo credit almay here at the huffington post we spend a lot of time coming up with way to waste le food spend le money on grocery and eat better meal there are many tool in our toolbox to make this all possible and today we re going to talk about one more the fifo method of sorting your grocery fifo stand for first in first out it s a method used in accounting and wait for it at the grocery store when the supermarket get fresh milk in stock for example they place the older stuff in front and the newer stuff behind it this ensures that the consumer will purchase the older product first before it spoil and they have to throw it out it s a simple concept but an effective one here s what you need to do with that information use this method at home putting away the grocery can sometimes feel like the worst part of this essential kitchen chore so it s understandable if you just shove the grocery into the fridge without a second thought we get it but stop instead move all the perishable older good to the front and place the newer grocery behind them this small step will ensure that you use up last week s grocery before digging in to the newer stuff start today and see the difference it really is that simple
question: the ridiculously simple trick that ll keep your food from spoiling what is the trick that will keep food from spoiling

title: scrumdiddlyumptious to oompa loompa six of roald dahl s splendiferous word have been added to the oxford english dictionary
context: roald dahl is remembered for his solitary kind hearted child hero charlie who visited a chocolate factory and sophie who befriended a floppy eared giant among them and their triumph over bullying adult but the beloved british child s book author wa also known for the distinctive language he used to create the vivid often dark world in which the character lived to honor the centenary of his birth this month the oxford english dictionary ha updated it latest edition today sept 12 with six new word connected to dahl s writing and revision to six other phrase popularized by dahl s evocative story in may the oxford university press also published a roald dahl dictionary complete with 8 000 word coined or popularized by the author there wa linguistic method to dahl s mad use of language he wa using very linguistic principle say vineeta gupta head of child s dictionary at oxford university press dahl invented word based on old word rhyme malapropism and spoonerism swapping the first letter of word around such a catasterous disastrophe from the bfg dahl also played with sound sizzle pan to refer to a frying pan in the bfg for example here are the new dahlisms added to the oed and the revised phrase with note on their origin new entry dahlesque the characteristic of dahl s work in the oed s word eccentric plot villainous or loathsome adult character and gruesome or black humour now have their own adjective the term wa first used in 1983 by the literary magazine book ireland golden ticket these refer to the ticket hidden in chocolate bar that granted access to willy wonka s chocolate factory in charlie and the chocolate factory 1964 the first golden ticket however wa awarded to 18th century painter william hogarth giving him admission to the vauxhall garden in london in recognition of his painting of the venue human bean this is a mispronunciation of human being uttered by the giant in the bfg 1982 we is having an interesting babblement about the taste of the human bean the human bean is not a vegetable the first instance of the phrase is over a century older having been used in an issue of the british satirical magazine punch in 1842 oompa loompa the diminutive factory worker who played music and danced in charlie and the chocolate factory were made more famous by the 1971 film adaption of the book starring gene wilder gupta called the phrase typical dahlesque reflecting how the author played with sound to convey meaning scrumdiddlyumptious extremely scrumptious excellent splendid esp of food delicious although the word wa first found in the american thesaurus of slang in 1942 dahl s giant s use of it planted it firmly in the mind of every child who read the bfg every human bean is diddly and different some is scrumdiddlyumptious and some is uckyslush witching hour referred to in the bfg a a special moment in the middle of the night when every child and every grown up wa in a deep deep sleep and all the dark thing came out from hiding and had the world to themselves we can thank shakespeare for this evocative phrase according to the oed witching time first appeared in hamlet 1604
question: six of roald dahl s made up word have been added to the oxford english dictionary to celebrate his centenary what is the name of the author whose centenary is being celebrated by adding six of his made up word to the oxford english dictionary

title: making olive oil in the peloponnese
context: even though the peloponnese is only an hour s drive away from athens it s a if you re entering another world or at least another country concrete box are replaced with olive grove and the word traffic jam tend to mean that a group of goat have convened gathering and blocking the road needle to say i greatly enjoy the small village of the peloponnese so when george papageorgiou the owner of esti olive oil asked me if i wanted to go to kalamata to see how they harvest the olive and turn them into olive oil i jumped at the chance to me this wa kind of like winning the lottery i wa going to the peloponnese and getting a chance to enjoy some liquid gold being greek i grew up eating olive oil i know others might disagree with me but i will take a good quality olive oil over butter any day i love using it to make popcorn i drizzle it on fresh tomato and slice of bread i use it to fry fish and a an ingredient in cake before there were rule for the amount of liquid you could carrying on a plane my mother and i would bring half gallon container of olive oil back from our trip to greece the best olive oil come from greece i say this with objectivity a a chef and would like to think that this override any bias that my greek heritage hold in greece it is said that the best of greek olive oil come from the peloponnese for year i have wished that greek would be more like the italian the italian do a fantastic job of exporting and promoting their product to other country with the booming introduction of greek yogurt into the u s i m hoping that greek olive oil will soon follow suit george papageorgiou is trying to make that happen the esti olive grove in kalamata is located in a beautiful sunlit valley the grove of mature olive tree look a if they belong in greek mythology the olive must be harvested at a specific time during the ripening process like goldilocks searching amongst the belonging of the three bear george is in constant search for the olive that are just right if the olive are too green the olive oil produced will taste bitter if the olive are too black the quality of the olive oil will be lost it s a constant balancing act a we headed into the olive grove numerous fine mesh net were being laid down to gather and catch all the olive worker set up ladder to reach the tall branch the lower hanging branch were gently being shaken taking care not to wound the tree i began to collect olive in my little basket a my hand turned a reddish brown i reminisced about the day i used to spend a a child collecting olive with my yiayia we took the gathered olive back to the production plant where george had them ground into paste using large millstone this he explained is the traditional method used for making olive oil after grinding the paste then get slowly stirred in a separate container for 20 to 40 minute this is a process known a malaxation with malaxation the slow churning action allows the small droplet of oil that were released in the milling process to aggregate forming large droplet of oil which facilitates mechanical extraction i wa a bit overwhelmed during the whole process i looked around the manufacturing facility much like a child the first time they visit disneyland i snapped picture i wanted to see what wa behind every door i asked george if the oil we had witnessed being made wa virgin or extra virgin i had always assumed that the grading of extra virgin denoted a different process or different stage in the olive s ripeness george shook his head this wa not correct in fact all olive oil produced by physical mechanical mean is virgin the differentiation of extra virgin is the virgin olive oil that satisfies specific high chemical and organoleptic criterion in layman s term it is the virgin olive oil that ha low free acidity and no quality defect the final room we visited that day wa lined with shiny steel tank much like a winery the storage of the olive oil in steel tank help to preserve it and keep it from oxidizing it s the final resting place for the olive oil before it is bottled in greek the word theoxenia come from mythology and relates to hospitality how host treat guest or even stranger it s an important part of greek culture this wa something george clearly keep in mind before leaving the facility that day george sent me home with a box filled with bottle of olive oil virgin extra virgin organic extra virgin that night and many night since i have enjoyed his olive oil in each bite i can taste the olive grove and it bright sun kissed fruit i can t help but think that everyone even the french might fall in love with olive oil if they had a chance to taste the greek rendition
question: the most unexpected country that rock at making olive oil what country is known for producing high quality olive oil

title: why 2017 is the year to visit kathmandu
context: with the two year anniversary of the nepal earthquake approaching the capital is back on it foot now s the time to go say martin symington why go now there s a compelling reason for visiting in 2017 every rupee spent in hotel and restaurant shop taxi or temple is helping kathmandu back on to it foot nearly two year after the earthquake which devastated swathe of nepal and severely damaged the capital kathmandu is bouncing back to it alluring self with astonishing verve rebuilding and restoration is proceeding apace while tourist are returning to bathe in the himalayan city s sensory overload temple and square prayer flag and sputtering scooter merchant yelling behind marigold garlanded stall amid waft of incense spice and holy cow dung get your bearing the old city known a durbar square lie at the centre of kathmandu to it north frenetic thamel is a maze of hotel restaurant trekking agency and shop to the south the bagmati river border peaceful patan district with it own durbar square and expatriate community beyond the former royal palace to the east are the smarter shopping centre and embassy local tempo minibus and bus are best avoided they re crowded slow and not the safest however taxi are cheap and plentiful and rickshaw can be a useful way of travelling short distance take a view puff your way up the 400 step stone staircase to the buddhist stupa of swayambhunath 1 known a monkey temple on account of the hundred of holy monkey who will be your chattering food begging companion if the day is clear the whole of kathmandu valley unfurls at your foot you will see from here how localised the earthquake damage wa isolated pocket have collapsed like card while large area remained more or le unscathed take a hike nowhere is the localised nature of the earthquake damage more apparent that in the area known a durbar square a riot of ancient palace temple and royal monument which comprise the unesco listed historic heart of kathmandu start at the northern thamel end check post 2 where tourist pay an entrance fee of 1000rs about 7 70 fee for free run of the whole area join throng of pilgrim at shiva dedicated mahendreshwar mandir 3 with it chiming bell and flickering candle follow the flow down to jagannath mandir 4 a hindu temple which attracts gawping fascination on account of it athletic and imaginative erotic carving which seems to suggest that the earth ha always moved in these part if it s between 10am and noon keep an eye out the kumari devi or living child goddess might put in an appearance at her window above the courtyard of her magnificently carved sacred home the kumari dar 5 however now that you are down at the south end of the historic region the heartrending extend of the earthquake damage becomes unavoidable cordoned off for safety is the red brick old royal palace 6 whose wall are now cracked while the adjacent basantapur tower 7 somehow remain precariously erect exit via freak street official name jochne 8 the legendary 1960s hippy hangout though it glory day are now over lunch on the run climb six flight of stair to the rooftop kasthamandap cafe 9 at 23 maru 00 977 1 6219177 no web for an open air coffee and snack under a sun umbrella there are commanding view over durbar square window shopping the thamel district north of durbar square survived the earthquake more or le intact and remains the backpacker hub a successor to freak street it s a carnival of noisy alley and tiny square packed with hundred of trekking agency and shop hawking everything from tourist tat to genuine tibetan antique one good bet for quality thanka painting and woven rug is amrita craft 10 on chhetrapait an aperitif owner prakash will probably be around to welcome you in person to zibro 11 on chaksibari marg 00 977 984 1059449 no web his laid back rooftop bar where young nepali shoot the breeze with holidaying indian and european traveller the music is on multi cultural message too with song from little known local band playing nepali folk rock fusion in the background it s a great place to make new friend over a glass of local craft beer khumbu kolsch dine with the local at bhojan griha 12 on dilli bazaar in the eastern district of kathmandu traditional newari dish are served to guest in a 19th century mansion restored with painstaking attention to detail dish include buffalo meat or vegetable filled momo dumpling and duck with peanut and spiced lentil the restaurant say that all produce is organic and no plastic is used main around 6 8 take a ride for the ride of your life board a small propeller plane for a dawn mountain flight along the crest of the himalaya you ll pas up close and personal many of the world s highest peak including mount everest flight are in the early morning when condition are generally clearest but good view are weather dependent and weather related cancellation are frequent an hour long flight with buddha air cost u 192 158 sunday morning out to brunch la dolce vita 13 at chaksibhari marg 00 977 1 4700612 no web doesn t have the best coffee in kathmandu but what it lack in a caffeine fix it make up for with delicious italian pastry pasta and gnocchi sprinkled with grated yak s cheese sit on the sunny terrace watching the street drama of chaotic thamel below open from 11am meal around 8 10 a walk in the park it say a lot that swapna bagaicha 14 on kaiser mahal tridevi marg is also known a the garden of dream a botanical park and serene retreat from the frenetic city it s just a few minute walk from central thamel sadly the park took a hard hit in the earthquake damaging some of the neo classical pavilion statue pond and fountain nevertheless the plant are still lovingly tended and the r 200 1 50 entrance fee is being put to good restorative use cultural afternoon the historic buddhist city of patan effectively a suburb of kathmandu is a 20 minute taxi ride across the tea coloured bagmati river patan is a repository of temple palace and stupa strewn around it own durbar square sadly several of these took hit in the earthquake the fac ade of the kwa bahal 15 also known a the golden temple is one almost untouched highlight the four giant prayer flag festooned ashoka stupa 16 are another and then there s the fact it s guarded by score of holy tortoise the icing on the cake treat yourself to a massage by a seeing hand blind masseur whose finger are attuned to muscle and tissue in way that the sighted will never match at the same time support this commendable organisation which provides employment and independence for nepal s blind men and woman a range of therapy are offered in a clinical setting in it premise off jyatha road thamel 17 getting there qatar airway fly to kathmandu via doha from heathrow manchester birmingham and edinburgh from 685 return other option include etihad via abu dhabi and jet airway via delhi or mumbai staying there hotel shangri la 18 is a the name suggests a swanky a kathmandu get it s an inviting low rise modern hotel with traditional flourish in a lush garden with cool pool double from 105 b b something of a thamel institution everyone from jeremy iron to ricky martin have stayed here the kathmandu guest house 19 is a bit rough round the edge these day but still a good mid range choice it s located in a former palace double from 65 b b on a budget hotel horizon 20 is a gem tucked away in an alley near the north end of durbar square breakfast on sequinned cushion in the courtyard is a treat double from 24 b b

title: legal weed sale halted in colorado town due to lack of staple in paperwork
context: a the list of of colorado county and city that are banning recreational marijuana sale continues to grow another small town will also go without legal weed but not because of a lack of interest rather due to a lack of staple krdo first reported about local marijuana advocate tim klob s petition where he helped gather nearly 600 signature to put a measure on the november ballot to allow recreational marijuana sale and industrial hemp grows in the southeastern colorado town of la junta i see this a a game changer for our economy klob said to krdo there s no other industry knocking on our door right now unfortunately for klob and for the citizen supporting the measure the petition effort failed because klob inadvertently violated colorado law when he didn t staple each petition volunteer s affidavit with the signature they collected when he turned the document in to the la junta city clerk s office though all necessary material were included in the document the lack of staple voided the petition through a technicality klob and la junta are now back to square one watch krdo s interview with klob here this week grand junction became the latest major colorado city to ban retail sale of recreational marijuana by it city council member even though several citizen requested that the issue be put to a public vote colorado spring the state s second largest city voted to ban recreational pot shop last july and became the largest community in the state to opt out of the state s new marijuana law in the state s capital city of denver which opted in on retail sale of marijuana a two year moratorium on new pot business license wa recommended by the city council the united state government took a historic step back from it long running drug war last week when attorney general eric holder informed the governor of washington and colorado that the department of justice would allow the state to create a regime that would regulate and implement the ballot initiative that legalized the use of marijuana for adult colorado gov john hickenlooper signed several historic measure to implement marijuana legalization in the state establishing colorado a the world s first legal regulated and taxed marijuana market for adult back in may colorado voter passed amendment 64 last november making the limited sale possession and growing of marijuana for recreational purpose legal for adult 21 and over a64 state that adult can posse up to an ounce of pot can grow a many a six marijuana plant at home with only three flowering at any given time but that home grown marijuana can only be for personal use and cannot be sold however adult can gift one another up to an ounce of pot a64 allows adult to posse up to an ounce of marijuana for recreational use even in those city or county that have banned retail sale colorado s 271 municipality and 64 county must decide by oct 1 a to whether they will allow for legal recreational marijuana sale recreational pot sale in colorado city that opt in can begin on jan 1 2014
