title: here s what happens when school let transgender student use the bathroom they want
context: at least once a day pam retzlaff answered a call from parent concerned about her decision to allow a transgender student at edgar road elementary school to use a bathroom different from his biological gender it wa hard in the beginning very hard she said you can imagine my first open house i had more parent in my office than ever before it wa new territory for retzlaff then principal of the school in webster grove missouri a st louis suburb but it wa never a question of whether she would or wouldn t open the bathroom and a time passed the call slowly began to subside going from once a day to once a week to once a month that wa more than two year ago a blip in the schoolwide effort to help the soon to be third grader transition a seamlessly a possible from female to male yet still no cohesive policy exists nationwide on the issue of bathroom access for transgender student even before controversy erupted earlier this year over new state law limiting transgender right or this month s deadly mass shooting at an lgbt nightclub in orlando many school across the country had taken proactive step to make the school environment safer and more welcoming to transgender student opponent of policy that accommodate the bathroom need of transgender student have argued that it s an issue of safety for non transgender student in reality however lesbian gay bisexual and transgender student face the greater risk of harassment and assault especially transgender student and supporter say the bathroom discussion should be focused on protecting their safety according to fbi statistic more than 20 percent of reported hate crime were attack based on sexual orientation and gender identity second only to race and more than attack based on religious bias although some state attorney general and legislator have taken the federal government to court over it directive instructing all public school district to allow transgender student to use restroom that match their gender identity school district in those very state have quietly dealt with the issue with relative ease and student rather than state official or school administrator are often at the forefront in pushing for the change eliza byard executive director of the gay lesbian and straight education network a new york based organization that support lgbt inclusive policy for teacher and student said school leader and student live with the issue and understand it better than elected official do if they were listening to local authority she said they d get out of the way atherton high school in louisville kentucky ha had a policy in place for two year that allows transgender student to use the bathroom that match their gender identity and principal thomas aberli say there have been no problem the most recent federal guideline are aligned with what we ve been doing for the past two year aberli said in an interview despite some concern that permitting transgender student to use the appropriate bathroom might threaten the safety and privacy of other student aberli said that hasn t happened at atherton we have several transgender student now he said it s just kind of a non issue in march springfield central high school in massachusetts converted two single user faculty bathroom into two gender neutral bathroom one each for faculty and student principal thaddeus tokarz said transgender student aren t required to use it though some choose to do so i believe we make it a point to have them use the bathroom they feel most comfortable with tokarz said in camas wash across the columbia river from portland ore liberty middle school principal marilyn boerke said she wa prepared for an onslaught of complaint from parent in the conservative district when the school adopted it policy in 2014 but it just didn t happen the 770 student school allows it five or so transgender student to use the bathroom that corresponds with their gender identity only two parent objected boerke said in response boerke told those parent that if their child were uncomfortable sharing a restroom with a trans student they could opt to use another part of that could be how our community at liberty is really all about family she said we just don t accept that kind of intolerance but the backlash is only beginning elsewhere in texas lt gov dan patrick ha demanded the resignation of kent scribner fort worth s school superintendent over the district s transgender inclusive bathroom policy patrick also argued for it repeal calling it social engineering texas is leading a multistate lawsuit in federal court against the obama administration s policy last month the u s department of education and the u s justice department told school across the country that title ix of a 1972 federal education law protects transgender student from discrimination based on sex including the use of bathroom locker room and showering facility the department reminded school that those that did not comply with title ix requirement risked losing federal fund in a virginia case a federal court agreed with the federal government and sided with a transgender student who challenged his school s policy that force him to a bathroom that doe not match his gender identity nevertheless texas and 10 other state sued the obama administration last month with mississippi kentucky and kansa later joining the effort this month the kansa board of education voted unanimously to oppose the obama administration s policy though the board will allow school district to continue policy that accommodate transgender student according to the gay lesbian and straight education network s 2013 school climate survey transgender and gender nonconforming student faced more hostility than lesbian gay or bisexual student did four in 10 said they felt unsafe at school because of their gender expression about half reported being verbally harassed and about 1 in 5 reported being physically assaulted the majority of student surveyed said they didn t report the harassment or assault to school official because of doubt the staff would do anything about it or fear that it could make thing worse some school that have accommodated transgender student say the move ha improved the learning environment this wa probably the best decision we made a a school all year said kevin biggs principal of roosevelt high school in de moines iowa although he said student were always able to use the most appropriate bathroom for their need biggs said a student visited him in november and explained that some transgender student didn t feel comfortable using the bathroom that were available the school created two all gender single stall restroom in february student can still choose what work best for them those little thing make a huge difference in a student s day they re distraction that can keep student from learning to their highest possible potential biggs said we wanted to make that possible student alonzo hernandez 16 helped kick start the process of creating a multi stalled gender neutral bathroom at the santee education complex a high school in los angeles where he is a junior hernandez is in transition from female to male and his effort wa driven in part by his own discomfort in using the school s existing bathroom he d sometimes avoid going to the bathroom the whole day to avoid harassment there d be time when i would personally wait in the stall to make sure everyone in the bathroom wa cleared out so i could come out of the stall he said in an interview the concern weren t unfounded jose lara dean of student and faculty adviser for the los angeles school s gay straight alliance said the discussion generated a small but vocal protest there were some protester sending hate message to the student telling them they are pervert going to burn in hell targeting the principal saying he s a pedophile lara said but ultimately student teacher and parent embraced the plan the student wanted to have a voice and they wanted to make a change and they made a change lara said
question: here s what happens when school let transgender student use the bathroom they want what happens when school let transgender student use the bathroom they want

title: how one theory you never heard of explains everything donald trump doe
context: when donald trump declared his candidacy for president a year ago nate silver s fivethirtyeight political blog said he had a better chance of cameoing in another home alone movie with macaulay culkin or playing in the nba final than winning the republican nomination with a net favorability rating of 32 percent according to fivethirtyeight and exactly zero chance of winning according to the atlantic how ha trump seemingly emerged victorious from a pool of 17 republican hopeful to try to answer that question would be to travel down a rabbit hole of speculation that ha swallowed so many one thing is sure though while donald trump ha thus far appeared to accomplish the impossible even he ha limit the reality is that trump like policymakers and politician past present and future is operating within the confines of the overton window of political possibility the overton window when you think about it it s so true this theory named for the late joseph p overton of the mackinac center for public policy is a way to explain how opinion about public policy shift over time and the constraint within which policymakers operate the overton window is the spectrum of idea that are politically palatable to voter although there is no limit to the number of policy idea available elected official are limited to only actively supporting idea within this window for example consider federal welfare policy even though there are load of idea about how to address poverty in the united state politician support and debate only a select few such a the minimum wage earned income tax credit medicaid etc these are within the overton window other idea such a a guaranteed basic income even though they may be debated in other country and supported by economist on both the left and the right are never seriously considered by politician because they lie outside the window trump s public policy explained with this in mind now consider trump s recent about face after he said the victim of the recent orlando shooting should have been permitted to carry gun into the pulse nightclub about a week after making the statement trump appeared to backtrack and said he meant nightclub employee and guard should have been armed not patron this wasn t just a flip flop or mere pandering it s more likely that trump s movement on the issue is evidence he realized his initial stance wa a step outside the overton window while many of his supporter are no doubt staunch believer in the second amendment even the nra which endorsed him said no one think that people should go into a nightclub drinking and carrying firearm using the overton window theory to your advantage it is important to remember that politician rarely move the window more often than not they only support policy that are deemed acceptable by their constituent when trump said orlando nightclub patron should have been armed the backlash showed him that position wa outside the window so he stepped his stance back to one more acceptable to voter the lesson in all this is that politician a friedrich hayek once wrote are like cork bobbing in the sea they only go where the current lead them and it is u you me and our neighbor who determine the direction of the current in other word if you want to see policy change if you want to expand the overton window appeal to the heart and mind of your fellow citizen and the politician will soon follow
question: how one theory you never heard of explains everything donald trump doe what is the theory that explains everything donald trump doe

compliance tax law for marijuana business and pretty much anything related to the operation of cannabis business regulated by the state of colorado i ve always been an advocate for the legalization of ha never been done before so there s a lot of opportunity to blaze the trail so to speak no pun intended she explains not to mention working to help victim of america s war on drug we ve had 40 year of a failed drug war our father our brother our child are incarcerated at alarming rate unfortunately for minority population and disproportional rate for minority population and a woman we shouldn t lyman s biggest passion is making marijuana and marijuana advocacy community more inclusive especially by creating space for those were were a vital part of the weed industry before it wa sanctioned title: is there really a 2 billion year old nuclear reactor in africa
context: an ancient nuclear reactor that wa churning away 2 billion year ago sound like a myth maybe it s because the term reactor usually implies a manmade structure but in this case the reactor is a region of natural uranium within the earth s crust found in okla gabon uranium is naturally radioactive and the condition in this rocky area happened to be just right to cook up some nuclear reaction the natural reactor must have annoyed nuclear scientist the first nuclear reactor to produce electricity started up in 1951 and this only produced a trivial amount of energy the pile of rock in the ground in okla on the other hand created nuclear power around 2 billion year ago it wa discovered in 1972 when some french scientist took uranium ore from the mine in gabon to test it uranium content typically uranium ore is made up of three type isotope of uranium each one with a different number of neutron uranium 238 which is the most abundant uranium 234 which is the rarest and uranium 235 which nuclear scientist are most interested in because it can sustain nuclear chain reaction one would expect to find that the uranium ore is composed of 0 720 uranium 235 since that is the percentage found in other rock sample from the earth s crust the moon and even meteorite however these french scientist found something fishy the uranium sample only contained 0 717 of uranium 235 what might seem to be a minor discrepancy of 0 003 is very significant with regard to uranium that meant that back at the mine around 200 kilogram around 440 pound of uranium 235 appeared to be missing it hadn t been lost or stolen instead this missing 0 003 had undergone nuclear fission and split into other atom this conclusion may very well have furrowed some brow since there are three very specific condition that a reactor need to churn out energy continuously and a even scientist had struggled to create a nuclear reactor it seemed unlikely that nature just happened to create one purely by accident unlikely but not impossible because that is exactly what happened the condition that the natural reactor happened to fulfill are a follows the first wa owning a good percentage of uranium 235 to fuel the reaction while 0 720 might seem small it s perfect for nuclear fission and when the ore sample from okla are compared to other sample from all over the world it is likely that this wa the percentage over 2 billion year ago when the reactor started the second condition is a source of neutron uranium 235 decay naturally into thorium and release a neutron in the process this neutron can then whoosh towards another uranium 235 atom and start the fission process nuclear fission is when an atom break apart into smaller atom usually releasing energy in the process this neutron fuse with a uranium 235 and together they combine to form uranium 236 which is unstable the uranium 236 is then overwhelmed with instability and split creating a variety of smaller stable atom and some neutron these neutron can then happily shoot towards other atom and continue the chain reaction the nuclear reactor had a supply of a regulating substance a well a flow of natural groundwater a the atom started to split they released neutron a well a energy the water would slow down the neutron but the energy would heat up the water after a time the water would get so hot that it would start to boil off eventually enough of the water would have boiled away until there wasn t enough left in the reactor to slow down the neutron the neutron started shooting off into the ground without reacting with anything and the reaction would stop then the natural flow of groundwater would trickle in until there wa enough water to start the whole process again this watery cycle probably continued for hundred of thousand of year sadly all good day are numbered even for a happy natural reactor the level of uranium 235 got used up and the level wa too low to sustain any more meaningful reaction the reactor eventually slowed to a stop leaving only a few trace behind that it ever existed including the enigma of the missing uranium featured image danilo russo flickr source naturally occurring nuclear fission

facebook account with other social integration planned and launch micro conversation based on their daily activity ultimately that process will build the ai s understanding of it subject and be able to function like a smarter more personalized version of the chatbots you can already interact with today we chose this approach because we would like to help people solve the blank page syndrome we have often seen when somebody try to write in their diary explains eterni me founder marius ursache we want to encourage people to start curating their digital legacy and we will do that by triggering conversation based on previously collected data of what they did felt or experienced though eterni me s new app will be collecting all this information the neural network backbone won t be able to turn that mass of unruly data into engaging conversation yet the artificial intelligence that we need requires a lot of effort and time it may take year ursache say a lot of the people who expressed interest in eterni me don t have this time this force u to use more or le the the approach of the cryonics initiative preservation first technology second meanwhile a semblance of the company s vision ha already come to life earlier this year entrepreneur eugenia kudya created an ai powered chatbot in honor of her friend roman mazurenko who died tragically in 2015 kudya and other mourner could speak with roman by talking to the bot or asking it question it response would be based on the thousand of text message and photo she had fed the neural network controlling it artificial intelligence while the roman bot couldn t narrate story in the same way that eterni me envisions it wrote in his voice talking to the bot helped kudya grieve and made her feel more connected to her friend inspired by the personal conversation that other people had with roman s bot she s now working on replika a new product that like eterni me will collect a person s story and memory and learn to mimic their conversational mannerism by texting with them the bot would first ask you about the past and eventually prod you about your daily life your friend could talk to your replika too asking it personal question or using it to schedule plan with the real you it s all about making people a little bit more open about themselves a little more vulnerable kudya say now even the first replikas we have on the app can tell you a lot about the person that trained it the goal of the platform she explains isn t to let everyone create their own roman that will live on after they die but to give everyone a kind of friend that is there every day to talk to to make you more connected with your friend and yourself but intention or not a person s replika bot would be able to keep responding like you and telling your story after you died in the same way that eterni me s avatar could over 100 000 people have reserved their replika name and 17 000 applied for early testing of the app but only 1 200 were given access to the beta version kudya wa vague about when she think the technology will actually be good enough for the general public the natural progression of eterni me or replika s idea would be to combine the ai with realistic digital 3d avatar something eterni me eventually plan to do to but ha back burnered while it work on the first part of it mission facebook is researching how to create life like virtual reality avatar a are a host of different startup including one called xxarray that explicitly envisions helping people create a digital legacy long time vr researcher jacki morie coined the phrase the ultimate selfie to describe how she predicts that current technology could eventually combine to create digital avatar that would not only would look like u but move like u and learn from u too she imago that in the not so distant future when using an avatar in vr is fairly common practice people will be able to train a digital surrogate that could live on after they re gone you ll be scanned and have this 3d construct that can then walk around in virtual world and it will retain the thing that you did within an ai she say this kind of avatar could become a repository for our experience and our memory while the idea of talking to a dead relative through a digitized ghost may seem creepy edging into bizarre uncanny valley territory expert say that on principle it s actually a completely natural progression of the way that people have always grieved heather servaty seib a grief researcher and purdue professor say that it s in line with the continuing bond theory of bereavement death change the form of your relationship with someone not the fact that you have one many already talk to the dead through a smartphone screen instead of at a graveyard or through a phone booth like in otsuchi japan where tsunami survivor call their lost loved one facebook allows people to memorialize the page of the deceased and those page often become a public and wide reaching digital wake where friend and family share photo memory or their message to the dead aftertalk prompt the bereaved to write letter to their loved one that can either be private or shared with a therapist or family member deadsocial allows user to set up a curated facebook page of sort where their love one can commune once they ve passed they can even choose to schedule personal message that will send from beyond the grave if people have always found way now to talk to the dead could it be problematic if they start talking back both servaty seib and grief therapist dr bob neymeyer agree that new way to communicate with the dead could be healthy for many patient still there are some potential pratfall related to how we mourn it could be damaging to child who generally don t fully grasp the concept of death servaty seib say or it could be addictive to people already prone to focusing too much on the dead deemphasizing other relationship and not moving forward say neymeyer he s had patient who have listened to the dead s voicemail over and over or spent day on end at their grave now imagine if someone had an extensive almost inexhaustible archive of conversation available with the deceased he say beyond the psychological implication palliative care doctor mark taubert say that he doesn t think that it will be technically feasible for the tech to answer the kind of burning question people will have for their digitized loved one i often find that the question a grieving friend or relative may have for the deceased are often quite difficult to answer for example did you ever forgive me for what i did in he say how could an artificially intelligent system taught simply to mimic your style and echo your memory tackle that difficult question in any real way digital legacy tool like eterni me or deathlogic don t just serve the people left behind they are very very much about the person who is dying or thinking about their own eventual death these service offer a way for u to build monument to ourselves they let u combine our curated memory and experience with all our messy data the text and tweet and like and photo and organize it into something that we hope will let our loved one and future generation actually understand something about who we were until we can really can upload our brain to the cloud that s our best shot at immortality

title: the one thing not to say to someone with ocd
context: i get it knowing how to respond to someone s disorder or disease can be tough i m one of those people who get uncomfortable extremely easily so i have sympathy for people that look similarly awkward when it come up that i have obsessive compulsive disorder i also get the desire to not only sympathize but to empathize by finding some way to relate to this very important and often dominating part of my life which is the only reason i can assume that i hear this or some version of this response so often omg same i keep my closet perfectly color coded now it s not always color coding closet it could be anything from polishing silverware to double checking lock to eating the same thing every day for breakfast and yes ocd symptom present both in a variety of way a well a varying degree but unless you are educated on the disorder have seen a therapist or have some sort of confirmation other than your own unfortunate desire to connect with me about this i m going to be honest and let you know i really really don t want to hear your superficial self diagnosis here s why it s insensitive to diminish ocd to the one slightly obsessive or compulsive behavior you have it show a serious lack of understanding of what ocd is and doe and is a subtle yet powerful way of saying oh we all have that it s not that big of a deal because even if color coding your closet is an annoying habit and i ll give it to you maybe even an obsession or compulsion your comment comparing this to actual medically diagnosed ocd come off a an underhanded way of telling me that it s not only something that everyone ha but something that doesn t warrant psychiatric or therapeutic attention for my disorder it s a response that i would equate to saying that you understand someone s pain over the death of an parent because you once had a pet that died thanks for the effort but no thanks for comparing my dead mother to your dead goldfish now i know this isn t your intention and i try to keep this in mind a i grind my teeth and try to explain somehow that no that really is not the same thing and don t get me wrong i m happy to explain it to you but i would much rather do so in response to a question or genuine interest not a backhanded attempt at empathy my ocd ha affected me for a long a i can remember and although it s now managed well enough where it s not necessarily something people notice on their own a proud accomplishment if i do say so myself there have been time it ha been debilitating severe anxiety bleeding knuckle from obsessive washing rapid weight drop from stress related appetite loss intricate and obscenely repetitive bedtime routine i m happy to explain this to you to answer any and all question anyone who know me know i m not exactly a shy or private person but please take this route instead of attempting to relate in a way that unless you actually have diagnosed ocd you would never be able to i know you don t mean to come off a both uneducated and insensitive so please don t respond a if you are

title: the top 5 free and open source inventory management software system
context: managing your inventory effectively can be the difference between making the sale and losing it to a competitor if you don t know what you have or where it is you re going to have a tough time selling it luckily you don t have to go broke just keeping an eye on your product here are five free or open source inventory management offering for small business inflow is an inventory management software focused on small and medium business the company ha been growing since 2007 and now claim over 750 000 user inflow ha a free option that limit you to 100 product and customer and a baker s dozen report you also miss out on some advanced user feature and inventory management option the free version ha no expiration though and small business will be well served by the small set of option default feature include barcoding different accounting method and automatic data backup among others once you outgrow the free version inflow can be upgraded for a one off 399 payment that will unlock unlimited product and customer more report and advanced feature like customized invoice and order form paying customer also get a year of support carta is the online offering from the people who brought you inflow carta also offer a slimmed down free version carta s limitation are based on the number of sale per month that can be processed at the free level it s a mere 10 luckily every level is currently free since carta is still in it beta testing phase you might have a few hiccup along the way but you can get the 99 per month package for free right now the company anticipates the free beta running through the end of 2015 so you ll have plenty of time to figure out which package work for you carta includes some interesting option for collaboration with buyer and seller so you can assist folk through the ordering process with the background from inflow carta should offer you everything a small business need rightcontrol lite provides inventory management for ten product line it also come with invoice and receipt generation tool geared toward the small business or self employed individual apart from a limitation on product line the lite flavor offer all the feature of it bigger sister and brother in the rightcontrol line user can set automatic reorder reminder when stock get low can print label for stock and can integrate with a barcode system if you need more than the ten product or want more user growing business can upgrade to rightcontol solo pro or workgroup for about 1 50 7 50 or 30 per month the company s rate are given in british pound each come with an increase in the number of product that can be managed we ve talked about odoo here before but it s because there s a lot to like for two people using the online system odoo is free if you download the open source version and host it yourself odoo can be free for everyone though you ll have to support it yourself odoo is designed a an erp but thanks to the software s add on app layout you can make it a large or small a your business requires for inventory management you ll probably want to take advantage of at least the warehouse management system and perhaps the purchase or point of sale system a well since it s an erp all of your data will be combined in the backend so purchase can flow into inventory and into your accounting a well odoo online can be a great open source answer for a small business while larger business can get a lot out of the full featured software abc inventory is the child of almyta control system it s a free package for a single user allowing you to manage multiple warehouse serial number warranty and a host of other inventory related data this free version is really designed to be run on one computer though a multiple workstation can t sync the same data a with almost all free option you ll be supplying the support though there are some forum to give you a hand if thing get tough abc is geared specifically toward smaller company that don t need all the bell and whistle that come with a bigger system final thought all of these system can manage most small business inventory requirement with many offering flexibility to move up a your company grows odoo may have the strongest position for an existing large company but the low price for it competitor mean that there are plenty of option within most budget what other free inventory software solution are out there let u know in the comment

title: why car went from boxy in the 80 to curvy in the 90
context: look at a photo of a street scene from the 70 or early 80 and a lot of thing look pretty much the same a today most of the building are similar people s clothes on the whole aren t all that different give or take a few shoulder pad one thing stand out all of the car look super boxy especially compared with the curving rounded exterior of virtually every car on the market today this underappreciated transformation is probably the most distinct design change to come to car over the past half century and for most u car it happened within just a few year starting in 1986 you can even pinpoint the exact year curve arrived for some model like the buick lesabre which had much harder edge along it hood roof and trunk in 1991 left than 1992 right in the decade since car have just gotten curvier and curvier why the big shift it turn out it wa largely due to three interrelated factor european style trend a government mandated push for fuel economy and new technology that allowed manufacturer to more easily design and create curved shape it all started with european luxury design by the 1980s making curved car wasn t an entirely novel idea it had just largely gone out of fashion among u automaker the streamliner of the 1930s such a the chrysler airflow had a sleek look designed to minimize wind resistance but the airflow and other streamlined american model were commercial failure outsold by bigger boxier car through the 1970s almost every american made car had hard sharp edge with few curve they were uniformly designed a a series of three connected box the hood the cabin and the trunk in europe though fuel wa always more expensive and designer especially in germany explored aerodynamic design much earlier on say penny sparke author of a century of car design in the 1960s and 70 luxury automaker like porsche bmw audi and mercedes benz were some of the first to reintroduce curved exterior one of the earliest most well known example is the porsche 911 which wa pretty curvy way back when it wa introduced in 1963 this aesthetic eventually became associated with these luxury car both in europe and in the u where they arrived a import and inevitably writes historian david gartman in auto opium a social history of american automobile design american automaker began to copy the european aerodynamic aesthetic in the mid 1980s a a way of courting upscale consumer ford more than any other company wa responsible for bringing this design change to the mass market designer uwe bahnsen did it first in europe with the 1982 ford sierra which wa far more curved than similar car of it era reviewer panned the look nicknaming it the jelly mould and the car did not sell well at first over time though buyer got used it especially a other manufacturer eventually copied the style for their own car in the u ford designer jack telnack who d worked on the company s european design team before taking over north american design in 1980 wa most directly responsible for the shift to curve his 1983 ford thunderbird design wa heavily shaped by wind tunnel testing prioritizing aerodynamic line the look soon filtered down to the mass market with the 1986 taurus it might look unremarkable today but the design wa positively futuristic at the time the car wa even used in the movie robocop which wa supposed to take place in the near future the taurus writes gartman wa definitely aiming at the upscale market of young well educated buyer to whom the bmw appealed the strategy worked the taurus wa a huge hit with massive sale that saved the struggling company and inspired a wave of copycat american car automaker had to improve fuel economy part of the reason the curvy look proliferated so quickly and is still with u today is basic physic curved exterior and more steeply pitched windshield make for le wind resistance a air can flow more easily over them this mean le gas ha to be burned to move the car the same distance at the same speed right a the taurus premiered automaker were dealing with corporate average fuel economy standard for the first time starting in 1978 the average fuel economy of each manufacturer s passenger car fleet sold in the u had to reach higher and higher level before plateauing in 1990 at 27 5 mile per gallon while automaker had already achieved some gain in efficiency with improved engine and other component the new curved aesthetic made it much easier and cheaper to achieve further improvement one ford designer claimed that while it would cost 200 to 300 million to achieve a one tenth mile per gallon increase by engineering under the hood aero design achieved a three to four tenth m p g increase for almost nothing gartman writes automaker began relying more heavily on wind tunnel and aerodynamic calculation when designing their car and engineer started working more closely with designer within just a few year virtually every car on the market suddenly looked like the once futuristic taurus they all looked the same because they were all being shaped in the wind tunnel and were designed for fuel economy say larry edsall the author of several book on car design history technology made it easier to produce curve a few key technological development made these design possible and have since allowed automaker to make their car curvier and curvier for decade designer had made car model using clay wood or other physical material during the 1980s they began using computer model it s much easier to make these sort of shape with computer drawing rather than wood sparke say they gave automaker the mean to produce those very soft curve manufacturing technology also made it easier and cheaper to produce curved shape in aluminum than before a a result since that initial shift in the 1990s exterior have only become curvier you can get a good sense of how profound the change ha been by looking at a newer car thought to be remarkably boxy the scion xb sure it ha a big blocky hatchback but it edge are still way more rounded than the truly boxy car of the 80 and even the groundbreaking futuristic 1986 ford taurus verge video this is the driverless future mercedes benz think we ll have in the year 2030

this unconscious bias people want to hire and promote people who are similar to them you have to do something to fight that bias a a linkedin editor i regularly work with thought leader in tech who share their insight on our publishing platform rather than encourage female writer to mask their identity and experience i suggest they own it in order to combat the misguided notion that the tech industry is only comprised of male leader woman must share their expertise on social network so that audience hear a diverse set of perspective to get more woman interested in pursuing career in technology current female leader must continue to strive to be seen rather than hide like greathouse suggests

title: scientist say this behavior can make men more attractive to woman
context: score of psychological study suggest that for guy attractiveness isn t just about the way you look from being a talented musician to walking a dog there are plenty of trait and behavior that can amp up your sex appeal to woman especially if you re looking to land a long term relationship a growing body of research on romantic attraction ha focused on the importance of altruism men who display helping behavior are generally perceived a more attractive than those who don t in a 2013 study on the topic researcher had young heterosexual men and woman rate picture of other men and woman on how attractive they would be for short and long term relationship some of the people pictured were said to engage in altruistic behavior such a volunteering at a homeless shelter other people pictured were described in neutral way such a love chinese food both men and woman rated the altruistic people a more attractive for long term relationship but woman showed a stronger preference for altruism than men did more recent research suggests that altruism could be even more appealing than good look in a study published this year researcher looked exclusively at heterosexual woman s preference for attractiveness and altruism in men about 200 woman were asked to look at photograph of men s face half those face had been determined to be extremely physically attractive the other half had been determined to be extremely physically unattractive the woman saw two pair of face at a time one attractive and one unattractive each pair of face wa displayed alongside a description of a scenario and how each man behaved for example two people are walking through a busy town and see a homeless person sitting near a cafe one man go into the cafe and buy a sandwich and tea for the homeless person the other man pretend to use his cellphone and walk straight past the homeless person all the woman were asked to rate each man on how attractive he wa for a short or long term relationship the researcher walked away with several key finding first a previous research had found altruistic men were more attractive than nonaltruistic men second altruistic men were more attractive for long term than short term relationship when it came to short term relationship nonaltruistic men were in fact more desirable than altruistic men perhaps the most striking finding wa that altruism appeared to be even more appealing than physical attractiveness when it came to long term relationship unattractive men high in altruism were rated more attractive for long term relationship than attractive men low in altruism it s hard to say whether these study finding apply to real life interaction but they do suggest that if you re a man looking for a committed relationship with a woman you shouldn t hesitate to flaunt the fact that you re an unpaid mentor for elementary school kid or that you help your elderly neighbor buy grocery every week it could be an easy way to gain an edge over the more self oriented guy out there

title: is it ethical to kill poacher
context: protecting the world s endangered specie from poacher is dangerous business over the past decade more than 1 000 ranger have died in the line of duty according to statistic released last week for world ranger day some death were caused by accident or animal most however were murder committed by heavily armed poacher who enter national park and other protected area in search of specie such a tiger rhino and elephant at the same time ranger have killed hundred of poacher often spurred by the shoot on sight policy that have become the norm in several park the number add up between 2011 and 2015 ranger at south africa s kruger national park alone reportedly killed nearly 500 poacher while these ranger are undoubtedly hero who all too often lay down their life to protect the animal in their care some organization have begun to raise question about the retaliatory bloodshed asking if it is ethical or moral for ranger to kill suspected poacher without arrest or trial the issue came to bear most recently last month after a guard in india s kaziranga national park which ha a shoot to kill policy critically wounded a seven year old boy from a tribe that life around the park we re pretty horrified by the situation said sophie grig senior campaigner at survival international a tribal right organization that ha criticized the recent kaziranga shooting and shoot to kill policy in general it seems to u a very worrying trend that is bad for both local people who get caught in the crossfire and for conservation grig also wonder if shooting poacher even solves the larger problem if you were arresting those people and then investigating them you could trace back and work out who the kingpin are she said if you shoot them dead you can t ask them any question annette hu bschle who recently authored a report on rhino poaching for the global initiative against transnational organized crime echoed those sentiment she said the current militarized approach is pushing people away from any chance they might have to participate in conservation there should be a greater focus on investigating the transporter and buyer prosecuting organized criminal such a kingpin and smuggler follow the money approach and seizing asset of criminal she said aside from legal strategy the issue of whether or not poacher should be killed brings up several potential line of ethical thought said anna peterson a professor in the department of religion at the university of florida and the author of being animal beast and boundary in nature ethic one way of thinking about it she said is to ask if individual sentient being have value and if there is a difference in that value between a human life and that of a rhinoceros she pointed to ethicist tom regan s test which asked if you would throw a dog out of a lifeboat to save yourself essentially regan said you would always throw out the dog on the basis of complexity and what would be lost by a human s death rather than a dog s death she said more broadly peterson said you could ask if a specie is rare and significant and if it ecosystem would suffer in it absence this ecological perspective could come into play when discussing specie such a rhino tiger and elephant we have that debate here about florida panther which are both rare and important predator she said finally peterson looked at the question from the field of ethic known a war theory the just war theory she said lay out a series of criterion such a do you have a just cause and have you tried to fix this peacefully if we consider preserving ecosystem to be a just cause then killing could be justified similarly so could looking at poaching a an economic issue a it threatens tourism or a a national security issue an important consideration involving organized crime smuggling national border and related crime such a drug and weapon no one ha easy answer ranger are doing difficult job in difficult circumstance grig said she added though that the often public enthusiasm for killing poacher seems contrary to the call to protect human right in just about any other crime i think this is something we need to be discussing she said
question: is it ethical to kill poacher what is the ethical standpoint on killing poacher

text: preserving ecosystem to be a just cause then killing could be justified

title: how artificial intelligence could stop those awkward moment when your credit card is mistakenly declined
context: it s an experience many shopper have had you re queued in line at the store prepared to make a purchase only to have your credit card declined for no apparent reason a perfectly legitimate charge ha been flagged a fraudulent and the result is an agitated customer and a retailer with unsold merchandise mastercard ha now turned to artificial intelligence to better differentiate between real and mistaken fraud hoping to tamp down on the former while allowing the latter to go through it s the latest financial service company to see the potential for the burgeoning field of machine learning to improve security on it network and enhance the customer experience financial institution have for year collected data on customer habit and routine and used the information to pinpoint card that may have been compromised that s the reason your card may be declined if you make an unusually large purchase shop at a store for the first time or buy gas in a place far from home the system is essentially deciding whether that behavior seems normal according to predetermined question then accepting or declining the purchase based on it decision the old method wa using test and threshold and other sort of rule with a rule based approach you get a tremendous amount of false positive said todd marlin a principal in ernst young s forensic technology and discovery service practice what we re seeing is sort of a gold rush into artificial intelligence marlin said machine learning can help fraud detection system become smarter about what fraud actually look like both across the network and on an individual level for example the system might detect that you haven t shopped at a particular merchant in the past but still accept the purchase because customer with a similar spending history shop there often or perhaps you travel to a certain state or country often enough that the system learns purchase there are likely to be legitimate citing a survey from javelin advisory service mastercard estimate that 118 billion in sale were declined due to falsely identified fraud in the united state in 2014 well more than the 9 billion lost to actual instance of fraud that s a large sum of money that retailer and credit card purveyor like mastercard could be pocketing mastercard s new decision intelligence software pull in data sometimes hundred of piece of data about a specific transaction at the moment a customer swipe his or her credit card the system then combine all of that information to yield a score indicating how likely the transaction is to be fraudulent each score build on the one before it and informs the one after it such that the computer s algorithm get better at detecting fraud without a programmer having to engineer every change the company called it the first use of ai being implemented on a global scale directly on the mastercard network for this to work we need all kind of data coming in said ajay bhalla the president of enterprise risk and security at mastercard we ve been working on a strategy of getting more data point into the network we see this a a critical component of our future strategy bhalla added we are embedding ai in everything we re looking at a a company for the last decade visa ha deployed it visa advanced authorization system to detect fraud the volume of data and the speed at which it s processed have increased considerably over that time said mark nelsen the company s senior vice president of risk product and business intelligence visa par through those large set of data to discern what characteristic distinguish legitimate and fraudulent spending and then us those characteristic to ass the veracity of future purchase we can look at that transaction and knowing what we ve seen in the past we can predict if this is going to be good or bad nelsen said digital payment platform are also embracing machine learning though fraud remains more difficult to detect in online or mobile commerce paypal ha developed it own artificial intelligence software to combat fraud allowing the company to move from a system that can analyze ten of data point to one that can analyze thousand there s a magnitude of difference you ll be able to analyze a lot more information and identify pattern that are a lot more sophisticated paypal s senior director of global risk and data science hui wang told american banker but visa mastercard and paypal have the financial heft and risk appetite to explore artificial intelligence in way that smaller and more regional player in the financial service industry do not said celent analyst arin ray while most in the industry think ai hold promise there remain question about how it will impact regulatory compliance and that make some hesitant to embrace the technology according to a report ray co authored in august the concept of ai ha been there for 50 year but it really ha had a rebirth of sort in the last three or four year the volume of data ha grown exponentially in recent time so there is definitely the need for tool to analyze it ray said in an interview one concern is how this technology will impact their existing operation since it s still unproven technology they don t want to take that risk if they have to make major change to their existing infrastructure he said
question: how ai could stop those awkward moment when your credit card is mistakenly declined what are some example of situation where a credit card is mistakenly declined

title: why woman are no longer catching up to men on pay
context: if you were an american man working full time in 1984 you earned on average a bit more than 22 an hour adjusted for inflation to 2014 dollar if you were particularly ambitious or particularly in need of cash you could make more money by working more hour but on a per hour basis you d still be making about the same a bit more than 22 per hour fast forward to 2015 though and the picture look a lot different the average man working a typical full time job 35 to 49 hour a week now earns about 26 an hour but the man working 50 hour a week or more now earns close to 33 an hour hourly pay ha risen more than twice a fast over the past three decade for men working long hour a employer increasingly reward employee willing to work extra hour with raise or promotion the pattern cross educational and industry line and hold when excluding overtime pay notice that i said men men make up a bit more than half the full time workforce but they account for more than 70 percent of those working 50 hour a week or more so a wage gain have gone disproportionately to people working long hour they have also gone disproportionately to men widening the earnings divide between men and woman overall the gender wage gap ha narrowed significantly over the past 50 year in 1964 according to data from the census bureau the typical woman working full time made about 59 cent on the dollar earned by a man by 2004 that had risen to 77 cent these calculation don t take into account difference in experience industry or other factor more recently however progress for woman ha nearly stalled out in 2014 the latest data available woman earned 79 cent for every dollar earned by men a 2 penny an hour improvement over a decade other measure of woman s progress in the workforce their rate of employment the likelihood that they will work in a historically male dominated field the rate at which they run big company show a similar pattern of what researcher martha j bailey and thomas a diprete in a new essay call five decade of remarkable but slowing change for american woman bailey and diprete s essay serf a the introduction to a remarkable new collection of paper from the russell sage foundation that examines the progress that woman have and haven t made over the past half century it isn t a simple story the u s ha already made major albeit incomplete progress on many of the most obvious cause of gender inequality explicit discrimination on pay overt barrier to employment taboo against working while raising child what is left is a tangle of cultural norm implicit bias individual preference and other subtler form of discrimination that are much harder to change or even to measure take the long hour anecdote i described above the rapid rise in pay for people working long hour ha played a major role in the persistence of the overall gender wage gap particularly for parent new research in the russell sage foundation volume estimate that the wage gap between mother and father would be 15 percent smaller if the extra hour increase hadn t occurred but that premium itself isn t the result of discrimination explicit or implicit woman who work long hour have seen even faster gain than men although they still earn le on average rather the trend contributes to the wage gap because men are so much more likely than woman to work those long hour that in turn is the result of a confluence of factor that are deeply embedded in the american economy and society woman on average spend much more time than men on housework while men especially a certain category of highly educated elite men are expected to work a much a possible and of course most importantly mother are still far more likely than father to be the primary caregiver for their child government policy could make a difference affordable child care for example could make it easier for woman who want to work long hour to do so but they can only go so far the russell sage foundation paper are full of such thorny issue a rising share of the gender wage gap is driven by pre market factor such a choice of industry and occupation those issue can also be the result of explicit or implicit discrimination but are much harder to address than wage differential within a given job and even force that should help close the gap such a education have proved insufficient woman have for decade been more likely to attend college than men there are now for the first time more female than male college graduate yet the pay gap is widest among the most educated worker girl now outperform boy in many science and math subject in high school but woman are still much le likely than men to work in many of the most lucrative technical field woman have actually lost ground to men in computer science in recent decade and the overall rate of occupational desegregation woman entering traditionally male dominated field and vice versa ha slowed there are some encouraging sign for woman those who do go into science and technology field earn nearly a much a equally experienced men though that isn t true in computer science suggesting the overall wage gap would narrow if more woman entered so called stem field moreover the motherhood penalty the relative decline in wage for woman when they have child ha disappeared or even reversed for highly paid highly educated woman perhaps because they are the most likely to have access to and be able to afford child care that suggests that making child care more widely available could help narrow the gender pay gap for le educated woman too something that is looking more likely now that both major presidential candidate are advocating affordable child care plan culture is changing too men are taking on a larger share of child rearing responsibility though the division is still far from equal still the overall picture painted by the russell sage foundation research is one of slow grinding and unsteady progress and of barrier that are hard to define and even harder to resolve hillary clinton may be poised to crack the ultimate glass ceiling but true gender equality remains a long way off the olympic tax speaking of high earning and high flying woman the internet wa abuzz this week with story about the hefty tax bill that gymnast simone bile and other olympic medalist will face when they get back from rio the bbc estimated bile will owe more than 40 000 a bipartisan bill to exempt olympic winning from tax is gaining momentum in congress but the whole issue is getting blown out of proportion the u s olympics committee award bonus to american medal winner 25 000 for gold medal and smaller amount for silver and bronze bile with her five medal will receive 110 000 which in theory could put her on the hook for more than 40 000 in tax the medal themselves are also taxable but their actual value is modest but it s unlikely she ll actually owe that much because bile and other olympian can deduct the cost of their training on their tax and in the case of high profile olympian such a bile and swimmer michael phelps their actual winning are dwarfed by far more lucrative and very much taxable endorsement deal by the time bile cash all those check from procter gamble her olympic tax bill will probably look like a rounding error the fed newly released minute from the federal reserve s july meeting this week suggest that board chair janet yellen and her colleague are still weighing whether to raise interest rate in september or wait until the economy improves further separate comment from key fed official this week indicated that new data since the fed s meeting hasn t resolved the question the fed is in a tricky spot the job market continues to show strength may s weak employment report look more and more like a blip but overall economic growth ha been disappointing and there have been recent sign that consumer spending a key pillar of strength in recent month is beginning to weaken then there is the election which complicates the fed s task in two way policymakers don t want to intervene too close to the election lest they appear to be trying to influence the outcome and they also have to grapple with the possibility that the election itself and the uncertainty around it will affect the economy most economist still think the fed will wait until after the election is over to raise rate number of the week back in july i wrote about the long term decline in teen summer employment particularly among lower income youth a report from the bureau of labor statistic this week indicates the recovery is gradually reversing that decline 53 2 percent of american age 16 to 24 had job in july up from 52 7 percent last year and 50 7 percent in 2013 the report didn t break out teen specifically but a look at the underlying data show that the employment rate for teen rose too moreover the employment gap between low income and more affluent teen narrowed somewhat the latest sign that the improving economy is gradually benefiting the most vulnerable worker
question: why woman are no longer catching up to men on pay what is the main reason behind the gap in pay between men and woman

text: men are so much more likely than woman to work those long hour

title: trump s order on abortion policy what doe it mean
context: a group of men standing around a desk it is not the typical image that go viral online the photograph in question wa taken on u president donald trump s first day in the oval office on monday when he signed a ban on federal money going to international group that perform or provide information on abortion men making decision about woman s body wa a much repeated phrase on twitter a it wa shared hundred of thousand of time including by author jk rowling the concern over lack of woman at the table come a mr trump s cabinet attracts attention for the high proportion of white male nomination and while some people welcomed the move on abortion others on social medium expressed alarm and confusion over what it impact could be viral image and headline do not always tell the whole story so here is an at a glance look at what president trump s executive order mean is this a step towards banning abortion in the u not in itself this particular executive order is relevant outside of u border the policy requires non governmental organisation receiving federal funding to agree to neither perform nor actively promote abortion a a method of family planning in other nation this particularly worry woman s right campaigner in developing country where fund or facility are already limited although this policy doe not directly affect service in the u mr trump ha said he support an abortion ban at home his signing of this order a one of his first executive action indicates he still see the issue a a priority is president trump the first to introduce a ban on foreign funding artificial intelligence system wa designed to answer question so it seemed like a strong fit to train the system to answer question correctly goel fed it forum post from the class s previous semester this gave jill an extensive background in common question and how they should be answered goel tested the system privately for month having his teaching assistant examine whether jill s answer were correct initially the system struggled with similar question such a where can i find assignment two and when is assignment two due goel tweaked the software adding more layer of decision making to it eventually jill reached the point where it answer were good enough i cannot create chaos in my classroom jill had to be almost perfect a a human ta or i am goel said the system is only allowed to answer question if it calculates that it is 97 percent or more confident in it answer goel found that wa the threshold at which he could guarantee the system wa accurate there are many question jill can t handle those question were reserved for human teaching assistant goel plan to use jill again in a class this fall but will likely change it name so student have the challenge of guessing which teaching assistant isn t human

title: is there a better way to observe veteran day
context: all this isn t to suggest that american never mark veteran day and memorial day in community across the country member of the military member of government and military family gather on both holiday to raise and lower flag decorate graf and participate in procession and parade on memorial day some people observe the national one minute moment of remembrance at 3 p m which wa passed into law by congress in 2000 observation of the moment is left up to participating organization such a amtrak and major league baseball and a in the u k and canada the veteran of foreign war vfw distributes poppy on veteran day and memorial day so that people can publicly commemorate the fallen the number don t lie though according to the vfw only 9 million poppy will be distributed in the u s population 316 million this year by comparison 45 million poppy will be distributed in the u k population 64 million for armistice day according to the royal british legion why doesn t the united state have a common culture of commemoration one potential explanation lie in the fact that the u s hasn t recently experienced the kind of generational destruction that say the first and second world war brought to britain and russia respectively britain lost approximately 2 percent of it population in the great war resulting in a lost generation jay winter of yale university told me that those men left behind a void an absence a black hole in the center of thousand of family defined in part by who wasn t there the soviet union suffered an even more dramatic loss in the second world war amounting to roughly 15 percent of it population by comparison u s loss in the second world war constituted about 0 3 percent of the population and 0 1 percent in the first world war the only american war that incurred such steep loss wa the civil war in which 2 percent of the population perished it should come a no surprise then that the trauma of that conflict led to the establishment of decoration day the precursor of memorial day difference in how military holiday are observed can t be reduced to a number game though in the united state at least they may also stem from a strain of american thinking that highlight historical triumph and skip over what those triumph have cost lindsey tepe of the new america foundation for instance ha written about the way in which public education ha become a battleground between those who view american history a a sweeping tale filled with grand hero epic battle and the continuing struggle for the right to life liberty and the pursuit of happiness and those who recognize that american history is also full of inconvenient truth and the injustice perpetrated throughout the course of building this nation winter argues that what make u s commemoration different is the emphasis on redemption in american narrative of war in the u k on the other hand the absence of the lost generation mattered more when america s national mythology and political discourse preach a tale of endless victory and exceptionalism there is le of an incentive to focus on those men and woman who didn t come home from battle what make u s commemoration different is the emphasis on redemption in it narrative of war the finer detail make a difference a well joe davis director of public affair at the vfw belief the all volunteer force established in 1973 drove a wedge between the military community and an ever growing civilian population during the second world war the united state fielded a conscription based military of approximately 16 million people out of a population of 135 million today the professional military is well below it troop level during world war ii and the u s population ha more than doubled in the interim davis also cited a a factor the shifting of memorial day from it original fixed date of may 30 to the last monday of may when you link a military holiday to a three day weekend you lose the meaning of the day davis told me whatever the explanation the lack of an appropriate occasion to commemorate america s war casualty ha been noted from 1989 until his passing in 2012 senator daniel inouye of hawaii a world war ii veteran repeatedly introduced resolution to return memorial day to it traditional date and by proxy it original intent separately two bill have been introduced in congress in the last two year alone one to establish two minute of silence on veteran day the other to do the same on memorial day neither bill ha been passed although the one for veteran day ha since been revised a an amendment to the national defense authorization act the timing of these bill is opportune judging by recent poll the american public is war weary and largely of the view that the war in iraq and afghanistan were failure a debate is also underway about what america s global role should be with many american leaning toward isolationism despite a surge of support for a more muscular u s foreign policy following isi s beheading of american journalist in this environment it would be worthwhile to rigorously observe a moment in which american collectively acknowledge the good that their country ha done in the world and the real human cost that have accompanied that involvement
question: is there a better way to observe veteran s day what is a better way to observe veteran s day

text: senator daniel inouye of hawaii a world war ii veteran repeatedly introduced resolution to return memorial day to it traditional date and by proxy it original intent

title: how to bridge that stubborn pay gap
context: so what might work to close the gap social scientist and policy maker have some idea a do company that have been trying to combat the problem in their work force publish everyone s pay when employer publish people s salary the pay gap shrink jake rosenfeld a sociologist at washington university ha found that salary transparency raise wage in part by lending legitimacy to employee argument in wage bargaining even being cognizant of gender pay disparity being an issue can change norm he said that ha been true in the public sector where disclosing pay information is often required alexandre ma an economist at princeton studied the effect of a 2010 california law that required city to publish municipal salary it prompted pay cut but only among men woman might have been spurred to negotiate after seeing that their salary were lower he theorized or city might have made salary more equitable to avoid lawsuit a few european country have required that big company publish pay information by sex president obama in 2014 required that federal contractor report it to the labor department other american company say they have analyzed pay this way though most do it privately marc benioff the c e o of salesforce com said last year that after such an analysis the company spent 3 million to make woman s salary equal to men s kimberly clark and pricewaterhousecoopers have said their examination led manager to address the fact that fewer woman were reaching top position to negotiate or not men are paid more partly because they re much more likely to ask for it when receiving job offer 51 5 percent of men and 12 5 percent of woman asked for more money according to a study of carnegie mellon university graduate student by linda babcock an economist at the university in other research she found that when woman did ask they asked for 30 percent le than men requested because starting salary determine raise and future salary woman who do not bargain lose a much a 750 000 for middle income job and 2 million for high income job over their career m babcock found but her research and that of others ha found that woman are penalized for negotiating while men are rewarded for the same behavior a the actress jennifer lawrence wrote in lenny after the sony hacking revealed that she wa paid le than her male co star she didn t fight for more because i didn t want to seem difficult or spoiled one solution m babcock said is to coach woman to negotiate another is to change corporate practice so the people who set compensation are aware of the disparity and are advocate for woman during negotiation another answer is to ban pay negotiation completely that is what ellen pao did when she wa chief executive of reddit the company established pay range based on role and experience and gave applicant nonnegotiable offer we put the onus on the company to pay fairly instead of on candidate to negotiate fair pay m pao wrote in the hollywood reporter don t rely on previous salary if woman can lose million over their career because they get job offer based on pay that is already low one way to stop the pattern is to ignore their past salary google ha said it doe this and instead make offer based on what a job is worth in august the federal office of personnel management said government hiring manager could no longer rely on an employee s previous salary when setting his or her new one the acting director beth cobert explained that the practice particularly disadvantaged woman who had taken time off to raise child woman are also more likely to have worked in the lower paying public or nonprofit sector don t ask about salary history for new hire and it really reduces the impact of previous discrimination m babcock said i think that is the most effective thing organization can do make work easier for mother research ha found that salary at men and woman s first job out of school are fairly similar the gender pay gap widens a few year later when woman start having child sometimes their pay lag because they take break from work when their child are young work fewer hour or take more time off than men for child care crisis sometimes their employer assume they ll do so even if they don t policy that help keep woman in the work force like affordable child care paid sick day and parental leave could help in state that offer paid parental leave for instance mother are more likely to return to work work more hour and earn higher wage economist have found if a cashier get pregnant ha no parental leave ha to leave and reapply for her job that s not the same a making a career choice said philip cohen a sociologist at the university of maryland one thing policy can do is make it easier for woman to stick with their career build more flexible workplace m goldin of harvard ha found that the pay gap is largest in occupation with the least flexibility in term of where and when people work like finance and medicine the gap shrink when people can work on their own schedule a in many tech job and when people can easily substitute for one another a happens among pharmacist then woman aren t penalized a much for working fewer hour company might address the culture of face time and overwork and change how they operate in a pharmacy for instance electronic medical record have made it easier for different pharmacist to serve the same patient change the law federal law doesn t require most of these thing so some lawmaker are trying other tactic the strongest equal pay bill in the country went into effect in california this month it say that men and woman must be paid the same for similar job not just for exactly the same job at the same site a the looser federal equal pay act requires the california law also prohibits employer from retaliating against worker for discussing pay proposed federal legislation known a the paycheck fairness act would require company to report pay data to the government give grant for negotiation training and make class action lawsuit easier but that legislation is stalled in congress

title: when s the best time to share on facebook
context: there s all manner of advice and guidance on the web for online publisher looking to optimize their social medium effort coschedule fast company hubspot shortstack forbes hootsuite quicksprout and others all claim to have the answer to such seemingly simple question a when is the best time to post on facebook and how often should you post story on facebook however many of the strategy used by publisher for optimizing engagement and boosting referral traffic from social are flawed using data from leading publisher we will dispel the myth and demonstrate that there are no universal best time to share content on facebook we analyzed the median traffic that article received from facebook three hour after they were shared using the median for all story and a year s worth of data helped ensure the analysis wasn t skewed by outlier our analysis garnered some fascinating discovery firstly when we compared three major publisher of national and international news based in south america france and the u k we found significant variance in the shape of the traffic profile for each publisher a can be seen in the above chart the south american publisher achieved best performance when sharing between 11am and 4pm and poor performance at other time the british and french publisher meanwhile achieved more consistent result throughout the day although both experienced peak in referral traffic at different time it s clear there is no one size fit all approach for publisher even if they are in the same category optimal time vary depending on the location of the audience one explanation for this could be that daily routine and behavior vary between country and culture which therefore impact medium consumption pattern the natural next question is whether there are country wide best time for posting story on facebook could it be that reader in france all consume content more consistently throughout the day than the south american can there be specific guide per country we compared traffic data from that same french news publisher with a top 10 french sport publisher of similar size and found that while before 10am they achieved similar result the curve then diverge by early afternoon the news publisher is enjoying a strong peak in traffic whilst the sport publisher is in a pronounced trough overall the sport publisher s traffic is more consistent with fewer dramatic peak and trough while the news publisher ha clearly demarked period when more reader are clicking through to their story even for two publication of equivalent size working in the same country there are stark difference in audience behavior depending on the subject matter of the content we also compared two similar publication in the same country and looked at the traffic profile of two top 10 french news publisher there were still crucial difference when one publisher experienced a peak in share performance at 11am it is in fact one of the worst time for the other publisher to be sharing interestingly there also seems to be significant variance based on article topic we looked at 220 000 facebook post made by our publisher client between march 20 and july 10 2016 and sorted them according to the time of day at which they were shared we then compared performance of post based on whether the article were about sport or technology all share were obtained using local time in order to compensate for time zone difference then normalized by average client performance and volume again there are important difference and these nuance help u understand the characteristic of audience and their varying appetite for particular content type at different time of the day but even these description of the individual publisher do not do the subtlety of the data justice to get the most accurate picture a publisher would need to perform this analysis again on a real time basis due to strong daily fluctuation indeed this is why many publisher now commit very significant resource to optimizing their performance with large social medium team and even data scientist featured image nick shepherd getty image
question: when s the best time to share on facebook what is the best time to share on facebook
