title: salesforcevoice 3 way to make your company more sale intelligent
context: you ve heard of street smart and book smart but is your company sale smart if you re like most organization the answer is probably not really sale team face two perennial problem no matter their industry or how large their company most lack a properly implemented training regimen and the resource to do their job efficiently you can have insanely talented salesperson and they ll still make the same mistake over and over again if they don t have proper training when people don t feel they re supported because they re constantly wanting for resource they eventually burn out but many company fail to address these need within their sale department and they end up losing their top representative because of it becoming sale intelligent modern technology didn t create a training or resource crisis but it did change the type of tool and training that social selling requires rapidly shifting sale technique demand a proactive attitude toward salesforce development productivity tool have enabled salesperson to work smarter and spend more time interfacing with client than managing mundane task the flip side of this is that prospect and customer expect rapid result and constant access sale team must be prepared for the 24 7 nature of their job this is where sale intelligence come in sale and marketing overlap more than ever before organization that rely heavily on cold calling for lead generation need to know whom to target and how to reach them with actionable message a few year ago they would have used simple google search and corporate website to piece together this information now a multitude of service help business identify prospect collect contact information load the data into their crms and schedule drip campaign in this sense many sale rep are operating their own mini marketing department sale intelligence encompasses this entire data gathering process it includes all the contextual information you need about your sale contact purchase history industry response rate and other metric that help you tailor your strategy to each target the better you know your audience the more effective your campaign will be that s sale 101 but sale intelligence platform enable you to put that concept to work by building more detailed profile than were possible in the past still the concept of sale intelligence is relatively new sale manager and executive are understandably wary of investing in tool and strategy if they re not clear on how the business will benefit sale intelligence tool improve efficiency and can increase conversion and profit but they re effective only if you approach them correctly here s how to build sale intelligence within your company 1 emphasize productivity the greatest virtue of sale intelligence tool is that they save so much time you most likely hired your rep on the basis of their sale acumen not their stellar research skill rather than having them spend hour scouring the internet for detail about prospect intelligence tool get them to the right people and company faster cultivate a passion for productivity among your sale teammate they ll be thrilled to try out new platform that provide them with more time to do what they do best sell 2 evaluate potential roi the big question with new tool are always how much will this cost and what s the roi analyze the amount of time and resource that can be saved using different platform then compare that with the cost of purchasing installing and maintaining the new system that will tell you whether sale intelligence is worth the investment usually the answer is yes 3 investigate key feature sale manager often tell me they re reluctant to adopt sale intelligence platform because the tool aren t intuitive they may have watched a demo video or presentation and come away feeling more confused than they were to begin with if you ve experienced this know that the fault probably lie more with the sale rep who led the demo than with the product itself have patience and seek out the feature that are relevant to your organization sale intelligence is critical to your company s growth what obstacle are preventing you from embracing these tool and what would inspire more confidence in them

title: what is the real monetary value of the rio olympics gold medal
context: the rio 2016 summer olympic game is being billed a the biggest sporting event on the planet it s difficult to argue against that claim a more than 11 000 athlete will be competing in 28 sport and 42 discipline for the event s ultimate prize the gold medal the podium value of the gold medal at the rio 2016 olympics is approximately 564 based on the price of gold at 43 76 per gram and the price of sterling silver at 61 cent per gram a of thursday this is in line with the 2014 sochi winter olympic game about 566 even though that medal wa 31 gram heavier however it is a long way off from the approximate 708 record price of the 2012 london gold medal due to the record high price of gold and silver at the time if the entire medal wa made of gold it would be valued at nearly 22 000 which is why 1912 wa the last time all gold medal were awarded a total of 2 488 medal were produced for the rio 2016 olympics 812 gold 812 silver and 864 bronze by the mint of brazil all of the medal are the same size and weight with a diameter of 85 millimeter and a weight of 500 gram making them the heaviest medal in the history of the summer olympics and tied for the largest medal in the summer game at least three winter olympic medal were larger and heavier each of the 812 olympic gold medal is plated with six gram of gold the minimum required by the international olympic committee with 99 9 percent purity the remaining 494 gram is made of silver with 92 5 percent purity the standard for sterling silver according to the mint of brazil the purity silver standard also is a minimum ioc requirement each of the 812 silver medal contains 500 gram of sterling silver the podium value is about 305 the 864 bronze medal contain 475 gram of copper 95 and 25 gram of zinc 5 the bronze medal have little intrinsic value for the first time in history according to rio olympic official the medal are designed in a curved dome shape higher in the center so the thickness range from 6 mm to 11 mm sustainable design the medal were produced with method that the rio 2016 olympic official described a symbol of sustainability and accessibility more than 30 percent of the silver used in the production of the medal are recycled from mirror waste solder and x ray plate the gold is mined entirely free of mercury more than 40 percent of the copper used in the production of the bronze medal came from the industrial waste of the mint of brazil through a process that wa developed internally even the ribbon attached to the medal were well thought out with half of the material woven from recycled polyester polyethylene terephthalate pet yarn recycled post consumer polyester made from bottle each medal come with a sustainably sourced wooden box certified by the forest stewardship council that contains a miniature sculpture of the rio 2016 logo the front of each medal ha the rio 2016 logo framed by laurel leaf which were given a award for the ancient olympics the reverse reveals the traditional etching of the greek goddess of victory in the foreground and the greek panathnaic stadium in the background above nike is the engraving of xxxi olympiad and the olympic ring adding a personal touch the name of the event in which the medal wa awarded is engraved by laser along it outer edge paralympic medal with new sound innovation the 2 642 paralympic award medal were made by the mint of brazil and are of the same weight dimension and material a the olympic medal the design is highlighted by a trail of seed that wrap from the front to the reverse side of the medal olympic official say the seed represent the courage persistence and development of athlete the rio 2016 paralympic game logo is on both side of the medal with braille inscription on the front side for the first time the medal come with sound so visually impaired athlete can identify the medal s color metal ball bearing were placed inside the medal which rattle when shaken the gold medal make the loudest noise and the bronze the weakest more than 100 employee in various professional field including art sustainability engineering and production were involved in the making of the 5 130 medal anthony demarco is founder of the jewelry news network please join me on the jewelry news network facebook page twitter jewelrynewsnet and instagram jewelrynewsnetwork
question: this is how much a gold medal from rio2016 is really worth what is the value of a gold medal from rio 2016

title: realistic optimist may have more success and happiness study suggests
context: are you a glass half full or a glass half empty kind of person a it turn out some people can be both so called realistic optimist combine the positive outlook of optimist with the clear eyed perspective of pessimist new research ha found these realistic optimist may get the best of both world using their realism to perform better at work and elsewhere but aren t getting bogged down by unhappiness said sophia chou an organizational psychology researcher at national taiwan university who presented her finding at a meeting of the american psychological association in honolulu hawaii earlier this month 7 thing that will make you happy optimist and pessimist past research ha shown that optimist value thought that make them feel good about themselves whereas pessimist prize a more truthful vision of themselves but a clear eyed view can be bad for pessimist well being a they tend to be more prone to depression chou said optimist tend to live longer and be healthier overall after several year working in business chou noticed there were some people who were both optimistic and realistic and that they tended to be very successful she wondered whether realism and optimism were really diametrically opposed so chou administered a battery of personality survey to about 200 college and graduate student in taiwan the survey tested how many positive illusion the student held a well a whether they were more motivated by self enhancement or reality realistic view the optimist sorted into two camp the realist and the idealist realistic optimist tend to choose accuracy over self enhancement the unrealistic optimist tend to choose self enhancement chou said interestingly the realistic optimist also got better grade on average than their le grounded peer probably because they didn t delude themselves into thinking they would do well without studying or working hard chou said traditionally a more realistic outlook is paired with poorer well being and greater depression yet the realistic optimist managed to be happy to understand why she dug deeper into the personality assessment self control key she found that realistic optimist believed they had more self control and control over their interpersonal relationship every time they face an issue or a challenge or a problem they won t say i have no choice and this is the only thing i can do they will be creative they will have a plan a plan b and plan c chou said that allows them to stay cheery and upbeat about the future even if they recognize the challenge of the present being a realistic optimist doe have one downside however they are more prone to anxiety than their completely unrealistic peer that s likely because they recognize the possibility of failure whereas their counterpart use positive illusion to ease their anxiety chou said the finding suggest that realistic and unrealistic optimist may actually be very different personality type chou said in order to cultivate a rosy but realistic outlook people should maintain a clear eyed view of reality but emphasize what they can control in most situation she said
question: people with this personality type may be happier and more successful what is the personality type of people who may be happier and more successful

title: spray on nail polish is perfect for people who can t paint their own nail
context: some may call the spray on nail polish trend lazy or messy but we think it s pretty awesome unlike traditional nail lacquer that require a steady hand and a long drying time aerosol based nail polish allow you to spray on a manicure in under 20 second amazing right though you may have come across that a seen on tv infomercial for spray perfect the company that s actually credited with revolutionizing the product is london based company nail inc their paint can spray are now available stateside in three highly pigmented shade including hoxton market a hot pink mayfair lane a pastel pink and shoreditch lane a gleaming silver milk makeup and china glaze have recently added spray on nail polish to their beauty line proving that this trend isn t going anywhere any time soon here s exactly how it work demonstrated in gifs by nail inc you start by applying a base coat because you ve got to protect your natural nail and provide a smooth surface for the pigment to adhere to you can either use your own traditional brush on base coat or one that may be sold with your spray on polish next shake up the can and spray on your nail polish pro tip place a paper towel or old newspaper to prevent getting product all over the place and be sure to hold the bottle at least 3 to 5 inch above your hand to evenly disperse the pigment don t worry about getting the spray on nail polish all over your finger you can remove the excess paint by simply washing your hand or using a makeup remover wipe seal your manicure with a traditional top coat and you re done

title: body language expert reveals nine way to spot a liar and how you can get away with telling fib
context: there s nothing worse than having the wool pulled over your eye and when it happens you often wonder how someone managed to deceive you now body language expert judi james ha revealed the key sign to look out for if you re concerned someone is being economical with the truth while she warns that there is no set formula for spotting a liar recognising some of the sign can help you root out a fibber forget all those claim of tell and other body language giveaway that reveal when someone is being economical with the truth a bad liar might blush and sweat and show physical sign of agitation like fidgeting she explained but a practised liar can easily deliver a lie while looking cool calm and confident despite the fact there are no one size fit all symptom to spot the following tip should help alert you to the fact that someone s not being totally honest with you the big pause lying is quite a complex process for the body and brain to deal with first your brain produce the truth which it then ha to suppress before inventing the lie and the performance of that lie this often lead to a longer pause than normal before answering plus a verbal stalling technique like why do you ask that rather than a direct and open response the eye dart human have more eye expression than any other animal and our eye can give away if we re trying to hide something when we look up to our left to think we re often accessing recalled memory but when our eye roll up to our right we can be thinking more creatively also the guilt of a lie often make people use an eye contact cut off gesture such a looking down or away the lost breath bending the truth cause an instant stress response in most people meaning the fight or flight mechanism are activated the mouth dry the body sweat more the pulse rate quickens and the rhythm of the breathing change to shorter shallower breath that can often be both seen and heard overcompensating a liar will often over perform both speaking and gesticulating too much in a bid to be more convincing these over the top body language ritual can involve too much eye contact often without blinking and over emphatic gesticulation the poker face although some people prefer to employ the poker face many assume le is more and almost shut down in term of movement and eye contact when they re being economical with the truth the face hide when someone tell a lie they often suffer a strong desire to hide their face from their audience this can lead to a partial cut off gesture like the well know nose touch or mouth cover self comfort touch the stress and discomfort of lying often produce gesture that are aimed at comforting the liar such a rocking hair stroking or twiddling or playing with wedding ring we all tend to use self comfort gesture but this will increase dramatically when someone is fibbing micro gesture these are very small gesture or facial expression that can flash across the face so quickly they are difficult to see expert will often use filmed footage that is then slowed down to pick up on the true body language response emerging in the middle of the performed lie the best time to spot these in real life is to look for the facial expression that occurs after the liar ha finished speaking the mouth might skew or the eye roll in an instant give away heckling hand the hardest body part to act with are the hand or foot and liar often struggle to keep them on message while they lie when the gesture and the word are at odds it s called incongruent gesticulation and it s often the hand or foot that are telling the truth judi james is supporting macmillan cancer support s new murder mystery fundraising game whodunnit and say learning how to lie might help if you decide to take part while i don t usually condone lying this is the perfect opportunity to try your hand at being economical with the truth she said convince yourself first the brain like to see the whole manufactured story which it can then perform using body language don t just think of the transcript visualise the whole story including all the smallest detail visualisation is the nearest you ll get to making the lie reality and that help make your body language signal congruent relax to combat the fight flight response breathe out slowly and deliberately to relax your muscle especially the one in your shoulder arm and hand keep your vocal tone a little lower lying can make u more shrill slow your blink rate fibbing often cause a give away accelerated blink rate slow your own down a little a this will help create reassurance in your audience keep busy if you re not very good at lying try to keep busy when you perform the lie actor call this a bit of business which is when le competent actor continue washing up or potting plant while being quizzed rather than struggling with their body language sip a cup of tea etc it might look rude but it can be better than over sharing in term of your body language giveaway tell the truth first in an emergency such a do you like my new hair cut or am i the best lover you ve ever had it can help if you expel the truth first for example it look terrible or no you re the worst followed by only joking of course you re wonderful macmillan cancer support s new murder mystery fundraising game whodunnit take place on saturday 25th march gather your friend for an evening of bluffing accusation and outrageous over acting to help raise vital fund for people affected by cancer for more information visit www whodunnit org uk
question: body language expert reveals nine way to spot a liar what are the nine way to spot a liar a revealed by a body language expert

title: why it s worth it to get your flu shot
context: oct 28 when her law office offered flu shot in mid october kelly walsh a paralegal in boston hesitated walsh didn t get vaccinated last year and didn t get sick the year before she had flu like symptom for a week after getting the shot i also worried if everyone at work knew i got a flu shot it ll be harder to take sick day if i do get the flu say walsh 38 ultimately however walsh got jabbed and expert agree it wa the right call a recent study by the center for disease control and prevention cdc and vanderbilt university medical center found that getting a flu shot reduced the risk of flu related hospitalization by 71 4 percent for all adult and 76 8 percent for those over age 50 during the 2011 2012 flu season the cdc estimate death associated with the flu number between 3 000 and 49 000 people each year one reason people don t get vaccinated is cost flu shot aren t always free most insurance doe cover vaccination administered at a doctor s office but walk into your local cv or walgreen and you ll likely pay at least 35 insurance won t necessarily cover shot at retail pharmacy employer can help bring down those cost and likely save themselves money a well the cdc estimate that seasonal influenza outbreak average 10 4 billion in direct cost due to medical treatment and hospitalization part of those cost are then passed along to employer in the form of higher premium and lost productivity typically more than 200 000 people are hospitalized each year for flu related illness many large firm like walsh s offer free flu shot clinic but letting worker know they won t be penalized for taking sick leave can also pay dividend for business big and small last winter wa a big year for influenza and it caught many patient and healthcare provider off guard after several year of milder flu season it s too early to know how this year s will compare or even how many people have come down with the flu so far this autumn since those number tracked by the cdc weren t reported during the recent government shutdown flu activity usually peak in the united state in january or february recent study from the european union show the vaccine offer le immunity and ha a shorter duration than previously thought according to kris ehresmann director of the infectious disease division at the minnesota department of health but now is the time to get vaccinated she add what s new this year say dr michael jhung medical officer at the cdc is that many flu shot will immunize against four strain of the flu virus for the first time an improved protection over year past drug company plan to make 135 million to 139 million dos of vaccine approved by the food and drug administration several vaccination option are available they include a standard dose for adult and child a high dose shot for people over age 65 a nasal spray for those who don t like needle and a dose that is egg free for patient who are allergic everyone over the age of 6 month should get one expert say we don t prefer one vaccine over another jhung say whatever vaccine patient choose we re happy the elderly child under age 5 pregnant woman and people with other chronic health condition are most vulnerable to the flu getting immunized earlier guarantee protection whenever the flu season start in earnest jhung note plus adult who don t get vaccinated can put others including child at risk only 42 percent of american got vaccinated in the 2011 2012 flu season the latest data available from the cdc a an added bonus a new study published in the journal of the american medical association found that up to 36 percent of those vaccinated reduced their risk of heart attack stroke or other cardiovascular health problem just by getting a flu shot based on these finding the researcher calculated that one death or serious illness due to heart trouble could be prevented by vaccinating 58 additional people peter delgado a 66 year old self employed accountant recently left a cambridge massachusetts rite aid before getting his flu shot there wa too much paperwork to fill out and they wanted to charge me 70 say delgado who life nearby the high dose version of the shot recommended for older people often cost more than the normal vaccine his wife however soon sent him back in i told him if you get sick from the flu and can t work you ll feel foolish over 70 say anne delgado 66 who is retired one shot could mean food on the table for u follow u reutersmoney or at http www reuters com finance personal finance editing by lauren young and meredith mazzilli

title: workaholic may face poor physical and mental well being study suggests
context: if you re addicted to checking your email and regularly work through evening weekend and vacation you might be a workaholic and your health may be suffering because of it recent research ha found a link between workaholism and reduced physical and mental well being the kansa state university study which will be published in the journal financial planning review found that well being is generally not a priority for workaholic we found workaholic defined by those working more than 50 hour per week were more likely to have reduced physical well being measured by skipped meal doctoral researcher sarah asebedo said in a statement also we found that workaholism wa associated with reduced mental well being a measured by a self reported depression score to figure out why some choose to work overtime even when they know it s not good for health the researcher turned to a mathematical analysis called becker s theory of the allocation of time which help to measure the cost of time the theory highlight the paradox that working overtime lead to more income but le time to spend this income it also suggests that a income increase worker are more likely to develop unhealthy habit around working excessively becker s theory look at the cost of time a if it were a market good asebedo said in the statement this theory suggests that the more money you make the more likely you are to work more if you are not engaged in work related activity then there is a cost to the alternative way in which time is spent even if you understand the negative consequence to workaholism you may still be likely to continue working because the cost of not doing so becomes greater the finding are based on data from the 1979 cohort of the national longitudinal survey of youth that included 12 686 young men and woman all the study participant were interviewed each year until 1994 and are still interviewed biennially of course it s no secret that overworking can have a negative effect on your health and happiness a number of study have shown the detrimental toll that work stress in particular can take on your health including depression and an increased risk of heart attack and diabetes and workaholism in particular ha been associated with poor sleep quality weight gain high blood pressure depression and anxiety not to mention unhappy marriage and higher divorce rate and with the possibility to work from anywhere at anytime it s easier than ever to become a workaholic in the first place more than eight in 10 american are stressed about their job citing an unreasonable workload a their number one stressor and 61 percent of employed vacationer will work through their vacation this year up from 52 percent last year but turning on that out of office autoreply and taking some time to rest and recharge can actually have a positive effect on not just your well being but also your productivity even a short nap can boost cognitive functioning improving creative thinking learning and memory renewal is not for slacker tony schwartz ceo of the energy project told the huffington post renewal is a way in which to increase your capacity to be more effective
question: bad news for workaholic what is the news for workaholic

text: link between workaholism and reduced physical and mental well being

title: expert warn that lining the toilet seat with paper could be spreading more bacteria

a possible according to today com germ are not easily spreadable on toilet seat since many different bacteria and virus don t survive long outside of a human body their special shape and material were specifically designed to prevent bacteria from dwelling on their surface for very long despite this many people opt to line the seat with toilet paper but really this seemingly clean practice may a important our skin doe a great job of blocking bacteria so trust in it ability to do it job when sitting on a dry toilet seat a long a you remain aware of where bacteria is actually present you can make smart decision toward remaining healthy happy and free of more germ than are necessary

title: it s a long shot but here s how trump could win

republican party behind his candidacy clinton meanwhile is fighting a contentious primary which keep her from doing the same there s still a strong case to make that donald trump is a long shot for the white house that he s too unpopular with too many american outside the republican party and that if the obama coalition hold he loses jamelle bouie jamelle bouie is slate s chief political correspondent at least that s what i think but humility is a virtue and life is volatile even if election often aren t that trump is a poor bet for november doesn t mean he couldn t win he could which raise an obvious question how would it happen and finding an answer here isn t too difficult you just need to reverse engineer the condition of a trump loss what are those condition at the top of the list is demographic trump is deeply unpopular with black and latino voter a well a with woman and young people but clinton is also unpopular albeit by a smaller magnitude given two unpopular candidate it s possible that popularity just won t matter a much that voter will take both candidate worst quality a a given and move on in which case both clinton and trump become generic nominee and what are the prospect this year for a generic republican nominee of five separate econometric model of the election four predict a republican win ranging from 50 9 percent of the vote to 55 percent of the two party vote the economy is middling president obama well liked but not hugely popular and clinton would be a third term for democrat given two generic candidate under those criterion the presidency would go to the republican say hello to president trump let s say you don t trust the model they couldn t predict trump after all then what how would trump win assuming key part of the electorate are aligned against him the answer is easy he win and turn out white voter in historic number assume higher nonwhite support for the democrat let s say a three point bump among black and a seven point bump among hispanic giving clinton 97 percent and 80 percent support respectively and trump need 66 percent of white to win both the popular and electoral college vote if turnout doesn t change you can play with the number over at realclearpolitics how would trump win assuming key part of the electorate are aligned against him he turn out white voter in historic number it s an extraordinary reach an increase of nearly six point over the white share in 2012 matching ronald reagan s performance in 1984 it would mean trump persuaded million of democrat to switch team despite their wide approval for president obama in other word it s not happening partisanship ha a tight hold on american voting behavior and it s hard to imagine how trump could break it barring a national catastrophe easier to imagine is higher white turnout if trump could reverse the yearslong decline and bring white turnout back to it 2008 level 74 percent then he could win with another couple percentage point among white even with the high black and latino turnout of 2008 this would give him teetering democratic state such a new hampshire pennsylvania and wisconsin a well a the three largest swing state florida ohio and virginia it s a heavy lift especially for a candidate who say he will eschew data gathering and other quantitative method for finding and mobilizing supporter but it s possible ok ok possible doesn t mean likely and it s hard to imagine a disorganized campaign exceeding team romney s ability to pinpoint and bring republican leaning white voter to the poll still with a smile from fortuna or whichever god of chance you prefer trump can win if anything guarantee defeat for an incumbent party it s a recession at the opening of the 1960 election in early spring of that year john f kennedy and richard nixon were neck and neck this continued into the summer and the early fall but by october kennedy had opened a small but persistent lead he won it s hard to isolate a single cause for kennedy s victory but he wa almost certainly helped along by the modest recession that struck in the spring and lasted until the following winter if not for that downturn there s a fair chance nixon would have become president a sudden slowdown could have the same effect on our election in fact the very presence of trump his proximity to the most powerful office in the world could destabilize market and make a downturn more likely and consider this on average the united state see a recession every five year we re due one is all we need for president trump a terrorist attack could do it driving voter into the arm of the authoritarian in the race but the literature is mixed on how terrorism affect voter it could make them more attuned to perceived outsider and immigrant in particular giving trump an advantage it could push them toward hawkish candidate with traditional credential helping clinton or given the candidate it could be a wash so let s table this one there s one last thing that could deliver the white house to trump a divided democratic party party unity is a prerequisite for national competition it s why the never trump movement fell apart after ted cruz left the race a serious effort to derail the republican nominee would guarantee a democratic white house because it s almost impossible to overcome the asymmetry in the still unlikely event that the present acrimony between bernie sander and the democratic party becomes an outright split democrat risk throwing the election to trump through in fighting and division if sander run a a third party candidate the game is over and democrat lose you see this in the most recent polling clinton s biggest weakness in the nbc news survey of registered voter is with sander backer who haven t crossed the threshold to team clinton if this persists it s dangerous if history is any indication however it won t be with all this said even the most probable scenario here that trump and clinton become generic candidate is a distant long shot they re just too well known for voter to treat them a interchangeable with any republican or any democrat and their personal quality mix with the fundamental of this election partisanship demographic and economic performance to create favorable terrain for democrat

title: a siri for your finance digit say trust me
context: late last year just in time for christmas shopping rachel rhoads got a nice surprise one of her secret saving account had grown to 900 behind her back rhoads a 37 year old los angeles based sale director for a jewelry line ha an account with digit a financial technology company with an algorithm that track user income and spending pattern it painlessly spirit small amount of money out of checking and into a saving account every two or three day i just thought it wa such a good idea to set it and forget it said rhoads who say she is like a squirrel in her approach to saving digit sends text with balance update which she largely ignores because i like to pretend the saving is not happening getting consumer comfortable with putting their finance on customized autopilot starting with a simple no fee and no interest saving account is the san francisco startup s mission in two year it user have saved more than 350 million this way according to it 31 year old founder and chief executive officer ethan bloch when the product moved out of pilot mode in february 2015 user were saving about 1 million a month now that s more than 35 million a month digit won t disclose the size of it user base but say it ha tripled from about a year ago digit had a saving bot before bot were cool or at least before the hype in the financial technology world reached a fever pitch it product is simple an algorithm look at a user s average high and low checking account balance when the user is paid and whether the pay cycle is smooth or choppy then after looking for bill due in the next week or two and analyzing recent spending it move an amount it judge the customer won t miss to a saving account the company make money from the interest rate it get on account asset digit announced today that it will be the first saving bot on facebook messenger s platform so user can just use facebook to communicate with it when digit moved out of it pilot phase it communicated only by text a natural language for many user since 17 percent of them are aged 21 to 24 and 44 percent are from 25 to 34 year old rhoads said they re cute text with some personality and not annoying at all after text messaging came io and android apps for user the company is now working on what bloch called the first artificial intelligence powered financial goal program user would set a date and amount and pick an emoji of course and digit s algorithm would make a series of projection based on balance to determine the optimal amount needed to start saving toward that goal or point out that the goal is unrealistic also on the product horizon is having digit s algorithm figure out how to move every dollar where it should go at the right time to minimize fee on student loan credit card account etc and maximize gain bloch said there are hitch since digit isn t a bank it can t pay interest and it will be competing in an environment of rising rate bloch said interest rate are not a huge deal for his customer because they regularly withdraw money and tend to save small sum another hurdle is that traditional bank technology can make it hard to connect account bank have not made it easy for customer to get their data bloch said because of that digit and product like acorn venmo betterment every day we have bank difficulty that affect thousand of customer behavioral finance underlies much of digit s design take the goal function for example if user get more specific about what they are saving for research suggests they are le likely to withdraw the money if an account is labeled charlie s education fund i ll think harder about withdrawing it than if it s just labeled saving bloch said currently 70 percent of digit user withdraw 80 percent of their saving every 90 day mainly to pay bill and meet short term need for cash to pay off debt or pay for travel bloch s broadest long term goal is to make digit s user interface far more conversational to humanize it so user feel more in control when they communicate with it we want to make digit understand more not a broad a alexa or siri but widen the aperture a little more related to finance and your money he said one day it would be awesome to say hey digit am i ok for retirement and all digit doe is send back a thumb up emoji that kind of complex analysis won t show up anytime soon but after a series b round of fundraising led by venture capital firm ribbit capital digit s 22 person team is sitting on 25 million in cash that bloch said will let the company be somewhat protected for the next few year in pushing the envelope largely to invest in product development the big question for u now is what more will our customer trust digit to do update amount of monthly saving of digit user and total amount of saving update amount of monthly saving of digit user and total amount of saving
question: this bot ha saved user 250 million and it s coming to facebook messenger what is the amount of money saved by the bot on facebook messenger

for 2017 deciding on investment strategy or goal can help u figure out what we want our long term financial picture to look like and shape our budget for the coming year when laying out an investing you speak to your investment strategy that year and can you walk u through your 2016 investment strategy jp livingston my investment strategy for several year ha been a twist on a broadly discussed strategy to go long on equity many financial expert those who aren t compensated for getting you to invest a certain way will tell you that if you are young and in the wealth accumulation phase of your life to consider parking your money in a low cost index fund for example vanguard s total stock market index fund vtsax there are a few key argument for this strategy first it s a nice hedge against inflation because the company in the index are presumably raising their price with inflation since company are valued on a multiple of revenue or profit this will be captured in the growth of the stock market secondly and most importantly is that it s hard to argue with it result the compound annual growth rate for stock on the s p index for the last 30 year ha been 11 there are very few if any opportunity available to u regular individual investor that can top that kind of return for the risk note you ll get an entirely different view from hedge fund or mutual fund they believe they can beat market return and so they charge high fee for their time and effort a few of them are worth it most of them are not kachroo levine what are you planning on changing about your strategy in 2017 livingston a a retiree steady cash flow is going to matter more to me than it ha in the past there are only two way to make money appreciation and income stock for example are about appreciation you make very little money on a regular basis usually a puny 1 2 in dividend but a year or two or three later you can sell it for much more than you paid and pocket the difference a heavily appreciation based strategy like going 100 into index fund will no longer meet my need income based strategy by contrast put a steady paycheck in the spotlight bond are generally purchased for the interest they provide sure they can appreciate or depreciate in value but the bulk of your return from a bond come from the monthly or quarterly dividend it pay i have a few year to build myself an income based strategy a i still have some deferred compensation coming from my old employer but i m looking to add one or two rental property to my portfolio in 2017 interest rate are still fairly low so it s not a bad time to be a borrower i would also look at adding more bond to my portfolio specifically leveraged municipal bond fund the leverage juice return and municipal bond are tax exempt but i do not want to buy bond right now a the fed ha signaled a plan to increase interest rate and even raised them just a week ago kachroo levine what are your financial investment goal for 2017 what are your priority livingston a i am newly retired my main priority is transitioning my portfolio into more income based opportunity that can provide steady money to cover my expense each year i m on the lookout for a rental property or two to take advantage of low interest rate and which will provide some much needed steady income in some part of the country like san francisco rental property are actually negative cash flow exercise and are predicated on appreciation in some area it will throw off 6 7 or more in income each year and fit my income need real estate is hyperlocal like that kachroo levine what are the key philosophy that help shape your investment strategy livingston i feel i ve gotten pretty far on just two thing first don t be afraid to say you don t know people get really weird and insecure when it come to money we re all lifelong learner i have to admit i don t know basic thing all the time for example while i ve read quite a bit about real estate investment i m constantly finding myself with a giant question mark a i apply those concept to my first live investment my priority though is to make money and learn not to impress people second don t give up until you really feel you understand something finally my other silver bullet question is to ask what are the argument against it or what are the three thing that could break this strategy there s no free lunch every strategy ha some vulnerability kachroo levine what advice can you offer for novice investor in 2017 specifically if you were speaking to people who had never invested beyond a 401 k or ira what would you say to them livingston you are in such an exciting place because there is low hanging fruit all around you a few thing 1 money management is an incremental game not a winner take all game that mean every tweak you make ha a noticeable impact on your money and it mean you don t have to choose between going whole hog or absolute zero you can devote however much time and effort you have and get proportional result and new idea to employ 2 momentum matter most start by joining a few interesting community and blog and read a little bit a few time a week cruise around on the reddit personal finance forum investment is only painful or boring when you try to cram too much too fast or you go find a dry educational source and force feed yourself the information momentum is the most important piece when you start any new project too many people think alright it s time to do this investment stuff and go and buy some highly rated book on amazon to start their education that s such a self defeating way to start is that how you got into skiing or guitar or interpretive celtic dance ha that kind of textbook strategy ever succeeded in firing up your passion kachroo levine for those seeking early retirement can you share why your investment are so crucial to your early retirement journey livingston your nest egg is like an entire extra employee doing work for you an employee that get better and stronger and eventually eclipse you say you make 100 000 pre tax and save 30 000 a year once your nest egg is three time your salary or 300 000 at a 10 return it will generate a much a you slaving a whole year to put away ha accomplished at 10 time your salary and a 10 return it is throwing off more money than you make in an entire year you could be sitting on the beach drinking mai tai and still see a year s worth of salary come in just from your investment of course you can t guarantee consistent 10 return but you have a long term bet that you can achieve during your accumulation phase by investing in low cost index fund more on forbes

title: what is the easiest way to quit smoking
context: what is the easiest way to quit smoking mar 04 2017 what doe matt damon drew barrymore ben affleck charlize theron and ellen degeneras all have in common they quit smoking using hypnotherapy celebrity have discovered the effective result of hypnotherapy and have used it to conquer their own smoking habit researcher at the university of iowa combined more than 600 study of smoking cessation program involving 72 000 people from north america and europe1 hypnosis wa found to be over 3 time more effective than nicotine replacement therapy and 15 time more effective than quitting cold turkey a comparison study of smoking cessation treatment wa conducted by north shore medical center and massachusetts general hospital2 26 week after discharge 50 of patient who received hypnotherapy exclusively were non smoker compared to the 25 of patient who didn t and only 16 of patient who used nicotine replacement therapy alone type of addiction smoking addiction is a combination of two type of addiction there s the physical addiction then there is the mental or psychological addiction although nicotine addiction is considered one of the strongest addiction even more addictive than cocaine the good news is that the physical side of thing doesn t last very long in fact some believe that you will lose the physical craving for nicotine in a little a 3 day the real struggle for smoker is overcoming the mental addiction the smoker ha essentially trained their subconscious mind to make smoking an automatic behavior these are the habit and ritual that a smoker ha developed over the year such a smoking when they wake up just before they go to sleep after they eat when they drive when they drink coffee or alcohol and so on how hypnotherapy help you quit so what will hypnotherapy do rather than just treating the physical urge that are part of your smoking habit hypnotherapy target the subconscious drive behind the addiction and break the positive association with cigarette that the mind ha formed this is replaced by an empowering smoke free perspective the hypnotist offer through verbal suggestion that deem smoking a something undesirable or unnecessary to do gradually these suggestion take hold and diminish the smoker s impulse to smoke furthermore hypnotherapy is considered to be a far more safe and natural method to quit smoking with and is non habit forming this cannot be said about most of the stop smoking aid we currently have on the market but going to a hypnotist can be expensive a much a 200 per one hour session and requiring a many a 5 session for the entire treatment if you re a celebrity like the one mentioned earlier then this isn t a problem but can the average smoker afford to go to a hypnotherapist well that question is left to the individual but consider that a pack a day smoker will spend in excess of 2000 a year on cigarette not even including the increased cost of life and health insurance and doesn t include the drastic cut in your ability to earn
question: what is the easiest way to quit smoking what is the best way to quit smoking

title: guess how much money bill gross made last year
context: how much compensation the folk at pacific investment management co better known a pimco haul in each year ha always been a topic of fascination on wall street in 2012 news report suggested that the firm s top 30 partner pulled down an average 33 million a year in compensation in recent year a subsequent column by felix salmon guessed that the average investment professional at pimco wa making roughly 7 million each annually a pimco spokesman denied salmon s claim responding that the number cited in your blog post today are wildly inaccurate salmon s speculation wa indeed wildly inaccurate to the downside actual bonus at pimco are higher much higher than probably any outsider previously believed based on news report public record and new data obtained by bloomberg view it appears that pimco had a 2013 bonus pool for it 60 managing director of almost 1 5 billion so how much have pimco s top executive earned according to document provided to bloomberg view by someone with knowledge of pimco s bonus policy the number break down like this gross earned 290 million a his year end bonus for 2013 mohamed el erian pimco s former chief executive officer and one time heir apparent to gross received 230 million el erian is a fellow bloomberg view contributor and the story doesn t end with pimco s two most visible former employee former deputy chief investment officer daniel ivascyn now serving a gross s replacement a pimco s chief investment officer took home a 70 million bonus wendy w cupps the global head of product management garnered 50 million making her one of the highest paid woman in finance her rocky push into equity wa the subject of well publicized haranguing by gross douglas hodge now the ceo took home 45 million of holiday cheer these giant bonus almost make the 22 million awarded to pimco s president jay jacob seem puny the top three manager after gross and el erian ivascyn cupps and jacob were rumored to have been behind the coup that sent gross packing to janus capital in september next month free of gross and el erian these three will have an extra half a billion or so to keep to themselves or distribute to the other managing director gross s bonus 20 percent of the total bonus pool for 2013 place him in a compensation class of his very own to put that figure into context in 2013 gross made just shy of what the next 20 publicly held finance company ceo made combined in the world of sport you would have to take the total salary winning and endorsement deal of lebron james lionel messi kobe bryant tiger wood and roger federer together to be on par with gross how pimco became such an earnings machine is a quirk it ha been four decade since it wa spun out of pacific life insurance co a move that wa made in part to allow gross a freer hand to manage the insurer s fixed income portfolio since then pimco ha grown into a behemoth in term of the bottom line and a a force in the bond market much of what we know about pimco stem from allianz se s 3 3 billion purchase of 70 percent of the firm in 2000 a publicly traded german insurer allianz ha released some detail about pimco s operation in it quarterly earnings report that data along with mutual fund disclosure and filing provide hint about the firm s revenue we can estimate earnings by looking at the largest pimco fund the 20 biggest have an average fee of about 61 basis point let s lower that to account for discount given to large institutional client and we get a rough estimate of about 50 basis point on 1 82 trillion dollar that yield 9 1 billion in revenue a year pimco is by any measure a fabulously wealthy company using my back of the envelope revenue estimate it generates far more revenue per employee than any bank or asset manager almost four time a much a goldman sachs when allianz bought into pimco it picked up about 250 billion in asset under management pimco currently manages about 2 trillion the bonus structure is a quirk of that original deal allianz partial purchase left pacific life owning 30 percent of pimco but pacific life wasn t interested in running the asset management business and even after the allianz deal everyone involved continued to defer to gross s financial and managerial judgment thus pimco based in newport beach california and 6 000 mile removed from it majority owner remained fully autonomous bloomberg view s fee analysis suggests allianz take about 70 percent of the total revenue pimco generates annually plus or minus a few percentage point pimco keep the rest this same deal structure continued even after allianz purchased the 30 percent of pimco that it didn t already own from pacific life in the mid 2000s a subsequent restructuring in 2011 saw gross and his team gain even greater control over the firm that gave pimco so much freedom in relation to it corporate parent that a one analyst described it to bloomberg news it appeared a if it wa the tail wagging the dog part of the reason for gross s longevity after the allianz takeover and another element of the firm s enormous wealth is what we might call the pimco premium despite being in a competitive field including giant company such a vanguard and blackrock pimco manages to charge more than the industry standard for access to it fund and it separately managed account why when competing for business the firm ha had an unbeatable combination of a long history and outstanding long term result at least it did until recent bad bet on rising interest rate by gross torpedoed the 1 3 and 5 year record of the flagship total return fund pimco also became the go to company for the federal reserve and u s treasury in many of the credit facility used to combat the continuing economic fallout from the financial crisis pimco s success in the federal government s program to jumpstart consumer lending and a variety of mortgage backed security program added more luster to it reputation gross even managed to buy up lot of mb s before the fed officially announced the program shareholder of the total return fund netted about 10 billion from it mortgage play beyond the sheer size of pimco s bonus there are other aspect of it compensation practice that should give pause to everyone involved in institutional asset management for one pimco ha been part of a publicly traded company allianz for the past 15 year unbeknownst to allianz s shareholder employee of one of it business unit have been paying themselves these extraordinarily large sum of money in the u s it is hard to imagine 1 5 billion in spending on anything not being disclosed almost 16 percent of pimco s revenue is a material amount of money that would normally require disclosure in the u s but allianz is a german company subject to different regulation another item worth noticing pimco investor represent pension fund foundation charitable trust 401ks and other retirement account pimco s enormous self paid bonus come right off of the top of the return those outside investor might otherwise receive in a recent allianz presentation following gross departure from pimco the firm s new chief executive doug hodge stated we don t comment on matter of compensation but while gross may be gone the high fee and compensation structure at pimco appear to remain firmly in place allianz doesn t seem inclined to change thing it started a 279 million award program this fall to keep people from following gross out the door however if there is going to be change it can only come from pimco s big institutional customer why should they pay a pimco premium pimco s profit are down by 7 9 percent in the third quarter of this year and the firm saw saw almost 50 billion in outflow last month janus gross s new home ha managed to attract only about 430 million in new money since he joined the market for fixed income asset management ha never been in greater flux than it is today the realignment of power among bond manager is only just beginning if ever there wa a moment when investor could demand more competitive fee from their bond manager it is now perhaps it might also be a good time for pimco itself to consider slicing it fee anecdotally story abound of pimco institutional salesperson offering steep one year fee discount a a way to retain asset if i were managing pimco even from 6 000 mile away i would be looking at way to make those fee reduction more permanent i bet i even could find close to a billion and a half dollar in saving
question: guess how much money bill gross made last year exclusive by ritholtz what is the source of the information in the sentence

title: facebook is building apartment anyone can rent but there s a huge catch
context: image getty facebook could be your next landlord in an effort to drum up support for the controversial expansion of it headquarters the social medium giant is trying to give back to the community by building at least 1 500 housing unit that can be rented by the general public not just facebook employee but there s a catch a facebook slowly wade into the real estate development business the company is pushing an aggressive pr agenda to convince people that facebook doe not exacerbate income inequality in area where it develops real estate facebook ha pledged that 15 percent of the new unit it creates will go to low or middle income family which is great until you realize that 85 percent of the building will probably be ridiculously expensive and probably populated by local tech bros facebook ha been embroiled in a fiery debate about income inequality for year this january the world bank published a 330 page report showing how the largest technology company are increasing income inequality rather than helping it some of the perceived benefit of digital technology are offset by emerging risk the report said many advanced economy face increasingly polarized labor market and rising inequality in part because technology augments higher skill while replacing routine job forcing many worker to compete for low paying job that s exactly what happened when facebook attracted thousand of new resident into the menlo park area where it headquarters is located most of the new resident are well educated high income earner who drove up housing pricers forced lower income family to move and exacerbated income inequality throughout the area obviously that doesn t win mark zuckerberg many new friend in the area meanwhile facebook is trying to win support for a lucrative proposal to expand it headquarters by 1 1 million square foot the proposal is still missing some important detail though for starter it s still unclear if facebook itself will develop the building or hire a third party secondly it s also unclear what the timeline for the development is despite lacking specific the impact of the proposal is obvious facebook would dramatically increase it footprint in an area where it s already driven up real estate price and driven out those who can t afford the rent sponsored this isn t the first time facebook ha been involved in controversial housing development either in 2013 the company built a 394 unit housing community within walking distance of it office that included it own sport bar outdoor pool and pet daycare at the time a wall street journal report referred to the project a being similar to a company town the name for small community built by robber baron of the 20th century that housed factory worker the employer provided everything including health care law enforcement and even church town like pullman illinois were created a capitalist utopia but ultimately the boss failed to protect worker and resident is facebook turning menlo park into a 21st century version of pullman it s too soon to tell the new office expansion is slated service at least 6 500 new employee and offering housing to the general public to offset crowding concern is certainly a gesture on facebook s part but while some poor people will get home in the new real estate development it s surely won t be enough to fix the area s greater socioeconomic problem wall street journal

title: our tailor and the ticking time bomb
context: at december s global diabetes summit in berlin doctor described type 2 diabetes a scarier than hiv and malaria causing more death than either but is society enabling the deadly killer it take a seismic event to get a transglobal family together in one place for mine it wa the death of my grandmother in kerala she had been our collective anchor my grandmother spoke five language so that she could communicate with all of her grandchild and knew exactly how everyone liked their tea and everyone liked it differently all with slightly different amount of sugar upon receiving the unexpected phone call a sleepless night pierced by even more phone call led to a hazy 40 hour which wa broken up by a taxi two plane a few chocolate bar a muted airport greeting and another car journey by the time i arrived in calicut at the house where i had spent my childhood there were only a few hour left until the funeral someone made me a syrupy tea which boosted my energy and briefly my mood i made myself another two more following the funeral my aunt who had travelled from america asked me to take a walk with her the oppression of the midday sun had subsided slightly and if we stretched our leg she said we would feel better about the tea and sweet we could have when we got back home calicut where i wa born is a city on india s south west coast i often thought with no authority other than nostalgic affection that it looked like someone had cut road into the middle of a lush forest there s significantly le traffic than in many other city in india coconut tree line the street a the arabian sea sparkle to the west and the wayanad hill rise in the east during the 13th century calicut became a major port for the indian ocean trade route merchant were said to manipulate the monsoon wind to transport spice cotton and sugar from there to the west and a my aunt and i took our walk we passed several street vendor a man wa pulping sugar cane into a drink feeling slightly light headed i wa tempted to buy one when something else caught my eye on the side of the road under a papaya tree a one room shop that i had been familiar with my whole life wa boarded up it had belonged to a tailor named padmanabhan he had with his sole sewing machine and thick robust finger been the architect of many of my family s fashion choice over the year he d cut and shaped my aunt s wedding sari and my cousin s he d made my school uniform and my niece s and nephew s he d disapprovingly made me my first pair of skinny jean and pretended not to smile when i told him that people had asked if they were from paris he died my aunt said following my gaze of what he wa only in his 50 wasn t he i asked not particularly surprised that the news of our local tailor had reached her in kansa type 2 diabetes he had to have his leg amputated so sad the international burden of diabetes is a much told news story new data from the international diabetes federation estimate that 415 million people in the world have diabetes by 2040 the figure is expected to grow to 642 million that s an estimated one in 10 of the world population currently a much a 12 of total health expenditure go on treating the disease india ha until it wa surpassed by china been called the diabetes capital of the world with an estimated 50 million people having type 2 diabetes and worryingly according to the world health organisation who that figure will only get worse to an estimated 87 million people with the disease in the country by 2030 type 2 diabetes diabetes is a condition that cause a person s blood sugar to become too high at december s global diabetes summit in berlin dr sanjay kalra and his colleague dr ashok k da delivered a speech where they called type 2 diabetes a ticking time bomb for india we need to understand and address the psychosocial domain of diabetes not just the biomedical fact dr kalra told me hiv is caused by relatively few high risk behaviour for diabetes high risk behaviour impact every sphere of life indian society frown upon iv drug use and extramarital sex but happily encourages unhealthy food and promotes inactivity car escalator remote control for tv following our interview dr kalra contacted me via whatsapp to offer a few extra fact did i know that 11 january 2017 mark 95 year since the first insulin injection wa administered in toronto and urbanisation and stress lead to the disease although it doesn t discriminate between class or socioeconomic background and could i please remind our reader that reducing sugar and engaging in physical activity like yoga or something fun like punjabi folk dancing or bhangra will go a long way towards reducing the condition back on the side of the road in calicut i looked at padmanabhan s boarded up shop and back towards my aunt she smiled and took my hand like she had when i wa a child to walk me back to the house

i had endured had brock admitted guilt and remorse and offered to settle early on i would have considered a lighter sentence respecting his honesty grateful to be able to move our life forward instead bos for being kind and understanding to my incredible parent who teach me how to turn pain into strength to my friend who remind me how to be happy to my boyfriend who is patient and loving to my never stop fighting i believe you lighthouse don t go running all over an island looking for boat to save they just stand there shining although i can t save every boat i hope that by speaking today you absorbed a small amount of light a small knowing that you can t be silenced a small satisfaction that justice wa served a small assurance that we are getting somewhere and a big big knowing that you are important unquestionably you are untouchable you are beautiful you are to be valued respected undeniably every minute of every day you are powerful and nobody can take that away from you to title: this is the secret to the insane blt at tom colicchio s new sandwich shop
context: when top chef judge and restaurateur tom colicchio and his business partner sisha ortuzar opened wichcraft 13 year ago they had no idea it would become a enormous a success a it ha or that it ingenious flavor packed sandwich would become synonymous with lunch for so many busy new yorkers back then colicchio and his team already had hit on their hand with craft and craftbar both groundbreaking farm to table restaurant when they first opened in manhattan and wichcraft wa just meant to be a little sandwich shop spinoff ortuzar who wa then one of the chef at craft wa known for doing these great sandwich after work and said hey let s do a sandwich restaurant and that s how wichcraft wa born colicchio told the feast over the year that little sandwich shop ha grown into a ubiquitous chain which just opened it ninth branch and is opening it tenth in grand central this fall thanks to colicchio and ortuzar s knack for creating some of the most thrilling ingredient driven sandwich soup and lunch offering in nyc tom colicchio right with sisha ortuzar still a colicchio himself admits sometimes those lunch order could take a little longer to prepare than a rushed and hungry customer might like now with it brand new location in tribeca colicchio say the reconceived kitchen set up will let the order come out much faster it sandwich like the phenomenal blt will take an average of five minute a opposed to 12 13 minute colicchio said the tweaking and rebranding of wichcraft will soon spread to all shop in the chain and colicchio said he s hoping to expand wichcraft to other city in the near future in the meantime anyone who won t be visiting in person anytime soon can live vicariously through this must try blt recipe which perfect the classic american sandwich the blt is available starting august 1 at the new tribeca location and all the wichcraft shop but for anyone trying the recipe at home there s one crucial secret to making the sandwich come out perfectly colicchio say if you re gonna make a blt you have to have great tomato in season and fresh otherwise don t make it wichcraft blt photo credit peden munk if you re like u you ll be whipping up this sandwich multiple time a week all the way through tomato season in new york that s typically august until early september and that s the only time you ll find this blt on wichcraft s menu the sandwich shop use eckerton hill farm tomato from the union square greenmarket along with berkshire bacon after the season is over it s not just the tomato that ll be gone the sandwich will vanish too wichcraft blt recipe make 4 sandwich 1 pound ripe heirloom or beefsteak tomato sliced 1 2 inch thick tip sit the tomato stem side down on the counter and using a very sharp knife slice it horizontally to prevent the juice from running out 1 pound thick cut bacon 4 large leaf of bibb lettuce 8 slice country bread 4 tablespoon aioli see recipe below sea salt and freshly ground black pepper for the blt in a heavy skillet over medium high heat cook the bacon until golden brown and crisp on both side transfer to paper towel to drain toast the bread on one side only evenly spread the aioli on the toasted side of four slice of bread place the tomato on top of the aioli making sure the slice don t overlap and the surface of the bread is covered season the tomato with sea salt and pepper place the bacon over the tomato followed by the lettuce close the sandwich with the remaining four bread slice toasted side down carefully cut into half and serve for the aioli 1 large egg yolk preferably from a pasture raised egg 1 2 teaspoon dijon mustard 1 2 teaspoon chopped garlic pinch of cayenne pepper 1 tablespoon white wine vinegar 1 cup grapeseed oil 1 2 teaspoon kosher salt freshly ground black pepper place the egg yolk mustard garlic cayenne pepper and vinegar in a food processor or blender start the blender and slowly add the grapeseed oi in a thin even stream when half of the oil ha been added add 1 tablespoon water then slowly add the remaining grapeseed oil and blend until you have a smooth aioli season with the salt and pepper use immediately or store in the refrigerator for 2 to 3 day

least 493 000 a year are saving an average of 25 000 bernie sander is right the top 0 1 percent have a much a the bottom 90 percent kansa s gross domestic product is still le than it wa at the end of 2011 said menzie chinn an economist at the university of wisconsin madison who ha been following kansa s economy meanwhile the economy in the rest of the country continues to expand it s remarkable chinn said it is perhaps le remarkable or surprising that california ha powered along the recovery nationwide ha favored massive metropolitan area stocked with high skilled worker which is to say place such a los angeles san jose and san francisco the damage from california s deep housing crash ha slowly healed in place such a the central valley still the noncoastal region of california lag far behind silicon valley and los angeles in their job and growth recovery the state s median income remains below pre recession level after adjustment for inflation although it still beat the national average will higher tax on the rich derail california s economic comeback few if any economist would say today that the recovery ha been sufficient for all californian but almost no one can say that raising tax on the rich killed that recovery or that given a choice of the two state economic performance over the past few year you d rather be kansa
