title: you probably know to ask yourself what do i want here s a way better question
context: everybody want what feel good everyone want to live a carefree happy and easy life to fall in love and have amazing sex and relationship to look perfect and make money and be popular and well respected and admired and a total baller to the point that people part like the red sea when you walk into the room everyone would like that it s easy to like that if i ask you what do you want out of life and you say something like i want to be happy and have a great family and a job i like it s so ubiquitous that it doesn t even mean anything a more interesting question a question that perhaps you ve never considered before is what pain do you want in your life what are you willing to struggle for because that seems to be a greater determinant of how our life turn out everybody want to have an amazing job and financial independence but not everyone want to suffer through 60 hour work week long commute obnoxious paperwork to navigate arbitrary corporate hierarchy and the blase confines of an infinite cubicle hell people want to be rich without the risk without the sacrifice without the delayed gratification necessary to accumulate wealth everybody want to have great sex and an awesome relationship but not everyone is willing to go through the tough conversation the awkward silence the hurt feeling and the emotional psychodrama to get there and so they settle they settle and wonder what if for year and year and until the question morphs from what if into wa that it and when the lawyer go home and the alimony check is in the mail they say what wa that for if not for their lowered standard and expectation 20 year prior then what for because happiness requires struggle the positive is the side effect of handling the negative you can only avoid negative experience for so long before they come roaring back to life at the core of all human behavior our need are more or le similar positive experience is easy to handle it s negative experience that we all by definition struggle with therefore what we get out of life is not determined by the good feeling we desire but by what bad feeling we re willing and able to sustain to get u to those good feeling people want an amazing physique but you don t end up with one unless you legitimately appreciate the pain and physical stress that come with living inside a gym for hour upon hour unless you love calculating and calibrating the food you eat planning your life out in tiny plate sized portion people want to start their own business or become financially independent but you don t end up a successful entrepreneur unless you find a way to appreciate the risk the uncertainty the repeated failure and working insane hour on something you have no idea whether will be successful or not people want a partner a spouse but you don t end up attracting someone amazing without appreciating the emotional turbulence that come with weathering rejection building the sexual tension that never get released and staring blankly at a phone that never ring it s part of the game of love you can t win if you don t play what determines your success isn t what do you want to enjoy the question is what pain do you want to sustain the quality of your life is not determined by the quality of your positive experience but the quality of your negative experience and to get good at dealing with negative experience is to get good at dealing with life there s a lot of crappy advice out there that say you ve just got to want it enough everybody want something and everybody want something enough they just aren t aware of what it is they want or rather what they want enough because if you want the benefit of something in life you have to also want the cost if you want the beach body you have to want the sweat the soreness the early morning and the hunger pang if you want the yacht you have to also want the late night the risky business move and the possibility of pissing off a person or ten thousand if you find yourself wanting something month after month year after year yet nothing happens and you never come any closer to it then maybe what you actually want is a fantasy an idealization an image and a false promise maybe what you want isn t what you want you just enjoy wanting maybe you don t actually want it at all sometimes i ask people how do you choose to suffer these people tilt their head and look at me like i have twelve nose but i ask because that tell me far more about you than your desire and fantasy because you have to choose something you can t have a pain free life it can t all be rose and unicorn and ultimately that s the hard question that matter pleasure is an easy question and pretty much all of u have similar answer the more interesting question is the pain what is the pain that you want to sustain that answer will actually get you somewhere it s the question that can change your life it s what make me me and you you it s what defines u and separate u and ultimately brings u together for most of my adolescence and young adulthood i fantasized about being a musician a rock star in particular any badass guitar song i heard i would always close my eye and envision myself up on stage playing it to the scream of the crowd people absolutely losing their mind to my sweet finger noodling this fantasy could keep me occupied for hour on end the fantasizing continued up through college even after i dropped out of music school and stopped playing seriously but even then it wa never a question of if i d ever be up playing in front of screaming crowd but when i wa biding my time before i could invest the proper amount of time and effort into getting out there and making it work first i needed to finish school then i needed to make money then i needed to find the time then and then nothing despite fantasizing about this for over half of my life the reality never came and it took me a long time and a lot of negative experience to finally figure out why i didn t actually want it i wa in love with the result the image of me on stage people cheering me rocking out pouring my heart into what i m playing but i wasn t in love with the process and because of that i failed at it repeatedly hell i didn t even try hard enough to fail at it i hardly tried at all the daily drudgery of practicing the logistics of finding a group and rehearsing the pain of finding gig and actually getting people to show up and give a shit the broken string the blown tube amp hauling 40 pound of gear to and from rehearsal with no car it s a mountain of a dream and a mile high climb to the top and what it took me a long time to discover is that i didn t like to climb much i just liked to imagine the top our culture would tell me that i ve somehow failed myself that i m a quitter or a loser self help would say that i either wasn t courageous enough determined enough or i didn t believe in myself enough the entrepreneurial start up crowd would tell me that i chickened out on my dream and gave in to my conventional social conditioning i d be told to do affirmation or join a mastermind group or manifest or something but the truth is far le interesting than that i thought i wanted something but it turn out i didn t end of story i wanted the reward and not the struggle i wanted the result and not the process i wa in love not with the fight but only the victory and life doesn t work that way who you are is defined by the value you are willing to struggle for people who enjoy the struggle of a gym are the one who get in good shape people who enjoy long workweek and the politics of the corporate ladder are the one who move up it people who enjoy the stress and uncertainty of the starving artist lifestyle are ultimately the one who live it and make it this is not a call for willpower or grit this is not another admonishment of no pain no gain this is the most simple and basic component of life our struggle determine our success so choose your struggle wisely my friend this post originally appeared on markmanson net follow iammarkmanson on twitter
question: you probably know to ask yourself what do i want here s a way better question what is a better question to ask oneself

text: what determines your success isn t what do you want to enjoy the question is what pain do you want to sustain the quality of your life is not determined by the quality of your positive experience but the quality of your negative experience

title: the one strange word you re seeing hearing everyone use right now
context: not long after noticing friend and coworkers using slash in everyday conversation i started seeing it cropping up everywhere all the time either spelled out in five character slash or just one i saw it used to tack on subsequent idea that could have been expressed in other perfectly conventional way but they weren t it wa invading text instant message email and even in person dialogue the slash wa being vocalized where it might otherwise appear in written form integrated smoothly into audible discussion since we aren t yet giving other punctuation the same treatment hello exclamation point still sound odd it didn t make much sense after so much time being delegated to such boring utilitarian function a date 8 30 2014 and fraction 3 4 cup the humble slash mark seems to be getting a linguistic makeover anne curzan professor of english at the university of michigan described the practice among student in her classroom last year since then curzan told me in an email she s been studying example of slash usage on twitter the most common use corresponds most closely to and or but she said a fair number are used to connect one idea to another perhaps meaning something like following up or a something like a spoken semi colon still other example use the slash a a way to indicate truth value for the element it connects curzan explained in other word saying one thing when what you really mean is the next like saying you need to rest when what you re really planning is binge watching tv grammatically speaking outside of it role a punctuation the slash also function a a coordinator coordinator also called coordinating conjunction include and but or and other word that function to link independent and dependent clause english speaker are pretty comfortable with this idea a geoffrey k pullum professor of linguistics at the university of edinburgh explained on his blog back in 2010 for example we might invite our friend roommate to go see boyhood while planning to stuff our purse backpack pocket with cheap candy our meaning is clear the person with whom we share a responsibility for rent is also our friend and whatever discreet container we bring to the theater will help u avoid paying five dollar for a box of sour patch kid the slash help u present alternative description pullum suggested however that it really only make sense in lexical rather than phrasal category with clause he wrote i think there is no possibility of using it at all consider i think i m having hallucination slash someone is playing trick on me doesn t seem like english at all doe it these day many english speaker would disagree curzan explicitly noted that the slash can now be used to connect full clause the most interesting implication to me she said is that this coordinator is expanding in use and taking on new meaning usage guideline are of course still very restrictive in formal writing when the style guide and writer handbook i consulted mentioned the slash at all they called it rarely necessary a 1977 edition of theodore bernstein s the careful writer referred to the simple and or a a visual and mental monstrosity that should be avoided tell that to anyone who considers themselves a slash dj to indicate their interest in the turntable art outside of a regular nine to five writer slash dj financial consultant slash dj animal whisperer slash dj or to jezebel editor kara brown who described robin thicke s paula a the singer s most recent album slash lame as attempt at gaining publicity saving his marriage while it d be difficult to pin down exactly why we started going slash crazy it sure seems to correspond nicely with our culture of digital communication abbreviated by a lack of time or screen space or both our technology ha allowed instant messaging to flourish so we might make our always important thought known a quickly a possible the slash work a a stand in whether written or spoken helping the writer express multiple idea without going through the trouble of stringing them together using appropriate grammar or else risking a series of awkwardly short bullet point sentence however strange i m going for a run slash walk in the park sound to your ear it get across the same basic message a the much wordier alternative i m going to run in the park but probably do a fair amount of walking too because running is hard using slash assigned more truth value to walk over run the slash give u a perfect opportunity to say two or more thing at once like this especially if one or more of those thing is our own unsolicited snarky commentary friendship slash rivalry review slash indictment in digital scenario where time is of the essence it might seem counterintuitive that typing slash in the written form would so often take the place of the shorter and equally comprehensible and or or if convenience is such a concern so maybe it speaks then to our comfort with digital communication tool like keyboard and touch screen typing is second nature to u and the slash is an almost mindlessly simple way to link our related thought it s a match made in um some factory in china breakfast slash lunch yum max s restaurant sm mall of asia http t co osswgvkla4 uriel yu medellin itsmeuriel august 4 2014 but will it stick around we can t say to certain linguist though change is actually a great sign change mean that people are using a language and using a language keep it healthy there s not a lot of new slang being formed for example in latin but everyone owns the english language or maybe no one doe and we re not that great at sharing if it is in fact here to stay some grammar stickler will undoubtedly be scandalized at the prospect of a new coordinator which curzan called a category title: are shorter work day better for your health productivity
context: there are 120 hour in a 5 day workweek and for most working american at least a third of that time is spent earning a living sure you ve got 16 ish hour away from the job each day but is that enough time to enjoy all your personal family community and social commitment without becoming a harried frazzled unproductive mess an ongoing study out of sweden seems to indicate that a shorter work day may actually result in more productivity by knocking off 10 hour of work each week for a year employee at a swedish nursing home were able to improve their health cut back on sick leave and enhance the care of their charge the new york time report under the experiment which focused on the future of work in gothenburg employee began working six hour day at the same pay rate a their previous eight hour day one employee say that after just one week he wa more energized and resident said their standard of care had improved what s good is that we re happy one employee tell the time and a happy worker is a better worker while worker reported feeling better about the job and their contribution employer that took part in the experiment found a 30 hour work week sharply reduced absenteeism improved productivity enhanced creativity and reduced turnover we ve had 40 year of a 40 hour workweek and now we re looking at a society with higher sick leave and early retirement daniel bernmar leader of the political party running the trial said we want a new discussion in sweden about how work life should be to maintain a good welfare state for the next 40 year the owner of a start up in stockholm which operates on a six hour day but didn t take part in the study say the shorter day have assisted the small company to double it revenue and profit for the past three year we thought doing a shorter workweek would mean we d have to hire more but it hasn t resulted in that because everyone work more efficiently the owner tell the time since we work fewer hour we are constantly figuring out way to do more with our time sahlgrenska university hospital in gothenburg tried a similar trial last year the hospital s orthopedics unit switched 89 nurse and doctor to a six hour day but unlike the start up it had to hire 15 additional worker while the trial initially cost the hospital an additional 123 000 a month it reduced sick call and increased the efficiency of the title: 3 thing to know about the future of virtual reality
context: delegate use the gear vr virtual reality headset manufactured by samsung electronics co at the samsung unpacked launch event ahead of the mobile world congress in barcelona spain on sunday feb 21 2016 strap on a rectangular black headset and you can traverse a sunken ship at the bottom of the ocean or climb to the top of a snowcapped mountain that s the promise of virtual reality vr headset like the oculus rift and htc vive a impressive a the technology already is many believe it s still in it early day that s because previous virtual reality style effort have flopped in the past nintendo s virtual boy come to mind but the latest crop of gadget are seen a more promising thanks to their much improved graphic head tracking ability and more few have watched virtual reality evolve a closely a the company building the hardware that power it time sat down with frank azor general manager of the dell owned gaming pc manufacturer alienware and nelson gonzalez alienware s cofounder and former ceo to discus what they have learned about vr and where they believe it s headed below are the key highlight from our conversation virtual reality will get more physical anyone who s seen or tried the htc vive know that some physical activity is involved the vive and it two controller are equipped with sensor that allow player to swing a virtual golf club or wield an imaginary paintbrush but what system like the vive or playstation vr currently lack is a sense of touch although it may look like you re swinging a golf club the device in your hand still feel like a video game controller the oculus rift doesn t yet support any motion controller although the company plan to launch such device later in 2016 this is going to be one of the first area in which virtual reality will improve say gonzalez the next evolution of vr would be where you participate physically in that vr world gonzalez said and not just sitting down if you re a quarterback you actually get to throw a football and you can interface with the team so that kind of stuff it s there it s going to happen incorporating better touch control will only be the start azor belief future vr device could refine concept first introduced a far back a 1962 with the sensorama which incorporated element like wind and smell headset today are doing an excellent job at catering to your visual sens and a little bit of audio a well said azor also alienware s fourth employee well that s just two of the sens once you begin catering to the rest of the sens like what we feel body wise temperature wise and smell the reality factor of virtual reality becomes stronger and the virtual piece begin to fade it s unclear exactly how and if technology like those azor described will ever take shape but some company are certainly trying leap motion a startup which launched a motion sensing camera for computer in 2013 is now building technology for interacting with vr environment without a controller startup thalmic lab also make an armband capable of controlling electronic device through gesture that work with the rift vr is an industry wide effort the oculus rift will likely be remembered a the first modern virtual reality headset but it take more than just one device to impact the industry in a meaningful way say azor azor draw comparison to the way the gaming industry developed over the past decade pc became better equipped to deliver high end gaming experience a company like intel amd and nvidia developed more powerful chip and graphic processor game became more accessible on pc a company like steam created platform for easily buying and browsing content everyone rallied around the pc gaming industry and now we have what we have today he said vr is the same type of thing no one company can solve all of the problem a wireless rift or vive won t happen soon there are two class of virtual reality device available today cheaper portable device like the samsung gear vr and google cardboard and beefier expensive system that offer more immersive experience like the rift and the vive the former plug into your smartphone to deliver vr that s wireless and convenient while the latter must be tethered to a pc to power their higher end performance it s unlikely that we ll see a high performance device like the rift go wireless anytime soon mostly because wireless technology isn t advancing at the same pace a vr hardware by the time we solve that a an industry we re going to want to give you version two of the product which is going to become the new benchmark azor said wireless technology is on a different schedule that s where the issue come in the latest and greatest will be wired for a fair amount of time moving forward
question: 3 thing to know about the future of virtual reality what are the three thing that one should know about the future of virtual reality

text: virtual reality will get more physical
vr is an industry wide effort
a wireless rift or vive won t happen soon

title: boeing is making a major change to it plane that could solve the biggest problem with air travel
context: during the development of the 787 dreamliner boeing encountered countless engineering hurdle one of which wa the decision to build much of the plane out of carbon fiber reinforced plastic and other composite material instead of the aluminum most commonly used on commercial airliner while the engineering of the composite airframe may have been a challenge it s a decision that allowed boeing to make a major change to it aircraft that could greatly reduce the effect of jet lag on it passenger the dreamliner ha a composite fuselage and that allowed u to pressurize it at whatever altitude we wanted because the material is not a susceptible to fatigue blake emery director of differentiation strategy for boeing commercial airplane told business insider in an interview currently most airliner have cabin air pressure equivalent to that of an altitude of 8 000 foot for the dreamliner boeing cut that down to 6 000 foot to lower the cabin altitude we actually increased the air pressure inside the cabin emery added it s a bit counterintuitive for most people why doe air pressure matter to passenger for most of u a long flight is usually followed by some combination of symptom that include headache lack of appetite lack of energy nausea and sleeplessness all of these affliction have been conveniently bundled together with a disruption of one s internal body clock to form something we call jet lag but the reality is that jet lag is far more serious the very symptom we attribute to jet lag may actually be attributed to acute mountain sickness which affect individual exposed to altitude above 6 500 foot in a study conducted by oklahoma state university with the help of boeing researcher wrote some passenger on long commercial flight experience discomfort characterized by symptom similar to those of acute mountain sickness the symptom are often attributed to factor such a jet lag prolonged sitting dehydration or contamination of cabin air however because barometric pressure in aircraft cabin are similar to those at the terrestrial altitude at which acute mountain sickness occurs it is possible that some of the symptom are related to the decreased partial pressure of oxygen and are manifestation of acute mountain sickness in 2015 boeing annouced it had made the lightest metal ever the study found that passenger who go from sea level up to 8 000 foot of altitude saw the oxygen content in their blood fall 4 although this didn t trigger full on acute mountain sickness it did bring on what the study called increased prevalence of discomfort after three to nine hour of exposure the research showed passenger body reacted at 6 000 foot similar to that at sea level emery said so we decided to pressurize the dreamliner at 6 000 foot at 6 000 foot the cabin air is more dense and ha a greater level of oxygen saturation a result the body doe not have to work a hard to oxygenate blood and sustain itself according to emery since there isn t a perfect one to one correlation between altitude and jet lag boeing ha taken additional measure to mitigate the symptom these measure include an increase in cabin humidity a well a a new air filtration system why haven t we had this all along the dreamliner won t be the only boeing jet to have a have a lower cabin altitude the company s upcoming 777x wide body mini jumbo jet will also be pressurized at 6 000 foot however unlike the composite dreamliner the 777x boeing s successor to landmark 777 will be primarily made of aluminum aluminum aircraft can be pressurized to 6 000 foot kent craver boeing commercial airplane regional director of passenger satisfaction told business insider in an interview in fact most business jet are already pressurized to that level in addition airbus is also working to lower the cabin altitude on it next generation of airliner airplane maker have traditionally avoided lowering the cabin altitude because boosting the air pressure inside the cabin put greater stress on aluminum airframe this increase the likelihood of metal fatigue and shortens the service life of the airplane however boeing belief it can successfully lower cabin altitude on the 777x without going to a composite body we know the 777 fuselage it structural quality and it fatigue margin really well a boeing spokesperson told u in an email we also understand the requirement of the lower cabin altitude in term of cycle and pressure on the fuselage a a result we can achieve it with a few local reinforcement and change those load out to accommodate lower cabin altitude the boeing 777x is set to enter service in 2019

title: why you should be selfish at work helping others will lead to generosity burnout and can damage your career
context: we re always being encouraged to help others before we help ourselves and in the workplace putting your need before those of your colleague is often seen a selfish behaviour but new research say being selfless at work can backfire giving at the expense of your own well being damage your chance of long term success in an article for the harvard business review wharton school of the university of pennsylvania professor dr adam grant and wharton people analytics researcher reb rebele explore the generosity burnout they believe that selflessness at work lead to exhaustion and ironically often hurt the people you intended to help although giver are the most valuable people in organization they re also at the greatest risk for burnout the author wrote in the harvard business review when they don t protect themselves their investment in others can cause them to feel overloaded and fatigued fall behind in their work goal and face more stress and conflict at home they said in their currently unpublished research author dr grant and mr rebele studied a range of job one data set came from a study conducted with more than 400 teacher in school throughout the u at the start of the year they asked them question about their approach to helping others their answer allowed the author to predict how well their student would do in their exam at the end of the year here is a sample question from their test quoted in business insider 1 prioritise say yes when it matter most 2 give in a way that is in your own interest and preserve your own energy resource 3 don t be afraid to refer work to other people when you don t have time 4 amplify your impact look for way to help many people in a single gesture 5 dedicate block of time to giving rather than doing it all the time it ll make you more focussed and effective 6 avoid people who only take they ll drain your energy source harvard business review imagine that you re teaching a geometry class and you ve volunteered to stay after school one day a week to help one of your student alex improve his understanding of geometry he asks if you ll also help his friend juan who isn t in your class what would you do a schedule a separate after school session to help juan so you can better understand his individual need b invite juan to sit in on your geometry session with alex c tell alex that it s nice that he want to help juan but he really need to focus on his own work in order to catch up d tell alex that juan should ask his own teacher for help surprisingly the pupil with teacher who answered a did the worst in their end of year exam the teacher who protected themselves and were le selfless got their student better mark selfless educator exhausted themselves trying to help everyone with every request the author said in the end they were damaging the very student they wanted to help not only in teaching but selfless people suffer most in workplace and find themselves drowning in admin and unable to pursue their own goal a a result their research also showed people who protect their own time can give the most long term contribution their work show it s about balancing time so when you help other people you don t set yourself back in the process dr grant and mr rebele explain that you need to remember three key thing when giving to other people being thoughtful about how you help when you help and whom you help no one can be available all the time to help other people
question: why you should be selfish at work why should one be selfish at work

title: the bizarre new way to eat egg that ha everyone going crazy
context: cured egg yolk are delicious but strong because they re super salty they re better used a condiment than a the main event for an umami boost try grating them just like cheese over pasta salad avocado toast popcorn or even scrambled egg currently cured yolk aren t even available in the most upscale grocery store so you ll have to make your own even better if you re raising chicken at home and have your own fresh egg on hand fortunately the process couldn t be easier here s how 1 start by combining 1 cup salt and 1 cup sugar in a bowl mix well to combine place half the mixture in a small baking dish 2 separate 4 egg yolk saving the white for another use carefully place each egg yolk on top of the salt sugar mixture and gently sprinkle the yolk with the rest of the salt sugar mixture this photo show the egg before they were completely covered you want them to be totally submerged in the salt sugar mixture cover the baking dish with plastic wrap and refrigerate it for 4 day 3 remove the egg yolk from the fridge after 4 day use a pastry brush to gently brush the salt sugar mixture off of the egg yolk run the yolk under cold water to wash any of the remaining salt sugar mixture off 4 place the yolk on a paper towel to drain and pat off any excess water transfer the yolk to a parchment lined baking sheet and bake them at 150 degree for 2 hour 5 at this point the egg yolk should be semi firm and look sort of like dried apricot use them right away or store them in an airtight container in the refrigerator up to 2 week in case you missed the memo egg yolk are totally good for you they re packed with protein vitamin d and omega 3 and even though egg yolk are high in cholesterol for most people consuming dietary cholesterol doesn t increase your blood cholesterol
question: the bizarre new way to eat egg that ha everyone going crazy what is the new way to eat egg that ha everyone going crazy

title: why you should never pet a service dog
context: flynn the dog doe a lot to help out his 17 year old human hailey ashmore he can open and close door fetch her parent and most importantly alert her to oncoming seizure hailey ha had flynn since november 2014 when the australian shepherd puppy began his training with her a a medical alert dog but when flynn wa only 7 month old a stranger accidentally put hailey in harm s way by stopping to pet flynn and the incident illustrates exactly why working dog should never be pet or played with while they re working hailey ashmore hailey wa visiting her dad at work when someone began petting flynn like he wa just a regular pup i immediately told him to stop hailey told the dodo but in just a moment of distraction flynn had missed a crucial opportunity to warn hailey about an oncoming seizure when he did warn her it wa too late i thought i had 10 minute to get safe take medication and call somebody for help hailey told the dodo unfortunately i didn t and ended up getting a nasty rug burn hailey ashmore since flynn wa only about 7 month at the time of the accident he wa and still is learning to ignore people petting him hailey explained we understand our dog are super cute but they are really important for our safety and health the dog is part of a team jessica reiss of canine companion for independence cci told the dodo it becomes almost an extension of that person just like someone s wheelchair besides the fact that the dog is part of who you are that touching can distract the dog from what they need to do cci is a nonprofit that train assistance dog including companion dog and service dog and then match them to people with disability cci doe not train medical alert dog like flynn hailey ashmore reiss explained that assistance dog are trained to go from being on to off in a few second from hanging out with a chew toy to helping their human in the blink of an eye when stranger stop to play with assistance dog they can interfere with their work they re not a piece of equipment reiss said they can be distracted hailey s story illustrates just how important service animal are for their human and why their vest shouldn t be ignored dog like flynn provide crucial medical assistance and while they re working they need to be 100 percent focused hailey sum it up this way if you wouldn t do it to a wheelchair please don t do it to our dog

title: the annoying question no mom want to hear when she go on vacation
context: last month i left my three child for almost two full week to travel across nicaragua with my stepmother and sister the trip wa full of surprise lizard in our suitcase a couple day on island with no wi fi and no english and day spent doing yoga on the beach to round it all out but what wa perhaps the most baffling part of the whole thing wa the one question i wa asked again and again from fellow mom who is watching your kid if i were a single mother the question might be valid but a a married mom whose husband ha an equal hand in raising our brood to adulthood it s quite astonishing to be asked that question again and again no i didn t hire a babysitter at least not for the night or weekend no i didn t leave them with the grandparent my husband wa with them why would anyone find this shocking ok so it s true the list of daily task for the care and upkeep of three child is seemingly endless from the moment they leap out of bed between 7 and 7 15 to the moment they hit the pillow around 8 or 8 30 the 2 year old must be changed washed brushed soothed fed held rocked amused and watched multiple time a day my 9 year old and 7 year old have homework to supervise friend drama to negotiate permission slip to sign and activity to attend they dress and bathe themselves but someone must be vigilant at all time to keep them on track most popular truth be told i work part time so the bulk of the child duty doe fall to me but my husband know the score he is responsible for preschool drop off every morning he pick up from gymnastics every wednesday and take charge of math homework and making sure our son read for exactly 20 minute every night he change diaper and also ha access to the giant family calendar that hang in our mudroom to track everyone s doctor appointment playdates birthday party and after school activity i might be behind the wheel mostly but he s always next to me in the front seat reading the map so why the question our society is full of all kind of family but our leafy suburb just outside of new york city often feel like there is one kind traditional two parent home where one parent usually the dad work full time while the long suffering mother doe everything with her kid when i went on a business trip for a week two year ago a friend confided in me my husband wouldn t even be able to pack a lunch if i left why are we accepting this a normal my husband regularly go to california for work last year there were long period where he left every tuesday and returned on friday afternoon not once in all those week of lonely night and busy morning did anyone ask him who wa watching the kid it s obvious right daddy get to go out in the world mommy stay home mommy ha it all under control and i do mostly but it s not easy when one spouse travel a job that really belongs to two people suddenly fall to one it s a fact my husband understands well this is why i needed a vacation alone how long are you gone again he texted me on wednesday six day into my 11 day trip i had to laugh but that is all i did because i knew that back home even though he felt like he wa drowning he would doggy paddle his way back to shore somehow my toddler s cot sheet might not get washed for preschool and my son might get a b on a spelling test instead of his usual a because my husband doesn t ride him a hard a i would ve if i wa home but my child would be clean well fed and mostly smiling when i got back and they were my husband is not a babysitter he is a parent just like me being alone with the kid is a challenge even for the most organized and dedicated among u but that doesn t make daddy le capable of it upon my return a friend said she could never do what you did her husband wouldn t be able to keep it together not without massive amount of help and that s exactly the reason to go kid need to know their daddy can care for them a well father have an equal part in creating them and should have an equal role in raising them so go on leave the kid with daddy it s good for everyone and i promise when you do i will never ask you who is taking care of them because i will already know

title: the bottom line homesick for another world by ottessa moshfegh
context: the protagonist of malibu the third short story in ottessa moshfegh s new collection spends his time making up job application so he can continue to receive unemployment benefit and try to coax money out of his aging uncle who ha a colostomy bag and doe little but eat fatty meal in front of daytime tv he s handsome but pimply and given to throwing up after eating he daydream of the beautiful woman he ll one day fall in love with but treat the real woman he meet like inconveniently sentient kleenex oh and then there are his hand a good looking a i wa i wa scared nobody would ever marry me he admits i had small hand they were like a girl s hand but with hair nobody marries men with hand like that when he go to a meet up he s planned with a strange woman he shove his hand down her throat enjoying that he can see how his intrusive hand bulge her neck he recall taking a prostitute to a motel room i sat down next to her and splayed my hand out on the bed what do you think about these i asked nobody ever gave me the answer i wanted nobody ever said oh so beautiful moshfegh s fiction is nothing if not distinctive a in her debut novel eileen the narrator of the 14 story in homesick for another world are gloomy narcissistic and self pitying their life are claustrophobic and squalid they re constantly squeezing their acne having sex with people they despise eating candy and drinking until they re sick developing meth addiction just for kick and always feeling slightly superior to their own surroundings despite their listless life they crave adoration but look on anyone who give it to them with contempt in one story a man ob over a woman who work at a video game arcade he frequents he finally manages to secretly court her via text but quickly loses his interest in her once she seems attainable he took out his phone and reread all her text again i am very lonely and troubled who are you she sounded desperate he thought he had made a grievous mistake he thought in a story called the beach boy a man s wife dy suddenly after their 29th anniversary celebration on a tropical island initially devastated and adrift he then catch sight of an unfamiliar face in the photo he developed from the trip though it s out of focus and context free he s convinced that it wa a picture taken by his late wife of a male prostitute from the island suddenly he s revolted by her the woman he thought wa a lady but who he s now certain wa unfaithful marcia wa gone for good now moshfegh writes after her ash were disposed of and he felt like celebrating the woman in homesick for another world are equally self involved and dismissive of their romantic partner in one story a woman life with her boyfriend who manages a dingy apartment complex while pursuing his dream of acting she quietly loathes him the way he clench his muscle constantly to stay in shape his devotion to a crystal skull he keep by his bed the yellow woman s blazer he bought secondhand and considers the height of manly fashion he develops a meth addiction she never really try to leave in another story a high school english teacher spends her summer in a dying small town subsisting on sub and drug she ha a brief fling with a local i still remember the humility it took for me to agree to take him home she hire a heavily pregnant young woman to clean her home then calmly ignores it when her housekeeper begin to hemorrhage on the job the unpleasant even grotesque behavior of her character seem amplified thanks to moshfegh s cool matter of fact prose in either first person or close third person narration the blunt unemotional word with which her character relate their petty cruelty addiction and even bodily function never cease to be slightly jarring in much fiction writer draw u in by painting the relatable lovable vulnerability within even their most nominally unsympathetic character complicating our impulse to divide the world into good and bad moshfegh s story do the reverse confronting reader with the squicky selfish and sociopathic inner self of even outwardly decent people reading homesick for another world offer a similar experience to watching a dark comedy like the british sitcom peep show there s something refreshing and funny about her unvarnished portrayal of human squalor but also something unsettling and difficult to swallow it s not a book to reassure reader of the essential goodness of the human race it s a queasy jolt to our optimistic self a reminder of the lowest most id driven proclivity of humanity this may sound unappealing yet moshfegh s talent is a sheer delight and the heedless misbehavior of her character is a reminder needed now more than ever that we re not such an elevated specie a we d like to think and that following our base impulse can lead u nowhere fast the bottom line moshfegh s story of selfish people doing foul thing capture the dark side of human nature which is easy but self deluding to ignore what other reviewer think the new york time if there s a thematic thread weaving through this collection it s the complicated relationship between entrapment in the physical body her character are often probing picking and searching with their fingertip a if seeking beauty and potential grace and entrapment in social landscape npr there s not a story in homesick for another world that s anything le than original and perfectly constructed moshfegh s talent is unique and her character unfiltered cold frequently pathetic are all the more memorable for their fault and obliviousness who wrote it ottessa moshfegh ha previously published a novel eileen which wa shortlisted for the man booker prize and wa given the hemingway foundation pen award after her book a noir novel about a miserable and self loathing young woman who work in a detention center wa nominated for the man booker prize she notoriously confessed to the guardian that she d written the book a a joke to get attention she ha published her short fiction in the paris review and the new yorker among other outlet who will read it fan of shocking provocative fiction starring intensely disagreeable character and reader who don t mind being grossed out opening line my classroom wa on the first floor next to the nun lounge i used their bathroom to puke in the morning one nun always dusted the toilet seat with talcum powder another nun plugged the sink and filled it with water i never understood the nun one wa old and one wa young the young one talked to me sometimes asked me what i would do for the long weekend if i d see my folk over christmas and so forth the old one looked the other way and twisted her robe in her fist when she saw me coming notable passage her pretty gleaming calf appeared between the rung of the banister a she came down the step she d folded the cuff of her legging up above her knee which were red from kneeling on the floor when her thigh appeared i saw a black stain of blood at her crotch she seemed not to know that she wa bleeding there wa no way she could have seen the blood past the mountain of her belly i suppose she gripped the bucket with one hand and the railing with the other a she descended the stair oh shit she said when she reached the landing i forgot the broom homesick for another world by ottessa moshfegh penguin press 26 00 published january 3 2017 the bottom line is a weekly review combining plot description and analysis with fun tidbit about the book

title: in the digital age is shopping america s new religion
context: this month art basel global director marc spiegler join cnn style a guest editor he s commissioning a series of feature on the topic of art and technology cnn american qatari artist sophia al maria is preparing for the biggest exhibition of her career her solo show black friday which open at new york s whitney museum of american art on july 26 will comprise over 100 new video screened on a series of broken or rejected consumer electronics the title al maria say is in part a reference to the american national holiday of shopping but also a nod to the holy nature of friday in islam the exhibition posit the thought that shopping mall have become a kind of replacement for religious structure in our contemporary consumer society she say gulf futurism black friday sits comfortably in al maria s roster of project exemplifying of a new generation of creative polymath the writer filmmaker artist ha produced photo directed film written article and screenplay and published a critically acclaimed memoir the girl who fell to earth in her memoir al maria talk about being brought up between two vastly different culture born to an american mother and a qatari bedouin father she spent her childhood in the u before moving to qatar there she experienced the intense and rapid technological and cultural development of the gulf still from the future wa desert part ii 2016 by sophia al maria witnessing this evolution inspired her to coin the term gulf futurism inspired by the idea that time travel had literally occurred in one generation in qatar from a sort of pre agrarian society at least in term of bedouin culture deep into hyper capitalism and consumerism a al maria describes it techno pessimism more than anything gulf futurism is perhaps an investigation into some of the more negative aspect of a hyper connected digital society that can sometimes be a lonely place a perspective al maria describes a techno pessimistic born in 1983 she describes herself a an early digital native part of the first crop of millennials while the rise of the internet wa a key aspect of her formative year her work often deal with the isolating nature of the digital space still from between distant body 2013 by sophia al maria a few year ago i had a real feeling of heaviness through thing like facebook like i wa dragging the ghost of every person i had ever met maybe it doesn t create community in the way that people think because with the ability to post whatever you want at any time you also get the ugly side al maria say planned obsolescence growing up in qatar provided a unique vantage point from which to witness the rapid evolution of history in a commercial and technological sense in black friday al maria will show the tangible result of such development the physical waste produced by a society obsessed with the latest electronic gadget this phenomenon of fervent consumerism also feed into our perception of what constitutes a piece of art the thing is that people s concept of art is still very much object based she explains so even with a video piece people will expect there to be something to play it on while much time is spent thinking of digital art a forward thinking and innovative the cost of this innovation may be a reduced life span for the artwork which have used the technological tool available to them in their time a al maria put it there s planned obsolescence in the device so there s planned obsolescence in the art there s so much work lost it s kind of tragic really

title: 5 essential investing move for millennials
context: if you believe recent report from the web you probably think millennials are financial floozy trading their retirement money for venti latte the reality is probably not that bad but also not a click worthy research from the transamerica center for retirement study indicates that nearly three quarter of millennials are saving for retirement and that we started doing so at an earlier age than previous generation well fargo data show that of those who are saving half are putting away 6 of their income or more what we re not so hot at according to many of these same survey is investing many of u are frightened or confused by the topic and even inclined to put our money in a sock and call it a day that s a problem because investing the money you save is nearly a important a saving it in the first place here are five crucial move millennials can make to overcome their investing anxiety 1 get an education at least this one will be free investing is understandably scary until you learn what you re doing it feel an awful lot like gambling in vega without the free drink there are plenty of resource to guide you through the basic you just have to put in the time khan academy is a good place to start a is nerdwallet s guide on how to invest in stock morningstar ha a good if slightly dated investing classroom and online broker often have a ton of beginner focused educational material on their website 2 say hello to risk risk is kind of like that friend who regularly cancel plan but always come through in a pinch there might be heartache in the day to day but in the long run you ll be glad you stuck it out in investing more risk mean the potential for more reward investment that require you to take on risk like stock have to offer you a premium for doing so could you lose money and never collect that premium sure but that s unlikely when you re in it for the long term history illustrates this a portfolio of 100 stock had an average annual return of 10 1 between 1926 and 2015 according to a study by vanguard a portfolio of 100 bond returned roughly half that averaging 5 4 to put that into real money term if you invested 5 000 for 50 year at a 10 1 return you d have 614 000 at a 5 4 return you d have just 69 000 but a 2015 study from blackrock found that millennials might have a much a 70 of their money in cash meaning a saving account a pillowcase old sneaker at today s historically low interest rate it s all roughly the same that 5 000 becomes just 8 000 at a 1 return in your shoe it stay 5 000 factor in inflation a force that millennials may soon notice for the first time in their adult life and you re actually losing money 3 take that risk through index fund about 70 would be a reasonable stock allocation for your retirement portfolio and even that might be on the low side at this age you should have most of your long term saving invested in stock the best way to do that is not by dumping your money into apple stock but with low cost index and exchange traded fund those fund pool investor money to buy many different investment in one swoop you can buy a couple of fund that hold the stock of u s company one that hold international company and one that hold emerging market company and you ll be reasonably diversified you can learn more about building a diversified portfolio in nerdwallet s piece on investing in your 20 4 put a lid on fee you can t control the ups and down of the stock market what you can mostly control are investing cost fee charged by your index fund called expense ratio administrative fee in your 401 k and transaction fee incurred when you buy and sell investment every dollar that go to these cost is a dollar that reduces your return keep transaction cost down by limiting unnecessary trading and using commission free and no transaction fee fund most broker will have a list of both type of fund if an index fund s expense ratio is more than 0 25 you can likely do better with another 5 use a roth ira or a roth 401 k contribution to a traditional 401 k or ira are made with pre tax dollar you pay tax when you take distribution in retirement but you can also pay tax now and spare your future self the burden by choosing a roth ira check roth contribution limit to gauge your eligibility or the roth version of your 401 k if your employer offer that option why choose a roth if your income is lower now than it will be later a likely scenario for many young professional you re locking in at lower tax rate and because you re not getting a tax benefit now you get to pull out the money both your contribution and investment growth tax free in retirement to see how valuable that is use a roth ira calculator
question: 5 essential investing move for millennials what are the five essential investing move for millennials

supporter materialized for his rally seemingly spontaneously but even with all of the new trump spending hillary clinton s campaign began to surge black and hispanic voter cast record number of absentee ballot and flocked to the early voting poll by tuesday morning democrat felt confident they could ride out the wave of what they knew would be a surge of republican voter who tend to vote in greater force on election day about 1 p m one source with clinton s campaign said the democrat were worried republican were crushing the vote in the panhandle southwest florida and smaller conservative leaning county by 5 p m our voter showed again the source not authorized to speak by the campaign said we felt pretty good the size of the vote wa historic in populous democratic stronghold like broward miami dade and palm beach county but turnout wa even higher in republican area by the end of the night trump s lead wa so big that even if turnout in florida wa modeled at 80 percent far higher than recent election clinton would still not win if she beat trump by double digit clinton s campaign wa almost reduced to a regional effort confined to the southeastern peninsula she won a stunning 571 000 more vote than trump in the miami fort lauderdale medium market one of ten in the state according to state election data posted after midnight she won three lesser market west palm a 44 000 vote lead gainesville 10 000 more vote and tallahassee 11 000 more vote trump blew away record in the tampa bay medium market the western edge of the vaunted i 4 corridor that help swing election in the county composing the market trump rolled up a 193 000 vote lead over clinton in the jacksonville market in the northeast he pulled in 165 000 more vote he held vote lead of 144 000 in naples fort myers market 126 000 in the pensacola market 83 000 in the panama city market and 58 000 in the orlando market which anchor the eastern end of the i 4 corridor one of trump s pollster tony fabrizio said the result showed that clinton exceeded president obama s margin in the florida market he won in 2012 but obama only carried florida by le than a point the difference here is that trump did far better than mitt romney did in almost every county on election day fabrizio said trump began election day down by at least 57 000 vote to clinton according to result posted on the florida division of election website just after the last florida poll closed at 7 p m central time but after that a election day vote poured in trump began building a margin that stretched to more than 100 000 by 8 30 p m by 9 10 p m trump s margin started to peak at just under 150 000 vote over clinton it started to trend down but not fast enough for the liking of democrat who just two hour before were musing about how trump had lost florida and therefore the white house so go florida so go the country said florida s senior senator bill nelson look at the hispanic turning out often the hispanic are registered no party affiliation but the young hispanic they ll be voting for hillary nelson and other democrat also expected clinton to pad her margin with african american support but while clinton rolled up vote with non white voter white voter appeared to heavily trend toward trump and white are still a majority of florida s voter roll 64 percent by registration and they vote in even greater number their outsized support counteracted the vote of hispanic and black 16 percent and 13 percent of the voter roll respectively trump s strong showing call into question those who believed his inflammatory comment about immigration reform would ultimately cost him florida trump s position put him at loggerhead with the spanish language powerhouse network univision which ha studio in the same city a his doral golf club my theory is that no one can make it to the wh without the latino vote it seems realdonaldtrump ha a different theory see you nov 8th univision pundit jorge ramos wrote june 3 on twitter repeating his oft held maxim proven wrong in this instance by trump about the power of the hispanic vote florida is also a retiree mecca with one of the oldest population in the country and poll after poll showed that the older the voter the more they liked trump most major survey also showed trump losing the state including exit poll on election day this wa a data defying feat that captured a populist fervor we just couldn t measure said one republican pollster who wa surprised by trump s number the trump campaign kept talking about the missing white voter well they showed up on election day in myriad way trump succeeded despite the conventional wisdom trump s campaign initially didn t run a robust absentee ballot program to get voter to fill out and mail back their vote he delayed advertising on television a must for any other statewide candidate and he refused at time to soften his tone on immigration trump didn t run a robust program in south florida targeting the hispanic community you could make an argument that his past statement about immigration and illegal immigrant made it impossible said curt anderson top adviser to gov scott the chair of the pro trump super pac but when gov scott won he did so because he really reached out if trump had we wouldn t be talking right now he would have florida in the bag maybe he ll win because of what s in the countryside so to speak or the panhandle but this is really doing it the hard way the florida meltdown is a familiar story for democrat still scarred by al gore s 2000 loss to george w bush in a razor close race though obama won the state twice both time were by narrow margin built on the strength of his appeal to minority voter in the state but the vaunted obama machine in florida wa no machine without obama on the ticket now democrat face a bleak prospect of the coming midterm election when liberal leaning voter tend to stay away from the poll while republican keep voting sen nelson s team fear a showdown with scott who ha won twice based on the strength of white voter and an outsider message clinton ally expressed increasing optimism about their chance in the state heading into election day energized by early vote result that showed hispanic turnout exploding exit poll reinforced that optimism showing clinton with a narrow lead and demographic trend pointing her way trump s strength wa no surprise to republican party of florida chairman blaise ingoglia who earlier in the day said republican had more energized voter who couldn t wait until election day to cast ballot we had the advantage in high propensity voter and they didn t ingoglia said but ultimately this is a message to the establishment it s an anti establishment year

called universal basic income or ubi while it s far from mainstream acceptance ubi is viewed by some a a mean to provide worker with economic stability a an increasing amount of the world s labor is simplicity in the sense that it s just direct cash and you can spend it however you want here s what you should know about ubi what is universal basic income in it most pure form a government would send all citizen a certain annual income to everyone regardless of their salary age or employment status typically in installment throughout the year in reality it get a little more complicated sending money to every single citizen is expensive so most ubi proposal involve some limit on who is eligible for the money minor and the already wealthy for instance might get smaller check limit aside the general point remains the same almost everyone get a check from the government to spend without restriction why is it popular the basic concept ha intellectual root dating back to at least the 18th century some on the political left have supported ubi a tool to redistribute wealth to the poor and provide a mean to improve people s quality of life while some on the right have seen it a a way to make the existing welfare state more efficient while promoting individual choice and reducing welfare trap despite sporadic support on both side of the aisle ubi ha historically remained on the policy fringe many worry that a basic income could reduce the incentive to work slowing the economy another concern is whether providing a basic income is the best way to spend public fund that could be specifically targeted to certain group in need the model most welfare program currently follow however a confluence of factor have started to push basic income into the mainstream rising inequality title: we shopper aren t to blame for food waste guess who is
context: l ast year ast year tesco s food waste mountain amounted to 59 400 tonne if you re finding that figure hard to envisage it s the equivalent of 119m meal and an increase of 4 on the year before from this we can deduce that tesco s voluble commitment to reducing it edible detritus ha yet to yield result but is tesco any worse in this respect than any other supermarket chain probably wisely the others don t publish their waste figure but let s just assume that if they had a better story to tell u we d already know all about it tesco s waste tally is certainly grotesque but pr executive expert in technique for smoothing over corporate difficulty would doubtless applaud the masterly way tesco deflected criticism on the day that his chain s depressing result were published chief executive dave lewis addressed a food industry summit where he exhorted food manufacturer to do more to reduce their waste across the supply chain after deftly passing the waste ball back to his supply base lewis reprised a favourite supermarket refrain blame the consumer while the majority of food waste arises from the home industry recognises the need to lead by example there you have the dramatis persona in tesco s food waste script profligate consumer supplier who earn a must work harder rating and enlightened tesco leading the vanguard in the national war on waste just in case you aren t finding the plot line 100 credible a further emotional strand is woven in tesco promise to redistribute all it unsold edible food to charity from 2017 putting a gloss on your waste problem by repackaging it a a food poverty solution is a tactic increasingly deployed by our major supermarket ideally from a supermarket pr point of view the term food poverty would appear in every headline that contains supermarket food waste for that allows our giant retailer to bask in the role of philanthropist who use their corporate might for the common good it place a halo of saintliness around all their business activity but a waste prevention strategy should never be confused with a poverty reduction strategy crumb from the rich man s table is a shallow and too easily self aggrandising response to the unacceptable reality that million of fellow citizen can t afford to eat good fresh food what s more the red herring of food poverty draw attention further away from one essential fact about supermarket we must digest if we are ever to make any progress waste is hard wired into the supermarket system when the supermarket began colonising the uk grocery market in the early 1980s they appeared to be a newer more efficient way of feeding the nation they promised vast economy of scale by virtue of their collective buying power and state of the art distribution logistics that would bring every agricultural product on the planet to our shelf 365 day a year this precision shopping model we were assured would produce dividend for consumer in the form of lower price and more convenient shopping who need parade of small independent shop when chain can feed u so much more efficiently and for le once we sniffed the milk and pared mould off cheese now we live in dread of food poisoning four decade on it s becoming obvious that supermarket are incapable of delivering this promise why they are retail dinosaur locked into a system that s riddled with problem one such glaring issue is food waste far from discouraging it the supermarket business model actively begets it there aren t to my knowledge any robust statistic on level of food waste in british household before the supermarket era but i d hazard a guess that they were much lower than they are now our rubbish bin really started filling up when instead of shopping for a little a wa needed every day or two we were persuaded to adopt the one stop supermarket shopping trip theoretically armed with a list we could buy all the food we needed for a week nowadays supermarket online ordering make that even easier to do just press the same a last week option so supermarket egg u on to overlook what we already have and to buy much more than we need they encourage u to hazard a weekly guess about what we ll consume rather than focusing on what s in our fridge and larder day to day if the untouched remnant of last week s order are stacking up in the fridge when the supermarket van arrives at our door most people will consign them to the bin schooled to believe thanks to supermarket use by and best before date that judging freshness is best left to distant expert once we sniffed the milk and pared mould off cheese now we live in dread of poisoning better safe than sorry surely but sell by date the progenitor of use by and best before were introduced by supermarket a stock rotation tool to help clunky mammoth chain keep tab on the unprecedented amount of product passing through their system not primarily a safeguard against food poisoning undoubtedly certain food sold by supermarket do pose a very real risk to health around two third of their raw chicken are contaminated with potentially lethal campylobacter at the point of sale even though they are well within their use by date yet again supermarket point the finger of blame at the stupid sloppy home cook who fails to slay the bacteria through thorough cooking rather than eradicating infection at their factory farm and don t forget that supermarket have actively undermined our national food handling experience and skill by telling u that we re too time poor to cook from scratch largely because it is much more profitable for them to sell u value added processed food whose apparent freshness is validated by reassuring date the bottom line here is that such date are absolutely no guarantee that food is truly fresh or safe yet they shape our daily decision about what we eat and what we bin battalion of quango non governmental organisation government agency and charity see supermarket a ally in the war on food waste but in reality they are a huge part of the problem if we are to stop waste at source we must look to and learn from the burgeoning grassroots initiative that aim to relocalise and scale down our food chain
question: th guardian we shopper aren t to blame for food waste guess who is who is responsible for food waste

title: how ha stephen hawking lived past 70 with al
context: an expert on lou gehrig s disease explains what we know about this debilitating condition and how hawking ha beaten the odds editor s note renowned theoretical physicist stephen hawking died on march 14 2018 at age 76 this story originally published on his 70th birthday on january 7 2012 is being resurfaced to explain how he beat the odds and lived so long with the disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis al stephen hawking turn 70 on sunday beating the odds of a daunting diagnosis by nearly half a century the famous theoretical physicist ha helped to bring his idea about black hole and quantum gravity to a broad public audience for much of his time in the public eye though he ha been confined to a wheelchair by a form of the motor neuron disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis al and since 1985 he ha had to speak through his trademark computer system which he operates with his cheek and have around the clock care but his disease seems hardly to have slowed him down hawking spent 30 year a a full professor of mathematics at the university of cambridge and he is currently the director of research at the school s center for theoretical cosmology but like his mind hawking s illness seems to be singular most patient with al also known a lou gehrig s disease for the famous baseball player who succumbed to the disease are diagnosed after the age of 50 and die within five year of their diagnosis hawking s condition wa first diagnosed when he wa 21 and he wa not expected to see his 25th birthday why ha hawking lived so long with this malady when so many other people die so soon after diagnosis we spoke with leo mccluskey an associate professor of neurology and medical director of the al center at the university of pennsylvania to find out more about the disease and why it ha spared hawking and his amazing brain what is al and is there more than one form of it al which is also known a a motor neuron disease and colloquially a lou gehrig s disease in the u s is a neurodegenerative disease each muscle is controlled by motor neuron that reside in the brain in the frontal lobe these are controlled electrically and are synaptically connected to motor neuron that reside lower down in the brain a well a motor neuron that reside in the spinal cord the guy in the brain are called the upper motor neuron and the guy in the spine are called the lower motor neuron the disease cause weakness of either upper motor neuron or lower motor neuron or both it s been known for quite some time that there are variant of al one is referred to a progressive muscular atrophy or pma it appears to be an isolated illness of the lower motor neuron however pathologically if you do an autopsy of a patient they will have evidence of deterioration of upper motor neuron there is also primary lateral sclerosis pls and clinically it look like an isolated upper motor neuron disorder however pathologically they also have lower motor neuron disorder the other classic syndrome is called progressive baldor palsy or progressive supranuclear palsy which is weakening of cranial muscle like the tongue face and swallowing muscle but it pretty much always spread to limb muscle those are the four classic motor neuron disorder that have been described and it wa thought for quite some time that these disorder were limited to motor neuron it s now clear that that s not true it s now well recognized that 10 percent of these patient can develop degeneration in another part of the brain such a other part of the frontal lobe that don t contain the motor neuron or the temporal lobe so some of these patient can actually develop dementia called frontal temporal lobe dementia one of the misconception about al is that it s only a motor neuron disease and that s not true what ha stephen hawking s case shown about the disease one thing that is highlighted by this man s course is that this is an incredibly variable disorder in many way on average people live two to three year after diagnosis but that mean that half the people live longer and there are people who live for a long long time life expectancy turn on two thing the motor neuron running the diaphragm the breathing muscle so the common way people die is of respiratory failure and the other thing is the deterioration of swallowing muscle and that can lead to malnutrition and dehydration if you don t have these two thing you could potentially live for a long time even though you re getting worse what s happened to him is just astounding he s certainly an outlier ha he lived so long because he got the disease when he wa young and had the juvenile onset type juvenile onset is diagnosed in the teenage year and i don t know enough about his course to say but it s probably something similar to juvenile onset disorder which is something that progress very very very slowly i have patient in my clinic who were diagnosed in their teen and are still alive in their 40 50 or 60 but not having ever examined him or taken a history it s a little hard for me to say he s a very good example of the sparing of the non motor part of the brain that can occur how frequent are these case of very slow progressing form of al i would say probably le than a few percent how much do you think stephen hawking s longevity ha been due to the excellent care that he ha received versus the biology of his particular form of al it s probably a little bit of both i just know him from television so i don t know what kind of intervention he s had if he really isn t on a ventilator then it s his biology it s the biology of his form of the neurodegenerative disease that determines how long he will live for trouble swallowing you can elect to have a feeding tube placed which basically take malnutrition and dehydration off the table but mostly it s about the biology of the disease hawking obviously ha quite the active mind and previous statement that he ha made seem to indicate he ha a pretty positive mental outlook despite his condition is there any evidence that lifestyle and psychological well being do much to help with patient outcome or is the disease usually too quick for that to make a difference i don t believe that add to longevity al still doesn t have a cure what have we learned about the disease recently that might help u find one or at least better treatment beginning in 2006 it became clear that like a lot of other neurodegenerative disease al wa determined by the accumulation of abnormal protein in the brain ten percent of al is genetic and based on a gene mutation i m sure there are also at risk gene for al but there are now multiple gene that have been identified a potentially causing the disease each one of them are interesting in that they lead to the accumulation of different protein in the brain knowing specific gene give u particular mechanism in the brain and would potentially give u target for therapy but none of this ha given u any robust therapy yet what doe stephen hawking s case mean for people who have the disease it s just an incredible incredible example of the variability of the disease and the hope for patient who have it that they could also live a long life unfortunately it s a small percentage of people for whom that actually happens
