title: blocking blue light help sleep
context: the disruptive effect of artificial light on sleep are well documented and have received an increasing amount of attention in recent year with good reason nighttime exposure to artificial light which for the great majority of u happens without much thought or awareness disrupts the body s circadian rhythm altering the 24 hour biological clock that control our sleep wake cycle in addition to wreaking havoc with sleep disruption to circadian rhythm also have been associated with a number of serious disease including cancer diabetes depression and heart disease in particular research in recent year ha shown that blue wavelength light is especially harmful to circadian rhythm function study have shown that blue wavelength light ha uniquely harmful effect on human and suppresses melatonin level more vigorously than other light wavelength unfortunately many energy efficient light source produce high concentration of blue light blue light is emitted by electronic device energy efficient light bulb and other common light source research investigating blue light blocking most often in the form of goggles that filter out this particular wavelength of light ha shown promise a new study of cataract patient indicates that artificial lens implant can help improve sleep scientist at china s sichuan university studied the effect of blue light blocking artificial lens implanted during cataract surgery the study involved 40 patient who required surgery for cataract in both eye cataract surgery commonly involves removal of the eye s damaged lens and insertion of an artificial lens cataract are a common condition among older adult approximately 60 percent of people over the age of 60 experience cataract the study subject 26 woman and 14 men with an average age of 74 were given artificial lens with blue light blocking capability researcher assessed patient sleep quality before surgery and again two month after surgery they found patient sleep had improved significantly across several measure patient were sleeping more during the night their sleep quality had improved their level of daytime dysfunction due to sleepiness had diminished the number of subject who met the criterion for poor sleeper had decreased lens replacement surgery is necessary for cataract patient but there are other le invasive way to filter out blue light that are also being investigated by sleep scientist research ha shown the benefit to sleep of manipulating and controlling exposure to blue light a study of 20 adult who wore either blue light blocking or ultraviolet light blocking glass for three hour before sleep found that both sleep quality and mood improved among those in the group who wore blue light blocking glass compared to the ultraviolet light blocking group shift worker are at especially high risk for circadian rhythm disruption because of their non traditional schedule in a study by scientist at quebec s universite laval nightshift worker used blue light blocking glass at or near the end of their overnight shift for four week at the end of study period their overall sleep amount increased a did their sleep efficiency while nighttime exposure to blue wavelength light is damaging to circadian rhythm exposure to blue light isn t always detrimental daytime exposure to blue light can stimulate alertness and help sleep later on a study of 94 office worker found that daytime exposure to blue light during work hour resulted in improvement both to sleep and to daytime functioning compared to exposure to white light subject who were exposed to blue light experienced improvement to daytime alertness mood and concentration these subject also experienced decrease in daytime sleepiness and they slept better at night this area of research is critically important and i expect we will see a great deal more investigation into the effect of blue wavelength light on sleep and health but you don t need special goggles or eye lens implant to protect your circadian rhythm and your sleep from the negative effect of artificial light here are some low tech suggestion that can help you limit exposure to artificial light in the hour before bed the last 1 2 hour before bed should be a time of winding down and preparing for sleep decreasing your exposure to light is an important part of this process you don t have to sit in a pitch black room but you should think about beginning to limit your exposure to bright light whether from your computer screen or your television reading under moderate lamplight is fine if you re using a tablet to read bring the screen s brightness level down make the last 60 minute of your bedtime ritual electronics free and keep electronic gadget and device out of the bedroom altogether get light exposure during the day daytime exposure to light both sunlight and artificial light can help strengthen circadian rhythm and boost daytime alertness leaving you better prepared to sleep when the time come if you need access to light in the middle of the night use small nightlights rather than switching on hallway or bathroom light and flooding your system with melatonin suppressing light use low illumination night light to guide you when you need to get up in the dark being aware of the effect of nighttime exposure to light and making some basic change to bedtime routine can go a long way toward getting you the darkness you need to sleep well even in this ever bright modern age
question: blocking this color light may help you sleep better what is the effect of blocking color light on sleep

title: here s why new york city smell so rancid in the summer
context: for traveler with the gleam of the big apple in their eye nothing seems better than new york city in the summertime restaurant have outdoor seating there are festival all over town and you don t have to worry about bringing your jacket to top of the rock but long time city dweller know the horror behind the mystique those awful smell that dominate every daily commute to and from the office here s why it s hard to escape the stench of the city in the heat of summer new york city ha the highest population density in the u and with 8 550 405 people roaming the nation s melting pot it s bound to get smelly a census conducted in july 2015 showed that the city had a population density of over 27 000 people per square mile to put that into perspective the u on average hold only 80 people per square mile that much combined body odor alone could be enough to scare anyone away with such an insanely huge number of people living in just one city it should come a no surprise that there is also an insanely huge amount of garbage produced although resident of the city produce 12 000 ton of waste every day new york city doesn t have any of it own landfill or incinerator garbage pile up in dumpster until it can all be taken across the hudson river to be incinerated in new jersey or if possible recycled locally and overseas but even after most of this waste ha been incinerated across the river strong wind can still carry the stench back over to the city on a hot day the sheer amount of garbage isn t the only problem there also ha to be a way to get all of it out of the city diesel truck carry garbage out of manhattan 7 8 million time each year let this sink in that s the same a driving around the earth 312 time and that s just for one city all this driving only add to pollution and the greenhouse effect causing the city to become warmer and smellier a time continues you may also be wondering why those subway vent on every block smell so much more putrid on a steamy summer day or how it is possible to smell a food cart from all the way down the street it turn out the combination of heat and humidity allow bacteria to grow faster and smell to travel further increasing temp mean molecule move faster resulting in enzyme speeding up metabolism and cell quickly increasing in size heat is bacteria s best friend so when you get stuck with one those incredibly humid day smell become only more potent the water in the air cause these odor to dissolve trapping them longer than if it were a dry day outside to many new york is the city of dream but you have to be willing to accept it for the good the bad and the smelly

title: man investigates a strange noise coming from a dumpster and make a stunning discovery
context: investigating strange cry emanating from a west virginia dumpster sound like the start of a horror movie chance are there would be nothing inside one of those that would make your day any better but james butler might disagree with you there james wa strolling through coonskin park a riverside sliver of nature located in kanawha county west virginia when he heard a strange noise coming from one of the dumpster there curiosity piqued he investigated only to discover something that had him fumbling for his camera retired west virginia police officer and aviation enthusiast james butler heard strange cry coming from a charleston west virginia dumpster on tuesday august 11 2015 curious he investigated the sound right away he noticed two thing five raccoon were trapped inside the coonskin park trash receptacle and one of those raccoon wa like nothing he d ever seen before a to how they got stuck james said the dumpster had apparently been emptied and the garbage level wa low and the raccoon couldn t reach the top to get back out and that rare raccoon he didn t really look like like his family member or like any raccoon james had ever seen this trashmonger wa an albino raccoon an incredibly rare specimen according to the indiana division of fish and wildlife how rare exactly the organization stated only one in 750 000 raccoon inherit the albino gene a mutation that mean the animal creates no melanin and therefore ha no pigmentation stunned by his find james didn t forget the real trouble at hand these raccoon were stuck thinking quickly james fabricated a little something to help the raccoon escape their trash pit prison a wood plank he leaned it on the inside of the dumpster and the raccoon could use it like a ramp they were free but that brought consequence the albino raccoon had been a well kept secret in coonskin park according to rodney jones chief of kanawha s park police department and once james shared his picture online officer jones feared it would become the subject of the public s curious camera now that the albino s getting publicity rodney said i figure people will start looking to see if they can find it around the park and people searching for a wild animal with a wild animal s instinct can be trouble we try to tell people with animal to keep their distance and don t try to feed them he said after emphasizing that raccoon carry deadly disease i d really hate to see an animal like that be destroyed because of someone s curiosity or stupidity worse the albino raccoon s appearance can make it a prize in the eye of some people something special that need to be captured or owned such wa the case with a four year old albino raccoon in georgia for part of her early life isi the albino raccoon had a miserable existence because of her unique look someone captured her and locked her in a small wire cage intending to use her for a taxidermy project luckily there wa good news in store for her the georgia department of natural resource rescued isi and delivered the raccoon to maxine rainey below director of the georgia animal sanctuary a new hope but both the sanctuary and the department of natural resource feared she wa a lost cause understandably isi wa aggressive human touch scared her and she lashed out at anyone trying to help her since she wa described a so aggressive maxine said we were just going to hold her for a couple of day but then what when maxine accepted the albino raccoon she gave the poor animal a look over she had urine burn smelled horrendous wa obese losing hair and had sore all over her foot no wonder she wa aggressive maxine though had hope for the poor animal she sat in the enclosure with the animal that by all account should ve been trying to tear her head off if she got too close but amazingly that didn t happen i d been going through some stuff in my personal life maxine said and i wa kind of having a sad day so i sat by her and she came right up to me she came up and sniffed me and put her little hand in my hand from there the raccoon s life only got better she s so gentle maxine said she spent the last couple day glued to my side sleeping on my lap having me carry her around i just saw a complete 180 degree flip in her personality the minute she wa exposed to some kindness for a raccoon once deemed so aggressive she had to be kept away from other raccoon at the facility that s a pretty glowing review but the story of isi only underscored the worry of rodney jones the chief of kanawha s park police department people like james butler are often fascinated with animal that are different and unique but it s important to remember they re wild animal potentially dangerous and capable of love and affection they re to be admired from afar james had the right idea when he saw the albino raccoon he took some photo set him free from the dumpster and let him go on his way hopefully others lucky enough to spot one of these beautiful beast in nature take the same approach

title: we calculated how long it would take to do everything buzzfeed tell you to do before you die
context: it s hard to look at buzzfeed without being reminded of your mortality the site spit out a seemingly never ending bucket list of thing we absolutely must do before we die place to see book to read urinal to pee in and a we all inch closer to our imminent death buzzfeed creates more and more of these article making it seemingly impossible to accomplish all of these thing before we kick the can if you re a young and bored a i am though you might wonder could you pull it off could you actually check everything off the buzzfeed bucket list and if so how long would it take a little while ago i set out to find out for myself here s how i did it first i had to compile all of the list buzzfeed ha published in it before you die format at the time i filed this story there were 182 list these ranged from appreciating the little thing in life like watching the sunset to full blown adventure like going to south africa s version of burning man buzzfeed writer also seem obsessed with food since practically every other list is about stuffing your face with 21 amazing aussie burger or the ten best new orleans po boy or the 15 best cheese toasties in london next i cataloged each task on each of the 182 list there are over a thousand individual task on motherboard counting the hour i ve spent on the internet next i calculated the time it would take to complete each of the task this is where it all got slightly more complicated since the time it would take to do most of these thing is highly individualized eating fish and chip for example how long doe that take the average person if you were really vying for time you could probably scarf some down in five minute but i d much prefer to spend an hour savoring of a nice greasy plate and what if the restaurant wa really busy and it took a long time for your server to bring the fish and chip to you i settled on 30 minute for eating fish and chip a well a the other food related task other task required a fair amount of research like hiking the camino de santiago otherwise known a st james path between spain and france which is le like a path and more like a pilgrimage the trail is nearly 500 mile long according to the trail s official website it take four to six week to complete i decided to allot 30 day to complete the trail even though the website also noted that you would need to hike 18 mile per day without any rest day to finish the trail in that time which seems completely insane i repeated this process for every single task on buzzfeed s list again there are over a thousand individual task here is a time table showing a small sample of the time i allotted for certain task some of the list contained fast easy task that be completed entirely from your couch like this one which requires you to look at 20 picture of miniature pig before you die but for most of them you have to travel some of the list like the five highest place to visit before you die require you to jet set from the haiku stair of oahu hawaii to the petronas tower of kuala lumpur malaysia to the taihang mountain in china in order to accomplish all of the task most effectively you would need to travel the world so i decided to calculate the travel time that it would take to work your way around the world in an order most efficient for accomplishing each of the buzzfeed task i decided to begin my hypothetical bucket list journey in boston where i live and work my way west through north america i would visit 36 state in the united state and stop in canada and mexico along the way then onto the dominican republic to explore the three shipwreck of bayahibe followed by stop at turk and caicos and belize some stop later i d spend 175 hour and ten minute flying from country to country in europe stopping in estonia to see the beech tree in hiiumaa before taking a quick ten minute flight over to finland to go to the kontula indoor skatepark in helsinki i d make my way over to turkey to swim in the crystal blue mineral water of the pamukkale spring in hierapolis and then pop over to jordan to grab a drink at the cave bar in petra i whittled the travel time down to one hour flight over border stopping in some country for only a few minute to visit a bakery or for a few hour to watch a sport game in total the round the world trip would take 26 day in travel time alone and would include 108 country the last thing i calculated wa sleep time i figured a person would be fairly tired after spending month on end climbing mountain reading play and visiting museum every day so i allotted the doctor recommended eight hour per night i really enjoy sleeping so this is painful for me to even imagine but when you re racing to finish an extensive bucket list in the fastest amount possible i suppose luxuriating in the rem cycle shouldn t be a priority i also factored in how long it took me to calculate the trip around 40 hour in total and how long it would take to actually book the flight hotel and day trip which would be possibly twice that in conclusion drumroll please i determined it would take 1 448 7 day to do everything that buzzfeed say you need to do before you die that s 207 week or just shy of four year i ll repeat that some of the timing calculation were arbitrary you could get stuck in a restaurant with poor service and it might take double the time to eat your fish and chip or you could arrive somewhere like the trinity church on king george island in antarctica and decide it wa too boring to stay the full hour your flight could get delayed or you could get food poisoning at one of the restaurant and choose to bail on the next day s activity if you got the timing wrong you might miss the small window when all 39 christmas market on the list are open or arrive at the mendenhall ice cave in juneau alaska to find that they have all melted but if you planned it just right and you had the time money and stamen to accomplish everything on the list then you could definitely do it that said i m not sure why anyone would want to there are a lot of thing on that list that i personally have no interest in doing why should i visit 39 different christmas market across europe i mean i m sure they re beautiful and each have nice hot chocolate and giant neon candy cane but what s the harm in not seeing all 39 of them is it really worth the hour it would take to learn all 44 of these air guitar song would i really be a lesser person for not having visited these 19 penis shaped object around the world i m not saying i wouldn t do it if someone offered me the chance to travel the world and see some of the coolest thing this earth ha to offer i d be hard pressed to say no of course i ll probably die before that happens buzzfeed ha a handy quiz for that too
question: we calculated how long it would take to do everything buzzfeed tell you to do before you die what is the duration of time calculated in the sentence

title: the real reason people write so much about mad men you keep clicking
context: one of the most consistent criticism of mad men from those who aren t mad men fan is that sniff derisively it s only beloved by the coastal medium elite because it s about rich white people who live glamorous life and work in advertising that strain of criticism became all the more pronounced in the buildup to the amc drama s series finale with vulture launching the latest broadside against the show s popularity a author michael idov argued that it wasn t truly popular just overhyped to support his claim he point in part to the show s lack of an audience in russia to some degree this is true back when the series debuted the medium wrote about mad men to a level far exceeding it actual rating the first season s viewership number dipped below the 1 million mark a few time a much more perilous event in an age when dvrs and streaming service were le prevalent but by season two the award and critical attention mad men garnered ended up boosting those number to more comfortable level and even if the show wa never a smash hit it had a long healthy run still there are a bunch of good mostly reductive reason for the medium to keep in idov s word shoving mad men down reader throat here are five 1 reader wanted to read about it in my pre vox life i wa the tv editor of the a v club a position that gave me unique insight into what sort of tv content reader wanted to consume and every time we wrote about mad men those number spiked the show wa consistently among the top five series we wrote about in term of readership and a well timed thinkpiece always had the potential to blow up the mad men audience overlap so neatly with the audience of people who read about tv on the internet that the venn diagram of the two might a well be a single circle this ha carried right over to vox we write a lot about the show because there s a huge audience out there ready to devour mad men content far beyond any other show i ve written about here that s not game of throne the mad men audience overlap so neatly with the audience of people who read about tv on the internet that the venn diagram of the two might a well be a single circle yes the huge explosion of commentary in the day preceding the show s finale wa driven by how much many of u in the medium liked the show but it wa also driven by the fact that our reader wanted to see this sort of material some of that wa an accident of timing 2 mad men debuted right after the soprano ended and filled the void the show left when mad men began in the summer of 2007 the soprano had ended just a few week before the wire never a popular in term of raw readership number though no slouch itself would end in early 2008 lost wa the king of the recap roost at the time but those who wrote about it usually focused more on grand unified theory of why the show worked rather than the sort of symbolic interpretation the soprano invited mad men also benefitted from the rise of tv recapping in general thus there wa a huge opening in the reading about tv on the internet marketplace that wa beginning to boom in the late 2000s and mad men filled it a surely a it filled the slot vacated by soprano at the golden globe and the emmy the two show thematic concern use of dreamlike imagery and storytelling structure were incredibly similar which only helped matter but mad men also benefited from the rise of tv recapping in general alan sepinwall began his seminal blog what s alan watching in late 2005 and by that final soprano season dozen of publication were dipping their toe into the recap water that number would explode in year to come and mad men wa a natural fit for publication that wanted to write tv recap and people who wanted to read them 3 there just wasn t a much good tv on when mad men started it wa popular to suggest that the end of the soprano the cancellation of hbo s deadwood and the impending end of the wire signaled the end of tv s golden age sound familiar instead mad men and later breaking bad picked up that ball and ran with it while fx entered the early stage of a hot streak that continues to this day but really in that summer of 2007 the established show worth writing about were few and far between especially if you didn t want to publish weekly in depth review of comedy a later development largely driven by content hungry site like well the a v club they were essentially limited to the wire dexter lost hero 24 grey s anatomy and maybe veronica mar if your readership wa especially young thus it wa easy to get the serious tv audience to tune in to mad men because there weren t a ton of other option mad men suggested every cable channel should have it own scripted drama series in development and now they pretty much all do contrast that to today when a show like the american can t get the same sort of readership traction a mad men even though it ha a loyal dedicated audience that like reading about it simply because there s so much more stuff out there this most recent season of that fx drama received the kind of acclaim mad men did in it heyday but it s much much harder for a series to cut through the noise from all those other show out there mad men suggested every single cable channel should have it own scripted drama in development and now they pretty much all do 4 mad men wa actually pretty popular when all wa said and done though it never pulled in big bang theory number amc told vulture s joe adalian that at the show s height a total of just under 7 million people watched it that number s not insignificant and even a tiny percentage of that audience consistently reading piece about the show online would be more than enough to drive significant traffic to most website especially back in 2007 when the overall online readership wa smaller 5 never underestimate passion a my colleague matthew yglesias wrote about the popularity of bernie sander presidential candidacy online a small but rabidly passionate audience for a particular topic can be lifeblood to a website that craves reader what hold true for sander is also true for mad men there are very few casual mad men fan and those passionate fan tend to seek out everything they can find about the show early on the medium positioned mad men a a sort of lifestyle choice the medium is of course at least somewhat complicit in this early on we positioned the series a a sort of lifestyle choice if you were cool you would watch mad men but tv site have said that about a lot of show over the year and few of them held up readership wise a well a mad men did whither boardwalk empire yes the early push might have been a bit much but mad men ended up having the good at least for the people who cared about it i agree with the theoretical concern behind the criticism of medium coverage of mad men those of u who write about television do too often ignore the show that a majority of american are actually watching show like the big bang theory and ncis and even empire but the kind of people who read our website are also far more likely to want to take a deep dive into the latest episode of mad men than they are to want to read a careful analysis of even several episode of ncis believe me i ve tried the answer to why the medium keep pushing mad men on the people is simple the people keep pushing it on u

title: do you have high cholesterol here are 5 food to eat and avoid
context: high fat low fat no carb more carb when it come to getting information on eating to manage high blood cholesterol confusion reign we checked the most recent research from trial that tested the impact of specific food on blood cholesterol the verdict good news first eating more nut legume plant sterol molecule found in plant and olive oil help lower blood cholesterol the bad news discretionary food aka junk raise blood cholesterol especially bad cholesterol called ldl eating le lower it do you know your blood cholesterol level if you don t ask your gp to check it over a third of australian adult have high cholesterol 1 eat legume legume and pulse including baked bean kidney bean chick pea lentil and split pea can help lower cholesterol level the most recent australian health survey found fewer than one in five australian ate them on the day of the survey the result of 26 randomised control trial the gold standard of research trial which included 1 037 people who had either normal or high cholesterol level were added together the data showed ldl cholesterol wa reduced by 5 percent in response to eating 130 gram of pulse per day this is equivalent to one small can or about a third of a 400 gram large can of baked bean pulse are high in vegetable protein and fibre they lower blood cholesterol in a number of way the soluble and insoluble fibre assist with lowering cholesterol absorption in the gut while they promote growth of beneficial gut bacteria in the large bowel legume and pulse take longer to digest compared to processed food this mean you tend to eat le when they re part of a meal 2 eat plant sterol margarine and spread plant sterol or phytosterols are chemically similar to blood cholesterol and are found in some plant food including nut they are concentrated from plant source and then added to some commonly eaten food such a margarine spread or milk plant sterol compete with two other type of cholesterol for absorption from the gut pre made cholesterol which is found in some food like prawn and cholesterol which is made in your liver this competition process lower the total amount of cholesterol that eventually end up in your blood a review concluded that two gram of plant sterol a day lead to an 8 10 percent reduction in ldl cholesterol the type of fat the plant sterol are mixed with is important a meta analysis of 32 randomised control trial involving around 2 100 people found bigger reduction in total cholesterol a mix of good and bad type and ldl cholesterol when plant sterol were added to margarine or spread derived from canola or rapeseed oil rather than sunflower or soybean oil 3 eat nut nut are high in protein and fat but the amount of polyunsaturated monounsaturated and saturated fat vary in a review of 25 intervention trial eating approximately 67g of nut a day about half a cup led to a 5 1 percent reduction in total cholesterol and 7 4 percent for ldl it didn t matter what type of nut people ate the more nut the bigger the cholesterol reduction people with higher ldl cholesterol at baseline or who were not overweight had a bigger improvement one caution is that half a cup of nut contains about 400 calorie 1600kj so you need to eat nut instead of another food or eat le each day but have them every day 4 use olive oil olive oil is a major component of the mediterranean diet and the predominant source of fat olive oil contains a high proportion of monounsaturated fat more than 80 percent of olive oil s healthy compound called phenolic compound are lost during the refining process so le refined variety such a virgin olive oil are a better choice a review of eight trial that included 350 people consuming high phenolic olive oil found medium effect on lowering blood pressure and small effect on lowering oxidised ldl a type of ldl with no significant effect on total or ldl cholesterol in contrast another trial randomly selected over 7 400 men and woman at high risk of heart disease to follow three diet the mediterranean diet plus extra virgin olive oil or mediterranean diet plus nut or a control diet low fat after 4 8 year follow up those in both the olive oil and nut group had a 30 percent lower risk of heart attack stroke or death from heart disease compared to control in a recent trial 47 men and woman were randomised to substitute 4 5 percent of their usual foodintake of olive oil or butter for five week and then crossed over to the other group for another five week researcher found total cholesterol and ldl cholesterol level were significantly higher after consuming butter compared to olive oil the reduction wa biggest in those who had high blood cholesterol to start with switching to a healthier spread make sense for those with high cholesterol 5 avoid junk food in our study we found people were able to make a number of smaller change across a range of the food that lower blood cholesterol level including increasing nut soy food and plant sterol but the biggest change people made wa cutting back on energy dense nutrient poor food junk food and eating a wider variety of healthy food the benefit of making these change they lowered their cholesterol lost weight and lowered their blood pressure a big study examined change in diet quality score and heart disease risk in 29 000 men from the health professional follow up study and 51 000 woman from the nurse health study 1986 2010 after four year of follow up almost 11 000 people had a heart disease event those who had the biggest improvement in their diet quality score had a 7 8 lower risk you can check your diet quality using our healthy eating quiz when it come to heart disease risk factor get your cholesterol and blood pressure checked next time you see your gp

title: pew report reveals who s likely to get married more than once
context: good news for romantic the divorce rate may be dismal but remarriage is on the rise according to new finding from the pew research center 40 percent of marriage involve one spouse who s been married before in 20 percent of new marriage both spouse have previously said i do there s so much dialogue right now about the retreat from marriage in general gretchen livingston senior researcher at pew and author of the study told the huffington post i wa really curious to juxtapose that with what s going on with remarriage livingston analyzed data from the 2013 american community survey a well a the 1960 and 1980 census and found that the number of remarried adult in the u ha hit 42 million which is almost double the amount recorded in 1980 and triple the amount in 1960 but not everyone is jumping to remarry after combining the hard data on remarriage pattern with the result of a recent pew survey about marriage livingston found that specific demographic are actually le likely to remarry than others among those who are divorced or widowed age made a big difference in desire to remarry there are two demographic shift that can account for this general surge in remarriage according to livingston for one the divorce rate is higher now than it wa in 1960 so the number of people who are a she put it eligible to remarry ha also risen but it s worth noting that the divorce rate peaked in 1981 and ha been slowly declining and leveling off ever since the more influential factor in the high remarriage rate however is a longer life expectancy for partner particularly among baby boomer while only 34 percent of those who were 65 and older and eligible to remarry had remarried in 1960 50 percent of that same demographic had remarried in 2013 the older you are the more likely you are to have ever remarried because you have more time in your life to have married once gotten divorced or widowed and found someone else and remarried livingston said younger american went the opposite direction 75 percent of people age 25 to 34 and eligible to remarry were remarried in 1960 while only 43 percent of that same demographic were remarried in 2013 it s very possible that this younger group of contemporary divorcee and widow hasn t soured on the institution of marriage completely however livingston pointed out that since younger demographic have tended to delay marriage the average age of first marriage is now is about 27 for woman and 29 for men a opposed to 21 for woman and 24 for men in 1960 perhaps this group is content to cohabit with partner or advance the relationship in other way rather than jump into marriage number two overall woman were le likely than men to want to walk down the aisle again age wasn t the only differentiating factor though when pew polled participant for the aforementioned survey on marriage they asked single men and woman who had been married before if they would be willing to marry again there wa a clear gender divide divorced or widowed men were more likely to want to remarry than woman in the same position a majority of once married eligible men 65 percent either expressed a desire to remarry or were still considering it in comparison 43 percent of woman said they d be willing to remarry and 54 percent specifically didn t want to ever marry again only 30 percent of men were completely against the idea of a second walk down the aisle previous study have suggested that men enjoy more health benefit relationship satisfaction and economic perk from marriage than woman do livingston said it s quite possible that widowed or divorced men have more motivation to jump back into a new marriage and regain those aforementioned comfort another interesting finding combined both age and gender in remarriage 16 percent of couple involve a husband who is at least 10 year older than his wife this age gap fall to a mere 4 percent in first time married couple if you consider that 39 percent of first time newlywed and 21 percent of remarried couple are within a year of each other s age this age gap among remarried couple becomes particularly noteworthy but don t make too many fact according to pew previously married people these day are just a willing to remarry a they were back in 1960 taken together these finding can add more detail to an ever shifting image of the american family maybe newlywed don t look quite a fresh faced a they did in the late 60 livingston said noting once again that 40 percent of today s newlywed couple involve at least one person who s been married before but i think it s very striking and just another example of how the definition of family and the norm are changing

title: the biggest mistake you re making in the bathroom

both say the center for disease control and prevention cdc we should be doing more of it throughout the day but it s our bathroom handwashing habit that have been carefully studied and they are disgusting the simple step is something many consider unnecessary in communal space from your office restroom to bar bathroom some people go so far a to turn on the sink and let the water run so it only sound like they re washing their hand when researcher hid in a public restroom in a michigan college town they reported that 10 percent of people didn t wash their hand after using the bathroom and nearly one in four just rinsed with water the average handwashing time six second far short of the cdc s recommendation for a 20 second scrub men were more than twice a likely a woman to leave without washing up men are le concerned about thing study author carl p borchgrevink an associate professor at michigan state university tell the huffington post they re not a thoughtful and they don t like to be told what to do men also seemed to think they were clean if they were dealing only with their genitalia many men suggested that unless they had a bowel movement there would be no need for washing their hand borchgrevink say michael sykes founder of the humor site the international center for bathroom etiquette say that the act of peeing is so easy for men that it may not register a a way of spreading germ men don t have to do much more than unzip their pant to take a pee and they might simply feel like going to the bathroom is so insignificant a to not even merit a hand washing he writes to huffpost in an email seventy percent of people confessed to sometimes rinsing without soap and 81 percent said they had witnessed a non washing event in a public restroom within the past year according to a 2013 survey by bradley corporation which happens to be a manufacturer of bathroom product again men were the grossest offender only 60 percent said they always washed their hand title: a university recognizes a third gender neutral
context: being a boy didn t feel right either i had a couple month where i gave it a go i tried to bind my chest with an ace bandage every day i wore some masculine clothes and told my friend to call me emmett neither category applied it felt not only like i wa invisible but especially at that time when hormone are aflutter like no one would really know what i wa like for the rest of my life gieselman began spending time at outright vermont a trans and queer youth center where the gender lexicon of activist and academe is widely accepted a soon a i learned about a genderqueer identity i wa like oh that s the one said gieselman who frequently end sentence with a gentle laugh before it had been really difficult to explain how i wa feeling to other people and even really difficult to explain it in my own head suddenly there wa a language for it and that started the journey gieselman dumped the girlie name bestowed at birth asked friend and teacher to use rocko the tough sounding nickname friend had come up with and told people to use they instead of he or she they ha become an increasingly popular substitute for he or she in the transgender community and the university of vermont a public institution of some 12 700 student ha agreed to use it while college across the country have been grappling with concern related to student transitioning from one gender to another vermont is at the forefront in recognizing the next step in identity politics the validation of a third gender the university allows student like gieselman to select their own identity a new first name regardless of whether they ve legally changed it a well a a chosen pronoun and record these detail in the campuswide information system so that professor have the correct terminology at their fingertip for year writer and academic have argued that gender identity is not a male female binary but a continuum along which any individual may fall depending on a variety of factor including anatomy chromosome hormone and feeling but the dichotomy is so deeply embedded in our culture that even the most radical activist had been focused mainly on expanding the definition of the two pre existing category today a growing number of student are embracing the idea that when it come to classifying gender there should be more than two option something now afforded by the dating website okcupid and by facebook which last year added a tab for custom alongside male and female with some 50 option including agender androgyne pangender and trans person a well a an option for controlling who can see the customized version activist on campus a diverse a penn state university at albany university of chicago university of wisconsin milwaukee and university of california riverside are laying claim to a degree of identity freedom nearly unimaginable when the first l g b t student center were established today s student who grew up with gay straight alliance in their high school with transgender people represented in the medium and with transgender right percolating through the court arrived on campus already l g b t friendly and in many case equipped with gender neutral housing and bathroom in hope of raising consciousness of the bias built into social structure and into the language we use to discus them student are organizing identity conference and inventing new vocabulary which include pronoun like ze and xe and pressing administration to make change that validate in language the existence of a gender outside the binary certainly there s a long line of people throughout history whose trait have put them outside norm and some culture long ago formalized the existence of a gender that isn t purely female or purely male like the american indian s two spirit or india s hijras but the binary is a belief system at least a old a adam and eve and most people don t even realize it s there it s like a constant coming out process educating those around you that there is a gender binary and this is what it mean to identify outside of it said gieselman who work on campus planning gender related event identifying a genderqueer is an opportunity to self invent unburdened from social expectation about dress and behavior occasionally gieselman wish for a lower voice and flatter chest but other time feel o k with even happy about having a feminine physique even within the same day or the next day i can suddenly really love how my chest look in a sundress said gieselman who wear two small nose ring in the bedroom closet hang t shirt flannel dress and a rack of bow tie it might seem a simple turn of event but adding gender neutral option to the university of vermont s information system took nearly a decade of lobbying the creation of a task force of student faculty member and administrator and six month and 80 000 in staff time to create a software patch one key to the development is dorothea brauer a plain spoken big hearted mental health counselor known to everyone a dot m brauer spent nine year working at the campus counseling center before becoming in 2001 the director of what wa then called the lesbian gay bisexual transgender questioning ally center while in her 20 and living in new jersey m brauer who wear her hair cut short with a single long braid down her back in tribute to a cherokee grandmother wa spending time with a woman when an acquaintance changed the course of her life by inquiring about the relationship and then pointedly but nonjudgmentally asking honey are you gay i said well yeah but only with anita recalled m brauer anita would turn out to be her life partner 32 year and counting that s how clueless i wa she said chuckling over a taco salad lunch at the penny cluse cafe in downtown burlington i wa 24 25 and scared to death i came out to my mother only my mother because i became physically ill with depression a decade later a one of the few out woman on campus in the 1990s she treated student with debilitating identity issue some of whom attempted suicide or faced a psychotic break l g b t q youth are more than twice a likely to attempt suicide a their heterosexual peer according to the center for disease control and prevention m brauer s first act upon being installed a the center s director wa to assign a graduate student to research and catalog the unmet need of the transgender community among the difficulty faced by transgender student inability to use bathroom marked men or woman for fear of a confrontation with a confused classmate being accused of using a stolen student id in the cafeteria because the name printed on it didn t match someone s gender appearance and having the faculty rely on a student information system that listed only legal name leading to occasion when a student might be embarrassed or inadvertently outed m brauer heard about one distraught transgender freshman whose professor while calling roll first read the student s feminine legal name then announced the male nickname m brauer reached out to the registrar keith p williams who worked with the university s lawyer to allow transgender student to change their first name in the schoolwide system but doing so required an in person visit to the dean of student office and filling out paperwork she then set to work waging a campaign to educate face to face member of the faculty staff and administration on why language sensitivity wa so important to a student s self respect and assisted student in getting school policy amended to specifically prohibit discrimination based on gender identity by 2009 faculty member themselves began pushing for a broader solution to the identification issue and mr williams created a task force to look into how student could register a preferred first name without having to make a special request the task force realized that the only way to guarantee a professor would properly refer to a student wa to supply the student s pronoun on class roster and advisee list then came the question of which gender neutral pronoun to offer student proposed they them pronoun but the faculty vetoed the idea because they said it is grammatically incorrect mr williams recalled they said you don t put a plural pronoun with a single individual a second option also being used in various trans community wa ze pronounced zee a riff on the german pronoun sie with hir replacing his her bowing to the faculty the task force selected ze and revised it information system becoming the first school in the nation at which student could select their pronoun they could also leave the field blank or opt for name only indicating a preference for being referred to by name instead of by pronoun the change fueled gender awareness campaign by student all over the country so many administrator were receiving request that in 2012 the american association of collegiate registrar and admission officer convened a task force to draft a list of best practice for handling transgender student record so far about 100 school now allow student and sometimes employee to indicate a moniker other than their legal first name according to the consortium of higher education l g b t resource professional and hundred more have contacted vermont on how to implement the pronoun choice in september the university s pronoun option were expanded yet again to include they a grammarian have reminded naysayer that the english language is constantly evolving since 2009 1 891 university of vermont student have specified a preferred pronoun with 14 opting for ze 10 for they and another 228 for name only on campus across the country gender conscious student have adopted the earnest p c practice of starting social interaction by introducing themselves by name and p g p or preferred gender pronoun the most semantically obsessed still object to the word preferred robyn ochs an educator who helped found an early l g b t faculty and staff group at harvard belief that vermont s change are nothing le than lifesaving some people try to reduce this whole topic to kid trying to be cool or they re just acting out or whatever just trying to be different or new said m ochs who ha visited some 500 campus to speak on l g b t issue and often facilitates a discussion she call beyond binary but there have always been people who have felt profoundly uncomfortable in their assigned gender role she said anything we can do to make them safer or make them feel recognized heard seen understood we should do to validate their identity and experience could in fact save their life how doe one explain to family member what it mean to be neither male nor female once at age 15 in conversation with an aunt at the kitchen table gieselman tried unsuccessfully to diagram the concept of gender and sex on a napkin with gender referring to the attitude and behavior a society associate with a person s biological sex and sex referring to a person s biological status not to be confused with sexual orientation one s romantic interest i don t even know what it wa i wa trying to show gieselman an eighth generation vermonter recounted with a laugh gieselman s grandmother too had a few question about the napkin they were very confused gieselman said and still are sara miller gieselman s mother said that when her teenager first came out to her and offered to provide a pronoun chart for reference she scoffed at the time it irritated me to no end said m miller a social worker i wa like really this is what our struggle is going to be about pronoun but m miller ha learned to accept the person her former little girl ha become it s grown out of the process of really seeing how rocko ha grown a an individual and an adult seeing how rocko is their own person and not a child m miller said this is how they present themself to new friend and colleague and employer and student that group know rocko only that way although m miller try her best to always use they them pronoun she often slip up but gieselman isn t bothered rocko and i have an understanding she know i try said m miller slipping up again at last summer s orientation for new faculty member m brauer handed out pocket size pronoun chart created by the l g b t resource center at the university of wisconsin milwaukee she also gave out her cellphone number and word of support if you re struggling with it give me a call any time and i ll walk you through it and give you time to practice and walk you through any question you might have use of they them is so widely accepted in the politically correct enclave that is burlington that a colleague at feldman s bagel where gieselman work part time recently asked if it wa o k to correct a customer who us the wrong pronoun because she knew gieselman wouldn t i know if something might be bothering them they wouldn t necessarily say something about it said alexa ciecierski a morning shift co worker at the apartment that afternoon gieselman talked excitedly about finally receiving documentation of a legal name change which arrived in the mail that afternoon and showed off several gig poster brought home by a roommate who manages local band on the coffee table a collection of angel card filled a small bowl each billet offering a single word like discernment or balance or integrity meant to be chosen and read for a daily dose of inspiration do you want to pick one gieselman asked me i reached in the bowl and pulled out strength gieselman leaned forward off the futon swished the card around plucked one from the center smiled then read it aloud freedom

title: some thing never change 1996 career advice that s still solid
context: in the summer of 1996 after my sophomore year of college i started an internship at a nonprofit technology association in downtown washington d c until that point i d only worked in retail and had no idea what to expect i asked my father and a professor for advice remarkably 20 year later much of that guidance still resonates door open based on who you know in the late 90 these were physical door rather than virtual one but the concept is the same when applying for a job or looking to connect with someone name dropping would increase your odds of getting a positive response today although we have exponentially larger network thanks to social medium deep in person relationship still provide the greatest networking benefit a you build your network of contact remember to follow up meeting a contact once is a wasted opportunity unless you periodically remind him or her of who you are and take step to grow the relationship over time in the 90 i wa encouraged to send snail mail holiday card to former boss and colleague and even to pick up the phone occasionally twenty year later it s all about linkedin in a new situation aim to assimilate corporate culture used to be one size fit all if you worked in a business office in any city in the world you were expected to behave professionally adhere to hierarchy and generally do what you were told without making wave individual company culture may be more unique today conservative versus liberal strict versus playful but the need to examine and then fit into a new culture whatever it may be remains dress for the job you want like business culture business dress wa once straightforward junior level professional in the 90 could wear business casual which consisted of khaki and polo for guy and slack or skirt paired with nice blouse for woman however by the time you reached a senior level you were advised to take it up a notch with tailored suit and pricey shoe and accessory basing your appearance on that of the executive sent a very clear signal that you intended to climb the ladder quickly and it still doe even if the executive in your company now wear jean and hollister tee shirt be humble and willing to learn from any task in the 90 if your bos asked you to grab coffee or make copy you did it with a smile you understood that you were paid for the privilege of watching and learning a the higher ups did the real work today those with little experience may feel empowered to say no to grunt work but that doesn t mean refusal is a smart idea human nature hasn t changed and humility will get you everywhere success is not about effort it s about visibility and value early in my career i made the mistake of churning out work product that no one ever saw i didn t get ahead until i made sure my manager were aware of how my contribution were impacting the bottom line today s emphasis on lean team and productivity mean that adding and communicating value is more important than ever a bad attitude will break your reputation losing your cool at work ha always been frowned upon and despite claim of a kinder gentler 21st century workplace it still is and now the stake are higher because your epic in office rant won t just be a legend passed down from employee to employee instead it could be taped on a phone and broadcast on social medium for perpetuity take advantage of company sponsored training opportunity the concept that employee should skill up to remain competitive ha been around for several decade and in the last year of the 20th century company had dollar to spend on tuition reimbursement and course like dale carnegie in 2016 training opportunity are scarcer and more varied online in person etc but they should still be coveted it s only a matter of time before individual will be responsible for 100 percent of their professional development if you want to keep a secret don t tell anyone workplace gossip ha been a thing since biblical time and in 1996 the chief concern wa that if you told a colleague a secret or rumor in confidence that individual would share it with someone else and it might be heard by the wrong person never ha this advice been more critical than today when thanks to the speed and ease of digital communication your secret will be heard by the wrong person guaranteed be respectful of others time back in the day we arrived exactly on time for interview we asked politely for networking conversation and check in meeting with our boss that fit into a half hour slot in the day planner when we thought people were busy then filing paperwork sending fax and leaving voicemail we had no idea what we were in for in 2016 people are so overscheduled and frazzled that they take their iphones to the bathroom if you make them wait they might just lose it s
question: 10 piece of career advice that are a true today a they were in 1996 what is the author s opinion about the relevance of the career advice given in the sentence

text: door open based on who you know
a you build your network of contact remember to follow up
in a new situation aim to assimilate
dress for the job you want
be humble and willing to learn from any task

title: bolivia s san pedro tourist prison 20 year on
context: it is 20 year since bolivia s chaotic san pedro prison became a tourist attraction a place where backpacker stayed for week and partied with inmate the story wa immortalised in a best selling book marching powder and now the book s protagonist a former inmate and author have reunited to return to the prison for a new documentary film the inmate thomas mcfadden say returning to his old cell scared him but i always wanted to go back to bolivia and there wa always a strong connection between me and rusty rusty young wrote marching powder in his twenty when a a young backpacker from sydney australia he stayed in the prison and later helped secure mr mcfadden s release by posing a an international human right lawyer it all began when mr mcfadden a british tanzanian wa caught smuggling cocaine in la paz airport in 1996 and found himself jailed in a place more like a warped small town than a prison prisoner were expected to earn a living inside and buy their cell a if they were real estate there wa a primary school for the prisoner child who they brought to live with them and in the most notorious twist of all there wa an in house cocaine factory i thought what is this place i even had to pay my own taxi fare to get there thomas mcfadden remembers today after his release in 2000 he left those day far behind and is now a chicken farmer in tanzania however his life changing friendship with his brother rusty ha gone the distance and he ha even named one of his child after him their unusual relationship began when mr young joined one of the illegal prison tour that the inmate ran for foreign backpacker from early 1997 until his release word had spread around local hostel that there wa an english speaking inmate who would show visitor around this strange microcosm centrally located in downtown la paz the prison became a tourist attraction that featured in lonely planet guidebook traveller paid an entrance fee and in some case opted to stay for week partying with the inmate lydia docking a british traveller went on not just one but repeated trip to the prison in 2008 led by a prisoner from portugal one of the other backpacker she met on her first day there later became her husband a a conversation starter we used to say we met in a bolivian jail she say from her new home in sydney she wa 24 at the time and is 33 now their san pedro tour guide came to their wedding after his release and although the couple ha since separated she still ha their dog named pedro after the prison despite her joke she is acutely well aware of the darker side of the story i m still confused by it still processing it she say over the course of three week we went most day i sometimes question why it wa mostly just to share experience and to understand how life start the same but can take such different path san pedro prison remains operational today despite many plan to close it for year it tour were an open secret but one day in 2009 a local television crew arrived to get footage for a story about a politician held inside while waiting in the plaza outside the cameraman caught a steady stream of tourist going in armed with the footage the bolivian press ran with the story the main concern locally wa not the tourist but the alleged corruption of the authority who were thought to be taking a cut of the tour profit who is watching the police asked an editorial in la razon newspaper during the ensuing clean up prisoner had their visitor right revoked for a day a riot followed and around 80 child were evacuated in 2013 the story took an even darker turn when news spread of a 12 year old girl becoming pregnant inside the jail after an alleged rape by her imprisoned father and other men child welfare charity called for a ban on child living inside large scale tour of the prison are no longer possible today backpacker typically opt for la paz walking tour which stop outside the prison wall and tell marching powder s story when rusty young and thomas mcfadden returned to the prison for their forthcoming documentary wildlands they happened upon one such tour group and snuck alongside them incognito they kept making factual error so i couldn t help asking smart arsed question say mr young eventually an irish traveller who had just read the book recognised the pair he whispered you re rusty you re thomas and we sneaked off together for a beer back in 2000 the two men travelled to colombia after mr mcfadden s release they found work a english teacher and worked on the book which became a new york time best seller thomas then moved to tanzania and rusty went back to australia where after the huge success of marching powder he had difficult second book syndrome his novel colombiano about a teenager who get drawn into a colombian terrorist organisation is due out later this year the documentary wildlands us their story in san pedro prison a a launch pad for exploring all side of the drug trade and includes interview with former undercover u police agent and an assassin who wa a right hand man to colombian drug lord pablo escobar but the long awaited marching powder feature film may still be year away the right were acquired by brad pitt s production company but have since expired narcos director jose padilha ha been linked to the screenplay and don cheadle and then chiwetel ejiofor expressed interest in playing thomas mcfadden but filming never got off the ground a for the sequel to the book perhaps that will come sooner my publisher been harassing me about that for year say rusty we already have a title marching on

title: pluto s little sister makemake ha something even pluto doesn t
context: the dwarf planet makemake discovered in 2005 is cold dark and remote it sits in the kuiper belt beyond neptune orbiting the sun at a distance almost 46 time farther away than earth and completing an orbit once every 310 earth year recent observation by the hubble space telescope however ha revealed that makemake is not a lonely a it once appeared it ha a moon finding a dark moon until this new discovery scientist believed makemake wa the only one of the four officially recognized dwarf planet in the kuiper belt pluto haumea makemake and eris without a moon the fifth official dwarf planet cere is closer to earth and also moonless however there were some inconsistency in prior measurement of makemake s light and heat observation from the spitzer and herschel space telescope revealed warm dark area on makemake s otherwise bright cold surface however makemake s apparently mottled surface would not make sense with a normally rotating dwarf planet unless it wa spinning with one of it pole facing directly toward earth a fairly unlikely situation the dark moon hypothesis offered a simpler explanation a charcoal black moon orbiting makemake imagine that the dark material isn t on makemake s surface it s in orbit image analysis lead and paper coauthor alex parker tweeted if the moon is very dark it account for most previous thermal measurement makemake is the second farthest away of the official dwarf planet eris is the farthest and the second brightest after pluto while it may seem strange that astronomer had been able to see moon around farther and dimmer planet while missing makemake s moon the reality is that this moon informally called mk2 wa very good at remaining hidden mk2 is over 1300 time dimmer and much smaller than makemake and it orbit appears to be edge on to earth so we don t see it circling makemake only oscillating back and forth looking for it is like looking for a firefly flitting back and forth across a spotlight if you watch it long enough and are lucky enough to look at the right time a this team of astronomer did the firefly might look obvious in parker s word not actually that faint but it wa easy to miss before part of a team from the southwest research institute in boulder colorado parker wa the first to notice makemake s moon in data from the hubble space telescope at first he thought someone else must have already seen it just to be sure he asked collaborator and team leader marc buie ha anyone seen the moon in the makemake data when buie replied there s a moon in the makemake data they knew they d made a major discovery the moon in the data it is unclear where exactly the moon came from or why it surface is black more observation of mk2 from hubble will help astronomer determine whether it orbit is circular or elliptical which will provide clue to it origin if mk2 s orbit is elongated it wa probably simply captured in makemake s gravity a it floated by many smaller kuiper belt object have dark surface like mk2 this is often because they are too small and their gravity too weak to keep bright ice like the one that cover makemake in place however mk2 s darkness could be due to constant interaction with the escaping atmospheric gas streaming off makemake like the top of a hearth blackened with ash it could have accumulated compound from makemake s past atmosphere if mk2 s orbit is circular a preliminary estimate indicate the moon may be merely debris from a collision between makemake and another kuiper belt object if mk2 wa created by an enormous crash between two kuiper belt object according to the paper the apparent ubiquity of trans neptunian dwarf planet satellite further support the idea that giant collision are a near universal fixture in the history of these distant world if all of the dwarf planet have satellite moon that may mean that kuiper belt object are often subjected to huge impact the new improved makemake system while mk2 doe create question about the makemake system and the kuiper belt it will also provide answer according to parker the discovery of this moon ha given u an opportunity to study makemake in far greater detail than we ever would have been able to without the companion makemake is sometimes referred to a pluto s little sister because of their similarity both are dwarf planet both have surface coated in methane ice and both have temperature that can drop to 400 degree fahrenheit the discovery that makemake ha a moon add yet another similarity to pluto when pluto s largest moon charon wa discovered in 1978 it led to enormous new insight about pluto itself including that it wa hundred of time lighter than wa originally estimated that s the kind of transformative measurement that having a satellite can enable parker said mk2 will almost definitely lead to a fundamental change in how we view the dwarf planet makemake looking at how mk2 orbit makemake will allow scientist to calculate the system s mass and probe it inner composition a caltech s mike brown a member of the team that discovered makemake in 2005 said the wide range of density of the dwarf planet is one of the most interesting mystery out there but we still have so few object that each one add a critical part of the story small world like makemake display a variety of internal composition they can contain rock and water ice a well a other more exotic ice and compound since mk2 will allow scientist to tell makemake s density and thus the density of the material it s made of it provides a new clue about the family of dwarf planet the james webb space telescope scheduled to launch in 2018 will be able to conclusively test the dark moon hypothesis even before then though information about makemake and it moon will continue to accumulate from new hubble observation teaching u about the outskirt of our solar system this new discovery open a new chapter in comparative planetology in the outer solar system buie said and it will add to our understanding of the many world around u

title: she put on 100 pound in just two year doctor couldn t find a reason until she found it herself
context: the one thing any teen doesn t want to have happen to them is rapid unexplained weight gain but lizzie denison ward a now 20 year old girl had this happen to her for two year she told the daily mail her story she started gaining weight in november 2013 she couldn t tell why since she had always been slender she went from 126 pound to 224 pound in two year when she went to her doctor to try to find a reason she wa gaining weight so rapidly they told her that it wa just her metabolism slowing down and if she wanted it to come off she should eat le calorie so she did but even eating 1000 calorie per day nothing changed not only that but she experienced a rash on her face she decided to do some private research and when she paid for an mri scan herself after doctor wouldn t help her she found that there wa a 4 mm tumor in her brain the tumor wa on her pituitary gland which wa preventing her from losing weight she had cushing s disease if left undetected it could have killed her by the time she had the mri she had gone up ten dress size lizzie finally had an answer to what wa causing her unhealthy weight gain but it wasn t without psychological cost i believed the doctor after i first saw them said lizzie but over time i thought there wa something else wrong because i ve always been thin her mother worried about her too she kept seeing her doctor but to no avail no one could get to the bottom of it and find out what it wa it wa a real low time and i wa feeling depressed now that she s finally had it removed she s so glad to be rid of the problem after i found out it wa a tumor i wa more relieved than anything i wa just glad i wa right and i wasn t just making it up five week later lizzie ha already lost 21 pound she ha medication to regulate her hormone level and she s back to a healthy lifestyle that s causing the weight to melt away the tumor took over my whole body and now i can finally go back to living like a normal student

title: hillary clinton is advertising in deep red nebraska here s why
context: a democratic presidential candidate ha not won a majority of vote in nebraska for more than 50 year but on thursday hillary clinton s campaign announced it would begin spending precious advertising dollar in the state the advertising buy is focused on nebraska s second congressional district and includes two ad about clinton s advocacy for child it is an expensive bet on a state that ha almost always voted red but there s a simple reason behind what seems like a gamble nebraska allocates it electoral college vote not in the usual winner take all method but by congressional district so a republican candidate can win in the state but a democratic candidate can still pick up electoral vote by winning over a district the second congressional district which is centered in omaha and it suburb ha a history of occasionally voting differently from the rest of deep red nebraska the district went for mitt romney in 2012 but for then sen barack obama in 2008 in 2014 when democrat lost a wave of congressional race across the country democrat brad ashford won the district s seat in u s congress and a a clinton aide pointed out the african american share of the vote in the district is higher than the statewide average and clinton ha shown she consistently over performs among black voter the electoral college s winner take all system mean that reliably democratic state like massachusetts and oregon or reliably republican state like texas and alabama are never seriously contested by presidential candidate they predictably vote democratic or republican but in nebraska and maine the two state that allocate their electoral vote by congressional district there is more room for the party to maneuver they can spend ad dollar and campaign in state that they could never win outright it s an electoral strategy that donald trump is hoping to take advantage of too this week he campaigned in maine which also allocates it electoral vote by congressional district but usually support a democrat he held a rally in bangor in the state s second congressional district which is predominantly white and rural clinton ha begun a broad and expensive advertising campaign in the swing state that you d expect florida ohio colorado iowa nevda new hampshire virginia north carolina in those state a well a in her nebraska ad buy clinton ha aired advertisement that tout her role in the creation of the child s health insurance program in the 1990s these are the two ad that will be playing in nebraska

many people do not even know they can get anaphylaxis from a wasp or bee sting and anybody can develop it at any point in their lifetime it is important to get tested for this type of reaction if you title: the dish you should never order in rome
context: when it come to dining in rome there s a pasta dish to avoid unless you know the one place to try it there seems to be molto confusion around the origin of fettuccine alfredo ask any true roman about it and you ll be met with a befuddled who is a alfredo that s because fellow american roman child didn t grow up scarfing down plate of this creamy comfort food like we did here then again olive garden ha yet to hit mediterranean shore alfredo after all isn t found alongside carbonara and amatriciana in the pantheon of celebrated local dish not because it isn t roman but because it never spread throughout the city it origin lay in a single no name trattoria on a side street near the trevi fountain in the early 1900s the eponymous alfredo di lielo needed a calorific meal to feed his pregnant wife so he combined butter and cheese and melted it over fettuccine noodle sated his wife insisted he add it to his menu but it remained a strictly of the house specialty despite the acclaim rumor swirl that mary pickford and douglas fairbanks ate it on their roman holiday in 1927 other trattorias likely rejected it due to inauthenticity alfredo used parmigiano for the cheese a bold move in pecorino romano country and butter which wa pretty much a foreign an ingredient to italian at the time a milk wa to the japanese but it did take off stateside thanks to a pennsylvania noodle company pennsylvania dutch marketed a creamy sauce called alfredo after influential new york restaurateur george renart raved about the dish in the saturday evening post when he returned from a trip to rome the version we eat now loaded with cream often with chicken is a bastardization of what alfredo cooked up a century ago and it s definitely not what you would find in rome now even if those trattorias from testaccio to prati had alfredo on the menu which they don t should we just quit the search and make do with carbonara instead local food expert elizabeth minchilli say no way i always encourage traveler to seek out alfredo in rome she say you just need to know where to go that would be trattoria della scrofa between piazza navona and the trevi fountain a 103 year old restaurant that alfredo started after his first spot wa flattened to make space for a shopping center what you ll get is a heaping plate of pasta prepped a alfredo did it all those year ago hot noodle on a hot plate mixed with lot of softened butter and lot of grated parmigiano right at your table what you won t get is cream garlic or an overwhelming crush of traveler which in rome is rewarding in it own right

hell for me i ate myself up to a size 5xl and 30 32 blouse 28 32 pant and 50 bra i didn t have a lap i couldn t hold my beautiful grandkids breaking point three thing in july 2013 my husband took me the tour with my husband i wa so sick and tired of all the blood pressure diabetes and acid reflux medicine i had had enough i went to dinner to celebrate july birthday in my family we all gathered to vegetable a much a i try to stay away from processed food in some case it s hard to avoid so moderation is the key i make my own snack like roasted pumpkin and sunflower seed almond pistachio cashew and roasted chickpea i lost 20 pound in 30 day and started going to the gym i wa sore for three month straight but i kept going every day even after losing 20 pound i could only walk on the treadmill at the lowest speed but i kept going i would be on it for an hour take a break and get right back on i stuck with the treadmill for the first nine month now i love going to the gym and my energy level is off the chart everybody who know me is cheering me on i want to do everything spinning dancing running horseback riding traveling the world now i can walk on the treadmill on it highest level for 45 to 50 minute for someone who could barely walk up a flight of stair without being winded i feel like i got my life back i m no longer on any of the medication one year later my husband said i bet you can run that dallas stadium now after weight 169 pound
