title: here s what happens when you give 1 000 to someone in extreme poverty
context: here s what happens when you give 1 000 to someone in extreme poverty margaret osuma oshien from siaya kenya a person who received just under 1 000 cash unconditionally from givedirectly org my wife adrienne and i are long time supporter of unconditional cash giving from handing 5 to a homeless person on the street in manhattan to raising 450 to give to a working father of one in rural south africa we believe in the virtue of sharing abundance in an empowering fashion that enables people to decide how best to allocate their resource themselves when we found givedirectly in november 2015 an org that give 1 000 unconditionally to people who are in extreme poverty a a solution to get them out of extreme poverty we fell in love unconditional they can do anything they want with it which is incredibly empowering to recipient but many people in the west think it s risky or even foolish we ve told countless friend and family about givedirectly and the concept of transferring cash is met with much skepticism soliciting response such a eh i only give people food and others such a how do they make sure people aren t defrauding them or stealing the cash i bet most people waste or squander the cash it probably doesn t have long term impact such a building a school could general angst about the savior barbie complex where western people go out to save people in poor country by telling them what they should do often a self serving endeavor and more after dealing with the frequent barrage of opposing view but always holding strong to our personal conviction we decided to dig for some more answer and see how many of these hole they were poking in our own justification could be filled since we currently travel abroad full time and kenya is an incredible country we decided to head out for a field visit and take a real peek under the hood of gd s operation outside of givedirectly s country headquarters in kisumu kenya in august 2016 my wife and i visited givedirectly s office in kisumu kenya and spent two 10 hour day in the field visiting real past recipient in the siaya where president obama s grandmother life and homa bay region after meeting the team on the ground and hearing about their day to day work we were really surprised and impressed by five main thing that actually directly addressed a lot of the negative feedback we ve heard in the past the vast majority of the team are local kenyan only two of around 80 or so employee are expat we think that s fantastic since we ve already known that 91 of the cash that we personally give to gd go directly into the field but actually a solid portion of the 9 administrative cost actually funnel into creating local job that afford hundred more people in east africa the opportunity to build bright future for themselves there s a huge unemployment issue in kenya and other east african country and foreign investment is still far behind demand so this kind of job creation ha a huge impact on the community beyond the employment opportunity the real incredible moment for u came when we had the chance to speak individually with a few of the local on the team candidly they are all proud to be working their ass off to improve the life of people in their own community we even heard two separate story from some senior level guy still under 30 year old who were driven to work at givedirectly after having their own first real exposure to abject poverty even just a few mile from where they lived they were moved to make a difference to pour their energy every day into giving other people in their community better life cavin oginga from kenya a field ops manager for givedirectly who applied for a job there after running a research project on givedirectly s work for poverty action org and seeing what a massive impact they were having one of the most interesting story we heard wa about a young woman who received a cash transfer from givedirectly in 2014 she used a large portion of the transfer to cover her school fee so that she could complete her schooling and then graduated and immediately sought employment she applied to work for givedirectly gd often ha 200 600 applicant for any one vacancy and she got the job from living off of le than one dollar a day to now being employed in one of the most competitive role available the cash transfer from givedirectly ha completely altered the path of her life and she will reach height that only two year ago she would have thought to be completely unattainable for her 2 there wa really no savior barbie complex in the givedirectly operation no one is coming in from wealthy nation and telling anyone else how to live their own life and what s best for them and no one here is swooping in from some rich country on a self serving mission save the world 3 auditing the rigor behind this operation is crazy they have 5 separate team of people for each stage in the transfer process from initial outreach through final follow up the recipient almost never see the same people so there s no nepotism and absolutely everything is audited 4 let s face it data is boring and unsexy yet it s likely the most powerful foundation for any for profit or charitable organization to build upon givedirectly is almost annoying with how data centric they are every decision literally every single question we asked them about why they do or do not do something wa backed by data and we re not talking about just any old data we re talking about peer reviewed audited and randomized controlled trial rcts the holy grail of i m right and you re wrong not that they carry that swagger on their shoulder whatsoever i m humble bragging on their behalf but if they re doing something it s because their data and 3 other independent source data ha proven that s the right decision 5 the mission per se of how gd give isn t about funding what they believe will have the most profitable result rather funding is based on who ha the greatest need basically it s the ultimate anti ruthless capitalism i loved hearing that i e not favoring a 22 year old with a bunch of entrepreneurial idea over a 35 y o single mother of 4 richard aura ongari from homa bay kenya sits inside of the small two room mud hut that he build with part of his cash transfer from givedirectly the majority of his transfer ha been spent on medication for a chronic illness before being able to afford the medication richard could not walk but now that he s being treated you can find him marching all around his property and enjoying his life with his child and grandchild now for the meat of it we went into small kenyan village and met these people who ve taken a cash transfer of 1 000 3 installment over a year here s the breakdown of how their money wa spent 1 housing everyone that we met improved their housing situation in some way they were fixing the following core issue and fyi we didn t see a single home that wa larger than 20 foot by 20 foot that size home would house 5 9 people this small mud shack is home to 5 before receiving his 1 000 transfer from givedirectly samwel odhimbo orimba and his family lived homeless on the shore of lake victoria in homa bay kenya this house where you can see through the wall is a major upgrade for this incredibly grateful and loving family a thatched roof which leak in every rain and must be replaced every 1 3 year i completely sleepless night who can sleep getting rained on ii lead to frequent illness sometimes chronic and death iii lead to missed frequently school for child iv lead to missed work and income b no home living with 4 8 people in a 10x12 one or two room mud hut c upgrading home living in a mud hut with hole in the wall d dirt floor in home constant insect infestation including jigas which burrow in your foot causing crippling pain 2 school fee after primary school kenyan have to pay 60 70 per 3 month semester for school given that people in extreme poverty often earn le than 5 a day for a family of 2 4 kid that meager amount can be a mountain forcing thousand of kid to miss out on school from 5 or 6 year old and onwards 3 child of givedirectly recipient eunice awino omondi and 5 of their friend all living in siaya kenya where president obama s grandmother life eunice s child are now much healthier because they can sleep through the night under a steel roof and not thatched grass that keep them up and cold when it rain 3 food probably the saddest of expenditure in my opinion but a lot of people that we met were purchasing a few month s worth of corn to feed their family i see it a the saddest because such a basic need that s consumed and gone without perpetual benefit bag of corn purchased with a portion of a cash transfer from givedirectly that sit in the recipient doorway living room foyer child s bedroom guest s bedroom 4 other outside of those top three which everyone seemed to have spent at least some portion of their transfer on people purchased medicine for chronic illness cancer hiv etc livestock for income and clothing shoe 5 i ll hide this little gem in here many skeptic think that large portion of the transfer will be wasted on vice like alcohol drug or tobacco or that the sudden influx of cash may increase a person s propensity to seek these substance however there is no evidence that vice consumption is different from others in the community who did not receive transfer with gd s rigorous measurement and auditing they find the effect on vice spending tobacco alcohol etc is negative and insignificant meaning there is no statistically significant effect on vice consumption here is the 3rd party study conducted by princeton edu this finding is consistent with a publication from world bank on vice spending and cash transfer that surveyed dozen of study from around the world now this ended up being a pretty diverse array of purchase considering that half were from one little village and half from another and for u it just highlight the variety of need that exists within any small community i think that if an organization went in to build clean water well offered solar panel mosquito net donate clothes built school or built house only a fraction of the gross value of the investment would be felt by the people in the community shoving a square peg of charity into a round hole of need this is exactly why we believe in giving cash and why we believe in givedirectly of course these people still have need for more but i can confidently say that 91 of what we give them go directly to people who need it most and 97 of that cash transfer served immediate need in their life and i don t think other ngo can say the same i think a more open and participatory conversation on eradicating extreme poverty is critical in this day and age extreme poverty sits at the bottom of maslow s hierarchy of need and contributes to massive issue all the way up the pyramid leading to widespread health epidemic overpopulation lack of education lack of environmental and conservational awareness increased violence and pollution we re all connected and the more people who live in dignity the better off we can all be do you think cash transfer are a terrible idea do you know of a better way
question: here s what happens when you give 1 000 to someone in extreme poverty what happens when you give 1 000 to someone in extreme poverty

title: british police officer reveal what they really think about the war on drug
context: a met police officer with some confiscated drug photo tom johnson this post originally appeared on vice uk good cop bad war is the story of an undercover police officer neil wood who spent over a decade infiltrating britain s biggest drug gang the book released last week provides a unique insight into a world of mind game and violence where the drug trade act a a production line for the creation of ruthless gangster ultimately his experience led wood to reject the way drug are policed in the uk the logic of the drug war only lead one way the police get smarter so the criminal get nastier thing can only ever go from bad to worse from savagery to savagery say wood now after having left the force he is chairman of leap uk law enforcement against prohibition a pro drug legalization activist group consisting of ex law enforcement official but to what extent are wood and his colleague at leap uk and those currently employed in the police force rare specimen how thin on the ground are drug cop who think they are fighting the wrong fight expressing sympathy for anything other than hardline prohibition even to their colleague is something of a risk in the black and white them and u world of police culture even so every now and then drug cop open up about the reality of clearing the street of dealer and drug neil wood buying crack while undercover in 1995 photo courtesy of neil wood i spoke to mike fisher a senior drug investigator for britain s organized crime busting bureau the national crime agency nca he asked for his name to be changed to avoid disciplinary action a his view will definitely not be found anywhere near the page of the nca s annual report if the nca stopped targeting drug gang it would change nothing he explained you would see little change in the high street society would not collapse a it is drug are freely available now all that would happen is that dealing would be more open but it may give u more of a chance to deal with crime such a homicide on the surface it s a counter intuitive line to take for a senior officer working within an agency for which the drug trade is a key target law enforcement against drug is completely ineffective and ha been since the misuse of drug act came into force in 1971 say fisher the idea of the state protecting you from yourself just doesn t work we ve spent billion of pound trying to prohibit drug but there s le chance of it working than canute stopping the wave photo andoni lubaki fisher tell me that arresting people on the street for drug is an endless cycle and that it s the same with the larger fish whenever we remove a big guy someone else usually a lieutenant replaces him within day the more we try the harder it get increased enforcement keep these people looking over their shoulder they become more covert about their activity and that make our job harder fisher s solution is to take the portugal route decriminalize personal use of all drug from cannabis to heroin and look at legalizing production and supply i believe consenting adult have a choice a to what they put in their body it will also make it easier for heroin and crack user to get the help they need and free up police time to go out on patrol and deal with other crime he say ideally production should be wrested from organized criminal and managed by government surprisingly he tell me around half of britain s elite drug detective at nca have similar liberal attitude to the drug problem but what about those drug cop working below nca level in town and city across the uk to gauge what they truly think about their daily task you need to be a fly on the wall so that s the exact position that university of sheffield criminologist dr matthew bacon took he spent two year embedded with drug detective in a town and a major city the identity of which are secret in the uk and wrote about his experience in taking care of business published last month most officer were anti drug and fully supported prohibition drug were seen a being behind all that s bad in society this gave them a righteousness in their action observed bacon but within this recreational drug user social dealer and nightclub were far le of a crime problem than alcohol a drug which few officer had a problem with it s perhaps not surprising given the police s moral code that most of the officer he hung around with viewed junky a lazy undeserving scumbags in 2012 a former undercover officer who disguised himself a a heroin user dealer told me it made me realize how bad cop can be to drug addict i wa abused assaulted and threatened with being fitted up by having drug planted on me on a regular basis to the anti drug team bacon shadowed heroin dealer were one of the most despised group in society so much so that they were seen a police property object that police could do with a they wished almost without exception dealer were depicted a deplorable and dangerous outlaw say bacon they were made the scapegoat of the drug problem photo marco tulio valencia drug cop who saw themselves a elite crime fighter had sufficient respect however for the the mr bigs of the drug world they saw those who ran professional outfit and had family at home a worthy adversary and a good collar for which they would earn respect among their colleague despite all this there wa acceptance often expressed by officer off duty after a few pint that they were not waging a war on drug but managing an unbeatable problem in order to keep the public happy one detective sergeant told bacon sometimes i think we re like those japanese soldier in world war ii you know those one on the island who just kept fighting because they didn t know the war wa over only difference is we d lost the war before we even started fighting another officer told him we ve thrown everything at it even the kitchen sink but drug problem just keep getting worse in the end the drug are still on the street no matter how many people we lock up there are rebellious notion even among the rank and file when i went stop and searching in soho with one of the met police s sniffer dog team in 2013 i wa surprised to hear from a regular beat officer and his colleague that they thought cannabis should be legalized entirely i say legalize the lot one said legalize it and tax it said the other if someone want to turn the sky green and the grass blue then it s up to them i can t see the difference between alcohol and cannabis the official line is that drug are under control but they are not i call up simon kempton a police sergeant from dorset who ha specialized in drug enforcement and sits on the national board of the police federation a body that represents rank and file officer he agrees with wood that the drug trade house the most violent people in the country but belief prohibition is crucial to taking them out i can t speak for everyone but in my opinion drug policing is worthwhile all day every day he say i get it it can seem futile when we take out someone knocking out kilo of cocaine who s replaced within two hour but the reason it s worth doing is because the drug is not just about the drug trade it s weapon terrorism people trafficking money laundering it straddle the spectrum of the most serious crime such a murder kidnapping serious assault which all go hand in hand with the drug trade we are taking out the worst people in our society when they assault people it s not just a punch up outside a pub we are talking about sending a message through retribution and torture these people have to protect their trade from others so they use extreme level of violence you have to be the scariest biggest person on the block otherwise they will take your money from you undercover police officer would not take the huge risk infiltrating gang if they did not think it wa worthwhile undercover drug policing is not cheap but it s very cost effective it s rare to get a not guilty after undercover work because of all the evidence that s been gathered yes people can feel demoralized that they ve put themselves on the line and then someone end up getting just a coupe of year but that s the way it is sometimes however sgt kempton said that for rank and file officer policing cannabis wa another matter and that many officer sympathized with the path taken by durham police in going easy on low level cannabis offense with dwindling resource force are having to focus their limited number on area which represent the greatest harm to wider society while policing cannabis is still a legitimate action i believe most officer and the public would support a focus on other area of crime over the year writing about the drug trade i ve met drug cop who have told me that their job is similar to that of the drug user or trafficker a series of almost addictive drug bust hit that perpetuate the game there are some who have crossed the line completely to become dependent drug user themselves and others who are disgusted by the stigmatization of drug user and even dealer one female drug cop i spoke to told me there are some pretty nasty piece of work out there but some of them are just ordinary people behind every user and runner there s a story she said a lot of people say drug addict and drug dealer are scum of the earth but they don t know anything about them wood book will open the public s eye to the raw violence and canniness of the drug world and the length police will go to in order to disrupt it but after year fighting at the apex of the drug war his conclusion and that of other experienced officer who have chosen to speak out must be heeded if we want to find a solution to a problem that ha been trashing community around the world for decade

title: how safe is your dna
context: a new high tech controversial law enforcement procedure ha some people worried it threatens the privacy of our dna cbs news correspondent anne marie green writes about how she came across this story and the angie dodge murder investigation which she reported for 48 hour in the dna of a killer i first learned about the 20 year old murder of angie dodge in a roundabout way after getting my dna analyzed by one of those commercial dna database when i got my result back i wa not surprised there were no big revelation and just a i suspected i am not related to royalty but i did wonder if i could learn anything more from the dna report that search sent me down a rabbit hole that lead me to the story of michael usry jr a young filmmaker who became a suspect in the angie dodge murder investigation after getting my dna report i learned that there are a number of genealogy site educational institution and company that are willing to offer you further insight into what your dna may reveal a long a you re willing to upload your dna profile to them some of these site charge money while others are simply willing to analyze your dna profile in exchange for adding your profile to their database i probably uploaded my profile to about four site one told me the type of workout supplement i should be taking another searched public family tree for family connection there wa even one that promised to create a diet tailor made for me based on my dna i gave no thought to how my profile could be used by these company or institution down the road then i heard that the new york city police department wa trying to get permission to do something called a familial dna search what doe that mean police hunting for a killer in a high profile murder case wanted to use his dna to search new york state s criminal database for a relative of his they had already searched for the killer but he wa not in the database if they could find someone related to him they would have a family name making it easier to track down the killer a quick search of the phrase familial dna and i learned authority in california had used it to apprehend a serial killer who had eluded them for 25 year the infamous grim sleeper lonny franklin jr had a son who wa serving time on a felony weapon charge and his dna had been uploaded to the california criminal database a familial search connected father and son allowing police to finally make an arrest a little more searching and i stumbled across a blog post about a young filmmaker named michael usry jr a familial search conducted by idaho fall police landed usry in a stark interrogation room where he wa grilled by detective and asked for his dna without any explanation i tracked usry down on facebook and asked him to call me when we finally spoke he told the whole story how his father had participated in a genealogical study through their church giving a sample of his dna to a public database which wa later purchased by ancestry com year later in an attempt to crack the 20 year old cold case murder of angie dodge police conducted a familial dna search in that very database and found an anonymous donor who appeared to be a very close match to the killer s dna after obtaining a search warrant for ancestry com to reveal his name detective learned it wa a man named michael usry sr when cop built out his family tree they found usry had a son cop tracked him down and began investigating a i talked with michael usry he told me he wa very angry about being caught up in the investigation but he wa even angrier about something else there wa a man serving time for angie s murder christopher tapp who usry belief is innocent after i hung up the phone i started researching angie dodge s murder and the case against chris tapp i learned that authority had never found tapp s dna at the crime scene tapp wa convicted and had at that point served nearly 20 year because of his own word a confession he made to police i wa immediately struck by the fact that michael usry jr and chris tapp had found themselves in similar situation 20 year apart both men said they knew nothing about the murder of angie dodge both men had their dna tested and both men did not match that of the killer yet one man went to prison and the other man went home that wa the story i pitched to 48 hour executive producer susan zirinsky chris tapp serving time for the murder of idaho teen angie dodge show cbs news correspondent anne marie green what his life is like inside the the day both michael usry and i went to see chris tapp in prison i wa struck by how soft spoken and kind tapp wa he cried twice that day once when i asked about the moment in his interrogation when he began to implicate himself in angie s murder and a second time when michael usry showed him a video of something that wa shot for a documentary usry is making about this case it wa an interview with tapp s wife lori who tapp had met and married while in prison in the video lori spoke of how much she admired her husband and believed in his innocence the interview wa conducted shortly before lori wa killed in a car crash and this wa the first time tapp had heard her voice since the accident i think there are many lesson in this case but writing strictly a it relates to the privacy of dna database the lesson is this when you trade your dna for information you are also giving it away and the database you give it to owns it what if that company go out of business and sell the database do the protection you have been promised still stand what if an insurance company want to know if you carry a specific gene that could increase your chance of getting cancer or indicates a penchant for risk taking right now the judicial system is playing catch up when it come to your right and protection so we should all be aware and read the fine print there is nothing wrong with wanting to know where you came from and what your gene can tell you about your health just make sure you know what you are signing up for despite what happened michael usry s father doe not regret participating in a dna study but rest assured that his son never will

title: why unbreakable remains the ultimate superhero movie little white l
context: i n the superman comic there is a character called bizarro a twisted villainous inversion of the iconic hero bizarro look and act like superman but life by the exact reverse logic he say adjective to mean their opposite he see it a a crime to do good and so on there s a great seinfeld episode based on the character in today s age of superhero movie ubiquity it s tempting to read 2000 s unbreakable a a bizarro version of everything that proceeded it the basic similarity are all there a cloaked protagonist with superhuman strength lock horn with a scheming criminally insane supervillain we see the reluctant hero played here by bruce willis come to term with his power use them for civic protection and watch him win the girl before finally overcoming his nemesis we get both character origin story in flashback and both are played by hollywood a lister it s the preeminent blockbuster blueprint and yet it by no mean and exaggeration to say that unbreakable is the exact antithesis of marvel and dc s current output for starter it clock in at 106 minute and it cast barely extends beyond the four central actor nothing explodes erupts or is shot at from beginning to end there is no shouting the film is shot and cut with a near maddening degree of patience it soundtrack almost noiseless for long spell and it resort to eye catching cgi not once it may be anathema to the box office behemoth of today but there s no doubt that m night shyamalan s film is a superhero movie in the truest sense nor that a it camera glide affectionately down the aisle of comic book store drinking in vintage illustration it show a genuine passion for the original form that is unmatched by anything that ha come since with the possible exception of sam raimi s spiderman film the present glut of cinematic universe forging comic book adaptation ha born some decent film and some terrible one but none can claim to rival the atmosphere and immersion of unbreakable remember the face clawing tedium that wa the final hour of man of steel indestructible hero and indestructible villain throwing each other through brick wall ad nauseum cgi skyscraper reduced to cgi rubble at a rate of knot the level of peril remaining at precisely zero throughout unbreakable s final encounter includes not a single building flattened not a single punch thrown and last all of five minute instead we see willis david dunn defeat his arch nemesis by dobbing him in to the authority it is a scene of understated gravitas perhaps the most affecting showdown of any modern superhero movie it s also significant that the other character at the heart of unbreakable is samuel l jackson s villain six year before he wa being driven to high pitched distraction by those muthafuckin snake on that muthafuckin plane hollywood s keenest scenery stealer took to the screen with uncharacteristic restraint a embittered comic art dealer elijah price barely raising his voice above a murmur throughout and his one concession to theatricality the berating of a customer intending on buying a limited edition print for his kid work a a nice metaphor for how the film want to treat it audience like adult if heath ledger s joker wa so arresting because of his lack of motive jackson s cane clutching baddie chill precisely because his are so plainly stated but while ledger used a manic physicality to unnerve jackson achieves the same end through the opposite mean his resolutely undemonstrative mr glass is straight from the john doe school of dead calm supervillainy the scene where he repeatedly sabotage a book store clerk s attempt to wheel him out of the shop is a more effective more affecting demonstration of directionless rage than any of the extravagant act of terrorism enacted by his screen successor while today s superhero movie aim for excitement via loud action and bloated narrative unbreakable is deadly quiet only lightly dusted with plot and told with an everyday realism that verge on mundanity it sole fight sequence is unpleasant and ungainly actively un thrilling shot from a distance in one unbroken take admittedly the film s slow pacing can seem a bit strained at time but it s a directorial style that take gut to pull off this effectively and one that s aged well over a 16 year period in which frenzied spectacle ha become the new normal two year after unbreakable wa released raimi s first spider man film became the highest grossing film of that year taking close to half a billion dollar worldwide and effectively igniting the superhero movie boom a decade on marvel s list of past and prospective release stand at 45 while dc having latterly leapt aboard the gravy train between them these studio are working hard to ensure that the summer blockbuster season remains choc a bloc with superhero movie a trend which show no sign of letting up these are mediocre time mr dunn jackson tell robin wright s audrey dunn in unbreakable people are starting to lose hope he didn t know the half of it published 21 aug 2016
question: why unbreakable remains the ultimate superhero movie what make unbreakable a superhero movie

title: something crazy is happening to swiss bond and it s a sad sign for the world economy
context: harold cunningham getty image investing in government debt used to be a boring pretty straightforward proposition you buy a bond then you get back interest payment so easy even your great uncle mort can do it jordan weissmann jordan weissmann is slate s senior business and economics correspondent these day thing aren t so straightforward the sovereign debt market have devolved into a bizarro world of upside down expectation yield on government bond from all around the world have been plunging thanks to anxious investor buying them for their safety bond yield fall a price rise and in many instance the return have cratered below zero a quartz report thursday around a third of all developed country government debt or more than 7 trillion in term of market value is now trading at negative yield meaning that buyer are willing to pay more for these bond than they will eventually get back if they hold them to maturity this is remarkable country like germany have been selling short and midterm debt at negative yield for a while but now it s happening with bond dated for 10 year or longer investor are basically banging down the door for the guarantee that they will only lose a little bit of money over the next decade or two the most mind blowing example of this trend is switzerland last week yield on all of it government bond out to 50 year turned negative investor are now expected to pay for the privilege of lending money to the swiss for a half century at a time other country are getting nearly a good deal fifteen year german and japanese bond yield have also drifted below zero even economically wounded spain can borrow for a few year at a time and theoretically make a profit it s like a bad financial world play on a yakov smirnoff joke in switzerland lender pay you why are investor settling for these kind of term for one they don t see many other safe option the world economy still feel shaky especially after the brexit vote which sent bond yield even lower meanwhile stashing cash in a vault somewhere cost money and effort you need to cover the cost of security and storage so they re willing to pay government to essentially hold their euro or yen or swiss franc the fact that long dated bond are going negative also mean that the market don t expect inflation to rise much down the line which mean they don t expect world growth to pick up much either it may even be a sign that some investor see deflation on the horizon since a bond with a negative yield could theoretically be profitable if price fall enough in a country all of which is to say today s sub zero bond yield are a sign of how deeply pessimistic investor have become about both the near and somewhat distant future and if they stay down they could create some nasty problem of their own when long term interest rate fall too low for instance it make it very hard for bank to earn a profit by borrowing and lending this is playing out all over but right now people are looking very nervously at italy s bank in particular which are parched for profit while sitting on a pile of bad loan a matt o brien note at the washington post low bond yield around the world can make it hard for central bank to ever raise rate since the second they do investor will rush to buy that government s bond among other thing that can push up the value of a currency hurting export and risking deflation
question: something crazy is happening in switzerland and it a bad sign for the world economy what is happening in switzerland that is a bad sign for the world economy

evolution changed u in any way actually yes thousand of gene have evolved recently in the last 40 000 year change we are seeing include smaller brain more efficient not dumber resistance to disease increase in adhd and blue eye yes blue eye genetic analysis say the first blue eyed human appeared 6 000 10 000 year ago somewhere in the black sea region for whatever reason the phenotype became very popular conferring a 5 greater chance for reproduction and today about half a billion blue eyed folk exist another famous example is hgbs sickling hemoglobin a gene that make human immune to malaria malaria is the number one killer of human so it make sense that a mutation eventually arose that make human red blood cell resistant to the malaria parasite and for the gene to rise in frequency in malaria prone population sub saharan africa unfortunately the same gene also cause sickle cell anemia we all have two copy of every gene in our body one from mom one from dad and if one copy is the malaria resistant mutant hgbs you re fine but if both are the mutant you get sickle cell disease the good news is that many other gene confer resistance to malaria and we are also seeing leprosy and tuberculosis resistance gene appearing too another example is the gene for lactose tolerance primitive man would drink milk a a baby and then never again so the amount of lactase enzyme which break down a common sugar in milk would fall after a few year of age over time however human have evolved so that certain population will keep producing the enzyme into late adulthood a expected the lactose tolerant trait appears most often in the region where dairy farming arose first and became an important part of the diet caucasian tolerance for milk is supposed to have evolved only 3 000 8 000 year ago and is now found in nearly 95 of north european our mouth are changing too they are getting smaller and more bullet shaped our teeth aren t quite changing a fast which is why orthodontics and wisdom teeth removal still exist for now more and more people are being born without wisdom teeth or have their wisdom teeth erupt later if at all wisdom teeth were useful before knife and cooking when human would probably lose molar to chewing hard food and needed the wisdom teeth a replacement today 35 of people lack wisdom teeth although the gene involved in this are unknown so we aren t quite sure why this is happening yet darwin s theory of natural selection evolves so what will we look like 100 000 year from now assuming we still exist that far in the future even if we ignore new title: in a rare move supreme court allows 24 week pregnant woman to abort
context: coming to rescue to a 24 week pregnant woman facing danger to her life due to an abnormality in the foetus the supreme court on monday granted her permission to terminate her pregnancy the bench allowed a plea of a mumbai based 22 year old woman to terminate her pregnancy after taking into account her medical report which of a team of seven doctor of king edward memorial kem hospital in mumbai the report say that the there wa very little chance of survival of the foetus and the lady s life would be engendered if it wa not aborted the apex court had appointed the board of seven senior doctor to conduct a medical examination of the lady and directed it to file a report about her condition and advisability of permitting a medical termination of pregnancy complying with it order the board filed a report and favoured medical termination of the pregnancy it said that the foetus wa detected with anencephaly a serious defect where part of the skull are not adequately developed on the basis board s suggestion the bench allowed the lady to undergo an abortion and directed that the termination would be done under the supervision of the board the court said that it wa not necessary to go into medical and medico legal aspect of the identity of the foetus and the matter is to be decided from the standpoint of the petitioner to preserve her life in these circumstance we consider it appropriate and in the interest of justice particularly the right of the petitioner to preserve her life that she be allowed to undergo the termination of pregnancy the termination shall be done by the doctor of kem hospital further the termination shall be supervised by the same medical board the bench said the court said the foetus is not compatible with living outside the uterus in other word the foetus would not be able to survive equally rather more important the continuance of the pregnancy would endanger the physical and mental health of the petitioner the woman approached the court after doctor refused to terminate the pregnancy a it wa not allowed under the medical termination of pregnancy act 1971 the law permit a woman to terminate her pregnancy till 20 week if two registered practitioner express the unanimous opinion that continuation of the pregnancy would threaten the mother s life or the foetus ha severe abnormality this is the third incident in recent year when the apex court ha allowed woman to abort beyond the period prescribed by law in july last year the court had allowed a rape survivor s distress plea to abort her 24 week pregnancy citing serious abnormality with the foetus the court had allowed her to abort on the basis of a medical report from kem hospital which said that foetus had serious abnormality with slim chance of surviving the full term originally published in the time of india just in

title: donald trump take poll lead over hillary clinton is it time to panic
context: for the first time republican donald trump seems to have edged ahead of democrat hillary clinton in presidential polling but only just what doe it mean and should those opposed to trump be worried the polling data site realclearpolitics rcp take an average of national poll that ask american who they would choose in a contest between the two candidate a scenario that now look inevitable on sunday rcp updated their number to show that trump is now on average 0 2 percentage point ahead of clinton that gap might be narrow but it ha still led some including a senior election analyst at rcp to conclude it s probably time to panic i d disagree for those concerned about the prospect of a trump victory it s been time to panic for a while zooming out from a single statistic show it delayed panic although this might be the first time that trump ha come out on top in the rcp polling average he ha come very close to doing so on two prior occasion in september and december of last year since september clinton s lead ha fluctuated significantly from being a large a 11 percentage point to a narrow a 0 6 in other word there have been many other period when trump s opponent should have been worrying before now just a it took pundit a while to wake up to the fact that trump wa a sufficiently popular candidate to win the republican nomination it seems that they have also been slow to switch focus to his chance of winning the white house part of the reason why they didn t panic before wa a belief that measuring american public opinion a long time before a national election is a bad predictor of voting pattern why because people change their mind november is still six month away the alternative view is that preference may be becoming hardened now making voter behavior le likely to shift looking backward rather than forward result from the last six presidential election suggest that 31 state are safe based on the fact that the same party ha consistently won them unsurprisingly polling company are investing their time and resource in state they think might swing and therefore determine electoral outcome nationally state like arizona florida north carolina ohio and west virginia so far polling suggests neither candidate ha a significant lead in those state which could provide extra cause for concern for those worrying about a trump win polling on a pedestal all that said the rcp polling average is not the perfect political barometer it is so often held up to be the polling average ha become the go to number for those trying to make quick sense of the state of the presidential race that s problematic in itself this election can t be predicted on the basis of just one number not least because a candidate s vote share doe not neatly translate to their chance of winning the white house each state wields a different number of electoral vote so it matter how a candidate s support is distributed throughout the country democratic victory in highly populous state which have more electoral vote to award could cause the performance of the democratic candidate in the electoral college to outstrip her or his performance in the popular vote in 2008 barack obama won 68 of the electoral college vote with only 53 of the popular vote clinton may be buoyed in the 2016 election cycle by traditional democratic strength in populous state such a new york new jersey illinois and california there s another much bigger problem with the rcp average though it s only a good a the individual poll that make it up rcp always take a straight average of the five most recent poll that were conducted once you peek under the hood you ll see that an average of 0 2 percentage point flattens out some very different finding these are the five latest poll rcp used to calculate trump s narrow lead abc news washington post trump lead by 2 percentage point nbc news wall street journal clinton lead by 3 percentage point rasmussen report trump lead by 5 percentage point fox news trump lead by 3 percentage point cbs news new york time clinton lead by 6 percentage point these poll have different result in part because they use different methodology for assessing public opinion although they were all conducted during a relatively similar period of time which is essential when trying to get a snapshot of what the public think now the poll by nbc wsj and fox news only spoke to registered voter rasmussen interviewed likely voter while the abc news washington post poll simply spoke to adult 82 of whom were registered voter all poll claim to speak to a nationally representative sample of adult but virtually none will publish data showing where their respondent were based perhaps rasmussen report had to adjust their finding to account for the fact that they only managed to speak to two people in iowa we just don t know language matter too two of the poll mentioned above conducted their interview in spanish and english it seems that the others did not methodology matter they re one reason why the footnote in each poll mention slightly different degree of accuracy take the abc news washington post poll for example those number have a margin of error of 3 5 percentage point that mean that trump s reported lead of 2 percentage point could have actually been a high a 5 5 percentage point or it could be that hillary clinton actually led by 1 5 percentage point polling is far from perfect to understand what will happen when the country vote this november pundit would do better to look at the electoral map demographic and most importantly of all listen to the concern of voter

text: it s been time to panic for a while

title: whale ear wax reveals animal s exposure to stress toxin scientist say
context: wax inside a whale s ear store all sort of useful information on the animal s exposure to pollutant and stress level throughout life researcher have found the team led by sascha usenko a environmental scientist at baylor university in waco texas extracted an earplug from a blue whale balaenoptera musculus killed in a collision with a ship off the coast of santa barbara california in 2007 and found it had come into contact with several organic pollutant and contained high level of the stress hormone cortisol a it reached sexual maturity it s difficult to recover time specific information on chemical exposure for almost any animal say stephen trumble a biologist also at baylor and a co author of the study published in proceeding of the national academy of science this week that is especially true of the relatively rare blue whale the world s largest inhabitant decimated by historic whaling practice blue whale number just 5 000 12 000 individual worldwide and they are threatened by entanglement in fishing net environmental noise and pollution scientist have long used whale blubber a a record of the chemical that these enormous creature absorb a they traverse the ocean but analysis of blubber doe not indicate when chemical contamination occurred or how long it lasted the whale earplug from a blue whale that wa used in the study whale earwax is a fat rich deposit that store the same chemical data a blubber but it also record time similarly to the ring of a tree the wax is laid down in light and dark band with each band correlating roughly to a six month period in baleen or filter feeding whale earwax form a solid plug that may be ten of centimetre long and remains intact even after it death chemical signature usenko and his team identified their specimen a a male aged about 12 year during his brief life he came into contact with 16 persistent organic pollutant including pesticide and flame retardant exposure to the most persistent chemical wa greatest in the first year and accounted for one fifth of his total lifetime contact suggesting a transfer of contaminant from his mother in the womb and during nursing maternal transfer of pollutant is known to happen in other mammal such a seal and human once these compound enter the food chain they are passed on and accumulate some of these chemical are no longer in use such a flame retardant that were outlawed in 2005 but they can stick around for 50 or 60 year say usenko other toxin uncovered from the earwax were probably picked up along the way mercury which can cause brain damage spiked twice in the sample at around five and ten year over the whale s life concentration of cortisol a stress hormone doubled the peak wa directly after the whale reached sexual maturity at about ten year old suggesting stress from sexual competition but it is unclear whether the overall increase wa caused by natural event such a weaning or by human activity such a pollution and noise the research is exciting say jeremy goldbogen a marine biologist at cascadia research collective in olympia washington but the inability to distinguish baseline stress level from those associated with anthropogenic disturbance is a limitation of the study the male blue whale whose earplug wa harvested for the study michelle berman kowalewskic ph d santa barbara museum of natural history santa barbara calif usenko and his team are now hoping to investigate that question by analysing some of the 1 000 or more whale specimen in museum worldwide if we can look at individual that lived in an environment without some of the stress we see now then we could tease out the cause of the cortisol increase he say this story originally appeared in nature news

title: 7 conservative classic every american should read
context: a the populist conservative movement continues to grow and expand in the age of president trump a new generation of energized voter and young people will do well to arm themselves with the intellectual firepower of the giant upon whose shoulder today s movement rest here then are seven conservative classic that should be on every american s bookshelf 1 idea have consequence by richard weaver originally published in 1948 idea have consequence foresaw the corrosive influence of moral and cultural relativism decade before the left harnessed those force to undermine western civilization one of america s greatest conservative intellectual and an esteemed twentieth century rhetorical scholar richard weaver erected an intellectual fortress around absolute truth long before progressive mounted their frontal assault on notion of right versus wrong good versus evil 2 the road to serfdom by f a hayek in the age of bernie sander today s young generation of would be socialist would do well to read friedrich hayek s 1944 classic broadside against socialism the road to serfdom a member of the austrian school of economics and a winner of the nobel prize in economics hayek warned of the totalitarian reality of socialism s conceit a he put it elsewhere a claim for equality of material position can be met only by a government with totalitarian power 3 the closing of the american mind by allan bloom long before anti milo rioter sparked violence at uc berkeley a university of chicago professor named allan bloom lit academia ablaze with this 1987 classic taking the professoriate to task for eroding higher education curriculum with progressive pablum a staunch defender of the classical canon of great work every thinking person must read bloom explained how the intellectual corruption of the humanity and art led to an erasure of student understanding of the proper moral order that undergirds western civilization 4 a choice not an echo by phyllis schlafly the late great matriarch of modern conservatism phyllis schlafly did more to advance and win the battle of idea than many young conservative understand the tip of her intellectual spear a choice not an echo reshaped the contour of american conservatism and ha sold an astounding three million copy since it release over a half century ago the original anti establishment crusader schlafly s book argued that conservative must be willing to fight for a voice within the republican party s establishment leadership and helped pave a path for barry goldwater s nomination 5 capitalism and freedom by milton friedman nobel prize winning economist milton friedman redefined the field of economics in addition to being an intellectual titan he wa a sterling writer with a knack for distilling complex topic with wit and clarity any nobel prize winner who can string together a sentence like this deserves to be read if you put the federal government in charge of the sahara desert in 5 year there d be a shortage of sand 6 a conflict of vision by thomas sowell there are no bad thomas sowell book so we could have easily recommended many of his other classic but a conflict of vision crystalizes the stake involved in the clash between conservative and progressive ideology and how radically different outcome are when one side prevails over the other one of america s most lucid conservative economist sowell s book draw upon everything from rousseau to hobbes to adam smith to illustrate the intellectual impulse that drive conservative and progressive to think and act the way they do 7 gulag archipelago by aleksandr solzhenitsyn hailed a one of the greatest nonfiction book of the twentieth century gulag archipelago is the first person account of soviet dissident aleksandr solzhenitsyn s eight year spent a a prisoner inside the russian gulag for criticizing stalin and the soviet communist system in his private letter a winner of the nobel prize in literature solzhenitsyn s ability to combine lyrical prose with piercing reportage of communism s moral horror are virtually without equal

title: eat these food for better sleep
context: whether it s a jolt after a cup of coffee or drowsiness after thanksgiving dinner most people have personally experienced how food and drink can affect their energy and alertness with a many a 35 of american adult suffering from symptom of insomnia it s understandable that there s a strong desire to take advantage of food and drink for better sleep both diet and sleep are complex which mean there s no silver bullet or single food that is guaranteed to help with sleep however there are some food and drink that may make it easier to get a great night s sleep specific food that can affect sleep researcher including nutritionist and sleep expert have conducted different type of study to try to discover the best food for sleep while this research provides important clue it s not conclusive in general there s a lack of direct evidence about specific food that are good for sleep in addition the range of variety of cultivar of most food mean that their nutrient profile can be inconsistent for example some variety of red grape have high level of melatonin while others have virtually none climate and growing condition may further alter the nutrient in any particular food product that said there are indication that certain food can make you sleepy or promote better sleep sometimes this is based on a particular research study and in other case on the underlying nutritional component of the food or drink dietary choice affect more than just energy and sleepiness they can play a major role in thing like weight cardiovascular health and blood sugar level just to name a few for that reason it s best to consult with a doctor or dietician before making significant change to your daily diet doing so help ensure that your food choice support not just your sleep but all of your other health priority a well kiwi the kiwi or kiwifruit is a small oval shaped fruit popularly associated with new zealand even though it is grown in numerous country there are both green and gold variety but green kiwi are produced in greater number kiwifruit posse numerous vitamin and mineral most notably vitamin c and e a well a potassium and folate some research ha found that eating kiwi can improve sleep in a study people who ate two kiwi one hour before bedtime found that they fell asleep faster slept more and had better sleep quality it is not known for sure why kiwi may help with sleep but researcher believe that it could relate to their antioxidant property ability to address folate deficiency and or high concentration of serotonin tart cherry and tart cherry juice a the name indicates tart cherry have a distinct flavor from sweet cherry sometimes called sour cherry these include cultivar like richmond montmorency and english morello they may be sold whole or a a tart cherry juice several study have found sleep benefit for people who drink tart cherry juice in one study people who drank two one cup serving of tart cherry juice per day were found to have more total sleep time and higher sleep efficiency these benefit may come from the fact that tart cherry have been found to have above average concentration of melatonin which is a hormone that help regulate circadian rhythm and promote healthy sleep tart cherry may also have an antioxidant effect that is conducive to sleep malted milk and nighttime milk malted milk is made by combining milk and a specially formulated powder that contains primarily wheat flour malted wheat and malted barley along with sugar and an assortment of vitamin it is popularly known a horlick s the name of a popular brand of malted milk powder in the past small study found that malted milk before bed reduced sleep interruption the explanation for these benefit is uncertain but may have to do with the b and d vitamin in malted milk milk itself contains melatonin and some milk product are melatonin enriched when cow are milked at night their milk ha more melatonin and this milk may be useful in providing a natural source of the sleep producing hormone fatty fish a research study found that fatty fish may be a good food for better sleep the study over a period of month found that people who ate salmon three time per week had better overall sleep a well a improved daytime functioning researcher believe that fatty fish may help sleep by providing a healthy dose of vitamin d and omega 3 fatty acid which are involved in the body s regulation of serotonin this study focused particularly on fish consumption during winter month when vitamin d level tend to be lower nut nut like almond walnut pistachio and cashew are often considered to be a good food for sleep though the exact amount can vary nut contain melatonin a well a essential mineral like magnesium and zinc that are essential to a range of bodily process in a clinical trial using supplement it wa found that a combination of melatonin magnesium and zinc helped older adult with insomnia get better sleep rice study of carbohydrate intake and sleep have had mixed result overall but some evidence connects rice consumption with improved sleep a study of adult in japan found that those who regularly ate rice reported better sleep than those who ate more bread or noodle this study only identified an association and cannot demonstrate causality but it support prior research that showed that eating food with a high glycemic index around four hour before bedtime helped with falling asleep at the same time sugary beverage and sweet have been tied to worse sleep so it appears that not all carbohydrate and high glycemic index food are created equal additional research is necessary to fully identify the sleep related effect of different carbohydrate the impact of carbohydrate on sleep may be influenced by what is consumed with them for example a combination of a moderate amount protein that ha tryptophan a sleep promoting amino acid and carbohydrate may make it easier for the tryptophan to reach the brain turkey is an example of a protein with high level of tryptophan

title: is your makeup adding year to your face the beauty blunder that are making you appear ten year older and how to fix them fast
context: makeup is designed to make woman look and feel their best but a poor application technique could end up doing the opposite according to the top beauty guru in the business applying your foundation blusher and concealer incorrectly can add decade to your look here they share the beauty blunder that are making you appear ten year older and reveal their top tip for ensuring your makeup work for you stop using a heavy coverage foundation rupert kingston co founder of delilah cosmetic explains that high coverage foundation can really accentuate fine line and wrinkle it s better to use a lighter fresher foundation to make the skin look more natural he advises just use concealer where you need it stay away from pressed powder rupert king maintains that they create a heavier dryer look to the skin instead aim for a more dewy moist look to the skin it will help to soften those dryer area where the fine line can show up if you still feel too shiny choose a micro fine loose powder and just apply to the centre of the face avoid nude lipstick rupert belief this hue can make you look sallow and drained and woman should choose colour with a fresher coral or peach undertone don t skip the moisturiser karla powell mua and brand ambassador for mua cosmetic say that applying make up to un moisturised dry skin can enhance your line so before applying your make up pack on a rich moisturiser which will leave your skin feeling nourished and smoother always do your brow brow tend to thin a we age but having a structured brow can take year off of your face instantly lifting and defining your eye area karla advises avoiding gel and pencil which can leave brow looking too harsh and drawn on and opt for a powder formula which will give a much more natural finish never go too dark a this can age you aim to choose only a shade or two darker than your hair colour she add stop using a heavy coverage foundation stay away from pressed powder avoid nude lipstick don t skip the moisturiser always do your brow with powder don t apply blush to the apple of your cheek avoid dark eye beware of the blush denise rabor international makeup artist and founder of wow beauty say many people believe you should apply blusher to the apple of your cheek which is incorrect a this can draw your face downwards you should actually brush blusher sparingly from your ear to halfway across your cheekbone which will make your face look slimmer he said avoid dark eye celebrity facialist and makeup artist nathalie eleni say that dark kohl under the eye can look harsh if not blended so opt for a softer shadow and blend along for a softer finish apply under eye cream correctly eva alexandrides managing director and co founder of 111skin explains that the skin underneath the eye is a different structure to the rest of the face and thus is a lot more sensitive rubbing and pulling at the skin a you apply the cream is a real no go and will make the bag appear worse and more visible use your ring or little finger when applying cream whilst only dabbing tapping or softly massaging the area with sweeping stroke finally give it about a minute or longer to absorb before you put any make up on top of it which will prevent any caking around the area

title: your brain ha a delete button here s how to use it

neural connection for year this ha been the focus for learning new thing but a it turn out the ability to learn is about more than building and strengthening neural connection even more important is our ability to break down the old one it s called synaptic pruning here s how it work your brain s delete button and how to use it imagine your brain is a garden except instead of growing flower fruit and vegetable you grow synaptic connection between neuron these are the connection that neurotransmitter like dopamine seratonin and others travel across glial cell are the gardener of your brain they act to speed up signal between certain neuron but other glial cell are the waste remover pulling up weed killing pest raking up dead leaf your brain s pruning gardener are called microglial cell they prune your synaptic connection the question is how do they know which one to prune researcher are just starting to unravel this mystery but what they do know is the synaptic connection that get used le get marked by a protein c1q a well a others when the microglial cell detect that mark they bond to the protein and destroy or prune the synapse this is how your brain make the physical space for you to build new and stronger connection so you can learn more have you ever felt like your brain is full maybe when starting a new job or deep in a project you re not sleeping enough even though you re constantly taking in new information well in a way your brain actually is full when you learn lot of new thing your brain build connection but they re inefficient ad hoc connection your brain need to prune a lot of those connection away and build more streamlined efficient pathway it doe that when we sleep

he put on his best john goodman i m talking about drawing a line in the sand dude and this scandal seems an appropriate place for the ioc to draw that line look at what happened to east german athlete athlete the stuff they gave them had incredible multi generational physiological damage i regard this a really evil whether you think that doping is inherently bad or the future of athletic excellence title: don t tell her she s getting bigger and never touch the bump fertility expert reveals the pregnancy etiquette everyone should follow

ha helped thousand of woman get pregnant and looked after celebrity including kate winslet and sophie wessex during their pregnancy share her advice 1 don t touch her bump invading people s personal space is not normal etiquette for everyday life you wouldn t rub or touch someone s belly on a normal day so why is this any different if you really want to you can politely ask if you can touch someone s pregnant belly but don t be offended if they say no a this is one of the most annoying and uncomfortable moment for pregnant woman if her baby is kicking and she want you to have a feel she ll invite you to 2 don t ask if she ha chosen a name this might not seem like a big deal but it can be to those who haven t thought of a name yet or those that have but feel that they might be bombarded with judgmental opinion gone are the day when we would name our child john or jane in recent time there s been a general trend to more creative name such a wolf or apple problem arise when she tell you what she s going to name her child and you can t resist sharing all your opinion on why this is a good or bad decision hearing opinion from everyone else is stressful for mother to be it s easier to not ask about the name and just wait for her to announce it once the baby is born i ve found that all child seem to perfectly fit their name in time even if it might sound a strange or unusual name at first 3 don t look shocked when you hear she s pregnant this often happens with woman i see who are also in high flying job when they say they are pregnant their friend and colleague jaw drop open and they get thing like but you re such a career woman or i didn t think you were maternal people can be ambitious and be mum it s not one or the other whether or not you ve seen her maternal side doesn t mean she doesn t have one and whether or not you think she fit into the classic mould of a maternal woman doesn t mean she won t be a brilliant mother 4 don t tell her she s getting bigger and bigger while seeing a friend s bump grow can be really exciting don t comment on the size or shape many of the most clueless comment that annoy pregnant woman come from people subtly judging them for packing on pregnancy pound a pregnant woman is aware that she is growing so there s no need to be constantly reminding her that she s huge big or massive even if she s looking a large she doesn t need to hear it 5 don t tell her she s not big enough following on from the previous comment it is also not nice to tell someone they look small or ask them are you gaining enough weight you may think you re paying a mama to be a compliment when you say you re so tiny or i can barely see your belly but you may only be making her worry about the development and growth of her baby 6 don t congratulate her on social medium if someone tell you they re pregnant they have chosen to tell you and not your friend family and random follower on social medium the decision on when to announce a pregnancy is not up to you therefore don t instantly go to congratulate them on social medium because you might share friend that they haven t told yet or they simply might be keeping the news under wrap until they feel ready 7 don t act like she s sick although pregnancy is in a way a medical condition pregnancy is not an illness pregnant woman can still have fun go out exercise and more attend meeting head department and in today s day and age where so many woman are doing multiple thing like running business building extension and becoming mother they last thing they want is to be treated differently every woman is different some may have severe symptom some may find pregnancy a breeze only they are aware of their limit and how much they can take that said pregnancy can make woman tired so do offer her a seat on the tube 8 don t tell her labour horror story whenever anyone s having a baby others love to share story of their own experience of labour but telling a pregnant woman about your two day labour that ended in emergency c section and you losing half the blood in your body is not helpful labour is a process and the great news is that in today s world with all our wonderful medical advance and pain control most woman get through it and usually once the baby arrives memory of labour fade away it is genuinely terrifying for a woman pregnant with her first child to hear labour horror story so don t share them 9 do tell her she s going to be just fine pregnancy can be a scary time for woman their life are about to change and many fear how they will think feel cope on the other side the bottom line is that all woman try their best and most woman even those who worry they might not be natural mother adapt once their child arrive it might take some longer than others to take to motherhood but that is understandable a there s a lot to take on a a mother in term of looking after a baby and juggling whatever it is they will have to juggle whether that s other child elderly relative high flying career evening course husband and everything else if you throw in fear of post partum depression and then the very real experience of having post partum depression it s no wonder woman feel overwhelmed and anxious about what lie ahead but i ve met thousand of mother over the year and you know they ve nearly all been absolutely fine grown into their new role admirably coped well and become wonderful parent this is what she need to hear
