title: this decadent pumpkin pie recipe ha a salty secret
context: lisa ludwinski of detroit s sister pie amp up canned pumpkin with a variety of winter squash and a layer of tahini i ve enjoyed plenty of pie made from canned pumpkin pure e and evaporated milk they are perfectly smooth and mild and custard like and they make everyone happy this pie is not that pie at least not anymore this is that pie after it left home and learned some thing this is that pie come back with secret and scar and story to tell it taste familiar like sugar pumpkin smoothed out with dairy and set with egg but it s more complex and delicious than ever behold sister pie s delicious tahini cardamom squash pie in all it glory photographer michelle chris gerard bloomberg the recipe see below come from lisa ludwinski of sister pie in detroit she doesn t fear this year s looming canned pumpkin shortage because she make the filling from a bunch of different winter squash split and roasted in her bakery s kitchen between september and november the mix change depending on what s good from delicata and butternut to buttercup and hubbard a little cream infused with floral cardamom pod loosens up the mixture which ludwinski pours over an almost jammy spread of cream cheese that s been blitzed with toasted walnut and tahini the peanut butter like paste made from sesame seed that thin layer of soft pleasingly salty tahini walnut spread is what make this pie sing lisa ludwinski run a team of 12 at sister pie which in addition to pie also sell cooky shortbread and savory dish like salad photographer michelle chris gerard bloomberg there s a large middle eastern population in detroit and i ve been really influenced by the brightness of middle eastern flavor ludwinski said over the phone also i have a total obsessive love for tahini one of michigan native ludwinski s earliest memory is of her parent taking her to a cinnabon and seeing the magic behind the scene i will always remember watching people put the cinnamon into the dough the slicing and the icing ludwinski say it s no coincidence that at sister pie she designed an open kitchen too anyone walking in for a cup of coffee and some shortbread can see baker scooping cooky sealing hand pie with a fork or rolling out dough by hand sister pie s counter is filled with other goody such a these freshly baked peanut butter cooky spiked with paprika photographer michelle chris gerard bloomberg ludwinski moved to new york in 2006 to pursue a career in theater but she wa sidetracked by the food scene at momofuku s milk bar where she worked for christina tosi she developed a taste for low moisture high fat plugra butter which ludwinski now us for all her dough you ve got to use it every time she say because the flavor is so different and so clear she picked up the habit of adding a splash of apple cider vinegar to the dough at four twenty blackbird pie shop in gowanus brooklyn where ludwinski spent a year making pie ludwinski say this give the crust a bit of extra flake and a mild tang this thanksgiving will mark the shop s first holiday since it opening back in april in detroit s west village and ludwinski is planning to stay open until noon to sell local fresh pie like sweet potato marshmallow brandy pecan and salted maple pumpkin it just seems kind of silly for a pie shop to be closed on thanksgiving she say lisa ludwinski of sister pie in detroit photographer michelle chris gerard bloomberg ludwinski s mother ha already ordered pie for the family s holiday meal from sister pie and her grandmother will supplement the dessert spread with her own pumpkin pie that one will be made according to the direction on the side of the can using ready made pie dough and it will also be gone before the end of the day sister pie is at 8066 kercheval ave detroit mi 48214 1 313 447 5550 or sisterpie com note that if you re not up for doing everything from scratch you can follow a side of the can pie recipe and just add that bottom layer of ludwinski s lovely sesame walnut paste for a delicious twist cardamom tahini squash pie adapted from lisa ludwinski of sister pie detroit ingredient for the pie dough 2 1 2 cup all purpose flour 1 cup unsalted butter chilled and cut into chunk 1 teaspoon salt 1 teaspoon sugar 1 2 cup ice water with a splash of apple cider vinegar for the tahini walnut paste 5 tablespoon toasted ground walnut 2 1 2 tablespoon tahini 2 1 2 tablespoon light brown sugar 2 1 2 tablespoon cream cheese softened pinch of salt for the squash pure e 2 winter squash such a butternut buttercup or hubbard 1 2 cup canned pumpkin pure e 2 tablespoon butter for the cardamom cream 1 cup heavy cream 1 tablespoon cardamom pod for the pie filling 1 2 cup light brown sugar 1 tablespoon cornmeal 1 2 teaspoon cinnamon powder 1 2 teaspoon cardamom powder 1 2 teaspoon grated ginger 1 2 teaspoon allspice powder 1 teaspoon salt 1 teaspoon vanilla extract 3 egg 1 cup cardamom cream see below 2 1 4 cup squash pure e see below to assemble and finish 1 egg beaten 1 tablespoon black and white sesame seed toasted step by step blind baking crust filling them with tahini walnut paste pouring over the roasted squash filling and getting the pie into the oven photographer michelle chris gerard bloomberg method 1 prepare the pie dough i n a large bowl combine the flour sugar and salt using a pastry blender cut the butter into the flour until it s in coarse piece about the size of pea add the ice water a tablespoon at a time and begin to gather the dough together with your hand pat the dough into a 1 inch thick square and wrap in plastic to chill for a couple of hour in the fridge or at least 30 minute 2 roast the squash while the crust is chilling preheat the oven to 400 degree using a sharp knife halve the squash and hollow out the seedy center with a spoon place squash cut side up on a baking sheet and brush with butter bake for about one hour or until the flesh is soft and cooked through once it s cooled scoop out the flesh and add to a food processor with the pumpkin pure e and mix until smooth if the squash is very wet place in a cheesecloth and press to get rid of any excess moisture set aside 3 make the cardamom cream i n a small heavy bottomed saucepan bring cream and cardamom to a gentle simmer turn off heat cover and steep for 20 minute strain and set aside to cool 4 mix the filling i n a medium bowl w hisk together light brown sugar spice cornmeal and salt in another bowl mix egg with cardamom cream squash and vanilla and whisk until smooth slowly pour egg mixture into sugar mixture and whisk until combined 5 prepare the pie crust flour your work surface and place the unwrapped dough in the center roll out keeping it moving with your hand and throwing on more flour a needed to prevent sticking until you have a disk of even thickness that s about 12 inch in diameter invert your pie tin or dish onto the circle and cut a circle that is about 1 to 2 inch larger than the tin place the folded dough into the pie tin and gently press it in roll up the extra dough hanging over the edge toward the center of the pie creating a ring of dough then crimp it all around put the crust in the freezer for at least 15 minute 6 blind bake the pie crust so that it hold it shape and is cooked through in the finished pie p reheat the oven to 425 degree with a rack on the lowest level remove the pie crust from the freezer and place a square of aluminum foil over it fill with dried bean and place on baking sheet bake in oven for 15 minute cool for 6 minute then carefully remove foil and bean turn heat down to 325 degree travel with u drive with u eat with u get our weekly pursuit newsletter 7 fill and finish the pie brush the crimped edge of pie crust with a little bit of egg wash then spoon all of the tahini walnut paste onto the bottom of the crust and spread evenly you can use your finger to gently press it down pour the squash filling over the paste and carefully transfer back to oven bake pie for 40 minute to 1 hour until the edge are puffed up and the center is only slightly jiggly then remove from oven and sprinkle lightly with sesame seed the pie should rest for at least 2 hour before slicing and can also chill for a couple of hour in the fridge after it s cooled if you like to serve it cold tejal rao is the new york food critic for bloomberg follow her on twitter at tejalrao and instagram at tejalra or contact her at trao9 bloomberg net left a slice of squash pie right salted maple photographer michelle chris gerard bloomberg

title: watch dillinger return to reading fest after singer s onstage dump wasn t quite what people expected
context: the dillinger escape plan have returned to reading festival for the first time after vocalist greg puciato took a dump onstage and hurled his excrement into the crowd during the band s 2002 performance at the event all because of puddle of mudd this time around the singer emphasized his civilized side by singing the set s opening number prancer sitting on a couch reading newspaper and sipping tea a widely reported the dillinger boy are breaking up after the release and touring cycle of their upcoming album dissociation due out on october 7 puciato told metal hammer about the band s decision extended hiatus would leave people to believe that we think that we re coming back we re breaking up we re not going on an extended hiatus this is a really weird thing to say but we really do still love what we do we don t love it any le we don t love making record any le we don t love being onstage any le and that s the hard part you re making a choice to stop doing something you love which sound insane to people but really what it s about is realizing that if you re a painter you don t just paint until you run out of paint you don t just paint until your arm fall off you make a decision at some time that you made a final brushstroke or when you make a movie you don t just film until you run out of film or hard drive space you make a decision artistically to say even if i m having the best time ever this is the end so in the last few year we started to reach what felt like a thematic conclusion to our band you know particularly ben and i where we realized that in our life psychologically that we were reaching sort of a resolve and that we had used our relationship with one another and our artistic outlet together in dillinger escape plan to kind of work through a lot of thing a people and a a couple of people we started to reach this resolve a thematic resolve and it started to show itself in our music and our lyric and i think we both just started to realize like hey if we re ever going to draw a line and say this is over this seems like a good time and we started talking about it and the fear aspect of it in a way cause right away there wa this gut feeling of oh shit my safety net is being taken away once you got over that fear i think we started to realize that this feel like a very empowering move to say hey now you can look at the dillinger escape plan a a body an artistic body not just on an album to album basis but you can look at the whole band artistically and say this is what this wa and it had a beginning and it had an end and they did close the circle and it is this thing that you can look at a a whole you know i don t like tv show where they just go on and on and on until the rating die i like a movie where someone say hey this ha an end and i made it and at the end i don t want to do another one i don t want to see pirate of the caribbean 7 you know and i feel like once we started to wrap our brain around that we started to feel really comfortable about it it feel correct that s all i can say about it back to the reading 2016 performance you can check out the footage below

title: can linux ever beat window at pc gaming
context: can linux ever beat window at pc gaming window ha long been the undisputed king of computer operating system when it come to gaming but is linux getting to the point where it can take on window in pc gaming a writer at techradar remains quite skeptical about the possibility of linux someday becoming the top gaming operating system for pc game carey report for techradar evidently window isn t going anywhere with a steam market share of nearly 96 a of march 2016 in fact epic game even recently called microsoft out on trying to monopolize pc gaming with it universal window platform initiative although microsoft ha lost sight of what pc gamers want in recent year see game for window live there s no doubt that the current xbox head phil spencer want to bring the company back to it root namely by integrating feature and game from the xbox one into window 10 in contrast valve s attempt at making linux not only the best place to play game from your steam library but actually the heart of your living room are tough to jive with despite making an effort with steamos it doesn t help that a number of company still haven t released their november 2015 bound steam machine after neglecting to comply with the operating system s handicap there s a clear winner here and unless linux rectifies it performance disparity lack of natively supported control option and impoverished game library the o to beat for pc gaming will remain window 10 more at techradar distrowatch review freebsd 10 3 s new feature jesse smith at distrowatch did a full review of freebsd 10 0 a while back and now he ha some thought to share about the new feature that have been added to the recently released freebsd 10 3 jesse smith report for distrowatch freebsd is a venerable operating system often deployed on server due to the project s focus on performance and stability at the beginning of april the freebsd project released version 10 3 of their operating system the release announcement for freebsd 10 3 mentioned several feature and improvement which caught my attention specifically the availability of zfs boot environment 64 bit linux compatibility and jail improvement were of interest to me i wa especially eager to try out freebsd s new jail technology using the iocage front end the iocage software ha been presented a an improvement on and replacement for warden a friendly front end for handling jail environment one of the first thing i wanted to do wa experiment with boot environment for those who have not used them before a boot environment is basically a snapshot of our operating system before performing any major configuration change or software upgrade we can take a snapshot of the operating system this give u a point in time when we knew the operating system wa working we then perform any change or upgrade we want when we boot the system we can choose from the boot menu which snapshot we want to use this allows u to effectively move backward in time and boot older copy of the system this make the operating system virtually bullet proof a almost any change short of hardware failure can be fixed by simply rebooting and selecting to boot an older copy of the operating system the pc bsd and opensuse project have used boot environment successfully for some time now but the technology ha not widely caught on elsewhere the next item on my list of thing to try wa 64 bit linux compatibility freebsd ha a compatibility layer which allows the operating system to run linux executables there are some restriction though for example up until now the linux executable had to be compiled for 32 bit system and any dependency had to be copied into place manually there is a package in the freebsd repository which installs the centos core userland software in essence this give u a bare bone installation of centos 6 in a directory on our freebsd computer this is handy if we need to run linux software alongside freebsd software or if we want to run linux software without the resource overhead of a full featured virtual machine the final feature i wanted to look at wa freebsd jail specifically the way the iocage software work and how it compare to the older warden jail management software jail on freebsd are basically very lightweight virtual machine part of the file system is roped off and process can run in this area jail without knowing about or being able to affect the rest of the system what primarily separate jail from virtual machine is jail all share the host s kernel meaning jailed process must be able to run on our version of freebsd in recent year docker ha provided similar functionality on linux more at distrowatch linus torvalds release linux kernel 4 6 linus ha been very busy working on the next release of the linux kernel and now linux 4 6 ha been released into the wild simon sharwood report on what s new in linux kernel 4 6 for the register new this time around is support for a bunch more arm system on a chip including qualcomm s snapdragon 820 ibm s power9 find it first support although perhaps prematurely given the silicon won t arrive until late 2016 whatever cpu you use to run linux it title: 5 video game that are taking forever to come out
context: making video game is many thing but easy isn t one of them depending on the scope of the project a single game can take hundred of people several year to build and with fickle market and studio losing funding even after a game is announced there s still a chance it will be canceled like these promising game but some game capture the imagination of gamers more than others and sometimes those game seem like they ll never come out here are five game that have either been announced or strongly implied game that people are chomping at the bit to play game we ve been waiting on for a very long time 5 beyond good evil 2 the original beyond good evil came out in 2003 it s a unique game that star jade an investigative reporter who s working on a case about a planet wide alien conspiracy she can kick serious butt when the situation dictate but she s also known to stop and photograph the fauna when she ha a free moment the game wa originally planned to be the first installment of a trilogy but poor sale put a wrench in those gear still the game wa well received by critic and a cult fan base ha been vocal enough that a sequel wa announced in 2008 in the year since an hd remake of the original came out in 2011 but we haven t heard much about the purported sequel is it still in the work will it really see the light of day we may have a while more to wait before we know for sure when we might see it ubisoft maintains that this game is in development and will be released sometime this console generation according to one rumor it could be an nx exclusive 4 kingdom heart 3 for a certain segment of fan the kingdom heart game are a dream come true they combine beloved disney character with fan favorite from square enix s final fantasy series if you happen to fit into the target audience chance are you re well aware of this long running series the original kingdom heart came out for playstation 2 in 2002 and ha seen seven sequel in the interim so it s kind of strange that the series hasn t managed to produce a third official installment instead sticking to prequels remake and some would say filler never fear a third installment is on it way and it s coming only to playstation 4 and xbox one no release date ha been set but have faith that this one will actually happen when we might see it hopefully by 2017 3 final fantasy xv fun fact the game that s currently called final fantasy xv began under the title final fantasy xiii versus which wa first shown to the public way back in 2006 here we are closing in on a decade later and this game still hasn t made it to market what s going on well final fantasy once the leading series of japanese role playing game ha fallen on somewhat hard time the 13th installment in particular didn t exactly light the world on fire in fact most fan of the series would agree that it s been a slow downhill slide since final fantasy x came out in 2001 developer square enix is looking to fix that tarnished reputation by releasing a big important game for the series 15th installment and judging by the trailer and the demo that released alongside final fantasy type o hd they re on the right track will the finished product live up to expectation for that we ll have to wait and see when we might see it november 29 2016 2 the last guardian many longtime playstation gamers have a strong connection to the work of team ico so far the developer ha only released two title ico and shadow of the colossus but they re both singular beautiful game that have made a lasting impression the last guardian is team ico s next project first announced with this trailer in 2009 the game wa scheduled to come out in 2011 but it never made it to market fan finally got a fresh look at the game at e3 2015 and some member of the press have even been able to play small chunk of it despite assurance that it ll launch in 2016 many fan are still skeptical when we might see it sometime in 2016 hopefully 1 half life 3 if there s one game more famous for not existing than the last guardian it s half life 3 if you haven t played the other half life game you might be wondering what the big deal is first off it s a terrific series of shooter that tell a great story in fact the series really laid the groundwork for all story based shooter to come it s no stretch to say that the original half life wa probably the first shooter to tell a story worth following at all making matter worse however is that the last installment half life 2 episode two which came out in 2007 ended on a major cliffhanger but instead of continuing that series and playing off that story s big ol hanging thread valve shifted it effort to the also excellent portal series by now the demand for half life 3 ha reached such a fever pitch that even if valve doe eventually deliver the game it couldn t possibly live up to expectation but do u a solid anyway valve give u half life 3 when we might see it no idea and there s no evidence that it s in development

title: is buying organic really worth it
context: buying organic food typically involves shelling out a premium but is the extra pinch to the pocket actually worth it last week a department of agriculture report revealed just how much it really cost to shop organic organic egg milk and salad green can cost upwards of 60 percent more than conventional alternative while item like apple carrot granola and spinach carry premium of between 7 and 30 percent the study said producing organic food tends to be costlier along every part of the supply chain including farming practice that usually require greater labor input and segregating organic ingredient from conventional one though there may be logical reason for the heftier price tag doe it really make sense a a consumer to pay more for organic food the answer it turn out is anything but straightforward here we explore this hotly contested issue what the heck doe organic mean anyway organic produce according to the usda must be grown without synthetic pesticide synthetic fertilizer or genetically modified organism organic meat ha to come from animal that were raised in a natural setting didn t receive any antibiotic or hormone and were fed 100 percent organic feed by this general definition organic food should be friendlier to the planet and pose le harm to human health chensheng lu an associate professor of environmental exposure biology at harvard university told the huffington post over email when it come to packaged food only a label that say 100 percent organic indicates a product made solely with organic ingredient organic on the other hand mean 95 percent of the ingredient are organic while made with organic ingredient is reserved for product with at least 70 percent certified organic ingredient there s skepticism among consumer however about the trustworthiness of organic label last year a study by market research firm mintel found that a majority of american consumer think organic labeling is merely an excuse to charge more indeed there s some evidence that organic label may not always be reliable a major issue expert say is a lack of a robust monitoring system to keep track of whether product that say they re organic really are still despite a flawed system there do appear to be measurable difference between food labeled organic and those that are not a 2012 meta analysis published in the annals of internal medicine comparing organic and conventional food for example found that exposure to pesticide residue wa more than five time higher in conventional produce a 2014 study found that organic food had significantly lower level of toxic metal compared to conventional alternative and substantially higher level of antioxidant so what doe this mean for human health according to the environmental working group nearly three quarter of 7 000 produce sample tested by the usda in 2014 contained pesticide residue in some case these pesticide persisted on fruit and vegetable even when they were washed or peeled pesticide exposure ha been linked to all kind of health condition from neurodegenerative disease like parkinson s to cancer and birth defect the jury however is still out a to whether or not the pesticide found in conventional food are present in large enough quantity to actually make a difference to human health in the 2012 meta analysis conventional fruit and vegetable were found to have far more pesticide residue than organic produce but the level were almost always under the maximum amount allowed by the environmental protection agency we re exposed to a cocktail of chemical from our food on a daily basis said michael crupain the director of consumer report food safety and sustainability center in an earlier post it s not realistic to expect we wouldn t have any pesticide in our body in this day and age but that would be the ideal we just don t know enough about the health effect some organic food skeptic have also pointed out that non synthetic pesticide are used on some organic farm a well and the science is still hazy a to whether or not those compound have ill effect when it come to the nutritional value of organic food there s also conflicting data the 2012 meta analysis did not find any significant nutritional difference between conventional and organic food a meta analysis published two year later in the british journal of nutrition however found that organic produce may have substantially higher concentration of antioxidant and other potentially beneficial compound a recent study published in february concluded that organic dairy and meat contain about 50 percent more omega 3 fatty acid omega 3 are linked to reduction in cardiovascular disease improved neurological development and function and better immune function wrote study co author chris seal a professor of food and human nutrition at the u k s newcastle university but getting enough in our diet is difficult our study suggests that switching to organic would go some way towards improving intake of these important nutrient a for antibiotic use in food animal the problem are more clear cut the center for disease control note that s cientists around the world have provided strong evidence that antibiotic use in food producing animal can have a negative impact on public health because the drug allow antibiotic resistant bacteria to develop so choosing organic meat or meat raised without antibiotic is better than conventional when it come to this issue other way of measuring worth when considering the benefit of organic food it can be tempting to focus on the impact of such product on human health but a marion nestle author of food politics and professor of nutrition at new york university noted choosing organic ha implication for the earth s well being too when done well more work go into producing organically and organic method are demonstrably better for soil and sustainability she told huffpost organic are about production value those value are important to me according to the food and agriculture organization of the united nation an agency dedicated to addressing world hunger there are many environmental benefit of organic agriculture including long term sustainability greater biodiversity and better soil health but organic farming still isn t perfect one meta analysis found that though organic farming practice had fewer environmental impact per acre this wa not necessarily true per product unit though the health impact of conventional food on consumer remain unclear the detrimental effect of pesticide and other chemical are more clearly documented in the case of farmworkers there s also some evidence that people living in farm community are at risk for chronic health problem a a result of chemical exposure pesticide used in strawberry farm in california for instance are associated with an increased cancer risk among child living in those area according to the department of pesticide regulation lu said choosing organic can also have positive impact on the food industry at large promoting organic agriculture will attract a new cohort of farmer who belief in producing healthier and safer food he said it s also good for the economy by eliminating the corporative monopoly according to food and water watch economic power in the agriculture and food sector is unusually concentrated the four largest company for instance control 85 percent of soybean processing and 82 percent of the beef packing industry an oligopolistic situation that s economically harmful for both farmer and consumer community with more medium and smaller sized farm have more shared prosperity including higher income lower unemployment and lower income inequality than community with larger farm tied to often distant agribusiness the nonprofit writes many organic farm are small operation though big organic farm do exist a well if buying from a small farm is important to you one option is to seek out a local farmer market where you re often able to speak directly with a person who helped grow your produce organic on a budget regularly purchasing organic product may simply not be financially feasible for many consumer so nestle suggests to just buy organic to the extent you can when you can and there are way to do it on the cheap or at least more cheaply 1 prioritize your purchase it is most important for young child pregnant woman and those with weakened immune system to eat organic food advised deborah gerszberg a nutritionist at columbia university s pancreas center in a blog post she also recommends buying organic animal product including egg and milk a often a possible some company aren t certified organic but still pledge not to use hormone or unnecessary antibiotic this would be a good second choice she said choosing organic option for thing that you or your household eat in large quantity is also a recommended practice the repetitive intake of pesticide from food could cause more harm to your health than sporadic exposure said lu for produce buy organic if you re planning to eat the skin of the fruit or vegetable choose organic for the food containing the highest amount of chemical residue and choose conventional food for food with the least residue said gerszberg the environmental working group s dirty dozen and clean fifteen list are helpful resource on this front the first highlight conventional produce with the highest pesticide load such a strawberry apple nectarine grape and spinach the clean list on the other hand catalog produce least likely to hold pesticide residue these include avocado sweet corn pineapple cabbage and cauliflower 2 buy in season and local if possible buying organic produce in season tends to be much kinder on the wallet in addition visiting a farmer market you could try purchasing a crop share or csa community supported agriculture to get local in season produce locally grown food is often fresher and tastier than the alternative the crop are picked at their peak and farmstead product like cheese and are hand crafted for best flavor writes vern grubinger a vegetable and berry specialist at the university of vermont livestock product are processed in nearby facility and typically the farmer ha direct relationship with processor overseeing quality unlike animal processed in large industrial facility buying local food is a community investment grubinger add a way to not just support local business but also to protect local ecosystem and help community become more self sufficient it also support a more sustainable food system by significantly minimizing the use of fossil fuel based transportation it s estimated that the average american meal travel about 1 500 mile to get from farm to plate according to the center for urban education about sustainable agriculture in contrast locally sourced food can travel 200 mile or le 3 buying generic and in bulk are money saver too many mainstream supermarket including safeway target wal mart and h e b carry organic store brand option while costco sam s club and bj s sell organic foodstuff in bulk some supermarket like whole food also have bulk bin stocked with organic grain dried fruit coffee and other product 4 keep an eye out for sale and coupon site like all natural saving and organic deal can help customer surface organic food deal 5 grow your own food it might sound daunting but growing your own produce isn t a difficult a it sound it just requires a bit of effort and patience good housekeeping ha some tip on how to start your own organic garden live in a small apartment the urban organic gardener website s got you covered the bottom line so is buying organic worth it depending on your priority it might be ultimately many expert agree that eating a balanced diet while remaining conscientious about how your food choice impact the health of the planet and farming community is key
question: is buying organic really worth it is buying organic food really worth the extra cost

title: john slattery s god s pocket show that seriously everyone want to work with him
context: after year of playing roger sterling on amc s mad men john slattery is comfortable with a drink in his hand sitting on a leather couch in park city utah with a bloody mary by his side slattery talk le about the ad men of the 1960s and more about the first film that he directed god s pocket which premiered at this year s sundance film festival the dark comedy need a better adjective than dark because most of the film reveals deeply rooted sadness disappointment and failure carried out to perfection by a dream team cast that includes philip seymour hoffman christina hendricks richard jenkins and john turturro slattery ha directed five episode of mad men but this is his first attempt at a feature based on the theater s applause on opening night his future a a director certainly look bright the huffington post joined slattery couch side to find out why it took 10 year to make this happen how surfing keep him from getting a little screwy and why he refused to be in front of the camera this time warning plot spoiler throughout when did you originally come across the material for god s pocket i read the book by pete dexter about 10 year ago and tried to get the right to it but it s a good thing i didn t get the right because i probably wouldn t be able to actually make a good movie then i tried getting the right but someone else owned them so i let it go about five year later someone reminded me of it and asked whatever happened to that book turn out the right were then available so i said all right i m going to outline this thing because i had written a shitty screenplay in between and i didn t want to do that again i did an outline about 100 page long and kind of just dumped everything from the book into it i said okay let s go get the right and then they came back to u and said that they had made a mistake the right were not available same people still owned it after you had put all that time into it i wa making the adjustment bureau at the time and wa sitting in a trailer for a large chunk of the day so it wa like are you going to watch tv or do this when i wa told i couldn t have it i thought well if they have owned this thing for so long and haven t done anything with it i m just going to write it anyway and if someone else make it first fine eventually bob gersh from the gersh agency worked out the deal do you think it made the project that much more appealing because you couldn t have it at first it sort of alleviated the pressure of a production deal or deadline in a way when you re sitting around like actor do and you start to go crazy because you need an outlet i would do this at the end of the day i d put in a few hour and crank it around a little bit and i wouldn t feel crazy that day do you have a different itch that s satisfied by writing versus acting it s the same if i were acting in a play or directing creative people go on vacation and four day in you re like i gotta get out of here i have a lot of energy so i m told i surf a lot you live in l a half the time for mad men we re in new york so i have a place i go surfing in long island isn t that freezing in the winter it is but there s all kind of gear now it s like skiing almost if i sit around and do nothing for a while i get a little screwy what did you find most compelling about the material in god s pocket what made you want to make this film it s very visual which appealed to me i sort of see thing in picture i don t know whether that make me dumb or smart like a kid almost and the dialogue by which i mean the character just the way they expressed themselves wa interesting it wa a simple to the point way of saying thing without saying everything the book is very interior it take place in mickey s head which wa difficult to do in a film you have to show that you can t tell it that wa a challenge mickey s state of mind and his anxiety in hanging on to this woman that he feel lucky to be with he feel that if i lose this woman then i ll never get anybody else like that i think there s a sentence that say he realized that would be the last woman he would ever get without paying for it so even though she might not be in love with him anymore he doesn t really belong in this place he ha no affinity for this place he just ha this woman what i think you get from christina s performance is the disappointment she feel he s not picking up on the signal of what she need you see them having sex and obviously that s not going very well he can t express himself and she need something she need to find out what happened to her son she need him to step up and do the right thing and he s trying but they re missing each other did you consider acting in the film no i got asked if i wa going to and every time i said no people were like good idea laugh which i wa like what the hell do you mean by that i ask because you ve directed a handful of mad men episode that s the least sort of fun of the whole thing being in it some moment where you get relaxed enough where you know the scene have done your homework know the line and you sit down and it can be really fun because you know what you re doing on one side of the camera and know what you re doing on the other like woody allen i mean i would never even put myself in the same stratosphere but he is woody allen he know what he know and he ha the time he ha ben affleck i have to say i admire the hell out of that guy with a move like argo to direct it and then give that kind of performance i don t know how the hell he dealt with that stress another example of director starring in movie is here at sundance zach braff s new film wish i wa here i m interested in zach taking 10 year to do this i m sure there are all kind of reason he wa acting he wa being successful in all kind of way i d like to try it sometime but you d have to build in the assurance that you have the proper amount of time so you didn t feel like oh i shouldn t have done this how did you cast this film did you just ask christina hendricks at the water cooler to come be in your movie i went to phil seymour hoffman first you go through the proper channel because you don t want to burden anybody with do me a favor that s a drag i sent him the script and i anticipated that he would let me down easy and say i like it but i don t have time i had sent it with an offer for the part of shelburne he called and said i love the script but i want to play mickey and it took me about two minute to realize what a great idea that wa so i said all right in then i mentioned it to christina because i wa directing an episode of mad men and saw her through the monitor and just realized she wa the perfect person i hadn t gotten phil to officially commit yet so i said here s the script i d love you to play this part and i hope to get phil she wa thrilled i sent it to richard jenkins who is represented by my agent about 45 minute later he called and said he wa in and then john turturro read it and called up and said he wa busy doing a movie but that he wanted to do it too i wa just floored there s a scene where christina is up on a balcony and the men are below in the street looking up at her she slowly walk inside and that quiet moment really illuminated how much power her character ha in this film she condoned this guy being beaten to death because he took advantage of her what i wanted to convey wa that this is a woman who know her currency all these guy know their weight in the world whether it s slapping somebody around or using the way you look to get what you want she know this guy want to get in her pant and she want to find something out she realized in that scene in the field that the way to do that is to let him do what he want but then he doesn t give her what she want and in the end she watch him getting beaten in the street and she just walk away letting it happen if she had said stop they would have stopped you mentioned earlier that making this movie 10 year ago would have been very different what do you think you bring to the table now i think just seeing more of everything life you get to a point where you re young and you re an actor and everything is always about if i could just get this if i could only get that and then you start to realize this is my place in the food chain this is what i do well i don t do everything well i can t play everything i m not a movie star i don t want to be a movie star your aspiration become more your own and then it occurs to you to want to put your own foot forward creatively you watch other people do their thing and you think i could do this i can try at this you also realize that there are sophisticated degree of performing there s actor a b c and then there s phil hoffman and richard jenkins and christina hendricks and john turturro and the fact that they said yes that s also a testament to you but when it really come down to it it s because you recognize what they do you really recognize what they re capable of doing and i should be so lucky to be able to work with those guy

title: you can be mentally stronger if you do this small act every day
context: a human we tend to set goal throughout our entire life and dedicate most of our time trying to achieve them that give u purpose and motivation to strive forward yet it can have detrimental consequence to our mental health activating stress indicator that come a a byproduct of pushing ourselves too hard towards massive goal a psychologist karl weick suggests in his article small win we should make it an everyday practice to focus our attention towards the positive by counting each small win we make by taking the alcoholic anonymous a an example he suggests that the principle work due to the change in perspective instead of focusing on overwhelming and complex goal participant are encouraged to choose small achievable daily action the impossibility of lifetime abstinence is scaled down to the more workable task of not taking a drink for the next 24 hour drastically reducing the size of a win necessary to maintain sobriety by celebrating these small daily win participant feel more confident and motivated to achieve the same satisfactory feeling the next day and so the behavior gain momentum leading to an almost effortless achievement of the ultimate goal the danger of dreaming big we are encouraged on a daily basis to dream big and set our bar high if we want to achieve great thing this phrase is an inescapable part of every motivational speech by almost every successful person who ever lived there is nothing wrong in the saying itself yet it tends to be misinterpreted by u the regular mortal who are fascinated by fairy tale story of dream that come true to those who are brave enough to wish and focus on the ultimate goal for every great achievement ever made there have been a million of small win and breakthrough that gradually led there and this is something many people tend to overlook when working on achieving their goal if we forget to appreciate the small win we regularly make the following negative consequence will appear our sense of self worth can be worsened we risk feeling bad about ourselves and feeling incompetent when we constantly compare present state to our final goal which can only lessen our chance of making progress we are prone to the feeling of failure and depression when our goal can t be achieved the increased amount of stress we have to cope with when we work on getting it all and now is counterproductive a it block our productivity and weakens our physical health once we change the perspective from big to small and break our final goal into smaller achievable chunk we take the pressure off and avoid the risk to our health by focusing on everyday progress we automatically feel much more motivated which cause our brain to get hooked on the positive rush and the feeling of accomplishment striving to achieve more understanding the importance of small win and knowing how to apply it to your everyday life will cause tremendous benefit to your goal achieving and your overall health here is the 4 step process you can take to develop the habit of celebrating small win step 1 start small first of all you need to write down your final goal and forget about it it sound silly but this will help you focus on the fragment ahead of you which is the only way to get thing done instead of wasting energy on planning month ahead focus on the next day s challenge only be here and now and only think one step ahead in order to move forward this will give you the constant sense of accomplishment which will motivate you to move forward and boost your self esteem step 2 reflect often every once in a while take some time to reflect on your progress so often we focus on goal yet to be accomplished and forget about the progress that ha already taken place this mean comparing yourself with yourself for example if your goal is to lose certain amount of weight instead of beating yourself up for not getting there yet you should compare some older photo of yourself to the new one by doing so you will get the visual proof of your progress which serf a great inspiration for future advance and inspires positive emotion step 3 reward yourself from early childhood we get familiar with the achievement reward formula which make u consider it a norm in each such situation therefore if you achieve certain success no matter how big or small your mind expects that you provide yourself with an adequate prize if the reward doesn t come your motivational fuel get drained making your effort futile so next time when you catch yourself single mindedly chasing a complex goal without appreciating the small win give yourself a break and treat yourself to a movie favorite sweet or a short trip with your friend step 4 enjoy the process maybe the most important element to keep in mind in order to maintain mental strength in a competitive and goal oriented world is to remind yourself to be content with yourself and the goal achieved remember to have fun and not take yourself too seriously enjoy experimenting and growing by appreciating the process and the lesson learned you will be able to avoid the stress and negative emotion even if you don t achieve the ultimate goal endorsed by ricky tang editor love this article
question: you can be mentally stronger if you do this small act every day what is the small act that can make you mentally stronger every day

text: counting each small win we make

title: cigarette tax hike in chicago make a pack of smoke in the windy city the priciest in the nation
context: tax on cigarette are rising yet again in chicago with a 50 cent increase that make smoke in the windy city the most highly taxed in the country chicago s city council overwhelmingly approved the cigarette tax hike a part of mayor rahm emanuel s 2014 budget on tuesday in combination with state and local tax the city tax increase push the total tax on cigarette sold in the city to 7 17 a pack wgn report chicago s per pack cigarette tax will be 31 cent higher than new york city s 6 86 per pack making them the priciest cigarette tax wise in the nation according to emanuel s budget the 50 cent tax increase is expected to bring in 7 million for the city the tribune report though the tax increase is relatively hefty it actually mark a rare concession from mayor emanuel the mayor originally proposed at 75 cent increase to the objection of city councilman concerned it would be met with increased illegal sale of loose cigarette in their ward the 3 million shortfall left by the lower tax increase will be filled by increasing the fine for parking in front a fire hydrant from 100 to 150 and tapping other revenue stream at the city s two airport ald jason ervin 28th said regardless of the mayor s decision to budge on the tax the high rate is likely to push smoker to purchase pack outside the city we still create the black market when we raise that bar at any level ervin told the sun time health official meanwhile were dismayed that the tax on cigarette wasn t higher the cheaper the cigarette the more people who are going to buy cigarette and the more people who are going to die the american heart association s mark peysakhovich told the sun time the day before the city council vote the city however is still cracking down on smoking in other way emanuel and a few key alderman are reportedly looking to heavily restrict e cigarette use in the city with rule that would effectively ban them from public space

title: why we sent a reporter to work a a private prison guard
context: read mother jones reporter shane bauer s firsthand account of his four month spent working a a guard at a corporate run prison in louisiana in 1887 a 23 year old journalist got herself checked into the woman s lunatic asylum on blackwell s island in new york city when she emerged she wrote about patient tied together with rope abusive staff and ubiquitous vermin lunatic treated with nothing more restorative than ice bath and perhaps most disturbingly patient who seemed to be perfectly sane dumped there by a society that had few safety net for woman who were single poor and often immigrant serialized by joseph pulitzer s new york world nellie bly s account later collected in a book called ten day in a mad house caused a sensation fueled in no small part by her pluck she d begun her career by writing a scathing rebuttal to an editorial titled what girl are good for though her inge nue look couldn t have hurt either but despite prose that shade purple to today s ear bly s work hold up not only for it daring but for it impact it prompted a grand jury investigation that led to change she d proposed including a 26 million in today s dollar increase to the budget of the city s department of public charity and correction and regulation to ensure that only the seriously mentally ill were committed access to prison ha been vastly curtailed there is no way to know what truly happens inside but to go there bly who d go on to get herself arrested so she could investigate condition at a woman s prison and to best jules verne s fictional protagonist by circumnavigating the world in 72 day wa not the first journalist to go inside an institution to expose it inner working or the last ted conover also reported from behind prison wall a did ben bagdikian for whom mojo s fellowship program is named in 1961 john howard griffin ingested a chemical that darkened his skin to investigate racial apartheid in the united state barbara ehrenreich took job at chain restaurant and walmart to spotlight the plight of low wage worker mac mcclelland worked a a picker in a warehouse of an online shipping behemoth to report for mother jones but while such investigation were commonplace in the muckraker era they ve grown increasingly rare why first there s a real concern over ethic when is it okay for reporter to not announce themselves a such there s no governing body of journalism but a checklist written by poynter ethicist bob steele provides guideline for assessing when this kind of reporting is acceptable i ll paraphrase when the information obtained is of vital public interest when other effort to gain that information have been exhausted when the journalist is willing to disclose the reason and nature of any deception when the news organization applies the skill time and funding needed to fully pursue the story when the harm prevented outweighs any harm caused after meaningful deliberation of the ethical and legal issue to see what private prison are really like shane bauer applied for a job with the correction corporation of america he used his own name and social security number and he noted his employment with the foundation for national progress the publisher of mother jones he did not lie he spent four month a a guard at a cca run louisiana prison and then we spent 14 more month reporting and fact checking we took these extraordinary step because press access to prison and jail ha been vastly curtailed in recent decade even a inmate have seen their ability to sue prison often the only way potential abuse would pop up on the radar of news organization or advocate dramatically reduced there is no other way to know what truly happens inside but to go there but here s the other reason investigation like this one have grown so rare litigation when abc news busted food lion for repackaging spoiled meat for sale back in 1992 a jury bought the company s line that the real offense had been the falsification of employment application and the reporter failure to fulfill their assigned duty i e repackaging spoiled meat the 5 5 million damage award wa eventually knocked down to just two dollar but it put a chill on this kind of muckraking for a generation and during that time corporate and official entity built an ever tighter web of legal protection nondisclosure agreement once mainly the provenance of people who work on apple product launch and beyonce video are now seeping into job of all stripe where they commingle with various other non disparagement clause and employer protection statute somewhere along the way employer legitimate interest in protecting hard won trade secret ha turned into an all purpose tool for shutting down public scrutiny even when the organization involved are more powerful than agency of government company interest in protecting trade secret ha turned into a tool for shutting down public scrutiny or when for that matter they replace the government when cca which run 61 prison jail and detention center on behalf of u taxpayer learned about our investigation it sent u a four page letter warning that shane had knowingly and deliberately breached his duty to cca by violating it policy and that there could be all manner of legal consequence the letter came not from cca s in house counsel but from the same law firm that had represented a billionaire megadonor in his three year quest to punish u for reporting on his anti lgbt activity when he lost he pledged 1 million to support others who might want to sue u and though we won the case were it not for the support of our reader the out of pocket cost would have hobbled u shane s story will draw a fair bit of curiosity around the newsgathering method employed but don t let anyone distract you from the story itself because the story itself is revealing a hell if you think story like this need to be told please make a tax deductible donation to mother jones to help underwrite our investigation
question: why we sent a reporter to work a a private prison guard what is the purpose of sending a reporter to work a a private prison guard

title: a shocking find in a neanderthal cave in france
context: in february 1990 thanks to a 15 year old boy named bruno kowalsczewski footstep echoed through the chamber of bruniquel cave for the first time in ten of thousand of year the cave sits in france s scenic aveyron valley but it entrance had long been sealed by an ancient rockslide kowalsczewski s father had detected faint wisp of air emerging from the scree and the boy spent three year clearing away the rubble he eventually dug out a tight thirty meter long passage that the thinnest member of the local caving club could squeeze through they found themselves in a large roomy corridor there were animal bone and sign of bear activity but nothing recent the floor wa pockmarked with pool of water the wall were punctuated by stalactite the one that hang down and stalagmite the one that stick up some 336 meter into the cave the caver stumbled across something extraordinary a vast chamber where several stalagmite had been deliberately broken most of the 400 piece had been arranged into two ring a large one between 4 and 7 metre across and a smaller one just 2 metre wide others had been propped up against these donut yet others had been stacked into four pile trace of fire were everywhere and there wa a mass of burnt bone these weren t natural formation and they weren t the work of bear they were built by people recognizing the site s value the caver brought in archaeologist francois rouzaud using carbon dating rouzaud estimated that a burnt bear bone found within the chamber wa 47 600 year old which meant that the stalagmite ring were older than any known cave painting it also meant that they couldn t have been the work of homo sapiens their builder must have been the only early human in the south of france at the time neanderthal the discovery suggested that neanderthal were more sophisticated than anyone had given them credit for they wielded fire ventured deep underground and shaped the subterranean rock into complex construction perhaps they even carried out ritual after all there wa no evidence that anyone actually lived in the cave so what else were the ring and mound for rouzaud would never know in april 1999 while guiding colleague through a different cave he suffered a fatal heart attack with his death work on the bruniquel cave ceased and it incredible content were neglected they ve only now re entered the limelight because sophie verheyden went on holiday when i announced the age to jacques he asked me to repeat it because it wa so incredible a life long caver verheyden work at the royal belgian institute of natural science where she specializes in stalagmite she treat them a time capsule using the chemical within them to reconstruct the climate of past millennium so when she learned about bruniquel cave while visiting the region on holiday and seeing a display at a nearby castle she had only one thought why hadn t anyone dated the broken stalagmite themselves she knew that rouzaud s date of 47 600 year wa impressive but suspect carbon dating is only accurate for sample younger than 50 000 year so the bruniquel material wa hitting the technique s limit they could well have been much older to get a better estimate verheyden assembled a team including archaeologist jacques jaubert and fellow stalagmite expert dominique genty in 2013 they got permission to study the site and crawled into it themselves i m not very big and i had to put one arm before me and one behind to get through say verheyden it s kind of magical even without the structure after drilling into the stalagmite and pulling out cylinder of rock the team could see an obvious transition between two layer on one side were old mineral that were part of the original stalagmite on the other were newer layer that had been laid down after the fragment were broken off by the cave s former user by measuring uranium level on either side of the divide the team could accurately tell when each stalagmite had been snapped off for construction their date 176 500 year ago give or take a few millennium when i announced the age to jacques he asked me to repeat it because it wa so incredible say verheyden outside bruniquel cave the earliest unambiguous human construction are just 20 000 year old most of these are ruin collapsed collection of mammoth bone and deer antler by comparison the bruniquel stalagmite ring are well preserved and far more ancient and if rouzaud s work made it unlikely that modern human built the ring verheyden s study grind that possibility into the dust neanderthal must have been responsible there simply wasn t any other hominin in that region at that time when you see such a structure so far into the cave you think of something cultural or religious why did they build the ring and mound the structure weren t foundation for hut the chamber contains no stone tool human bone or any other sign of permanent occupation and besides why build shelter inside a cave a plausible explanation is that this wa a meeting place for some type of ritual social behavior say paola villa from the university of colorado museum when you see such a structure so far into the cave you think of something cultural or religious but that s not proven add verheyden indeed despite some fanciful speculation about cave bear cult no one really know nor is it clear how the neanderthal made the structure verheyden say it couldn t have been one lone artisan toiling away in the dark most likely there wa a team and a technically skilled one at that they broke rock deliberately and arranged them precisely they used fire too more than 120 fragment have red and black streak that aren t found elsewhere in the chamber or the cave beyond they were the result of deliberately applied heat at intensity strong enough to occasionally crack the rock the neanderthal group responsible for these construction had a level of social organization that wa more complex than previously thought the team writes

context: we ve seen the future of fast food and it s full of secretive cooking utensil popping out of wall and a whole lot of quinoa eatsa an innovative vegetarian automated restaurant chain which just opened it first east coast location in new york on wednesday is looking to revolutionize the food industry by offering customer a one of a kind food experience the tech savvy restaurant aim to offer fresh affordable food fast but with an unconventional twist it replaces the presence of good old fashioned cashier and waiter with robot instead of the usual face to face ordering and pickup customer at eatsa simply order their food by mean of in store kiosk online or through an app on their phone the food then mysteriously appears on location in a glass cubby displaying the customer s name and they re free to chow down this mean no line no counter and no human conversation because what could be worse the concept while intriguing also sound a bit terrifying so with a mind full of skepticism mashable headed down to the newly opened midtown manhattan location to see what all the hype is about while one might assume a cashier free environment would be completely devoid of human interaction that wa far from the case though i initially feared the establishment would have a lifeless art gallery esque vibe the music wa pumping the customer were chatting and upon walking into the sleek restaurant i wa instantly greeted by a friendly eatsa mascot much like apple genius eatsa ha several employee stationed on the floor to offer customer assistance and ensure you re not entirely left alone there are always people on the floor our mascot we call them and we re out here helping the guest and getting them through the process explained scott bruggman an eatsa corporate trainer who began a an r d chef creating bowl to the right of the wood floored room stood a row of electronic ordering kiosk and to the left the restaurant had several table for those who wanted to engage in a slightly more familiar dining experience this all felt relatively tame but the back of the restaurant held the real magic a wall made entirely of electronic microwave looking cubby that would reveal your mysteriously prepared meal zap since there wa no one to take my order i made my way to the kiosk to choose from the customizable bowl bite and beverage on eatsa s strictly vegetarian menu once i put in my request for a hummus falafel bowl i walked toward the illuminated cubby and within minute my name wa displayed on the screen above them alerting me that my order wa up this wa the moment of truth right before your food arrives in your cubby eatsa fill you with intrigue your cubby turn completely dark to prevent you from seeing the secret of the kitchen and tantalizingly display the word it s coming after you re given a playful peek at your meal the cubby give you the literal green light and you can receive your meal by tapping the glass twice tbh it felt like something straight out of the jetsons the process wa quick simple and the food wa fresh a promised though i wa satisfied with the space age experience i couldn t stop wondering what the hell wa going on behind that wall of mystery i turned to dean marsh director of market operation for the east coast for some answer but wa kindly shut down marsh adamantly explained that much like the secrecy of costumed character at disney world the public is not supposed to know what truly go on in the depth of the eatsa kitchen very ominous despite the attempt to keep the trick of the trade to themselves many believe that several human chef work alongside robot the eatsa bot are back there bruggman said there s a lot of different thing going on and we use a much technology a we can to better enhance the experience first time customer and vegetarian madee bryke and her boyfriend andrew powell also had their theory there are people back there i know that bryke said i think it s fun that there s robot but there are definitely people still working a of right now bruggman described the tech and human ratio a a real blend that s how we make it so fast and so quick with the rise of technology creating strong barrier against personal interaction one of the major concern the innovative restaurant raise is that the lack of human interaction may come across a too impersonal while this may seen like a dream for introvert surprisingly the futuristic vibe only made thing more fun millennials such a sabina m who work a few block away and wa eating there for the second day in a row felt that if anything the environment wa encouraging people to be more social maybe it s just because of the novelty she said but it seems like people are almost more social here cause everyone s like woah this is crazy so it s kind of getting people to talk to one another bryke and powell also millennials agreed i definitely think it almost open it up to more talk it seems like they have a community bryke said her boyfriend powell said that when you think about it the automated restaurant is not much different from other form of take out people already order seamless and then go pick it up from a delivery guy so how is this much different it s almost like a robot s making it anyways to get a sense of how the older demographic wa feeling about the revolutionary service gen x er and first time customer maarten nederlof gave mashable his two cent we re a little older and have been watching the whole decline in social interaction he said so this is a walk on the non interacting side for u but i think for younger people who have no social interaction coming here is a great avoidance scheme nederlof explained that there are still table so people getting food can sit down inside and socialize therefore it s the best of both world are you really missing out on that much he questioned marsh director of market operation for easta feel the restaurant s technology is actually giving people more time to engage in social interaction where you may spend 15 to 20 minute at any of our competitor getting in and out with the regular fast food concept for u it s three to four minute we feel that extra time give you even more time interact with people he said though the manhattan eatsa ha only been open for a few day the restaurant s unique style is receiving a lot of love just like like the five other location in california and d c every restaurant competitor on the street ha been in at least two time and we ve only been open for two day we ve gotten a lot of interest from the big boy the mcdonalds and starbucks of the world he said what s next perhaps an automated restaurant to please all the meat eater out there
question: the future of fast food ha arrived and it s a one of a kind experience what is the future of fast food

title: many young american blame college for rising student debt
context: new york a majority of young american say student debt is a major issue facing the nation a new poll find and many blame college for the problem fifty eight percent of adult age 18 to 24 consider rising student debt level in the united state a major problem according to survey result released exclusively to the huffington post on tuesday by the harvard university institute of politics only 3 percent said it s not an issue at all while 22 percent called it a minor problem yet even among people who weren t enrolled in college 54 percent still considered student debt a major issue a plurality 39 percent blame college and university for the rising amount of student debt compared with just 10 percent who think student are at fault survey respondent were more likely to blame college for rising student debt if they were currently enrolled in school the cost of a college degree ha increased 12 fold in the last 30 year while having such a degree ha become even more important to those seeking full time employment but policy expert and consumer watchdog have increasingly flagged the wealth loss and ripple effect that the nation s 1 2 trillion in student debt is having on the economy a a whole young people who are coming of age today understand that getting a postsecondary education is important but they have a lot of fear about the rising cost of higher education said rory o sullivan policy and research director at young invincibles a group that aim to represent young people in policy debate matthew segal co founder and head of millennial advocacy nonprofit ourtime org wa pleasantly surprised to see that young adult are putting responsibility for the trend with college people are finally realizing that the college arm race must stop if we are ever going to rein in cost segal said segal noted that george washington university for instance is currently building a 130 million super dorm on campus and student at the university of pennsylvania are able to dine at a juice bar after hitting up the golf simulator at one of the campus fitness center this phenomenon of spending resource on extravagant secondary amenity isn t limited to private school either iowa state university recently spent 46 2 million renovating one of two campus gym resulting in a facility equipped with rock wall and hot tub while the university of california davis offer swimming pool in some residence hall too many college are acting in the interest of building prestige over providing an affordable pathway to higher learning for their student segal said however 32 percent of respondent in the new survey pointed the finger at the federal government which handle roughly 85 percent of the nation s outstanding student debt the u s department of education collected 42 5 billion from borrower in fiscal year 2013 alone although o sullivan belief there s plenty of blame to go around he wa struck by how few placed responsibility on state government despite the connection between state legislative appropriation and tuition at public college only 8 percent of harvard s survey respondent said state government were to blame for rising student loan debt a 2012 new york federal reserve study linked mounting tuition cost at public university where a majority of student get their degree to state budget cut a previous huffington post yougov poll found most american believe state university are no longer affordable we invest le than we used to per student o sullivan noted young invincibles is currently working with student group on campus to raise awareness of how the state budget process affect their tuition bill o sullivan belief the trillion dollar number ha captured the attention of many people but now it s important to explain why student debt is big and what it is we need to fix it more than 7 in 10 in the harvard poll said that their own financial circumstance were an important factor in whether or not they attended college the huffington post collaborated with the harvard institute of politics on question asked of college age american a larger update to harvard s biennial study of younger american will be publicly released wednesday
question: most millennials believe student debt is a major problem and this is who they blame what is the main problem that most millennials believe is a major problem
