title: the vet who euthanised herself in taiwan
context: a new law banning animal euthanasia is set to take force in taiwan it come almost a year after the shocking suicide of a vet overwhelmed by grief at the plight of stray animal the bbc s cindy sui explores this tragedy perhaps veterinarian and animal lover chien chih cheng wa in the wrong job at the wrong time she often worked overtime rarely took a proper lunch break and sacrificed her holiday to give the dog more attention and make their life better winnie lai her colleague at a shelter for abandoned dog in taoyuan city remembers a a graduate of taiwan s top university with the highest score in a civil service examination m chien could have chosen a desk job at head office but opted to personally care for the many pet abandoned each year in taiwan the shelter s lobby wa decorated with picture of animal drawn by m chien to encourage adoption but many of them were destined to be put down on 5 may last year m chien took her own life using the same drug she used to put down animal she said she wanted to help people understand what happens to stray in taiwan taiwan wa gripped by anger and soul searching in the week that followed most of it focused on a life tragically cut short but people also asked why frontline worker in taiwan s battle against pet abandonment were being put under so much pressure you might also be interested in in an interview m chien once did with a local tv station cti she described the first time she saw an animal put down i went home and cried all night she said but it wa medium appearance like this that meant she came under personal attack when it wa revealed she had put down 700 dog in two year she wa labelled the beautiful slaughterer shelter worker dreaded putting down the dog but m chien and others saw this a a better end for the unwanted ageing or difficult to adopt animal than leaving them at risk of disease in overcrowded shelter they called her a butcher we are frequently scolded some people say we ll go to hell they say we love to kill and are cruel said kao yu jie one of her co worker but people still abandon their dog you hear all kind of reason their dog is too mean or not mean enough bark too much or doesn t bark enough high kill rate taiwan ha two main problem when it come to animal welfare the number of pet being abandoned and the number of stray allowed to reproduce in reality the situation ha improved over the past decade thanks to increased public awareness and effort by shelter and activist to discourage abandonment and encourage adoption but the number of animal put down remains high and shelter are still underfunded and understaffed the work is difficult and hour long in some shelter half the animal are killed in 2015 around 10 900 were put down and about 8 600 shelter animal died last year from other cause such a illness in the cti interview m chien described the process of putting a dog down we first let it take a stroll and eat some snack and talk to it then we take it into the humane room when you put it on the table it s very scared and it whole body is shaking but after we administer the drug it leaf in three to five second it no longer shake actually it s very sad no psychological counselling wa provided for the staff psychological support in this and other field is practically unheard of in taiwan the taoyuan shelter actually had one of the lowest euthanasia rate and highest adoption rate of any shelter but a letter m chien left behind when she killed herself suggested her concern for the welfare of the animal had consumed her her colleague attest to this although expert remind u that many and complex factor lie behind any suicide she put herself under a lot of pressure she cared a lot about the animal and the pressure from the work affected her said m lai in the letter m chien wrote i hope my departure will let all of you know stray animal are also life i hope the government know the importance of controlling the source of the problem please value life the irony of her exhortation to value life wa not lost on observer and blame wa quick to be handed out newspaper accused the government of murdering her with many saying it failed to come up with effective way to stamp out pet abandonment or prevent stray from reproducing some accused higher level bureaucrat of trying to convince the public that m chien simply couldn t handle her work pressure but other commentator said that while shelter worker were easy to target all of society must take responsibility many believe the root of the problem is the insufficient enforcement of a neutering and spaying law the chief of the animal protection section of the council of agriculture chiang wen chuan said a law requiring spaying and neutering only recently came into effect and doesn t allow staff to impose fine immediately and even though staff pay visit to the owner of 60 000 animal each year to urge them to follow the law only 30 of the island s 1 7 million dog have been spayed or neutered we are very short staffed all of taiwan only ha 140 animal protection staff said mr chiang it s a systematic problem ending euthanasia and expanding shelter and staff will not solve the problem some taiwanese also believe such medical procedure change the personality of their pet others want to breed to give to friend or sell short term measure m chien already knew when she died that a new law wa coming into force from 4 february 2017 it will be illegal to put down abandoned animal budget have also increased by 40 there will be more inspector and now anybody who wish to abandon their pet at a shelter will have to pay a fee a high a 125 100 the authority say this is nothing to do with m chien s suicide and her story which wa simply a human tragedy the government ha pledged to increase funding and staffing at shelter and provide psychological counselling but many see these a short term measure activist want the government to crack down on breeder implement subsidy for ngo to spay and neuter and provide assistance to group that take in stray perhaps m chien wa not the catalyst for the change but her love for animal will not be forgotten by her husband also an animal control worker and her colleague all of whom were left pain stricken by her death

title: chinese father realizes his greatest regret after his son dy in car accident
context: 1 share share tweet share share email a father realized one of his biggest regret after his son s fatal car crash and is now committed to helping asian immigrant parent avoid his mistake while on a trip to china in june last year paul li received tragic news that his 18 year old son wa one of the victim in a fatal high speed car wreck li an investment analyst from rockville maryland had tried convincing his son to join him on his trip to china according to washington post his son declined his offer and told him dad don t worry about me i will work hard and i will be successful and you will be proud of me on june 25 2015 sam elli left a party in north potomac where he had been drinking and crashed his car into another vehicle that killed li s son calvin and a fellow classmate alex murk elli a one time star quarterback at wootton high school pleaded guilty on two charge of vehicular manslaughter and wa sentenced to four year in prison calvin an extroverted football player and recent graduate at wootton high school had been admitted to the university of maryland in college park where he would have attended a a freshman friend remember calvin a a football fanatic who wa charismatic upbeat and funny he wa the wide receiver no 7 on his high school football team and once had aspiration of becoming a professional football player li recalled crushing his son s dream during his middle school year when he told calvin son you go back to study you re not going to be a football player you are chinese that moment would become one of his greatest regret li a chinese immigrant who arrived to the united state during his twenty reflected after his son s passing if i knew what i know now i would ve been a much better parent when i look back i cannot forgive myself even though i know maybe in reality he would not be a football player but it wa just the way i shattered his dream when he wa small and i know for sure there are other chinese parent who are doing the same to their child right now and i don t want that to happen li recognized his son s struggle to reconcile the dual chinese and american culture in which he wa raised a a child calvin attended chinese school on the weekend and excelled in mandarin however a he grew up calvin began distancing himself from his parent cultural tradition and value a a teenager calvin strove to be more americanized and had no interest in eating out at chinese restaurant with his parent listening to chinese news or traveling to asia he wanted to break away from the kind of stereotype that are linked to asian american such a academic excellence in math and science li said so his calvin s way of doing that wa to distance himself from anything chinese i felt that s not the right way of dealing with identity but at the time i wa not aware of this issue i wa not understanding enough to help him i wa just forcefully saying you know you re a chinese kid calvin associated with few other asian student in his social circle and while he maintained good grade his passion wasn t academic li struggled to understand his son s avoidance of his cultural heritage and desire to adopt an all american attitude growing up society often think asian kid they re doing well in school they re working hard they tend to be overachiever they don t have any problem but in fact they do have problem and many of the problem are overlooked by not only their parent but also by the society in march li established a foundation name for his son and announced that he will be donating 1 2 million over the span of three year for a university of maryland fellowship the fellowship will be dedicated to studying the kind of issue facing the child of asian american immigrant involving family dynamic identity formation and cultural gap janelle wong the director of asian american study at university of maryland belief such family will benefit from the research finding that will be presented at lecture and community workshop visited 40 955 time 1 visit today

title: the difference between a job and a calling
context: i ve learned that work is most fulfilling when it s a calling and often it s a calling because you find a deep sense of purpose and positive impact in your role and fortunately the data show that purpose is incredibly tied to both business and personal success in corporate culture and performance author john kotter and james heskett write that purposeful value based company outperform their counterpart with 400 higher revenue 700 greater job growth and 1 200 higher stock price but having purpose doesn t only impact the organization you work for it also impact you research from the hay group show that highly engaged employee are on average 50 more likely to exceed expectation than their least engaged counterpart a a result i believe that to be both successful and fulfilled it is crucial to understand what purpose mean to you granted finding your purpose is a proactive pursuit many people start to explore their feeling when they re unhappy dissatisfied with their job and or upset with their personal life but it is important to find time to reflect when you find yourself in a good place too when you re experiencing fulfillment and joy in your work or in your personal life take a moment to ask yourself what am i doing right now that is making me fulfilled are you helping someone are you coding are you being creative are you creating the best financial model the world ha ever seen the answer to this question often bring to the surface what is important to you and can help you recreate that satisfaction moving forward i ve also found it helpful to create a personal vision for your life spend some time thinking about what your ideal day would be like i keep a dream book myself and i ve filled it with thing that are important to me from building a great tech company that is tackling a hard but important problem to building and maintaining lifelong friendship to checking item off of my travel bucket list it even includes a picture of a well landscaped backyard because that s been on my list of project to tackle and trust me you need vision to see beyond the weed that are back there today so spend time creating a vision for your life ask yourself key question about the role that purpose will play trust me your vision can and will change over time but knowing what you want your life to look like and then working to establish annual monthly or even daily goal and habit to help you live that life in and out of the workplace is absolutely key to success and more importantly it is absolutely key to finding your passion for life
question: this is the difference between a job and a calling what is the difference between a job and a calling

text: it s a calling because you find a deep sense of purpose and positive impact in your role

title: do tree sleep at night
context: after a long a long day of photosynthesizing do tree fall asleep it depends on how you define sleep but tree do relax their branch at night which might be a sign of snoozing scientist said in the only reported study to look at tree siesta researcher set up laser that measured the movement of two silver birch tree betula pendula at night one tree wa in finland and the other in austria and both were monitored from dusk until morning on dry windless night in september this wa close to the solar equinox when daylight and nighttime are about equal what is the oldest tree in the world the laser scanner used infrared light to illuminate different part of the tree each for fraction of a second this provided enough detail to map each tree within minute the researcher said the silver birch branch and leaf sagged at night they reached their lowest position a few hour before sunrise and then perked up again during the wee hour of the morning the researcher found tree might sleep after dark according to precise laser measurement that detected the plant branch drooping at night credit eetu puttonen our result show that the whole tree droop during night which can be seen a position change in leaf and branch study lead author eetu puttonen a researcher at the finnish geospatial research institute said in a statement the change are not too large only up to 10 centimeter 4 inch for tree with a height of about 5 meter 16 foot it s unclear if the sun woke up the tree or if they relied on their own internal circadian rhythm the researcher said but the fact that some branch started returning to their daytime position already before sunrise would suggest this internal circadian clock hypothesis is right the researcher wrote in the study which wa published online on feb 29 2016 in the journal frontier in plant science the finding isn t too surprising but oddly enough it hadn t been studied until now the researcher said most living organism have day and night circadian rhythm and any gardener will notice that some plant open their flower in the morning and that some tree close their leaf at night the researcher said the famed botanist carl linnaeus 1707 1778 found that flower confined to a dark cellar still opened and closed and naturalist charles darwin 1809 1882 noted that the nocturnal movement of leaf and stalk on plant looked like sleep however their study concentrated on small plant grown in pot the finding in tree represents the first study to use laser to precisely measure the nighttime movement of wild tree the researcher said the tree study didn t address why the branch and leaf drooped at night but it s likely related to the turgidity or the internal water pressure within the tree the researcher said plant movement is always closely connected with the water balance of individual cell which is affected by the availability of light through photosynthesis said study co author andra s zlinszky a researcher at the centre for ecological research at the hungarian academy of science how tall can tree grow the researcher said in the future they plan to examine the water movement within each tree and compare it to measurement made by the laser scan this will give u a better understanding of the tree daily tree water use and their influence on the local or regional climate puttonen said

title: how to fall asleep in under a minute
context: tech savvy culturally aware underemployed spiritual but not religious these are all word and phrase that have come to be associated with the milliennial generation which is also sometimes referred to a generation y recently however two additional adjective have worked their way into the millennial description pool stressed and sleepless the correlation between stress and sleep deprivation is becoming increasingly apparent in american society npr maintains that 60 million american are currently battling insomnia according to an american psychological association study titled stress in america more than 50 percent of millennials report to having been kept awake at least one night over the course of the past month due to stress this is comparable to only 37 percent of baby boomer and 25 percent of matures why doe stress affect sleep stress is widely recognized a the body s response to potentially harmful situation whether real or imagined although the effect of stress most certainly vary from person to person general reaction include quickened breathing tightened muscle spiked blood pressure and an increased heart rate fight or flight or sleep these are in short all individual component of the body s intrinsic and universally acknowledged fight or flight response many stressed out people have trouble falling asleep because they feel the weight of these symptom most heavily at night best selling author dr andrew weil who received his m d from harvard university in 1968 is a huge advocate of the benefit of holistic breathing practice in combatting stress and anxiety on his website dr weil writes breathing strongly influence physiology and thought process including mood by simply focusing your attention on your breathing and without doing anything to change it you can move in the direction of relaxation because the effect of stress include quick and shallow breath that stem almost exclusively from the upper chest perpetually stressed and anxious people are actually in the detrimental habit of under breathing many stressed people are even known for subconsciously holding their breath that being said mindful breathing practice are noticeably absent from the vast majority of western medicine those most familiar with the relationship between breathing and the body tend to be yogi and practitioner of eastern wellness methodology how to do the 4 7 8 exercise dr weil is an influential public supporter of a previously little known breathing technique known a the 4 7 8 exercise this trick which began to capture national attention several year ago and ha since been the subject of innumerable headline including one on oprah com is shockingly simple take hardly any time and can be done pretty much anywhere here is how you do the exercise place the tip of your tongue against the tissue ridge right above your upper front teeth keep it there for the remainder of the exercise exhale completely through your mouth making a whoosh sound a you do so close your mouth and inhale slowly through your nose while mentally counting to four hold your breath for a mental count of seven exhale completely through your mouth for a mental count of eight make the same whoosh sound from step two this concludes the first cycle repeat the same process three more time for a total of four rendition in a nutshell breathe in for four hold for seven and breathe out for eight you must inhale through your nose and exhale through your mouth the four count inhale allows chronic under breather to take in more oxygen the seven count hold give the oxygen more time to thoroughly permeate the bloodstream and the eight count exhale slows the heart rate and release a greater amount of carbon dioxide from the lung alina gonzalez who wrote how i learned to fall asleep in under 1 minute for byrdie com say that 4 7 8 helped her fall asleep amid her nerve and severe anxiety the week before she wa scheduled to give the bridesmaid speech at her best friend s wedding when gonzalez told her friend that she wa having trouble getting to sleep due to a combination of stress and pre wedding jitter the bride to be who wa a licensed wellness practitioner told her that the 4 7 8 technique would change her life it did like so many others who swear by this method the originally skeptical gonzalez wake up each morning to the incredulous realization that s he doe not even remember completing the final 4 7 8 cycle because it put her to sleep so quickly the 4 7 8 exercise certainly ha the potential to help overly stressed anxiety ridden millennials a well a member of the general population at large fall asleep more quickly it is also known to have positive effect when implemented throughout the day during time of stress anger guilt frustration or internal tension when weighing the painlessness of this completely free method against the irritability headache distractedness impaired cognitive skill weight gain and even heart disease that can result from the performance killer known a sleep deprivation it seems worth a shot
question: how to fall asleep in under a minute what are some tip for falling asleep quickly

text: breathe in for four hold for seven and breathe out for eight you must inhale through your nose and exhale through your mouth

title: are student athlete more likely to commit sexual assault
context: are student athlete more likely to commit sexual assault an investigation found that baylor university had mishandled sexual assault accusation against it football player by kate wheeling then baylor head coach art briles look on from the sideline photo ron jenkins getty image last week kenneth w starr wa stripped of his title a president of baylor university after an independent investigation found that the university had mishandled sexual assault accusation against football player football head coach art briles wa also fired a a result of the investigation starr who will continue to serve a both chancellor and a law professor gained notoriety a an independent counsel for his investigation of president bill clinton the new york time report mr starr s demotion delivered a twist to the biography of a man whose reputation wa built on what many considered an overzealous pursuit of allegation of sexual transgression by mr clinton now he is being punished for leading an administration that according to a report from an ostensibly independent investigator looked the other way when baylor football player were accused of sex crime and sometimes convicted of them the relationship between athlete and sexual assault is a decade old discussion since at least the 1980s high profile rape case involving famous athlete have led the press to speculate on whether player might be more prone to committing act of sexual violence a string of sexual assault allegation in recent year ha ensured that college athletic program and the athlete that populate them will remain in the spotlight in the last two year alone player from the university of tennessee knoxville florida state university and the university of oregon have made headline for assault allegation more than 160 higher education institution are under investigation by the department of education s office of civil right for sexual violence allegation but are athlete actually more likely to commit sexual assault or are we just more likely to pay attention when they re the one accused of committing the crime one factor to consider is that sexual violence doe not occur in a vacuum anthropological research suggests that rather than a purely psychological or biological driven act sexual assault are also highly influenced by culture peggy sanday an emeritus professor of anthropology at the university of pennsylvania found that some society are more prone to rape than others tribal society with higher level of male dominance sex segregation and tolerance of interpersonal violence had higher rate of rape in other word some environment can encourage sexual aggression the recent investigation into baylor concluded that university official created a cultural perception that football wa above the rule college athletics are highly sex segregated extremely male dominated and at least in the case of some sport football and hockey for example violent by design while no university could be accused of explicitly encouraging sexual assault several have been blamed for condoning such behavior or sweeping assault allegation under the rug the recent investigation into baylor for example concluded that university official created a cultural perception that football wa above the rule and the perceived lack of consequence for star athlete might embolden them to behave in sexually aggressive way consider survey that have found that between one in six and one in three men would be willing to use force to obtain sex from woman a long a there were no consequence for their action while member of sport team and other male dominated group like fraternity and the military are indeed more likely to commit gang rape than the average person there are few conclusive study to show that athlete are more likely to commit sex crime there is some evidence that not all athlete are equally likely to be violent according to laura finley a sociologist at barry university finley told wisconsin public radio that player of power and performance sport football hockey wrestling and basketball commit violent crime more often that their peer in sport like swimming or tennis an analysis of national football league player by benjamin morris at fivethirtyeight showed that though the football star displayed lower level of domestic and sexual violence than the national average the rate of domestic violence wa still much higher than expected given their income bracket without better data it s hard to say anything definitive on the matter even the oft cited statistic that one in three sexual assault on college campus are carried out by athlete date back not to a scientific study but to a 1986 philadelphia daily news article one 1995 study did however find that male athlete were overrepresented in report of sexual assault on campus literature review which are usually useful for identifying pattern in the sea of conflicting single study that science produce are also unreliable here one recent review found that the bulk of research on the subject wa inconclusive another however found higher rate of violence among student athlete we can at least say with certainty that university have not been effective in handling the case of sexual misconduct by athlete a 2014 survey found that in more than one fifth of university the athletic department oversaw case involving sexual assault allegation against athlete prompting the national collegiate athletic association to issue a resolution that athletic department can only participate in but never lead investigation into such allegation still the recent investigation at baylor found that the university s football program frequently dealt with sexual assault allegation internally

session at the clinical research centre there at the university the researcher controlled the sleep pattern of the participant meaning that sometimes they slept 7 hour and at other time their sleep wa reduced down to only 4 hour and 11 minute the researcher also controlled how much food and what food wa being served to the participant serving them three meal a day at 9 am 2 pm and 7 pm after the fourth night of each session the participant were offered snack from which to choose they included the kind of snack we like to indulge in when we are stoned such a extremely sweet or salty food they found that those that were sleep deprived were far le likely to resist the offer of snack and their urge to binge on them wa highest in the afternoon right through to the early evening sleep deprivation and obesity it ha long been believed that there is a link between sleep deprivation and obesity and this study can confirm the very reason that they may be linked depriving the human body of sleep interfere s with it production of hormone that control thing like appetite and satiety the scientist conducting this study looked into the kind of hormone that were present in the blood during the study they looked specifically at the hormone ghrelin and leptin ghrelin is the hormone that deal with appetite whereas leptin is the hormone that tell the brain when the body is full of food the endocannabinoid system finally the scientist decided that they would delve a little further into the body s craving for food and have a look at the endocannabinoid system the same system that is excited and activated by using marijuana erin hanlon who lead the study found that there wa a certain endocannabinoid that wa increased after sleep deprivation that could be the cause for the increase in appetite endocannabinoid 2 ag is the chemical that increase the amount of pleasure you feel after you eat and is an endocannabinoid that also increase after the use of marijuana we know that marijuana activates the endocannabinoid system and cause people to overeat when they are not hungry and they normally eat yummy sweet and fatty food hanlon said sleep restriction may cause overeating by acting in the same manner so it seems that sleep deprivation ha a very similar effect on the body in term of appetite a using marijuana doe this mean that a future of dealing with obesity through medicine that target the endocannabinoid system is possible although much more consideration would be required before moving into it do you experience the munchies when you are sleep deprived let u know your thought on our social medium or in the comment section below
question: you ll never guess what else give you the munchies what give you the munchies

title: is it safe to drink blood
context: with such a high interest in vampire these day they re all over television movie and bookstore shelf many people may be wondering if human really can survive a vampire turn out sucking blood isn t just fiction fun in 2011 a 19 year old texas man named lyle bensley allegedly broke into a woman s apartment and bit her on the neck this wa not bedroom playacting between lover bensley claimed to be a century old vampire who needed blood to stay alive the woman escaped and called police and lyle the would be vampire wa arrested for assault but is it safe to drink blood in very small amount say a few teaspoon and if the blood is free from pathogen such a the many blood borne disease blood might not harm you beyond that watch out circulatory system fact function disease the strange fact is blood when drank is toxic when confined to place where blood is supposed to be such a the heart vessel and so on it is essential for life but when ingested it s a very different story of course all toxin have dos and just a a tiny bit of poison won t necessarily harm you the more you eat or drink the greater the danger 7 strange way that people act like vampire because blood is so rich in iron and because the body ha difficulty excreting excess iron any animal that consumes blood regularly run a risk of iron overdose while iron is necessary for all animal and indeed most life in high dos it can be toxic this condition called haemochromatosis can cause a wide variety of disease and problem including liver damage buildup of fluid in the lung dehydration low blood pressure and nervous disorder even so blood feeding in human seems to be more common than one might expect john edgar browning of georgia tech who ha researched the practice suggests in a bbc article that thousand of people across the united state drink blood for various reason some of these people say the oxygen and iron enriched substance give them energy and none of the drinker interviewed by browning have had any ill effect from their behavior so perhaps they didn t overdo the blood meal no vampire i ve interviewed ha complained of any medical complication a a result of consuming blood browning said according to bbc unlike human the body of animal that digest blood have adapted specialized digestive mechanism according to katherine ramsland in her book the science of vampire penguin putnam 2002 the vampire bat requires an enormous intake of iron which help make hemoglobin for carrying oxygen from the lung to the body tissue yet the iron intake is generally higher than what the bat need so it ha a special process for secreting the excess when ingested the blood go through a tract that s adapted for extracting nutrient research on this system suggests that bat have a mucous membrane along the intestinal tract that act a a barrier to prevent too much iron from getting into their bloodstream you however are not a vampire bat because human did not evolve such an iron extracting mechanism drinking blood can kill u if you re thinking of sampling human blood make sure there s a doctor handy for you not your victim editor s note this article wa first published on sept 2 2011 benjamin radford is deputy editor of skeptical inquirer science magazine and author of six book including scientific paranormal investigation how to solve unexplained mystery his web site is www benjaminradford com

title: i d never heard of this condition until the terrible joint pain set in
context: the first hint of trouble came just a week after i had knee replacement surgery i wa rearranging the bedclothes over my new knee when i realized the down comforter felt like lead and lifting it felt like doing a bench press that seemed curious but i wa so bent on getting the new knee to work properly that i ignored my sore arm a well a a stubborn stiffness in my neck and hip physical therapy wa my focus and the goal wa to get back to my favorite pastime rowing it had kept me in shape for year and i wa missing early morning on the potomac month later i still hadn t picked up an oar instead i d endured anemia weight loss fever stiffness and sometimes excruciating pain in my hip and leg i felt a if i d been hit by the flu or maybe a truck getting out of bed wa painful and getting into a boat again seemed an impossible task the culprit polymyalgia rheumatica or pmr an autoimmune disease that spread painful inflammation through most of the body s joint never heard of it neither had i yet it strike many older american usually in their 70 and 80 more woman than men the afflicted are more often of northern european extraction indicating to researcher that genetics may be at work fortunately pmr responds quickly to the steroid drug prednisone the important thing is to recognize not ignore the symptom and seek help i felt better within a day of finally seeing my doctor being diagnosed and taking my first dose of prednisone in most case the condition can be cured although slowly over month sometimes year and in some situation it can be complicated by a more serious disease why and how pmr strike is mysterious although researcher are looking at virus or stress a trigger for the disease but undeniably it is associated with aging and particularly the aging immune system with the first wave of baby boomer heading into their 70 this year america s elderly population will swell and doctor think there will almost certainly be more case of pmr basically polymyalgia rheumatica trick the immune system into attacking it own body sending antibody and immune cell into the hundred of fluid filled sac called bursa that lie throughout our joint and surrounding soft tissue in the healthy body those sac some no wider than a dime others the size of a silver dollar keep our joint moving smoothly but when inflamed by pmr they cause pain and stiffness pmr also impedes the bone marrow s ability to make red blood cell causing anemia such an inflammatory response is like a complex cascade according to marcy o koon moss director of consumer health for the arthritis foundation which count pmr among more than 100 disease it focus on it s not one thing that happens the cell involved signal each other and communicate she said many people stricken with pmr confuse their symptom with aging and just soldier on but a the disease progress and becomes more debilitating most figure that something beyond old age is at work phil ringo 74 of haverford pa couldn t imagine what wa wrong four year ago when he began feeling sore and ill i thought i d gone from a pretty vigorous 70 year old to an old old man he said grandchild were saying what s wrong with papa unable to get out of a chair or into a cab without a struggle he got no answer from his doctor and when he tried for an appointment with one of the nation s top diagnostic clinic they basically said you re an old guy ringo said just get used to it he wa finally diagnosed and treated after a friend with the disease convinced him to see a rheumatologist actually pmr is famously tricky to diagnose a definitive test doe not exist for pmr said rheumatologist rebecca manno a john hopkins school of medicine faculty member and researcher and there are other condition that mimic pmr such a rheumatoid arthritis various infection and even some form of cancer so the diagnostic process can be torturous leslie kermath 70 of whitefish mont spent almost a month undergoing test before her doctor felt confident that pmr wa causing her pain stiffness and fever along the way she got antibiotic for an existing urinary tract infection wa sent to the hospital for a chest x ray and a cat scan after a test flagged a possible blood clot later she had another cat scan of her abdomen and pelvis because her hip were terribly painful a lyme disease test came back negative eventually her blood test which showed increasing level of inflammation plus her symptom and age nailed the diagnosis for kermath s doctor who started her on prednisone how many woman of caucasian origin who are older think they re just aging and can t do everything they used to when they actually have this disease said kermath who is an avid hiker most doctor suspecting pmr order several blood test almost always two that look for inflammation the erythrocyte sedimentation rate known a the esr test and another for crp or c reactive protein doctor also check for antibody associated with rheumatoid arthritis to rule out that disease when i finally dragged myself to my internist three month after my symptom showed up she immediately suspected pmr given my age 73 my symptom and lab result showing considerable inflammation and anemia she started me on prednisone and sent me to a rheumatologist after eight week of prednisone my inflammation number had fallen to near normal and my anemia wa under control my rheumatologist ha reduced my steroid dose but only very gradually because rebound do happen the hope is that i can be steroid free a sign of a cure sometime in 2017 treating pmr is one of the more gratifying part of my practice said my doctor joseph p laukaitis in my experience about 95 percent of patient fully recover for a pmr patient prednisone feel like a miracle drug because it so quickly attack inflammation and banishes the pain and stiffness but in fact prednisone is wonderful wicked in manno s word the side effect that some people experience are considerable a thinning of the bone already a problem for many older woman high blood pressure weight gain high blood sugar insomnia and a distinctive addition of facial fat known a moon face most patient who take prednisone for pmr will also be prescribed a drug to slow bone loss and that medication too ha side effect although diagnosing pmr can be difficult doing so is crucial because a much more serious disease giant cell arteritis strike about 10 to 20 percent of people with pmr giant cell arteritis cause inflammation and damage to blood vessel in the head and elsewhere untreated it can cause blindness stroke even death pmr patient can expect their doctor to look for symptom of gca severe headache tender scalp jaw pain and blurred vision any one of those can indicate that the artery of the head are inflamed the diagnosis often requires a biopsy of one of the artery in the scalp to confirm inflammation again prednisone is the treatment much of today s research into pmr and gca look for alternative to prednisone biologics drug made from living organism hold promise because some can inhibit an inflammatory response a it pick up steam the arthritis foundation s o koon moss said it s like interrupting a chain reaction there are also promising clinical trial of drug that treat rheumatoid arthritis and have fda approval for that and they may be effective for pmr manno said until other drug become available prednisone will remain the preferred treatment despite all it of downside a i face month of treatment for polymyalgia rheumatica taking smaller and smaller dos of prednisone each month i hope to avoid remission and eventually regain my strength exercise is key a it so often is when ill health strike so you ll find me on the stationary bike or walking or if not rowing at least beginning to build up stamen on the indoor rowing machine the rowing season of 2016 may have eluded me but the 2017 season is only month away

range and thus you can figure out where you d like to go next without the app distracting you from the task of driving find a few point of interest write them down or put them in your car s navigation unit then drive there driving is great when you park do so in a safe and legal location be sure to follow all applicable traffic and parking law a you normally would rule no 3 leave your phone on but on silent and hidden one big downside to the game is that it ha to be on and running to work or to log those brief moment where you re traveling at low speed more on this later this will drain your battery life fast according to anyone who s ever played the game for more than 30 minute fortunately most car now come with power outlet so your car is bizarrely well suited for hunting poke mon once phone in the trunk i will say that my fear of becoming that guy who mowed down an entire median full of ornamental shrubbery while playing poke mon go ha made me a le distracted driver with the game on gone is my temptation to glance down at text message at stop light i simply don t want to interrupt the game or get caught using it behind the wheel one of many landmark you ll find a poke stop in sounded like a solid plan nope the app wa one step ahead of that idea after my roughly 48 kilometer drive to test this idea barely netted any km towards egg hatching i wondered what wa up turn out there s a speed limit on what the game will log in term of distance traveled while i couldn t find the limit published on any official channel one unofficial source on quora claimed the app is limited to 20 kph which sound about right because you have to drive safely we don t recommend puttering around at speed slower than 20 kph on public road that s only about 12 mph for those of u not fully dedicated to the metric system 12 you would blow the fuse in your horn if you got stuck behind some jamoke doing 12 mph on a public road it s still worth having the app on and hidden in your car a it poke stop or gym to drive to based on the option available toss your silent phone on a charger out of reach and have at it

context: every blue eyed person on the planet is descended from a single european who lived around 6 000 to 10 000 year ago and who first developed a specific mutation that account for the now widespread iris coloration originally all human had brown eye although genetic variation relating to a gene called oca2 resulted in change to the amount of pigment produced by different individual resulting in the emergence of different shade of brown armed with this information scientist had for many year searched for the source of blue eye on the oca2 gene but without success more recently a mutation to a separate nearby gene called herc2 ha been identified a the cause of blue eye this alteration switch off oca2 the gene that determines the amount of the brown pigment melanin that we make it is thought to have first occurred when human began to migrate from africa to europe meaning that every person with blue eye is a descendent of a single early european the fact that every blue eyed person alive today ha this same mutation is pretty compelling evidence for this theory although the identity of the initial mutant remains something of a mystery to date the earliest set of sapphire colored peeper ever found belong to a 7 000 year old skeleton that wa discovered in northern spain naturally the eye had long since decayed however genetic analysis revealed that they would have appeared blue in color

title: 5 reason the seventh inning stretch is one of baseball s most fascinating tradition
context: there are several competing theory a to why in the middle of the seventh inning every baseball game come to a stop so everyone can stretch sing a really old song and take a breather but for more than a century the seventh inning stretch ha been one of baseball s most cherished moment exemplifying the humor sportsmanship and love of tradition that make the sport unique here are five reason why baseball wouldn t be the same without this random joyful moment the music aside from the national anthem at the beginning of most sporting event no piece of music is so deeply associated with a specific moment in sport it wa written by jack norworth who had a successful career in show business starring on broadway in the early 1900s before also appearing in several sound film the mysterious origin the origin of the seventh inning stretch are lost to the shadow of history one popular story date back to the day of president william howard taft who wa attending a game in 1910 and stood up during the middle of the seventh inning to stretch his leg naturally the story go when all of the other fan in attendance saw taft stand they followed suit another theory about the tradition s origin cite an 1869 issue of the new york herald which documented a game in which the entire crowd simply stood up after a brutally long second inning of play thus inventing the stretch albeit a bit earlier in the game other competing account are out there but no conclusive proof president william howard taft throw out the first ball to open a baseball season in history in washington in april of 1910 photo by mark rucker transcendental graphic getty image the camaraderie dave ferguson a baseball enthusiast and the radio host of beyond the cheer belief that no matter which origin story you prefer the seventh inning stretch remains a integral to the game a anything it s actually taken on it own life depending on the team ferguson told huffpost the player look at it a a break from the game itself and it s appreciated by the fan tony la russa the seventh inning stretch is another tie to our history ap the tradition the seventh inning stretch is another tie to our history tony la russa the three time world series winning manager told the huffington post la russa belief that the stretch help to remind player and fan of the game s root which is especially valuable even a other thing change such a the structure of the playoff or the addition of instant replay the relief baseball is physically and mentally grueling the lack of a game clock the open ended nature of every game it division into turn based inning rather than period or quarter all these element contribute to baseball s unique flow the 162 game of the regular season are played over about 185 day plus the seven week of spring training and the playoff during the season player work daily on their physical conditioning in the weight room batting cage or bullpen and they are constantly reviewing video for tendency ichiro suzuki the new york yankee outfielder and future hall of famer told the huffington post a few week ago that he took a mere three day off after his 13th season before resuming hitting duty and the game themselves may be getting longer making the seventh inning stretch even more of necessity for player according to mlb com the average time for a nine inning game in the 1970s wa around two hour and 30 minute during the 2000s however that time had increased by a full 20 minute this past season the average game time tied the all time high of two hour 58 minute and during those nearly three hour actual baseball happens for only 18 minute including ball in play and wild pitch according to a study by the wall street journal relive the longest game in baseball history email me at jordan schultz huffingtonpost com or ask me question about anything sport related at schultz_report also be sure and catch my nbc sport radio show kup and schultz which air sunday morning from 9 12 et right here

title: the crazy cooking hack that slash the calorie in rice by half
context: whether you think rice is a friend or foe to your diet there s one thing we can all agree on it s delicious if you don t agree i m sorry but i don t understand you now scientist have gone and done something incredibly cool they figured out a new way to cook the grain that could cut it calorie in half or more new research wa presented at the 249th national meeting exposition of the american chemical society and revealed that adding a teaspoon of coconut oil to boiling water with a half cup of non fortified white rice letting it simmer for 20 to 40 minute then refrigerating it for 12 hour may reduce the number of calorie your body take in by 50 to 60 percent like i said seriously cool the researcher explained that rice contains two kind of starch one that is easily digestible and one that s resistant our body don t have the enzyme needed to digest the resistant kind which mean it can t break down that starch and transform it into the sugar that typically get absorbed into the bloodstream if you have extra sugar in your bloodstream that get turned into fat which we know is no good in other word the scientist wanted to find a way to get the rice to have more resistant starch rather than digestible one to avoid that extra sugar in the body this is where the coconut oil come in adding it to the cooking process make the starch granule resistant to the action of digestive enzyme and then letting the rice cool for 12 hour push the process along translation same amount of rice fewer calorie into the body bonus you don t have to eat the rice cold to get the desired effect reheating it the next day won t affect result the researcher found no word yet on whether it work on brown rice or if other oil will do the same thing but more testing will be done to figure all that good stuff out for now we ll just continue to sing the praise of coconut oil a we dig in to a bowl of rice totally guilt free
question: the crazy cooking hack that slash the calorie in rice by half what is the crazy cooking hack that slash the calorie in rice by half

title: this u s city is welcoming veteran with an innovative new program
context: fred johnson is effusive after a 29 year career in the army including three combat tour he ha moved on to a dream job a a fundraiser for a nonprofit in louisville kentucky a city he love i can hear the excitement in his voice a he tell me i must visit louisville you ve gotta come dude it s awesome johnson told me this is an up and coming town but johnson might not have been able to find the job and community of his dream were it not for where opportunity knox an innovative new veteran re integration program last year johnson wa one of more than 100 000 soldier leaving active duty army service every single one of them pass through fort knox before re entering the civilian world those army veteran are looking for job and community where they can begin a new life a civilian the greater louisville kentucky area where fort knox is located ha a vibrant cultural scene and growing economy in need of capable worker and young family vision of america getty image the louisville kentucky skyline until recently however there wa no coordinated effort to connect the soon to be civilian in fort knox with job opportunity and communal life in louisville so in september 2014 three regional chamber of commerce launched where opportunity knox to try to change that the program ha the enthusiastic backing of the u s army but it doe not take a dime from the government it relies exclusively on funding from philanthropic foundation and it ha already racked up some impressive number where opportunity knox claim credit for connecting 1 500 veteran to job in the region already and it ha the goal of navigating 10 000 veteran to job in the greater louisville area by 2017 filling a void the transition to civilian life for soldier being processed at fort knox ha two stage according to retired col walter herd the director of the army s transition assistance program preparation for a career outside the army and connection to opportunity in the civilian world the army spends two week on the first part herd said helping soldier with everything from their own personal and psychological understanding to their budgetary need culminating with a re sume and job preparation connecting those soldier to a career and community is how where opportunity knox complement the army s work representative of the group are often on premise at training session in fort knox to ass soldier need and answer question they advertise their availability to talk by email or phone on rallypoint an internal military professional networking site where opportunity knox emphasizes that it is not a job placement program it just give veteran the personal support insight and connection to the employer community that they are le likely to find on say monster com in addition to a team of several permanent staff member where opportunity knox us a proverbial army of regional veteran connector 35 trained volunteer to help veteran identify job opportunity in the region and a local community to live in that meet their need the latter component mean helping veteran identify everything from a quiet neighborhood to buy a home to educational service for child with disability to adult recreational sport league i m excited about where opportunity knox because it connects them not just to a job but to a community retired col walter herd director army transition assistance program herd said there is no veteran reintegration program in the united state a comprehensive a where opportunity knox the army doe not owe it to a soldier to get them a job but we believe we do owe it to a soldier to get them ready and get em introduced to something on the outside so they can at least begin that conversation herd said the preparation piece is the easy part the hard part is the connection piece i m excited about where opportunity knox because it connects them not just to a job but to a community the feeling is mutual for kentucky s business community where opportunity knox is a portal to a pool of reliable skilled worker that they say would otherwise be lacking a economic developer workforce is a challenge said eileen pickett an economic consultant and co founder of where opportunity knox we have this ongoing problem and certainly now since we ve gotten past the recession we re starting to see growth and we need people with the right skill the population of the greater louisville area ha grown 2 8 percent since 2010 in no small part due to it relatively successful recovery from the great recession unemployment in the louisville metropolitan area went from a peak of 11 9 percent in february 2010 to 4 percent today that is a better record than the country a a whole which went from a peak official jobless rate of 10 percent in october 2009 to 5 percent today daniel marans retired col walter herd is director of the army s transition assistance program the federal reserve bank of st louis point to the greater louisville area a a model for successful diversification of what wa once a primarily industrial economy the city and surrounding area now also boast a thriving service sector louisville proper is home to ups worldport air hub a well a two ford production plant and the corporate headquarters of health insurance giant humana and while the city is known for it bourbon distillery think maker s mark woodford reserve and evan williams it is also the base of yum brand parent company of kfc pizza hut and taco bell army veteran are ideal candidate for the mid and high skill job that make the region s business tick herd and pickett insist for one thing a person must be healthy free of a criminal record and have completed high school to get into the army in the first place soldier then learn concrete skill in the army that often translate into civilian occupation everything from truck driving to supply chain management to computer science but more valuable than the skill the army teach soldier are the attribute that service instills herd said soldier are virtually guaranteed to develop discipline a collaborative spirit and an ability to think on their foot before they emerge from fort knox s wall to return to the civilian world and those are often the intangible quality that make people reliable employee and innovator the military is pretty much a pre screening event for employer because all employer want the same people right they graduated school they re healthy they stay out of trouble herd said so we take those people and we train them and discipline them and mature them and we steal them for a few year and then we give them back to society the military is pretty much a pre screening event for employer because all employer want the same people right they graduated school they re healthy they stay out of trouble retired col walter herd director army transition assistance program the visit to an army base that inspired a new initiative pickett got the idea for the program after taking a group tour of fort irwin the army s training center in california there she saw the life size replica of entire town in afghanistan and iraq that soldier trained in before being deployed to war zone overseas it is the crucible that turn young high school graduate into hardened adult ready to face unknown physical and mental challenge in a foreign nation what wa so striking to me this wa really my first kind of up close with the military i remember this captain who told u their job is to make every soldier that come through there have their worst day in the service happen at fort irwin so it doesn t happen somewhere else pickett said to pickett it wa obvious that any soldier that underwent training at that base let alone the experience that followed would make for terrific employee and member of the community if they could make it through fort irwin wouldn t they make a superb supply chain manager for ups i wish every american could go through there pickett said i wa just inspired by it daniel marans eileen pickett an economic consultant co founded where opportunity knox translating army speak to corporate speak given how intuitively appealing these veteran sound a employee one would think veteran would have a relatively low unemployment rate but unemployment among young post 9 11 veteran ha been higher than among their non veteran peer in 2014 the unemployment rate among post 9 11 veteran wa 7 2 percent compared with 6 percent among non veteran for post 9 11 veteran age 18 to 24 the jobless rate wa 16 2 percent compared with 12 5 percent among non veteran of the same age the figure have since declined but on the advice of the bureau of labor statistic we are using annual data here for greatest possible accuracy the reason are complicated the high incidence of post traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury among returning iraq and afghanistan veteran no doubt play a role though that may be more due to employer stigma about the condition than their actual effect there are other factor however that have more to do with the military s separation from civilian society the network that soldier rely on to advance in the military often do not extend into the civilian world a a result it is hard to make professional connection with peer in the civilian world that are so essential to finding a job in today s economy herd belief that departing soldier are also sometimes unsure how to present the broader attribute they acquire in the military a professional asset in the civilian world the hard part come in translating those skill from army navy speak to corporate speak and explaining how military service specific skill are universally applicable kathy robinson founder turning point kathy robinson founder of turningpoint a boston based career counseling firm and a former human resource executive ha worked alongside veteran recruited them to work for company and advised them on finding work veteran bring a lot to the table when it come to collaboration ability to ass a vision and execute on that vision when i wa working with veteran they were often the most effective people in their job robinson said the hard part come in translating those skill from army navy speak to corporate speak and explaining how military service specific skill are universally applicable in fact those with the most easily translatable skill often have a harder time realizing the value of the attribute they have honed in the military let alone communicating them in term employer can easily grasp herd note that machine gunner and infantryman who worked in position that do not exist in the civilian world are le likely to be unemployed than army truck driver who can easily become civilian truck driver fred johnson fred johnson volunteer with healing and the art to help younger veteran cope with ptsd you can actually see the community change johnson the army vet see another challenge in the transition to civilian life like many veteran johnson wanted a job that provided him with a sense of purpose like the kind he enjoyed in the army given johnson s worry about the applicability of his army skill in the civilian world altogether he did not think he would have the luxury of finding a job that fit that description that wa before he met with the folk at where opportunity knox they told him about an opening at fund for the art a louisville nonprofit that raise money for art supply and program in louisville s underprivileged school johnson is now the organization s director of workplace giving i had a certain idea in mind for what i wanted to do and they helped me work through that johnson said they helped me learn how to go through the civilian interview process i knew what i wanted and they helped me articulate that in a way that made sense through his work at fund for the art johnson see himself a part of a process of community building in the underserved west side of louisville he compare it to the reconstruction work he did in the iraqi city of baquba after the army brigade he led helped conquer it i tell them follow your heart not the money you can actually see the community change fred johnson army veteran and director of workplace giving fund for the art when we attacked that city it wa like a wasteland johnson said then we helped rebuild the city we are trying to do that here in louisville on the west side it is almost barren it almost reminds me of baquba in addition to the army instilling in him a desire to be a part of something greater than himself johnson said his service equipped him with communication skill and a comfort with diversity of all kind both of those characteristic are asset to him in his fundraising work the vast majority of people in the army unless you don t do your work who care same thing with a female a gay person or any ethnic or racial minority johnson added the west side of louisville is very poor and racially diverse i fit in a well there a at humana or brown forman where everybody is wearing suit but johnson said he wa also fortunate that fund for the art wa willing to give him an opportunity to prove himself despite his lack of formal fundraising experience and struggle with post traumatic stress disorder from combat in iraq and afghanistan i told fund for the art ceo christen boone this is what my ptsd mean and this is what i am doing to overcome it johnson said i said i am bringing more positive baggage than negative she took a chance on me i wish more ceo and executive had the courage and prove himself johnson ha local magazine business first recently named him one of louisville s top 20 veteran in business now johnson is using his experience to help younger returning veteran find their way he volunteer with a joint civilian military initiative called art and healing the group us art to help veteran cope with ptsd i tell them follow your heart not the money johnson said you can actually see the community change where opportunity knox helped give johnson the confidence that the skill he acquired in the army had prepared him well for a civilian career he explains to younger veteran that they too have attained those skill even if they do not yet know it a lot of time the younger kid do not realize what they ve learned he observed they are 21 year old i say no dude you experienced a lifetime in that short span you just don t realize how many tool you have
question: this u s city is welcoming veteran with an innovative new program what is the name of the u s city that is welcoming veteran with an innovative new program

title: the terrifying way not sleeping enough actually change your gut
context: study link insufficient sleep to some pretty scary consequence including an increased risk of stroke heart disease diabetes obesity and even some cancer expert still don t fully understand why not getting enough sleep is connected to all of these condition but new research published this month add one piece to the puzzle not getting enough sleep may cause change to gut bacteria that could fundamentally change our metabolism affecting a host of bodily system gut microbiota are the trillion of microorganism living in our intestine that help keep our metabolism immune system and other bodily function running normally explained senior study author jonathan cedernaes a sleep researcher at uppsala university in sweden mounting evidence ha linked an unhealthy gut microbiota with inflammatory bowel disease allergy neurodegenerative disease and metabolic disease including obesity and diabetes this new study is one of the first to suggest that not getting enough sleep is one way of making our gut bacteria unhealthy cedernaes explained the researcher followed nine individual who spent two night sleeping in a lab for eight and a half hour and then another two night of sleeping in a lab for only four and a half hour the study included a fairly small number of people but the strength behind the data is that the researcher were able to compare the effect of varied sleep level on gut bacteria within the same individual plus they only included subject who reported having gotten consistent sleep and regularly timed meal the week before the study which meant everyone s gut bacteria started out at a somewhat typical level the data showed that getting le sleep didn t necessarily change which gut bacteria the individual had but getting le sleep did change the level of specific strain of bacteria the amount of certain type of bacteria decreased by nearly 50 percent and that wa after only two night of not getting enough sleep the finding wa significant because the wrong balance of bacteria in our gut is thought to be one of the big factor that cause obesity in some individual cedernaes explained what s more the ratio of specific strand of gut bacteria observed after individual had not gotten a full night s sleep mirrored the level of the same gut bacteria previously observed in people who were obese or had other metabolic disease gut bacteria are a crucial natural component of our body cedernaes said they break down fiber that we cannot digest otherwise they can also help u extract nutrient there wa yet another interesting finding from the study the individual were 20 percent le sensitive to the effect of insulin after having le sleep a potential diabetes risk compared to the day after the night they had slept longer sleep loss ha been linked to decreased insulin sensitivity in previous study cedernaes said and while his new research did not necessarily suggest the effect wa a result of the gut bacteria change the link is still an important observation because over time constant insulin insensitivity is a well established driver of diabetes additional longer study will be necessary to prove that the gut bacteria change observed after a few night of insufficient sleep are linked with the various metabolic disease thought to be connected to chronic sleep loss like obesity diabetes and heart disease but the new data make a strong case cedernaes said a strong case for catching your z

sibling we assume this time around he s mr potts only child not cool gaston luke evans while trying to win the affection of his future father in law gaston pretend to believe maurice s warning that a beast s castle he discovers a tree that had been knocked down by lightning standing upright again gaston and lefou exchange glance implying that maurice ha lost it and tell him it s time to turn uncomfortable with the idea of leaving maurice for dead pleads with gaston to reconsider but gaston push forward and return to town without maurice little doe he know maurice will beat him back to town telling local the story about how gaston left him there to die if only they believed him the live action beauty and the beast remake made history by featuring disney s first ever exclusively gay moment in the new film josh gad s character lefou gaston s best friend and confidant wa presented differently than the 1991 animated version lefou is somebody who on one day want to be gaston and on title: the magic word this researcher say can get people to agree with you
context: amy cavenaile the washington post istock a new national poll about how american voter perceive donald trump and hillary clinton asked who between the presidential front runner ha higher moral standard clinton lead trump in this ambiguous category 47 percent to 36 percent according to the result the survey released wednesday by quinnipiac university didn t elaborate on what moral encompasses that could help the democratic candidate by making her policy position appear stronger according to new research a perception of morality strengthens an argument giving it more sway than opinion based on tradition or practicality in the study published in the journal of experimental social psychology ohio state university doctoral student andrew luttrell and his team hypothesized that the people or cause we most admire share a common trait they re connected to our sense of morality a psychological shield against outside attack a in oh you disagree with me well i won t be swayed because i m standing up for what s right the researcher wanted to see if a person s opinion grew stronger or wa more likely to withstand challenge if their viewpoint wa declared to be moral so they set up a series of experiment with three group of roughly 100 participant how democratic and republican moral compare to the rest of the world luttrell and his colleague gave the first group all college student information about a new senior exam policy and asked them to write down their thought next the participant separated by partition received printed feedback on their opinion some were told their idea on the phony exam policy reflected tradition others heard their idea projected morality like this while your thought were similar to other student on a variety of dimension you seem to have based your thought about senior comprehensive exam on morality tradition more than the average student simply telling someone their attitude wa moral luttrull found gave it more power compared to those in the tradition group the participant who heard their thought reflected morality were more likely to say they d sign a petition to support the bogus policy put their name on a list of student who support the policy and vote in favor of the policy they marked their interest in these action on a scale of one to nine in the next two experiment one with college student and one with a broader sample of adult researcher asked participant to perform a similar task this time focused on recycling the group s consensus recycling is generally a good thing after respondent wrote down their individual thought and took the same nine point test they received feedback on their recycling belief some heard their view were practical others heard moral then the researcher tried to change everyone s mind they slipped respondent a note that said recycling put more car on the road and encourages pollution people s attitude in the morality group and practicality group didn t significantly differ before they read the anti recycling message but afterward a post test revealed the moral respondent viewed recycling more favorably 7 56 on a nine point scale than the practical respondent 6 88 those led to believe that their recycling attitude were grounded in morality were more resistant to the anti recycling message than those led to believe that their attitude were grounded in practicality the author wrote the takeaway according to luttrell framing a cause a moral is a smart tactic for politician and advocate any issue it appears can be viewed through the morality lens which is why we ll be probably fighting about politics forever is moral a magic word he said in some way it might be we grow up thinking morality is this thing that s untouchable what s moral is permanent and cannot be challenged fresh off his vatican visit democratic presidential candidate bernie sander visit a church in brooklyn and say income inequality isn t just a political issue it s a moral issue reuters
