title: tv the book why buffy the vampire slayer wa one of tv s best show ever
context: today is publication day for tv the book two expert pick the greatest american show of all time the anthology where matt zoller seitz and i rank the top 100 american sitcom and drama ever and write essay about them and a whole lot of other thing movie miniseries current show show that weren t top 100 worthy but were sentimental favorite in some way etc you can order it in multiple edition including an audiobook recorded by matt and me at amazon barnes noble ibooks google play kobo or your favorite indie bookseller we re very proud of the book and can t wait for people to start reading but if you still need a taste or two to push you over the buying edge the ringer ran an excerpt last week featuring part of our explanation for how the top 100 wa chosen along with our joint essay on deadwood while matt s home base at vulture this morning ha the essay on our top ranked show the simpson maybe my favorite section of the book and the favorite of many of the early reviewer is called the great debate where matt and i argue out what should get the top pick after we initially wound up with a five way tie for first place included below is the essay i wrote about a little show called buffy the vampire slayer which finished in a tie for 25th place alongside appropriately enough fellow classic high school drama freak and geek and my so called life among our pantheon of series coming up just a soon a i get the mustard out buffy the vampire slayer wb 1997 2001 upn 2001 2003 total score 94 tv show title rarely bring viewer into the tent but they can keep them out if you want to give your charming blended family comedy an ironic name like trophy wife don t be surprised if your target demographic take it literally and stay far away see also terrier selfie crazy ex girlfriend now buffy the vampire slayer ran seven season wa never in danger of cancellation at any point it jumped network after season 5 only because upn wa looking to steal a hit from it rival the wb launched a long running and eventually very good spin off in angel wa beloved by it fan and helped define the identity of an entire tv network for the short but memorable existence of the wb by any standard you want to measure buffy wa a success except maybe this one if you tell someone who s never watched it that a show called buffy the vampire slayer is among the best tv drama of all time they will roll their eye at you and change the subject to something le divisive like immigration policy would a buffy the vampire slayer by any other name have been a crossover hit rather than a cult classic or won more award or simply have been an easier sell to non fan certainly you can imagine wb executive thinking that which is why they briefly tried to get joss whedon to shorten the title to just slayer whedon held firm and not just because it might have created confusion between the show and the thrash band that brought the world song like reign in blood and mandatory suicide he knew that buffy the vampire slayer wa the perfect title for his series because it captured the exact spirit of what he wa planning to make you could give it a more serious or distinguished title but no matter the packaging the show inside would be about a vapid teenage girl buffy summer sarah michelle gellar who discovered that her destiny wa to protect humankind from vampire demon and other creature of the underworld and a show whose tone shifted rapidly between horror melodrama action and pure comedy the name tell you all of that and suggests that if you re turned off by it you re probably not going to like the series to which it s applied it wa a tonal balance that director fran rubel kuzui didn t even bother attempting with the campy buffy movie adapted from whedon s first script the show though would have room for many different emotion all juggled expertly by gellar anthony stewart head alyson hannigan and the rest of the cast it wa a series made cheaply even by the standard of tv s fifth place network but it almost never seemed ridiculous despite the primitive effect and awkward stunt doubling for gellar if it wanted to make you laugh at a bit of witty banter i laugh in the face of danger then i hide until it go away it could if it wanted it latest monster to creep you out it found the most disturbing context possible and if it wanted to make you cry it wa pointless to try fighting it if anything the exaggerated nature of the various undead villain only made the high school setting more effective because what is adolescence if not a time when every problem get blown wildly out of proportion in the real world a girl whose boyfriend started treating her badly after they finally have sex wouldn t need to worry that he had turned pure evil a happened with buffy and her vampire love interest angel david boreanaz but it might feel that way for a while and a real teen boy going through the change of puberty might occasionally imagine himself a monster but laconic guitar player oz seth green actually transformed into a werewolf every time the moon wa full turning monster into metaphor for teenage emotional turmoil wa a clever gambit and one that played particularly well during the show s three season set in high school buffy is by our ranking anyway one of the best tv show ever set in high school but it wasn t entirely immune to the same problem that eventually beset all such show when their character head to college even so those later season still had a knack for landing on the right parallel between the supernatural and the universal like buffy s little sister dawn michelle trachtenberg literally being put on earth to cause her problem which in this case involved the literal end of the world those later year also offered some thrilling formal experiment including hush an homage to silent horror movie involving demon who rob people of the ability to speak or scream the body a stripped down outing where buffy confronts the mundane reality of her mother s death from natural cause and the musical episode once more with feeling where a curse force everyone to express their feeling through song back to that title whedon once suggested to the new york time if i made buffy the lesbian separatist a series of lecture on pb on why there should be feminism no one would be coming to the party and it would be boring the idea of changing culture is important to me and it can only be done in a popular medium whedon didn t invent feminism in tv storytelling or even the idea of cross pollinating it with fantasy and sci fi trope for much of it run buffy overlapped with xena warrior princess but he created one of the finest example of it and wrapped it up in a wildly entertaining package that included a name that may have made some potential viewer roll their eye but that made enough of them smile and think this might just be a show for them and it wa

title: the 10 least stressful job in 2017
context: stress play a big role in our daily life and according to career website careercast some job create more anxiety than others last week my colleague karsten strauss covered the most stressful job and this week i m writing about the least stressful careercast evaluated 200 profession and rated them on 11 measure of stress such a the amount of travel required the growth potential of the industry and job and the physical demand of the role the report isn t a survey careercast relies largely on data from the u s bureau of labor statistic to score every position on each metric and then roll that up into an overall stress score more methodology detail are available here to see the 10 least stressful job and their median salary view the gallery below although these job are rated a low stress based on careercast s approach by no mean are they easy or unimportant some such a audiologist and tenured professor require a ph d others like medical and pharmacy technician provide critical support in the process of saving life careercast s stress rating are average and exception always arise for instance having a difficult manager or extremely demanding client can make any job unpleasant also much stress is self induced and best managed by mean other than switching job like limiting the number of task you take on but we wanted to publish this list because we think it s informative and thought provoking two year ago my colleague susan adam published many interesting reader response to an earlier version of this annual list diagnostic medical sonographer ranked first on careercast s list of the least stressful job photo credit shutterstock diagnostic medical sonographer wa rated a the least stressful job the position involves using medical imaging equipment like ultrasound machine medical sonographers assist physician in conducting and interpreting these test and to become one you ll need to take an accreditation program that last between one and four year median pay in 2015 wa 63 630 the second least stressful job wa compliance officer a role with a median salary of 65 640 that requires making sure your colleague abide by law and regulation a compliance officer at a bank might monitor trader to check if they re following insider trading regulation operation research analyst ranked eighth with median income of 78 630 using mathematical and analytical method operation analyst help organization solve complex problem

title: fat burning food already in your kitchen from chili to mustard how to turn 8 classic ingredient into bulge beating superfoods
context: you might be familiar with the notion that eating food that are high in calorie along with a lack of physical activity cause an imbalance in metabolism which lead to obesity the tricky thing for many of u is getting the balance right and ensuring we maintain a healthy weight however the metabolism is not always an easy thing to understand and differs from person to person varying in efficiency and requiring differing amount of energy to process the food and drink consumed wouldn t it be fabulous to be able to eat food that can help you lose weight simply by eating them although this doesn t quite make sense on first reading you may be surprised to know that there really are food that can help you do just that research suggests that there are some food that may help manage weight by boosting the metabolism due to their thermogenic effect on the body in other word the amount of energy used and heat produced a your body process this food all food when consumed speed up the action of the muscle in the digestive tract using up energy and producing heat in the process this is known a thermogenesis however certain food use up more energy and create more heat a the body burn calorie the harder the food is to digest the more calorie the body will have to burn to fully break it down before it can absorb the nutrient from it thermogenesis kick in after every meal and the digestive process continue to burn calorie many hour after a meal is eaten the thermogenic effect of food will depend upon the type of food and the amount of food consumed in the diet a a whole an effective weight loss programme can be modified to include some of these thermogenic food to help you to achieve your goal but it is important to remember that this effect will only be achieved a part of a balanced diet with this in mind here are eight food that can have a thermogenic effect on your body 1 chili pepper capsaicin a compound in chilli pepper stimulates the body to burn energy and create heat in our body white fat cell store energy and brown fat cell are thermogenic producing heat by burning fat a 2015 study suggested that increasing capsaicin in the diet may stimulate thermogenesis and also induce white fat cell to behave like thermogenic brown fat cell use fresh chili chilli flake or cayenne powder to add flavour to marinade and dressing or simply sprinkle liberally on your meal 2 whole grain and vegetable complex carbohydrate such a brown rice oat and quinoa also high in protein are high in dietary fibre that the gut cannot fully digest and break down the extra effort the body ha to put in requires extra energy burning it energy store to digest these indigestible food it is no surprise that any weight loss programme will encourage eating high portion of vegetable and in particular the leafy green such a spinach rocket watercress kale and cabbage these vegetable are all high in insoluble fibre a with complex carbohydrate these will have a thermic effect on the body a more energy is used up in an attempt to digest these indigestible compound so aim to reach your seven a day of which five are vegetable and a maximum of two are fruit choose fruit with high fibre content such a apple or pear 3 black pepper piperine a compound found in black pepper ha a thermic effect and can be responsible for the breakdown of some fat cell so reaching for the black pepper not only offer the benefit of it thermic effect but also add extra flavour to your meal 4 ginger ginger also contains capsaicin responsible for it fiery flavour eating ginger fresh or powdered in your food can speed up the metabolism due to the increased heat production study also suggest that ginger can reduce feeling of hunger and may help to manage weight use it in stir fry curry and marinade or try a warming ginger tea slice into thick disc and add hot water and allow it to steep for 10 minute ginger can also be grated from frozen or stored in the freezer already sliced ready to use in a tea 5 garlic like ginger garlic with it fiery kick contains compound that can enhance thermogenesis in brown adipose tissue use extra clove if you enjoy the taste and include in marinade and dressing for a flavour boost 6 mustard mustard contains compound found in other spicy food and in particular capsaicin that not only give it it characteristic flavour but also can also help to increase the body temperature when eaten add in a teaspoon of mustard to your salad dressing or include it in a casserole for added flavour 7 green tea study show that both caffeine and catechin polyphenols micronutrient found in green tea can help to stimulate the metabolism boosting the number of calorie used by the body therefore it can promote weight loss when combined with a healthy balanced diet and increased physical activity 8 protein when compared to fat and carbohydrate eating a meal high in protein ha a bigger thermic effect protein are complex nutrient and will require more energy to break them down a part of the digestive process for example if you eat a chicken breast containing 300 calorie around 30 percent i e 100 calorie will be burned during digestion research ha shown that eating a high protein diet lead to lower weight gain in part also due to it positive effect on post meal hunger and desire to eat always ensure good protein with every meal or snack not only for it thermogenic effect but also to help you stay full vegetarian protein source include quinoa bean brown rice and lentil

title: if you leave your kid alone it s not predatory stranger who are a risk
context: once when she wa in about the first grade she even found a snake there s no way i would have picked up a snake in front of my parent she say the reason i knew it wa ok wa i had also gone by myself to the library to take a snake safety class yes a snake safety class you can pretend you re the queen of sheba she say playing on her own let her imagination soar a a child ashley thomas loved to go by herself to a meadow about a 10 minute walk from her house in ojai california ah the old time memory of the day when kid could play on their own without someone posting a video online to shame their parent or calling the police to have mom arrested and the child seized by social service only in the past decade or so ha no child left alone become the social and legal norm in the u s a doctoral student in cognitive science at the university of california at irvine thomas is the lead author of a recently published study designed to understand what s going on after all under most circumstance the objective risk to child left by themselves is extremely low the chance that a stranger will abduct and kill or not return a child the great fear driving the new norm is about 0 00007 per cent or one in 1 4 million annually it s much more dangerous to drive a child somewhere or even to walk with one across a parking lot than to leave a kid alone in a well ventilated car news report and crime show feed exaggerated fear thomas and her co author note that legal norm needn t follow inaccurate belief about risk the fact that many people irrationally fear air travel doe not result in air travel being criminalized they write parent are not arrested for bringing their child with them on airplane in contrast parent are arrested and prosecuted for allowing their child to wait in car play in park or walk through their neighbourhood without an adult they note indeed parent safely make decision every day without thinking about other tiny risk when you decide to park your car in a parking lot you don t look up at the roof to see if a sniper could hit you thomas say you don t think about whether the store you re taking your child into might get held up nor should you yet leaving your kid alone even for a short time in safe circumstance can lead to a child abuse investigation what s going on the researcher suspected that the overestimating of risk reflects moral conviction about proper parenting to separate the two instinct they created a series of survey asking participant to rate the danger to child left alone in five specific circumstance a 2 1 2 year old at home for 20 minute eating a snack and watching frozen for instance or a 6 year old in a park about a mile from her house for 25 minute the reason for the parent s absence were varied randomly it could be unintentional for work to volunteer for charity to relax or to meet an illicit lover because the child s situation wa exactly the same in all the intentional case the risk should also be identical asked what the danger might be participant listed the same one in all circumstance with a stranger harming the child the most common followed by an accident the unintentional case might be slightly more dangerous because parent wouldn t have a chance to make provision for their absence such a giving the child a phone and emergency instruction or parking the car in the shade but survey respondent didn t see thing this way at all a mother s unintentional absence wa seen a safer for the child than a mother s intentional absence for any reason and a mother s work related absence wa seen a more dangerous than an unintentional absence but le dangerous than if the mother left to pursue an illicit sexual affair they write the same wa true for father except that respondent rated leaving for work a posing no greater danger than leaving unintentionally moral disapproval informed belief about risk that wa true even when the survey explicitly separated the two factor first asking participant to rate leaving the child from 1 nothing wrong to 10 highly unethical immoral people rated the risk higher when they first made a moral judgment people don t only think that leaving child alone is dangerous and therefore immoral the researcher write they also think it is immoral and therefore dangerous that is people overestimate the actual danger to child who are left alone by their parent in order to better support or justify their moral condemnation of parent who do so the result is a feedback loop that increase the legal and social penalty for leaving kid alone and reinforces the belief that even the briefest parental absence amount to child abuse these belief don t just affect busybody they lead police prosecutor judge and juror to overestimate risk take what happened to julie koehler she left her three daughter age 8 5 and 4 watching a video in the minivan while she went into an evanston illinois starbucks for three minute when she saw a police officer talking to the girl through the open window she thought nothing of it until he returned and her 8 year old started cry she rushed out of the store and the situation deteriorated from there koehler is a public defender in the homicide division she knew she hadn t broken any law and she had two lawyer her husband and mother to call to the scene she wasn t arrested but the state nonetheless initiated a child abuse investigation official interrogated the kid required a pediatrician s exam demanded that koehler supply two reference and questioned them and her about her mental health including whether she wa on any medication what if i wa taking an anti depressant would that have affected the outcome of the case she asks the investigation determined that the report of abuse wa unfounded but it taught koehler the hazard of leaving your kid for even the briefest time under the safest circumstance the real stranger danger doesn t come from would be kidnapper it come from people who think they re doing good

process and monopoly utility say david our hypothesis and what we ve proven is that people will change and people making choice with their pocketbook drive change solar energy is beating the cost of natural gas plant across the country right now even the operating cost and that s not even including the volatility premium you d have to price in to a natural gas plant you d be building for 20 year operating consistently 24 hour a day because they really can t be shut off you can t just turn off a coal fired power plant for four hour in a day you end up burning a lot more energy a lot more coal title: dr karl can you get pregnant during a pregnancy featured story additional story
context: can human become pregnant while already pregnant it s possible but rare can a woman get pregnant when she is already pregnant in other word can she have two foetus in her uterus at different stage of development the technical term for this is superfetation in human it s possible but it s very uncommon two thousand year ago that great greek thinker aristotle wondered about this very topic specifically a regard the hare aristotle noticed that when a hare gave birth quite often the offspring in a single litter would fall into two distinct class there would be a bunch of full sized robust baby hare and another bunch of scrawny frail baby hare it wa he thought a though the mother hare had become pregnant and then while pregnant had conceived a second time there wa nothing fundamentally wrong with the smaller weedy offspring aristotle thought apart from the fact that they had not spent enough time growing in their mother s uterus and he wa right normally in human there are three separate barrier to stop a female from getting pregnant again if she is already pregnant the first barrier is the hormonal change after conception that stop the ovary from releasing another egg dr karl explores the uncommon phenomenon of superfetation the second barrier is physical a mucous plug almost immediately after conception a plug form in the cervix and sits at the top of the vagina this plug stop any other sperm from entering the uterus and getting to a second egg third there are physical and chemical change that happen to the inner lining of the uterus in pregnancy these change usually stop a second fertilised egg from being able to attach to the uterine wall even so some animal specie manage to get around all these barrier about 1 to 2 per cent of all pregnant cow show sign of being potentially fertile while they are already pregnant and superfetation ha been observed in animal such a the mouse the rabbit the sheep the buffalo the mink and the australian swamp wallaby superfetation is extremely uncommon in human with fewer than a dozen case in the medical literature a typical case is that of julia grovenburg a 31 year old woman from arkansas m grovenburg and her partner had been trying to get pregnant for three year and had begun to consider adoption of a child but amazingly she conceived twice in 2009 a few week apart the daily mail claimed that in a desperate and final attempt to have child of their own the couple had given it one last try this is a curious use of the word desperate possible superfetation ha been observed in cow i might be old fashioned but it seems odd to me to regard sexual intercourse a a desperate and final attempt to get pregnant it make you wonder what measure they tried before they got desperate anyhow m grovenburg wa pregnant but then thing went odd the ultrasound showed two independent baby each living in their own separate amniotic sac but one wa much larger and more developed than the other a the ultrasound scan mounted up for m grovenburg both foetus seemed to be growing normally and healthily though it appeared a if one foetus had simply started a few week after the other in other word mr grovenburg had conceived a second baby a few week after becoming pregnant with the first now we don t have rock solid proof that this is what happened we would need a series of ultrasound scan to prove that these scan would need to document a series of change starting with no foetus or amniotic sac in the uterus and then a single foetus in it single amniotic sac and a second foetus appearing in their own second amniotic sac after a few week people don t usually get a series of ultrasound scan immediately after sexual intercourse so this kind of hard data is difficult to get but there is some evolutionary biology behind superfetation female european brown hare frequently have a second pregnancy while already pregnant this mean female can have about one third more offspring in each breeding season for human more baby each breeding cycle isn t always a plus especially if you re trying to get a good night s sleep if you have inside knowledge of a topic in the news contact the abc it s a phenomenon known a superfetation and while it s rare it can happen
question: wondering if you can get pregnant during a pregnancy dr karl ha the answer for you science can you get pregnant during a pregnancy

text: the technical term for this is superfetation in human it s possible but it s very uncommon

already eclipsed the top four social networking apps twitter linkedin facebook and instagram in their aggregate monthly active user this rapid growth is also poised to leave the rest of the mobile app ecosystem in the dust according to emarketer more than 1 4 billion consumer were using messaging apps by the end of 2015 that s 75 of all smartphone user and an increase of 31 6 over the previous year and that number ha grown rapidly since a of this week facebook messenger ha already amassed 900 million user on it own at a time when most smartphone user download zero apps per month and a quarter of all downloaded apps are abandoned after a single use user are spending an average of 200 minute a week on whatsapp so this is clearly a medium we should pay attention to but how should publisher and news organization play with it to answer that question we need to grasp what it is about messaging that s allowed it to become pervasive so that we can gain a better understanding of how content could fit comfortably on it why messaging is different text message the ubiquitous kind that are primarily used by consumer on their mobile device more aptly mimic the fluidity of human communication than other digital form the technology embedded in text message sits in the background versus in your way for instance you can respond to a text message immediately or whenever is most convenient for you it doesn t require conversing party to be available simultaneously a a phone call or video chat doe nor doe it assume that people would rather correspond asynchronously a with email text message also offer a better representation of a person s relationship by focusing on long term conversation message are typically organized in a list form that is automatically updated every time you interact with it the people you talk to most frequently and recently at any given moment surface at the top of that list you don t have to manually program and repeatedly update the list in the way you may have back when you added your friend and family member to phone based speed dial or in the way you need to tell facebook which friend are closer to you than others a status that can change from time to time also in the context of the text message thread a message you receive carry the expectation that you will engage with it in this fundamental way messaging differs from push notification or alert which instead serve to simply broadcast information the expectation with an alert is that a soon a you interact with it it go away a soon a you interact with a text message it sits at the top of your messaging list this focus on fluidity and conversation allows text messaging to more adequately fit the demand of our dynamic circumstance and relationship than other form of digital communication to successfully engage with the medium therefore publisher should harness these unique feature that have made messaging powerful cost center or revenue stream publisher will also need to know if messaging offer a clear path or at least a dimly lit one to monetization in order to see how widely they can experiment and whether this new outlet will represent a new cost center or revenue stream while it s too early to tell there are a few unique related aspect that are potentially promising by virtue of it living on your phone messaging is a natural access point to both your social and mobile data by virtue of it living on your phone natively harnessing an ongoing memory of your conversation and serving a the best digital representation of your relationship messaging is a natural access point to both your social and mobile data for instance facebook messenger is aware of your identity social graph location conversation history and more this ongoing memory coupled with the fact that user are already becoming increasingly comfortable with making payment on their mobile device position in messaging payment service a potential facilitator of paywalled content once they set up their relationship with a service like stripe or facebook messenger s native payment feature user can theoretically convert to paying subscriber with a quick text versus detailing their personal and financial information at every point of sale this could make payment via messaging more effortless than they are to facilitate via website this unique access to data also allows for messaging to support personalized and perhaps more appropriate user interaction with sponsor a opposed to simply serving banner ad that may feel disruptive to the conversational experience messaging apps have the potential to serve offer based on a user s preference in this vein facebook messenger revealed that it will be experimenting with sponsored message since preserving a personal tone is essential to the messaging experience publisher and advertiser will likely explore this area cautiously so we will hopefully see more intuitive exercise in commercialization using this new medium for instance since facebook messenger may already know of some service and company you like via the data you have fed the parent platform over time it will probably prioritize facilitating message between you and those company you already trust and may want to hear from on the flip side if an advertiser get too noisy or feel irrelevant you can easily block them from messaging you again editorial experiment before monetizing it publisher need to test the medium itself the most obvious lowest friction way to experiment within messaging platform is to simply focus on them a new distribution point for content that s already been created predictably many big publisher have dipped their toe in this way for instance the economist and buzzfeed both experimented with the messaging app line to push out news alert that include link back to their respective publication for the full story setting up this type of experience is similar to using twitter to alert user simply create an account on a text messaging app allow user to subscribe to that account and either manually send out notification or set up automated news alert while easy and cheap to fulfill this use case render an experience that s closer to that of a billboard than a conversation which is why the economist deemed the exercise a brand building initiative since the user can t really interact with the message at best this experiment s result will be commensurate with the effort and at worst they may mirror punishment by way of a slow release of the entire work of shakespeare over text in taking a step towards experimenting with the conversational aspect of messaging some publisher have run effort like live editorial commentary in this paradigm a publication s staff member chat amongst themselves for instance discussing a news event and the subscribed audience can follow the conversation a it unfolds and maybe even participate in the discussion the guardian hosted a whatsapp chat alongside the gop debate in december and the huffington post ran a similar effort around various news topic on viber another related use case involving editorial conversation is acting out a script the bbc recently used viber to tell the story of a real kidnapping in mexico by having it editorial staff role play using actual quote from people involved in the case a in the news alert use case for this type of experience publisher need to create account on messaging platform and build their subscriber base but this experiment also call for extra time commitment from editorial staffer to write script and or run the live chat it can also require an outside trigger event like a debate to be happening concurrently on another screen that chat subscriber are also tuning in to chatbots while potentially engaging hosting live conversation on messaging apps is resource intensive and limited in it interaction with end user a editor can t scale themselves to respond to every user s question or comment this problem ha prompted publisher to experiment with chatbots to allow user to interact with the news in the context of text messaging a bot is an account operated by software in place of a person given a pre prescribed set of rule a human editor make a bot can theoretically respond to a user in a way that mimic a human response quartz recently released a news app that sends a user a blurb about a story and employ a bot to ask the user to select between reading more about that specific story or moving on to the next story forbesbot on telegram cnn created a similar bot on facebook messenger using the just released send and receive api and publication like forbes and techcrunch have created bot on the messaging platform telegram using bot creator chatfuel purple is yet another similarly powered bot that text user with election news allowing them to delve deeper into a subtopic within a message by texting back a pre designated keyword e g kasich contained within that original bot message powering these experience relies on a diligent combined effort of developing a bot frequently via a third party and dedicating editorial resource to writing short conversational prose out of published story in it current state the news bot is a novelty that more closely mimic the experience of interacting with an automatic phone teller than talking to a human journalist the seemingly endless loop of repeatedly hitting button or expressing keywords in order to get a response to a specific question can leave a user quickly fatigued the underlying problem is that bot are essentially formula created to handle a limited set of scenario within a pre defined framework and they haven t gotten to the point where they can manage massive bank of scenario smoothly enough to handle every day decision this problem isn t so different from why with self driving vehicle we re clearly pretty close to making a car that can handle highway driving with no human input since the range of possible event is pretty small say benedict evans a partner at the venture capital fund andreesen horowitz but driving in central rome or moscow is an entirely different matter that need an entirely different level of decision making what doe that hand gesture mean to handle the multitude of scenario presented in an open ended system like chat we need a far more sophisticated bot that can scalably and quickly run decision based on all potential user input a form of artificial intelligence ai that can more holistically mimic human conversation the current limitation of chatbots haven t stopped messaging platform like telegram kik and facebook messenger from launching their own bot ecosystem nor have they hindered publication like the washington post from creating their own homegrown bot the promise of true ai an interaction framework that would allow news provider to offer each of their user a bespoke conversational experience at scale is far too meaningful to give up on that s why in tandem with releasing it limited scope send and recieve api for bot creator facebook ha also released bot engine a system based on machine learning that can pave the way for more complex scenario like handling different variation of the same user question ai powered news looking to the future you can imagine an ai based chatbot that truly comprehends intention behind language a bot that you can have long term discussion with about the news the way you would with a well informed friend this intelligent bot could also fulfill the promise of voice based product like apple s siri or amazon s alexa it would both learn who you are and understand the content within story enough to surface news you d likely be interested in whether or not you explicitly told it you were or perhaps before you even knew you were this type of bot would be promising in the sense that it may change the current rut we are in with digital news a relationship which twitter s co founder and medium founder ev williams aptly describes a stuck in the idea that the medium people consume is what they want will writer soon share the kind of power and influence over creating digital user experience that graphical designer now have while we don t currently have ai powered news we can start paving the way for it by crafting the right type of conversation based framework for it what s exciting about this for writer and journalist is that the archetype text messaging is based on broadly described a conversational user interface ui is largely driven by exposing functionality through language designing a killer chatbot therefore relies at least a much on using the right kind of language a it doe on a creating a great graphical user interface will writer soon share the kind of power and influence over creating digital user experience that graphical designer now have unlike website and mobile apps which rely heavily on navigational design and button to express breadth of coverage and direct user to the content they may be interested in with chatbots all of your feature need to be reachable solely through word so picking the right thing to say and the tone of your dialogue with the user is crucial explains matty mariansky who created meekan a calendaring bot for enterprise messaging platform slack this new role of language can empower writer to design experience for messaging based service for instance mariansky hired dedicated scriptwriter to come up with more than 2 000 sentence to handle a meeting request while mark zuckerberg argues that the best messaging experience will combine conversational and graphical ui rather than rely on word alone the role of language a a form of user experience design becomes even more important when we start designing our bot to be flexible enough to work with both text and voice when the bot is stripped of a screen altogether a with service like siri and alexa language is the user experience it wouldn t be far fetched therefore to imagine a scenario in which journalist extend their writing skill and editorial judgment to not only cover story but design the channel through which these story are distributed these writer may also be critical to the development of an entirely new bot influenced lexicon introducing new word and phrase into our vernacular and through them new way for user to interact with the news this type of shift the ability for writer and publisher to design digital experience with the same skill set used to hone their journalistic craft could profoundly change their current shaky relationship with digital product and news distribution and in turn with their monetization stream and reader journalist don t have to sit back and watch this bot story unfold there are no definitive paradigm yet so we can help write the book on creating the most engaging experience
question: how should publisher and news organization utilize the text messaging medium what is the best way for publisher and news organization to use text messaging

title: aleppo evacuation halted a rebel open fire on convoy

title: tom hank riveting performance make captain phillips one of year s best so far

best actor winner and five time nominee is at his very best before the key sequence in paul greengrass new film should provide oscar prognosticator with all they need to know about the 57 year old actor s award chance captain phillips is set to open the 2013 new york film festival but sony and producer scott rudin set up screening this week for critic and journalist to see the film while all eye are fixed on toronto thus far the move paid off review have been solid with some in contention editor kris tapley huffpost entertainment s own mike ryan more infatuated with the film than others variety critic scott foundas the wrap critic alonso duralde heed the word from the former camp captain phillips stand at the very top of the recent spate of thinking person action film from the last few year on par with kathryn bigelow s zero dark thirty and well ahead of ben affleck s best picture winning argo the reason is hank who give the type of performance everyone ha wanted to see from tom hank since the early 2000s his richard phillips is not the most emotional of men an opening scene with his wife played very briefly but beautifully by catherine keener establishes him a the kind of thoughtful quiet type who one can assume watch the history channel and like tommy lee jones movie yet a greengrass keep turning the screw on phillips and his situation that cool demeanor begin to crack shatter and later turn to dust hank is put through the ringer greengrass closed quarter camera work keep in him the action even a thing get impossibly physical and the result are breathtaking like the best acting hank performance actually feel real by the end of the film it s hard to tell where hank end and phillips begin this is the time of year when a new oscar front runner debut almost every day gravity and 12 year a slave reached the top of the line after raf last week yet captain phillips belongs in those whispered early award musing not just for hank and greengrass a previous nominee for united 93 a film that bear similarity to captain phillips in structure and form but for best editing christopher rouse best cinematography barry ackroyd best adapted screenplay billy ray and if a wave of support carry the film to multiple nomination perhaps best supporting actor for barkhad abdi the newcomer play muse the lead somali pirate in the film a relatively decent man turned to evil behavior by his standing in life abdi and barkhad addirahman faysal ahmed mahat m ali a the other pirate help keep the film from ever truly demonizing phillips kidnapper an easy pitfall that greengrass deftly avoids the problem is that abdi doesn t have an easy road to supporting actor the category is a loaded a usual with actor like daniel bruhl for rush michael fassbender for 12 year a slave josh brolin for labor day steve coogan for philomena bradley cooper for american hustle and even hank for saving mr bank potentially standing in his way that however is back room chatter for another day for now just know that captain phillips is one of those truly terrific movie that everyone hope to see in the fall it s riveting filmmaking captain phillips open on oct 11

title: this almost free item is one of the most important thing you can keep in your car
context: you get a lot of advice about what you absolutely positively must have in your car most of it is spot on some of it is a tad excessive you don t really need a space blanket if you aren t planning a long trip through a desert or a frozen wasteland some folk take their preparation to an extreme i myself wa guilty of this for a time when living in los angeles i wanted to guard against the consequence of an earthquake by keeping a few gallon of water stashed in my minivan you don t have to go that far but even if you don t have jumper cable a tool kit a tire pressure gauge and all the other stuff the gearheads say you should have on hand there is one item that in my book is absolutely necessary it s a rag yes a humble rag could be an old dishtowel or washcloth could be an old t shirt could be a bandana but everybody must have one in their car why because the rag can serve many purpose you can use it to wipe stuff off of the engine so you can get a better look at fluid level you can use it to wipe the dipstick when you check your oil you can use it to protect your hand when you have to loosen a stubborn lug nut you can use it to clean your headlight and taillight when winter get them all grimy and slushy you can also use it if it isn t too filthy to clean up spill in the interior and even to polish up the exterior best of all this is an item that for most people will be 100 free because rag are often headed to the garbage so get yourself a good old rag and keep it in your vehicle you ll be glad you did

title: here s what happens if you never wash your jean
context: provided by the independent the argument for not washing your jean ha traditionally been about making your denim last longer hot water and detergent can speed up how quickly your jean fade levi s ceo chip bergh say we should stop washing our jean because it s good for the environment since it save water and energy if you talk to real denim aficionado they tell you don t wash your blue jean bergh said in a 2014 interview at fortune magazine s brainstorm green conference this advice may seem cringeworthy but apart from smelling microbiologist say there is nothing to worry about from a health perspective if you never wash your jean is not washing your jean safe there is no evidence that not washing jean is hazardous to your health according to bernhard redl an associate professor in the molecular biology department at the university of innsbruck in austria this generally hold true when your denim is worn under normal condition such a everyday street wear bacteria skin cell and sweat are transferred to our pant from our own body but skin microorganism are generally not hazardous to ourselves said rachel mcqueen a professor of human ecology at the university of alberta in canada mcqueen s research focus on the development and retention of odor in textile there are environment where having sterile clothing is important mcqueen said that would be true in a hospital for example where clothing can transfer infection however sanitizing your hand is going to be a more important issue here than washing your jean she said a few year ago one of mcqueen s student wore his jean for 15 month straight without a single wash and then tested the level of bacteria on them the student teacher team wa surprised to find that the unwashed jean carried nearly the same amount of bacteria a those same pant after they had been washed and then worn for another 13 day what i found wa just normal skin flora mcqueen told the national post in 2011 the count were really really similar the bacteria load from the swabbed area were pretty much the same the freezing myth although not washing your jean doesn t seem to pose any health risk the smell could become a problem denim head have suggested freezing your jean a a way to kill bacteria and the stench although there is no scientific proof that this method is effective it is clear that freezing doe not kill most of the bacteria said redl but put them in a dormant state bacteria stop growing in the freezer but will become active again once you slip your pant back on and those germ are warmed up by the heat of your body i think airing your jean outdoors in the sunlight would be a more effective method of getting rid of odor and a lot of bacteria said mcqueen
question: here s what happens if you never wash your jean what happens if you never wash your jean

title: shoveling snow can kill men canadian study find
context: men are more likely to have a heart attack after a snowfall and it s probably from the exertion of shoveling snow canadian researcher reported monday they found a slight increase in both heart attack and death from heart attack in quebec after a storm the likelihood went up with each extra day of snow they reported in the canadian medical association journal we suspect that shoveling wa the main mechanism linking snowfall with myocardial infarction heart attack dr nathalie auger of the university of montreal hospital research center and colleague wrote men are potentially more likely than woman to shovel particularly after heavy snowfall snow shoveling is a demanding cardiovascular exercise requiring more than 75 percent of the maximum heart rate particularly with heavy load they added the team studied 128 000 heart attack case between 1981 and 2014 and more than 68 000 people who died a single day of snowfall raised a man s risk of heart attack by just le than 1 percent they wrote and it raised his risk of dying from a heart attack by 12 percent eight inch of snowfall raised the risk 16 percent compared to a day in the same month that did not have snow they reported and men were one third more likely to die of a heart attack the day after an eight inch snowfall compared to a dry day woman were not more likely to either have heart attack or to die of them after snow the team found snow shoveling is hard it s not a daily activity and it strain the heart auger s team said people often exhale hard with their mouth closed while lifting a heavy shovel full of snow a dangerous habit called the valsalva maneuver they noted using the arm intensively and repetitively especially while standing upright can also raise the risk that a piece will break off from a clogged artery the researcher noted cold temperature make blood vessel constrict which add to the danger it might not only be shoveling that doe it people using snow blower have also been reported to have higher rate of heart attack the canadian team noted the national safety council ha some advice for how to safely shovel snow do not shovel after eating or while smoking take it slow and stretch out before you begin push the snow rather than lifting it if you do lift it use a small shovel or only partially fill the shovel lift with your leg not your back do not work to the point of exhaustion talk to a doctor before shoveling if you have a history of heart disease stop immediately if you feel dizzy or tightness in the chest
question: read this before you go out to shovel your driveway what should you do before you go out to shovel your driveway

text: talk to a doctor before shoveling if you have a history of heart disease stop immediately if you feel dizzy or tightness in the chest

title: minnesota want to legalize medical marijuana but police agency are in the way
context: minnesota will consider passing legislation to legalize the medical use of marijuana but police agency are standing in the way a bill in the state house of representative would legalize the condition approved by the state commissioner of health patient would first need to obtain an id card by getting written certification from a doctor say measure hf 1818 which wa introduced by rep carly melin d hibbing last spring there s evidence that state politician are open to passing such a bill a similar effort wa approved by the minnesota house and senate in 2009 before being vetoed by then governor tim pawlenty r this time around governor mark dayton d say he d sign the bill but not without the support of minnesota law enforcement agency so far not a single agency ha lent it support to the bill their opposition according to a report in local paper st cloud time is based on fear that marijuana s medical benefit are still unproven that any legalization effort will increase the drug s availability to kid and that the bill is too broad in listing qualifying condition the head of one police agency put it another way he openly admitted that he wa worried legalizing weed for medical purpose might make it harder for police to get federal drug war dollar minnesota receives million in anti drug money from the white house every year and asset seizure from drug raid have become an integral part of state police budget politics in minnesota reported earlier this month a a result melin ha said she may draft a compromise bill to legalize marijuana extract in pill or liquid form while such a law would be much more restrictive in term of which patient could receive cannabis for treatment some law enforcement agency have said they might be open to such a measure obviously any compromise is disheartening for patient melin told the la crosse tribune but we re facing reality around here which is if we can get anything done there s going to have to be compromise minnesota voter on the other hand have shown they overwhelmingly support legalizing medical marijuana in all it form a st cloud state university poll from last year found 76 percent support for the issue hf 1818 ha been referred to the health and human service policy committee and is scheduled to have a hearing wednesday evening melin said her compromise bill could be ready a soon a next week

title: super smash bros 4 3d multiplayer lag during gameplay is a consistent problem here s how to fix it
context: there s no denying that super smash bros 4 on the 3d is a great game the release date brought a fighter with many character lot of gameplay mode and frantic item throwing fun but nothing s perfect in the case of smash bros 4 the mulitplayer lag is a huge issue whether it be local multiplayer in sm4sh or online the game stutter early and often the game is superb which is why it pain u that no matter what stage we choose our smash bros 4 fight always take place in lag city we got a hint of this when we did our review for ssb43ds but chalked it up to all other player being located halfway across the world in japan now that the game s out in our country we thought our lag issue would be alleviated boy were we wrong now don t get u wrong we agree with louis ck the fact that we can play a video game with anyone around the world is amazing but smash is serious business despite being a fighting game the lag is pretty consistent so we quantified it smash bros super smash bros 4 lag online multiplayer we began our testing using both the for fun and for glory mode on the 3d similar to when i played sm4sh for the review we experienced constant lag throughout gameplay during our for fun play button press were consistently between 30 to 40 millisecond late not a huge amount obviously though certainly noticeable during our 3rd match during for fun while playing online using our home wifi network smash bros 4 decided to leave u indefinitely in the training mode just before the match begin we re not sure if this wa a network problem someone dropped off or just a glitch in the game without the ability to hit the home button we were forced to turn it off on to for glory then smash bros for glory saw lag go a high a 63 millisecond after button were pressed though similar to for fun the lag wa consistent if you re fine with pressing button twice just to make sure they register you can complete a match relatively trouble free smash bros ssb4 local multiplayer playing smash with our bros in person wa a different story for some reason having everyone in the same room made our multiplayer lag experience worse than the online equivalent i and two others with the game sitting in a circle err triangle not more than 5 foot from each other ran into considerable lag when playing super smash bros 4 we played the game for nearly 3 hour using various character and stage in a set of about 15 stage the first few went off without a hitch with the occasional hiccup the same couldn t be said for the second half of our marathon smash session 5 of the latter 7 match lagged uncontrollably to the point where the loading spinner appeared on screen telling u to wait having one player completely lose all their stock life with only 2 fighter remaining on screen didn t help the situation despite having never moved physically the rate of waiting for the throbber varied at time reaching 3 4 second in a 2nd round of local smash bros 4 multiplayer testing read playing in the office for science 2 player wa much easier on the system the most lag we encountered occurred when 2 human player and a 3rd cpu player wa thrown in the mix surprisingly 2 human player and 2 cpu resulted in no lag smash bros ssb4 online lag fix and placebo having this much lag in a multiplayer game especially one like super smash bros 4 detracts from the overall experience though at least online the lag wa consistent enough to get used to the sporadic nature of local multiplayer s random loading dial and epic slow down make more than 2 human player battle pretty annoying so guy found out i had lag because of my 3d aluminum case smashbros pic twitter com wd5lw2pqns raymond lancione raylancione october 7 2014 if anyone s having smashbros lag online apparently it get better if you plug in the charger while playing it wa me milu miluette october 6 2014 connectivity can depend heavily on location so i really don t know what to say at the very least we ve confirmed that smooth play is possible under various condition of external network during multi player you re connected with another player and sending light amount of data back and forth so if the game feel laggy it s due to the connection speed if you play when it s laggy then the person you re playing with will experience the same lag so it s best to play when the connection is clear during development there were case where we had too many people and the connection became sluggish so we turned off our cell phone and the connection would clear up it s best to avoid playing while streaming something or by a tethered connection free wi fi spot are probably not very good either wordpress the part where i complain about the 3d hardware something tell me the new 3d wa made because the current one can t handle super smash bros this is the first time a smash game ha been made available for handheld and already we ve seen report of broken circle pad and awkward control scheme the 3d charger improving the online performance likely hint at the processing power of nintendo s hardware likely holding back in an effort to save battery life not to mention og 3d owner not getting access to the beloved c stick nintendo s hardware always lag behind the competition but they ve been able to get around it by bringing u great game but what happens when even your own killer first party title doesn t run properly on yesterday s hardware you swore by would the p vita have these lag issue could the ice climber have part of smash bros for the iphone not that you could ever seriously play smash on a smartphone but not the point though all in all smash player now that the 3d version isn t the real experience having the game with u at all time is nice but the real showdown will take place on the wii u in hd and with gamecube controller in hand if nintendo can bring a smooth experience to the full edition of super smash bros 4 fan may be likely to forgive the gaming company are you experiencing lag in your online battle in smash bros 4 let u know your experience below
question: how to fix lag in ssb4 on 3d how can i improve the performance of ssb4 on my 3d

text: 2 human player and 2 cpu resulted in no lag
get better if you plug in the charger while playing

converse to associate with elected official they sit on board with in a way that allows them to do their business to advocate and represent the best interest of their community a lot easier begay said right now it s a hardship for these official because they have to post open meeting law and post notice for simple discussion if they need to get together to address issue begay said the bill isn t intended to give lawmaker an opportunity to discus unethical or immoral criminal issue behind closed door we re all held to a certain standard and i think that s the expectation that we re not trying to decrease transparency and openness but we re leaving that discretion to the elected official themselves to ensure that when public input and public comment is needed that they do that he said in fact allen told the arizona daily sun that the state s open meeting law produce an undemocratic law making process because official aren t allowed to meet privately to discus legislation official must send staffer to serve a a go between among colleague to reach a consensus that process allen told the arizona daily sun is undemocratic because it allows unelected staff member to play a central role in drafting law staff wasn t elected staff isn t accountable allen told the daily sun dan barr a first amendment lawyer with the firm perkins coie said the time when a policy is deliberated before a measure is introduced is a critical point for public input it allows you to see how your various public official are approaching their job how they view certain issue what their thought process is what their reasoning process is barr told the huffington post it allows people then to participate in that barr added that open meeting law shouldn t be weakened just because they make the life of title: the antibody that were invented to help immunologist find god
context: in the classic 1966 science fiction film fantastic voyage a submarine is shrunk to microscopic size and injected into the blood stream of a scientist to remove a blood clot in his brain the film illustrates many aspect of biology perhaps most memorably when raquel welch venture out of the submarine and is attacked by antibody molecule which recognise her a a foreign invader and try to destroy her the antibody of the film look like wriggly bit of string that rush at her and then adapt themselves to the shape of her body for an immunologist fantastic voyage is interesting a it wa made when there were competing theory of how antibody worked one the instructional theory suggested that all antibody molecule were the same but they folded themselves around their target and learned it shape to forestall future invasion before destroying it the alternative clonal selection theory say that there were billion of different antibody each with a different shape each b cell a type of immune cell specialises in making just one type of antibody when a foreign invader such a bacteria enters the body only one b cell will recognise it that b cell would begin to rapidly divide making large number of clone these newly cloned b cell secrete large amount of antibody which stick to the invader and mark it for destruction the instructional theory wa championed by no le a person than two time nobel prize winner linus pauling while macfarlane burnet also a nobel prize winner wa the key proponent of clonal selection the maker of the film followed pauling though whether this wa for scientific reason or because the interaction between stringy antibody and welch made for better cinema isn t clear however they were wrong clonal selection theory won the argument nowadays clonal selection seems so obviously right that it is difficult to remember that it initially appeared to have a fatal flaw scientist knew that the immune system of an animal could make antibody to any foreign antigen in the 1930s karl landsteiner showed that antibody could be made to chemical that never even existed naturally this led to a problem for the clonal theory to be correct there had to be pre existing antibody in animal or human capable of recognising any antigen that might ever exist this would require billion of different antibody and a every antibody is encoded by a separate gene for there to be billion of antibody molecule there would also have to be billion of different gene but there are no more than 25 000 gene to encode for everything in the human body considerably fewer than needed to make the clonal selection theory possible the god problem in several in the 1960s and 70 immunologist were increasingly convinced by the clonal selection theory this led to a race to discover the solution to the problem of how so many different antibody could be encoded it wa termed the generation of diversity or god problem the god problem wa such an important and intriguing question that it attracted many of the best scientist of the decade and resulted nobel prize scientist showed that god wa due to several biological mechanism that people had not realised could happen including rearrangement of chunk of dna in chromosome and deliberate mutation of dna sequence the difficulty and novelty of the science meant that immunologist had to develop new technology and some of these technique which were used to answer fundamental question ended up having practical application perhaps most notably ce sar milstein wa interested in understanding how during an immune response antibody improve and become better at binding to their antigen he wanted to immunise an animal and then at various time isolate b cell to make antibody he could then use these to study how well they bound to their antigen and also sequence the gene encoding the antibody to see how it changed over time in doing so he developed together with george ko hler in 1975 a method that made b cell live forever making limitless amount of what they called a monoclonal antibody milstein realised that their technique called hybridoma technology had much wider application in science and medicine the impact of monoclonal antibody a scientific tool and for the treatment of disease ha been immense because they can be made in large amount and are specific they are used in many experiment and clinical test they have now also become an important type of drug having an important role to play in treating many cancer a well a other disease such a rheumatoid arthritis in economic term monoclonal antibody therapy are estimated to have had sale of u 75 billion in 2013 in an age that demand that science is useful and should be applied it is perhaps worth remembering that one of the most important technology in medicine and biology wa developed to answer a very basic scientific question scientist are motivated to develop new technique to answer important question they often later find that these technique have important practical application beyond their original purpose application that could save million of life
question: the antibody that were invented to help immunologist find god what is the purpose of the antibody mentioned in the sentence

text: monoclonal antibody a scientific tool and for the treatment of disease

title: 7 transcendental festival out in the middle of nowhere

thousand are having legitimately moving and profound experience that might actually make them reassess how they choose to live their everyday life here we round up some global option when it come to festival you really have to commit to boom portugal taking place every two year beside a lake boom celebrates the full moon with a psychedelic maelstrom of event encouraging people to converge and experience an alternative reality all style of music can be found but the emphasis is on the electronic along with talk group meditation and film screening it claim to be an autonomous zone of cognitive liberty and therefore is completely free from corporate sponsorship and logo meadow in the mountain bulgaria situated in the rhodope mountain this festival is not interested in a list line ups but rather providing a mean for escapism with attendee revelling in the wildlife and fauna that cover the site and erecting stage timber shack and art installation out wood sustainably sourced from the surrounding forest also it throw a pool party for everyone the day after the festival end burning man black rock desert the mecca of transformational festival you already know the main detail whiskey she stayed there for a while had a couple of drink thanked the bartender and then walked back to her camp afrikaburn tankwa karoo electric forest rothbury michigan it s hard to think of a festival more picturesque than this one which take place in a dense forest that is lit with neon so a to give it an otherworldly look the emphasis here is on art with the tall tree being utilised to create some stunning installation and nook but there is also a packed dj line up each year and an enormous stage afrikaburn tankwa karoo this is not so much a festival a a temporary city with community building decommodification creativity self reliance and radical self expression a it core value afrikaburn is a vast in scale week long experience involving a ton of performance this year s theme is simply play envision costa rica if the lush rainforest of uvita isn t enough for you at sunset the tropical beach of playa hermosa open at this festival which is all about exploring our fundamental connection with nature art spirituality yoga music dance performance education and sustainability are the cornerstone of envision which is filled with temple and healing sanctuary nowhere spain finally we come to the appropriately named nowhere surrounded by rocky mountain in the scorched spanish desert this festival is so intense it s website come with not only a survival guide but an emotional survival guide

title: kfc s secret ingredient is the most underappreciated spice in the world
context: colonel sander nephew recently revealed what he claim is the secret recipe for kfc chicken although kfc ha since denied that this is the exact formula we assume that it s close the nephew joe ledington did have it in a handwritten note taken from the colonel s second wife s will and he claim that his job a a boy wa to mix the spice blend in a tub the famous blend of 11 herb and spice includes only one real surprise a ton of white pepper the main ingredient is white pepper ledington told the chicago tribune i call that the secret ingredient nobody knew what white pepper wa nobody knew how to use it in the 1950s food scientist dr steven witherly author of why human like junk food wa taken aback when he saw the recipe wow that much white pepper he say wa his first reaction but he also think that it make a lot of sense i ve had a lot of chef tell me that the most underappreciated of all spice is white pepper because it ha subtle but very strong effect on the sensory system witherly said white pepper is the husked form of the more common black pepper cook illustrated say that it ha a more floral earthy flavor and greater complexity while black pepper is more aromatic with more spicy heat interestingly google search for white pepper have doubled over the past decade white pepper also ha some powerful physiological effect thanks to a compound called piperine piperine ha been shown to do a wide variety of thing including activating taste receptor to make salt taste saltier and sugar taste sweeter activating a special receptor in your brain that trigger the release of feel good endorphin increasing intestinal water flow and production of digestive enzyme and possibly even helping to counteract the effect of high fat diet the upshot according to witherly is that it could make kfc more addicting one of the theory i ve put forth is that if you eat something that doe something to you and it s beneficial your brain figure it out it want you to do it again witherly say kfc s alleged secret recipe is a follows 2 cup white flour plus 2 3 tbsp salt 1 2 tbsp thyme 1 2 tbsp basil 1 3 tbsp oregano 1 tbsp celery salt 1 tbsp black pepper 1 tbsp dried mustard 4 tbsp paprika 2 tbsp garlic salt 1 tbsp ground ginger 3 tbsp white pepper a great a white pepper may be of course other factor may be more important in making it delicious witherly concludes in why human like junk food that the key to kfc s deliciousness is the combination of flavor active compound flour salt pepper and msg with a pressure cooking technique that retains the chicken s moistness and juiciness and that s why 12 million people eat kfc every day
